superEntry.entry:
alphabetical letter H H
The sixth letter of the alphabet: called HaA='N [and HaA (respecting which latter see the letter b). It is one of the letters termed mahomuwsap, or nonvocal, i. e. pronounced with the breath only, without the voice; and of those termed Haloqiy~ap i. e. faucial, or guttural, for] the place of its utterance is in the fauces; and were it not for a hoarse aspiration with which it is pronounced, it would resemble E: next after it [with respect to the place of utterance] is h: [E having the lowest place of utterance; then H; and then h:] and H and h are never consociated in any uncompounded word of the which the letters are all radicals, because of the mutual nearness of their places of utterance: they occur together in Hay~ahalo; but this is only a compound word in the classical language; and as the name of a certain kind of tree it is a post-classical word. (Kh, L.) ＝ -A2- [It is often put for Hiynay^i*K. ＝ -A3- As a numeral, it denotes Eight.]

HaA HA
and HaA='N: see the letter H, and see arts. HwA^ and HY.

1 Hab~a Hb
[signifying He, or it, was, or became, loved, beloved, an object of love, affected, liked, or approved, is originally Habuba or Habiba]. You say, Hab~a A_ilaY~a h`*aA Al$~aYo'u, [aor.
Habu3a
or
Haba3a
,] inf. n. Hub~N, This thing was, or became, an object of love to me. (K. [The meaning is there indicated, but not expressed. In the CK, Al$~aY'a is erroneously put for Al$~aYo'u.]) And Habubotu A_ilayohi I became loved, beloved, or an object of love, to him: [said to be] the only instance of its kind except $arurotu and labubotu. (K.) And maA kunota HabiybFA walaqado Habibota, with kesr, Thou wast not loved, and thou hast become loved. (S.) See also 5. ― -b2- Hab~a, formed from Habuba, by making the former b quiescent and incorporating it into the latter, is also a verb of praise [signifying Beloved, lovely, pleasing, charming, or excellent, is he, or it]; (TA;) and so Hub~a, [which is more common,] formed from the same, by incorporating the former b into the latter after transferring the dammeh of the former to the H. (ISk, S, TA.) A poet says,
wazaAdahu kalafFA fiY AlHub~i A^ano manaEato
waHab~a $ayoy^FA AlaY AlAnosaAni maA muniEaA
[And her denying increased his devotion in love: for lovely, as a thing, to man, is that which is denied]. (TA.) And Sá'ideh says,
hajarato gaDuwbu waHab~a mano yatajan~abu
waEadato EawaAdK duwna waloyika ta$oEibu
[Ghadoob hath forsaken thee, (and lovely is the person who withdraweth far away,) and obstacles in the way of thy drawing near have occurred to separate thee and her]. (S, TA.) [See also Hab~a*aA, below.] ― -b3- [Both are also verbs of wonder.] You say, Hab~a bifulaAnK, (As, S, and so in copies of the K,) and Hub~a, (I 'Ak p. 236, [where both forms are mentioned as correct,] and so in the CK,) How beloved, or lovely, &c., is such a one (As, S, K) to me! (As, S.) [See also 4.] A'Obeyd and Fr read this Hab~a, saying that it means Habuba bflAn, and that the former b is rendered quiescent by the suppression of its dammeh, and incorporated into the latter. (S, * TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 4, in two places. ＝ -A3- Also Hab~a, [aor., accord. to analogy,
Habi3a
,] He stood still, stopped, or paused. (K.) ＝ -A4- And Hub~a, with damm, He was fatigued, or tired. (K.)

2 Hb~bhu A_ilaY~a Hbbh AlY Hbbh Aly
He, or it, [rendered him, or it, an object of love, lovely, or pleasant, to me;] made me to love, affect, like, approve, or take pleasure in, him, or it. (K.) You say, Hb~bhu A_ilaY~a A_iHosaAnuhu [His beneficence made him an object of love to me]. (A, TA.) And Hab~aba A@ll~`hu A_ilayohi AlA_iymaAna [God made faith lovely to him]. (A, TA.) And Hub~iba A_ilaY~a biA^ano tazuwraniY [Thy visiting me hath been made pleasant to me]. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- Hb~b Ald~awaA='a [He formed the medicine into pills, or little clots or balls: see its quasi-pass., 5]. (K in Hvr, &c.) ＝ -A3- And Hb~b He filled a water-skin &c. (AA, TA.) ＝ -A4- See also 5.

3 muHaAb~apN mHAbh mHAbp
, (S,) or muHaAbabapN, (K,) and HibaAbN signify the same [as inf. ns. of HAb~]. (S, K.) [You say, HAb~ baEoDuhumo baEoDFA They loved, affected, liked, approved, or took pleasure in, one another.] And HAb~hu He acted, or behaved, in a loving, or friendly, manner with him, or to him. (A, TA.) ― -b2- See also 4.

4 AHb~hu AHbh AHbp A^Hb A^Hbh A^Hbp Hb HbA Hbyb
, (S, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_iHobaAbN; (KL;) and Hab~ahu↓, (S,) first pers. Hababotuhu, (Msb, K,) aor.
Habi3a
, which is anomalous, (S, Msb, K,) the regular aor. being
Habu3a
, which is unused, (Msb,) [said to be] the only instance of a trans. verb whose second and third radical letters are the same having the measure yafoEilu as that of its aor. without having also the measure yafoEulu, (S,) and therefore by some disapproved, as not chaste, and disallowed by Az, though he allows the pass. form Hub~a, (TA,) inf. n. Hub~N, (K,) or this is a simple subst., (Msb,) and Hib~N; (K;) and [Hab~ahu↓,] first pers. Habibotuhu, aor.
Haba3a
; and HaAb~hu↓, inf. n. HibaAbN, of the dial. of Hudheyl; (Msb;) and AstHb~hu↓; (Msb, K;) signify the same; (S, Msb, K;) He loved, affected, liked, approved, or took pleasure in, him, or it: (A, K, and KL in explanation of the first and last:) he held him, or esteemed him, as a friend: (KL in explanation of the first and last:) or AisotiHobaAbN signifies the esteeming [a person or thing] good: (S:) and the preferring, or choosing, [a person or thing,] as also A_iHobaAbN: (KL:) and AstHb~hu EalaY gayorihi means he loved, or esteemed, him, or it, above another, or others; preferred him, or it, to another, or others. (K, A, * TA.) maA A^aHabotu *`lika, in the dial. of the tribe of Suleym, is for mA A^aHobabotuhu [I loved not, or liked not, that]; like Zanotu for Zananotu, and Zalotu and Zilotu for Zalilotu. (Lh, TA.) [A^uHib~u A^ano yakwuna ka*aA may be rendered I would that it were thus, or that such a thing were.] It is said of Ohod, in a trad., huwa jabalN yuHib~unaA wanuHib~uhu, meaning It is a mountain whose inhabitants love us, and whose inhabitants we love: or it may mean we love the mountain itself, because it is in the land of people whom we love. (IAth, TA.) And one says fiY saAEapK yuHib~uhaA AlT~aEaAmu for yuHab~u fiyhaA [In an hour, or a time, in which food is loved, or liked]. (TA.) ― -b2- maA A^aHab~ahu A_ilaY~a i. q. Hab~a bihi [How beloved, lovely, pleasing, charming, or excellent, is he, or it, to me!]; (As, S, K, * TA;) and so A^aHobibo A_ilaY~a bihi. (A, TA.) [De Sacy, in his Gram. Ar., sec. ed., ii. 221, mentions the saying, maA A^aHab~a Almuw^omina ll~`hi wamaA A^aHab~ahu A_ilaY A@ll~`hi, as meaning How greatly does the believer love God! and how great an object of love is he to God!] ＝ -A2- AHb~, (S, K,) inf. n. as above, (S,) also signifies He (a camel) kneeled and lay down, and would not spring up: (K:) or was restive: or kneeled and lay down: (S:) or was afflicted by a fracture, or disease, and would not move from his place until cured, or remained there until he died: (AZ, S, K:) or became jaded: (TA: [agreeably with this last explanation the act. part. n. is rendered in the S and K on the authority of Th:]) or was at the point of death,
by reason of violent disease, and therefore kneeled and lay down, and could not be roused. (AHeyth, TA.) Accord. to AO, A^aHobabotu Hub~a Alxayori Eano *ikori rab~iY [in the Kur xxxviii. 31] means I have stuck to the ground, on account of my love of the horses, [lit., of good things,] and so been diverted from prayer, until the time of prayer has passed: (TA:) by Alxyr is meant Alxayol. (Jel.) ＝ -A3- Also He became in a state of recovery from his disease. (K.) ＝ -A4- And It (seed-produce) had, bore, or produced, grain. (S, K.)

5 tjb~b jb tjbb
He manifested, or showed, love, or affection, (S, K,) A_ilayohi to him. (S.) tHb~b and Hab~a↓ are both syn. with tuwd~d. (TA.) ― -b2- [Also, app., He became, or made himself, an object of love or affection to him: see muHab~abN, said to be syn. with mutaHab~ibN.] ＝ -A2- He became swollen, or inflated, like a jar (Hub~), from drinking. (A, TA.) ― -b2- It (a water-skin &c.) became full. (AA, TA.) ― -b3- He began to be satiated with drink. (K.) ― -b4- He (an ass &c.) became filled with water: (S:) and Hab~aba↓ also is used in this sense, but ISd doubts its correctness: (TA:) one says, $aribati AlA_ibilu Hat~aY Hab~abato The camels drank until they were satiated. (S.) ＝ -A3- tHb~b Aljaliydu kaAll~uw^oluw^i AlS~igaAri [The hoar-frost formed into grains like small pearls]. (TA in art. SA^b.) ― -b2- tHb~b Alr~iyqu EalaY AlA^asonaAni [The saliva formed, or collected, in little bubbles upon the teeth]. (Az, TA.) ― -b3- taqaT~aEa All~abanu wataHab~aba [The milk became decomposed, and formed little clots of curd]. (S in art. bHvr.) ― -b4- tHb~b Alz~ubodu [The butter formed into little clots, when first appearing in the milk or cream]. (S and K in art. vmr.) The verb is also used in like manner in relation to honey, (K in art. Hvr,) and dibos (S in that art.,) and medicine. (TA in that art. [See also 2.]) ― -b5- tHb~b Aljilodu [The skin broke cat with pimples, or small pustules: so in the language of the present day: see Hab~N]. (TA in art. Hvr.)

6 tHAb~wA HAbY tHAb tHAbwA
They loved, or affected, or liked, one another. (S, A, * K. *)

10 A_isotaHoba3a
see 4. ＝ -A2- AisotaHab~ato kari$u AlmaAli The stomachs of the cattle, or camels &c., retained the water [that they had drunk], and the time between the two waterings thereof became long, or became lengthened. (K.) This is at the conjunction of [the periods of] AlT~arof and Aljabohap [the ninth and tenth of the Mansions of the Moon, which, in central Arabia, about the commencement of the era of the Flight, took place on the 12th of August, O. S., (see manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl,)] when Canopus rises with them. (TA. [AlS~arofap is there put for AlT~arof; but evidently by a mistake of a copyist. There is also another mistake, though a small one, in the foregoing passage: for Canopus rises, in central Arabia, after AlTrf, and before Aljbhp; and rose aurorally, in that latitude, about the commencement of the era of the Flight, on the 4th of August, O. S.])

Habo Hb
and HabK A cry by which a he-camel is chidden, to urge him on. (TA voce Hawobi, q. v.)

Hab~N Hb
, (S, Msb, K,) a [coll.] gen. n., (Msb,) n. un. Hab~apN; (S, Msb, K;) Grain of wheat, barley, lentils, rice, &c.: (Az, TA:) accord. to Ks, only of wheat and barley: (TA:) or wheat &c. while in the ears or other envelopes: (Msb:) [but applied also to various other seeds; among which, to beans, (as in the Mgh in art. bql,) and peas and the like; and kernels; and] the stones of grapes, dates, pomegranates, and the like: (Mgh voce EjamN:) by some it is applied even [to berries; as, for instance,] to grapes: you say Hab~apN mino EinabK, as well as mina Albur~i, and mina Al$~aEiyri, and the like: (TA:) [and hence, to beads: (see Hib~N:)] the pl. (of Hab~N, Msb) is HubuwbN (S, Msb, K) and Hub~aAnN, like tumoraAnN, (K,) pl. of tamorN; (TA;) and (of Hab~apN, Msb) Hab~aAtN (Msb, K) and HibaAbN, [or this is pl. of Hab~N also,] like kilaAbN as pl. of kalobapN [and of kalobN]: (Msb:) and Hab~N is also called [by lexicologists, but not by grammarians,] a pl. of Hab~apN. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Seed-produce, whether small or large. (TA.) ― -b3- And AlHab~apu AlxaDoraA='u (S, K) i. q. AlbuTomu [The fruit of the terebinth-tree, or pistacia terebinthus of Linn. (Delile, Flor. Æg. no. 936.)] (K.) ― -b4- And AlHab~apu Als~awodaA='u (S, K) i. q. Al$~uwniyzu [The black aromatic seed of a species of nigella]. (K.) [But see art. swd. And for other similar terms, see the latter word of each.] ― -b5- And Hab~a AlgamaAmi and Hab~u Almuzoni and Hab~u qur~K Hail. (S. [See a metaphorical usage of the first of these in a verse cited voce A^an~a.]) ― -b6- [Hence likewise,] Hab~N also signifies Pimples, or small pustules: [so in the present day: and any similar small extuberances: a coll. gen. n.: n. un. with p.] (S and K * in art. Hvr.)

Hub~N Hb
Love; affection; syn. wud~N, (A,) or widaAdN; (K;) inclination of the nature, or natural disposition, towards a thing that pleases, or delights; (Kull p. 165;) contr. of bugoDN: (Mgh, TA:) Hub~N and Hib~N↓ and Hub~apN↓ [this being said in the S to be syn. with Hub~N and in the K to be syn. with maHab~apN, and it is used as an inf. n. in an ex. cited voce daAHN in art. dwH,] and HubaAbN↓ (S, K) and HibaAbN↓ (K) and maHab~apN↓ (S) signify the same; (S, K;) i. e., as above. (K.) The degrees of Hub~ are as follow: first, hawFY, the “ inclining of the soul, or mind; ” also applied to the “ object of love itself: ” then, EalaAqapN, “ love cleaving to the heart; ” so termed because of the heart's cleaving to the object of love: then, kalafN, “ violent, or intense, love; ” from kulofapN signifying “ difficulty, or distress, or affliction: ” then, Ei$oqN, [“ amorous desire; ” or “ passionate love; ”] in the S, “ excess of love; ” and in the language of the physicians, “ a kind of melancholy: ” then, $agafN, “ ardour of love, accompanied by a sensation of pleasure; ” like lawoEapN and laAEijN; the former of which is “ ardour of love; ” and the latter, “ ardent love: ” then, jawFY, “ inward love; ” and “ violence of amorous desire, ” or “ of grief, or sorrow: ” then, tatay~umN, “ a state of enslavement by love: ” then tabolN, “ lovesickness: ” then, walahN, “ distraction, or loss of reason, in love: ” and then, huyaAmN “ a state of wandering about at random in consequence of overpowering love. ” (Kull ubi suprà.) [Accord. to the Msb, it is a simple subst.: but accord. to the K, an inf. n.; and hence,] Hub~FA limaA A^aHobabotumo, meaning A^uHib~u Hub~FA [I love with loving, i. e. much, what ye have loved]. (Har p. 186.) Hence the phrase, wakaraAmapF naEamo waHub~apF↓ [Yea; and with love and honour will I do what thou requirest: or for the sake of the love and honour that I bear thee: or Hb~p may be here used for Hub~FA to assimilate it in termination to krAmp: see what follows]. (S, TA.) Hence also the saying of Abu-l-' Atà EsSindee,
fawaA@ll~`hi maA A^adoriY waA_in~iY laSaAdiqN
A^adaA='N EaraAniY mino HubaAbiki A^amo siHoru
[And by God, I know not (and indeed I am speaking truth) whether disease have befallen me in consequence of love of thee, or enchantment]: (S, TA:) but IB says that the reading best known is mino HibaAbiki↓; and that HibAb, here, may be an inf. n. of HaAbabotuhu; or it may be pl. of Hub~N, like as Ei$A$N is of Eu$~N; (TA;) or it may be an inf. n. of Hababotuhu: some also read mino HabaAbiki↓, with fet-h to the H, said to mean on account of the love of thee, and of the main amount thereof: (Ham p. 26:) and some read mino janaAbiki “ from thy part ” [or “ from thee ”]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also HabiybN. ＝ -A2- Also a Persian word, arabicized, (AHát, S, Msb,) from xunob, (AHát, TA,) [or xubo or xuPo,] i. q. xaAbiyapN, (S, Msb,) A jar, (K, MF,) whether large or small, used for preparing wine: (MF:) or a large jar: (K:) or one for water: (IDrd, TA:) or the four pieces of wood upon which is placed a two-handled, or two-eared, jar: (K, TA: [in the CK, by a misplacement of words, this last signification is assigned to HabaAb:]) pl. [of pauc.] A^aHobaAbN (K) and [of mult.] HibaAbN and HibabapN. (S, Msb, K.) From this last signification is [said to be] derived the phrase Hub~FA wakaraAmapF [pronounced Hub~FA wakaraAmaho, lit. A jarstand and a cover will I give thee, or the like], krAmp signifying the “ cover ” of a jar, (K, TA,) whether of wood or of baked clay. (TA.) [If this be the true derivation, the phrase may have originated from a person's asking of another the loan or gift of a jar, and the latter's replying “ Yea; and I will give thee a jar-stand and a cover; ” meaning “ I will do what thou requirest, and more: ” but this phrase is now, and perhaps was in early times, generally used, agreeably with the more common significations of the two words, in the sense assigned above to the phrase Hub~apF wakaraAmapF.]

Hib~N Hb
: see Hub~N: ― -b2- and HabiybN, in four places: ＝ -A2- and Hib~apN. ＝ -A3- Also, and HibaAbN↓, [but the latter is doubted by the author of the TA, and thought to be perhaps syn. with Hib~N in the sense of muHib~N, and in the L it is said to be syn. with Hb~N, but in
what sense is not explained,] An ear-ring [formed] of one Hab~ap [or bead]. (K.)

Hab~apN Hb Hbh Hbp
n. un. of Hab~N [q. v.]. (S, Msb, K.) [Hence,] jaAbiru bonu Hab~apa a name of (assumed tropical:) Bread. (ISk, S.) ― -b2- See also Hib~apN, in two places. ― -b3- [A grain; meaning the weight of a grain of barley;] a wellknown weight. (K.) ― -b4- A [small] piece, or portion, of a thing. (S, K.) ― -b5- Hab~apu Alqalobi The heart's core; (AA, TA;) the black, or inner, part of the heart; or i. q. vamaratuhu; (S, A, K;) which is that [same thing]: (S:) or a black thing in the heart: (K:) or the black clot of blood that is within the heart: (T, TA:) or the heart's blood. (K.) You say, A^aSaAbato fulaAnapu Hab~apa qalobihi [Such a woman smote his heart's core]. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- A want: or an object of want; a needful, or requisite, thing: syn. HaAjapN. (K.)

Hub~apN Hb Hbh Hbp
: see Hub~N, in two places: ― -b2- and HabiybN. ― -b3- [It is also used in a pl. sense.] You say, huwa mino Hub~api nafosiY [He is of the beloved of my soul]. (TA voce Hum~apN.) ― -b4- And Hub~atuka also signifies What thou lovest to receive as a gift, or to have. (K.) You say, Aixotaro Hub~ataka Choose thou what, or whom, thou lovest; as also muHab~ataka↓. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A grape-stone: sometimes without teshdeed; (K;) i. e. HubapN. (TA.)

Hib~apN Hb Hbh Hbp
, a pl., [or rather quasi-pl. n.,] The seeds of desert-plants that are not used as food; pl. HibabN: (S:) or seeds of herbs, or leguminous plants, (buquwl,) and of odoriferous plants: (K:) or of the latter only; (Ks, Az, TA;) and one of such seeds is called Hab~apN↓; (Az, TA;) or Hib~apN; the coll. n. being Hib~N↓: (Msb:) or different seeds of every kind: or the seeds of the herbage called Eu$ob: or all seeds of plants: sing. the same, and Hab~apN↓: or this signifies everything that is sown: and Hib~apN, the seed of everything that grows spontaneously, without being sown: or a small plant growing among the kind of herbage called Ha$iy$: (K:) and dry herbage, broken in pieces, and heaped together: (Aboo-Ziyád, K:) or dry herbs or leguminous plants: (K:) or the seeds of wild herbs or leguminous plants, and of those of the kind called Eu$ob, and their leaves, that are scattered and mixed therewith; such as the quloqulaAn and basobaAs and *uraq and nafal and mul~aAH, and all kinds of those herbs or leguminous plants that are eaten crude, and those that are thick, or gross, and bitterish: upon these seeds and leaves, cattle, or camels &c., pasture and fatten in the end of [the season called] the Sayof (T, TA.)

HababN Hbb
: see HabaAbN. ― -b2- Also, (S, K,) and HibabN↓, (K,) A beautiful arrangement of the teeth in regular rows. (S, K.) ― -b3- And Streaks of saliva on the teeth. (TA.) ― -b4- And (both accord. to the K, but the latter only accord. to the TA,) The saliva that flows over the teeth, or collects in the mouth, in little bubbles. (T, K, TA.)

HibabN Hbb
: see HabaAbN: ― -b2- and HababN.

HabaAbN HbAb
: see Hub~N. ― -b2- HabaAbuka Thine utmost: (Msb:) or the utmost of thy power: (S:) or the utmost of thy love: or, of thine endeavour (jahodika [like juhaAdaAka and HumaAdaAka and quSaAraAka and gunaAmaAka and nuEaAmaAka]). (K. [In the CK juhodika.]) You say, HabaAbuka ka*aA, (K,) and HbAbk A^ano tafoEala *`lika, (S, Msb, * TA,) and HbAbk A^ano yakuwna *`lika, (TA,) Thine utmost, (Msb,) or the utmost of thy power, (S,) or of thy love, or of thine endeavour, (K,) will be such a thing, (K,) and thy doing that, (S, Msb, * TA,) and that event's taking place. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, and HababN↓ and ↓, The main body, the mass, or bulk, or greater part or portion, of water, (S, K,) and of sand, (K,) and of [the beverage called] nabiy*: but it is said that the third word applies particularly to water: (TA:) or the first signifies the streaks, or lines, of water, (As, K, TA,) resembling variegated work: (As, TA:) or the waves of water that follow one another: (TA:) or the bubbles (S, A, K) of water, (S, K,) or of wine, (A, TA,) that float upon the surface; (S, A, K;) as also the second (AHn, A) and the third: (AHn, TA:) [it is a coll. gen. n., in this sense, of which the n. un. is with p:] accord. to IDrd, Hbbu AlmaA='i and HbAbu AlmaA='i signify takas~aruhu [app. meaning the ripple, or broken surface, of water, such as is seen when it is slightly fretted by wind, and when it flows over uneven ground]. (TA.) Tirota biEubaAbihaA wafuzota biHabaAbihaA, in a trad. of 'Alee, relating to Aboo-Bekr, is explained as meaning Thou hast outrun others, and attained to the place where the flood of El-Islám collects, and reached the first [springs] thereof, and drunk the purest of it, and become possessor of its excellencies: [this is the only explanation of it that I have found:] but it is also otherwise explained. (Hr and others, TA in art. Eb.) ― -b2- HabaAbN also signifies (tropical:) Dew-drops; (A;) the dew (IAth, K) that is on trees &c. in the evening. (IAth, TA.) It is said in a trad., of the inhabitants of Paradise, that their food shall turn into a sweat like HbAb Almsok, by which is meant Musky dew: or, perhaps, musky bubbles. (IAth, TA.)

HubaAbN HbAb
: see Hub~N, in two places: ― -b2- and HabiybN. ＝ -A2- Also The serpent: (S, IAth, K:) or a serpent not of a malignant species: (TA:) and the name of a devil, (S, K,) accord. to some; (S;) but said to be so only because a serpent is called $ayoTaAn. (A 'Obeyd, S, TA.) ― -b2- And a pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of which the sing. [or n. un.] is HubaAbapN [accord. to the CK HubaAbapu], meaning A certain black aquatic insect or small animal. (K.) ＝ -A3- A^um~u HubaAbK (tropical:) The present world; (K, TA;) metonymically used in this sense. (TA.)

HibaAbN HbAb
: see Hub~N, in two places: ＝ -A2- and Hib~N.

HabiybN Hbyb
A person loved, beloved, affected, liked, or approved; (S, * A, Msb, * K;) as also maHobuwbN↓ and muHab~N↓, (S, Msb, K,) of which two the former is generally used for the latter, (S, K, TA,) in like manner as are used mazokuwmN and maHozuwnN and majonuwnN and makozuwzN and maqoruwrN, each of which has its proper verb of the measure fuEila, (TA,) and Hib~N↓ (S, K) and HubaAbN↓ and Hub~FpN↓, which last is also applied to a female, and has for its pl. HubabN: (K:) the fem. of HabiybN is with p; (Msb, K;) and so is that of maHobuwbN↓, (K, TA,) [and that of muHab~N↓,] and that of Hib~N↓: (TA:) the pl. of HabiybN is A^aHib~aA='u, instead of HubabaA='u, which would be the reg. pl. but for the repetition of the b; and the pl. of HabiybapN is HabaAy^ibu: (Msb:) the pl. of Hib~N↓ is A^aHobaAbN [a pl. of pauc.] and Hib~aAnN (K) and Hub~aAnN (MF) and HubuwbN and HibabapN and Hub~N↓, which last is rare (EaziyzN) [as a pl.], or is a quasi-pl. n. (K.) Though muHab~N↓ is uncommon it occurs in the following verse of 'Antarah:
walaqado nazalot falaA taZun~Y gayorahu
min~iY bimonozilapi AlmuHab~i Almukorami
[And thou hast taken (and imagine not otherwise), in respect of me, i. e. of my heart, the place of the beloved, the honoured; or become in the condition of the beloved, &c.]. (T, TA.) ― -b2- Also, (IAar, KL, TA,) and Hib~N↓, (K, KL,) A person loving; a lover; a friend; (KL;) i. q. muHib~N↓: (IAar, K, TA:) [fem. of each with p:] the pl. of the first (i. e. Hbyb) is A^aHobaAbN (TA) [and A^aHib~aA='u and A^aHib~apN, mentioned by Golius as from the S, but not in my copies of the S: both, however, are correct: the former, the more common: the latter, a pl. of pauc.]. You say AimoraA^apN lizawojihaA muHib~apN↓ and muHib~N↓ [A woman loving to her husband]. (Fr, S, K. *) ― -b3- A^abuw HabiybK The kid. (Har p. 227.) ― -b4- AlHabiybapu: see muHab~N.

HubaAHibN HbAHb
, (K,) or A^abuw HubaAHibK, (S,) [A kind of fire-fly;] a fly that flies in the night, (K,) resembling fire, (S,) emitting rays like a lamp: (K:) AHn says that HbAHb and AbwHbAHb were both unknown to him, and that nothing respecting them had been heard by him from the Arabs; but that some people asserted the insect thus called to be the yaraAE, a moth that, when it flies by night, no person not knowing it would doubt to be a spark of fire: Aboo-Tálib says, as on the authority of Arabs of the desert, that HbAHb is the name of a flying thing longer than the common fly, and slender, that flies between sunset and nightfall, resembling a spark of fire: (TA:) or, accord. to As, it is a flying thing, like the common fly, with a wing that becomes red; when it flies appearing at a distance like a lighted piece of fire-wood. (Har p. 500.) naAru AlHubaAHibi (S, K) and naAruA^abiY HubaAHibK and simply AlHubaAHibu (S) mean The fire of the fly above mentioned: or of El-Hobáhib or Aboo-Hobáhib: (TA:) [for] El-Hobáhib, (S,) or Aboo-Hobáhib, (K,) is said to have been a niggardly man, who never lighted any but a faint fire, fearing to attract guests, so that his fire became proverbial. (S, K.) El-Kumeyt says, describing swords,
yaraY Alr~aAw^uwna biAl$~afaraAti minohaA
kanaAri A^abiY HubaAHiba waAlZ~ubiynaA
[The beholders see, in the sides of the blades thereof, and the extremities, the semblance of the fire of the fire-fly]: (S:) here the poet has made HbAHb imperfectly decl., regarding it as a fem. [proper] name [of the fly above mentioned]. (TA.) Or nArAlHbAHb (S, K) and simply AlHbAHb (S) signify The fire that is struck by a horse's hoofs: (Fr, S:) or the sparks of fire that are made to fly forth in the air by the collision of stones: or the sparks that fall from the pieces of wood that are used for producing fire [by means of friction]: (K:) or they are derived from HaboHabapN, (IAar, K,) signifying “ weakness, ” (IAar, TA,) [and their meaning is faint fire.] ― -b2- A^um~u HubaAHibK A flying insect resembling the [species of locust called] junodab, (K, * TA,) spotted with yellow and green: when people see it, they say, bar~idiY yaA HubaAHibu [Spread forth thy wings (burodayoki), hobáhib]; whereupon it spreads its two wings, which are adorned with red and yellow. (TA.)

Hab~a*aA *
, meaning HabiybN, as in the phrase Hab~a*aA AlA^amoru [Loved, beloved, affected, loved, or approved, is the thing, or affair; or lovely, charming, or excellent, is it]; (K;) and in Hab~a*aA zayodN [Loved, beloved, &c., is Zeyd]; (S;) is composed of Hab~a, (Sb, Fr, S, K,) a verb of praise, in the pret. form, invariable, originally Habuba, (Fr, S,) and *aA, (Sb, Fr, S, K,) its agent, (S,) which together constitute it a single word, (Sb, S, K,) a noun, (Sb, K,) or occupying the place of a noun, (S,) governing the noun [particularized by praise] that follows it in the nom. case; (Sb, S, K;) the place that it occupies in construction making it virtually in the nom. case as an inchoative, and the noun that follows it being its enunciative: (S:) [but see what follows.] It is used in the same manner as a prov.; (Sb, K;) [i. e., it is not altered to agree in number or gender with the noun particularized by praise, which follows it;] remaining the same when used in the dual and pl. and fem. sense; so that one says, Hb~*A zayodN and Alz~ayodaAni and Alz~ayoduwna and hinodN and A^anota and A^anotumaA and A^anotumo [&c.]; (Ibn-Keysán, TA;) and Hb~*A A@moraA^apN, not Hab~a*ihi AlmaroA^apu; (Sb, S, K; *) which shows that the noun that follows it may not be regarded as a substitute for *A: (S:) [but see what follows.] It is allowable, but bad, to say, zayodN Hab~a*aA. (TA.) [There are, however, various opinions respecting Hb~*A and the noun that follows it.] Some hold that Hb~*A is a noun, composed of Hab~a and *A, and is an inchoative, and that the noun particularized by praise is its enunciative; or that the former is an enunciative, and the latter an inchoative, reversing the usual order: others hold that Hab~a is a verb in the pret. form; and *A, its agent; and that the noun particularized by praise may be an inchoative, of which Hb~*A is the enunciative; or it may be an enunciative of which the inchoative is suppressed, so that Hb~*A zayodN is for Hb~*A huwa zayodN [Loved, or beloved, &c., is this person: he is Zeyd], or Hb~*A AlmamoduwHu zayodN [loved, &c., is this person: the person praised is Zeyd]: others hold that Hb~*A is a pret. verb, composed of Hab~a and *A, and that the noun following it is its agent; but this is the weakest of opinions: one also says, in dispraise, laAHab~a*aA zayodN. (I 'Ak p. 235.)

Golius, app. from his finding HabarN explained in the KL as an inf. n. meaning The being happy, &c., ($aAdo $udano,) assigns to Hubira jiloduhu, as on the authority of that lexicon, the meaning of “ hilaris lætusque fuit; ” but I have not found this verb in any Arabic work.] ＝ -A2- Hubira jiloduhu His skin was beaten so that there remained the mark of the beating. Ink, syn. madaAdN, (Msb,) and niqosN, (K,) with which one writes: (S, Msb:) so called because it is one of the means of beautifying writings; (Mohammad Ibn-Zeyd, TA;) or because it beautifies, and makes plain, handwriting; (Hr, TA;) or because of the marks that it leaves: (As, TA:) pl. [See also HibarapN.] ― -b3- A mark, or sign, of the enjoyment of ease and plenty: (As, S, K: [in one copy of the S, and in the CK, for A^avaru Aln~aEomapi, I find, erroneously, A^avaru Aln~iEomapi:]) and [hence,] beauty; (As, S, A, K;)
beauty of aspect; or a beautiful and pleasing aspect, that satisfies the eye by its comeliness: (As, S, TA:) colour; complexion: (Fr, IAar, S, TA:) pl. A^aHobaArN (S) and HubuwrN. (K, * TA.) One says, A_in~ahu laHasanu AlHibori waAls~ibori Verily he is beautiful, and of goodly appearance: (As, S:) or of beautiful complexion. (IAar.) And *ahaba Hiboruhu wasiboruhu His colour, or complexion, (Fr, S,) or beautiful, (A,) and goodliness of form or aspect, departed: (Fr, S, A:) from the saying, jaA='ati AlA^abilu Hasanapa AlA^aHobaAri waAlA^asobaAri [The camels came beautiful in colours and in appearances]. (Fr, S, A. *) One says also, waAls~abori fulaAnN Hasanu AlHabori↓: where Hbr seems to be the inf. n. of Habarotuhu “ I made him, or it, beautiful. ” (S.) ― -b4- Also, (S, K,) and HaborN↓ (TA) and HabarN↓ (K) and HabaArN↓ (S, K) and HibaArN↓, (A, K,) A mark, or trace, (S, A, K,) of beating, (A,) or of a blow that has not brought blood, or of a healed wound, (TA,) or of work, or labour: (A, TA:) pl. of the first [or second] HubuwrN (Yaakoob, S, K) and [of the first and third, accord. to analogy,] A^aHobaArN; (TA;) and of the fourth HabaAraAtN, (Yaakoob, S, TA,) it having no broken pl. (TA.) One says, bihi HubuwrN Upon him are marks [of beating, &c.]. (S.) And AlD~arobi bijilodihi HibaAru↓ Upon his skin is the mark of beating. (A.) And AlEamali biyadihi HibaAru↓ Upon his hand is the mark of work, or labour. (A.) ― -b5- See also HibirN. ― -b6- And see HubuwrN. ＝ -A2- Also, [like the Hebrew ???, and the Chaldee ???,] A like; an equal; a fellow. (K.) ― -b2- See also HaborN.

HubaAraY HbAr HbArY HbAry
[a word respecting which J says,] its alif [written Y] is not the fem. alif nor the alif of quasi-coordination; [as F says of the alif of qabaEovarFY, though he finds fault with J for saying thus of the alif of HubaAraY; (see A^alifu Alt~akoviyri, in art. A)] the name [says J] being only composed with it, so that it is as it were a part of the word itself, which is imperfectly decl. when determinate and when indeterminate; i. e., without tenween: (S:) but its alif is the fem. alif; for were it not so, it would be perfectly decl.; (K;) and J says that it is imperfectly decl.: (TA:) and his saying that the alif is [as it were] a part of the word itself is a strange expression, for which it would be difficult to give an answer, and which therefore requires not exorbitance: but “ it is sufficient excellence for a man that his faults may be counted: ” (M:) [A species of bustard;] a certain bird, (S, Msb, K,) well known, of the form of the goose, with a dustcolour upon its head and belly, and the back and wings of which are for the most part of the colour of the quail; (Msb;) or it is a long-necked bird, of an ash-colour, of the form of the goose, with a beak somewhat long, and that is preyed upon, but does not itself prey: Az says that it does not drink water, and that it lays its eggs in distant sands: [the truth is, that it drinks seldom: the male bird has a pouch, extending from beneath the tongue to the breast, said to be large enough to contain seven quarts of water; and it has been supposed by some that he fills this with water for the supply of himself and his mate:] and Az further says, We used, when we journeyed, to proceed in the mountains of EdDahnà, and sometimes we picked up in one day between four and eight of its eggs: it lays four eggs, of a bluish colour, more delicious in taste than those of the domestic hen and than those of the ostrich: and others say that it brings its food from a greater distance than any other bird; sometimes from a distance of many days' journey: also, that it is constantly provided with a thin excrement, or dung, which it voids upon the hawk when pursued by the latter; thus saving itself,
by preventing the hawk from continuing its flight, and, as some say, causing its feathers to drop off: whence the prov., A^asolaHu mino HubaAraY: [see art. slH:] (TA:) HubaAraY is applied alike to the male and the female, and used as sing. and pl.: (S, K:) but it has pl. forms, (TA,) namely, HubaArayaAtN (S, Msb, K, TA) and HubaAraAtN: (TA:) accord. to Sb, it has not HabaArK, [in the TA incorrectly written HabaAriY, as though it had the article Al prefixed to it, or were prefixed to another noun,] nor HabaAy^iru, [though both of these are mentioned as pls. of it in several of the grammars of the Arabs,] in order to distinguish between HubaAraY and nouns of the measures faEolaA='u and fiEaAlapN and the like. (TA.) It is said in a prov.,

i. q. rasanN [as meaning A rope, or cord]; (S;) a certain thing well known; (Msb;) a thing with which one ties, binds, or makes fast, a beast &c.; syn. ribaATN: (M, K:) and i. q. rasanN [as meaning a halter]; (M, Msb, K;) as in the Kur cxi. 5; (TA;) and so muHab~alN↓: (M, K:) in the former sense, the pl. (M, Msb, K.) In a trad. in which it is said that a man's hand is to be cut off for his stealing a
Habol, the Hbl of a ship may be mean. (Mgh in art. byD.) ― -b2- [Hence, (assumed tropical:) A bond; cause of union; or link of connexion:] connexion with another by the bond of love or friendship or the like; (S, K, TA;) pl. HibaAlN: (TA:) mutual connexion by such a bond. (ISd, Msb, K.) You say, waSala fulaAnN fiY Haboli fulaAnK (assumed tropical:) Such a one married his daughter to such a one. (Har p. 223.) And huwa yaxoTubu fiY Haboli fulaAni (assumed tropical:) He aids such a one in seeking, or demanding, a woman in marriage. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., A_in~a bayonanaA wa bayona Alqawomi HibaAlFA wa naHonu qaATiEuwhaA (assumed tropical:) Verily there is between us and the party a connexion by the bond of love or friendship or the like, and we are severing it. (TA.) You say also, A_in~ahu lawaAsiEu AlHaboli (tropical:) Verily he is large, or liberal, in disposition; [or in the scope of his friendship;] and Day~iqu AlHaboli (tropical:) narrow therein. (TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A covenant, or compact: (S, Msb, K, TA:) (tropical:) a covenant, or an obligation, by which one becomes responsible for the safety, or safe-keeping, of a person or thing: (K, TA:) and (tropical:) a promise, or an assurance, of security, or safety; (A 'Obeyd, S, Msb, K, TA;) such as a man, desiring to make a journey, used [and still uses] to take from the chief of a tribe: (A 'Obeyd, TA:) pl. HibaAlN. (TA.) You say, kaAnato bayonahumo HibaAlN faqaTaEuwhaA (tropical:) There were between them covenants, and obligations whereby they were responsible for one another's safety, and they broke them. (TA.) And it is said in the Kur [iii. 108], A_il~aA biHabolK mina A@ll~`hi wa HabolK mina Aln~aAsi (tropical:) Unless [they have] a covenant from God and a covenant from men: (Ibn-'Arafeh, TA:) for the unbeliever requires a covenant from God, which consists in his being of those who have a revealed scripture without which he cannot retain his religion nor enjoy protection, and a covenant granted to him by men. (Er-Rághib, TA.) And it is also said in the Kur [iii. 98], waA@EotaSimuwA biHaboli A@ll~`hi i. e. (tropical:) [And hold ye fast] by the covenant of God: (TA:) or (tropical:) the means of approach, or access, unto God; i. e. the Kur-án, and the Prophet, and intelligence, &c., which are the means of obtaining the protection of God; for HabolN is metaphorically applied to (tropical:) any means of access to a thing: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or these words of the Kur mean (tropical:) and follow ye the Kur-án, and abstain from schism. (A'Obeyd, TA.) And in like manner, the saying of Ibn-Mes'ood, Ealayokumo biHaboli A@ll~`hi, means (tropical:) Keep ye to the Book of God; for it is a security for you, and a covenant, against the punishment of God. (A'Obeyd, TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) An elongated, or extended, tract of sand, (T, S, M, Mgh, K,) collected together, abundant, and high: (T, TA:) or HabolN mina Alr~amoli means a long, extended, tract of sand, collected together, and elevated: (Msb:) [or simply a long, or long and elevated, tract of sand; likened to a rope, as is indicated in the Mgh:] pl. HibaAlN. (TA.) ― -b5- [(assumed tropical:) A long, creeping, or twining, stalk or shoot or branch; likened to a rope or cord: pl. HibaAlN: often occurring in descriptions of plants by AHn and others.] ― -b6- See also HabalapN. ― -b7- AlHabolu (assumed tropical:) The wariyd; [a name applied to each of the two carotid arteries, and sometimes to each of the two external jugular veins;] also called Habolu Alwariydi; a vein between the windpipe and the [two sinews called the] EilobaAwaAni; (Fr, TA;) a certain vein in the neck, (S,) or in the Haloq. (Msb.) ― -b8- (assumed tropical:) The EaAtiq [or part between the shoulder-joint and the neck]: (K:) or AlHabolu, (K,) or Habolu AlEaAtiqi, (TA,) signifies the Tariyqap [app. here meaning, as it does in some other instances, oblong muscle] that is between the neck and the head of the shoulder-blade: or a sinew between the neck and the shoulderjoint: (K:) or Habolu AlEaAtiqi signifies a bond, or ligament, between the EAtq and the neck; (T, Msb, TA;) or between the neck and the shoulderjoint: (Lth, TA:) or certain sinews. (S.) ― -b9- (assumed tropical:) A certain vein, or nerve, (Eiroq,) in the fore arm, (K, TA,) extending from the wrist until it becomes concealed in the shoulder-joint: (TA:) or Habolu Al*~iraAEi is [a vein, or nerve,] in the arm: (S:) or HibaAlu Al*~iraAEayoni signifies the sinews that appear upon the two fore arms; and in like manner, those of a horse. (TA.) One says, huwa EalaY Haboli *iraAEika, (S, TA,) a prov., (S,) meaning (tropical:) He, or it, is near to thee: (T, S, Sgh:) or within thy power, or reach; or possible, or practicable, to thee; or easy to thee. (ISd, Z, TA.) ― -b10- Also, (K,) or Habolu AlfaqaAri, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) A certain vein, or nerve, (Eiroq,) in the back, (K, TA,) extending from the beginning thereof to its end. (TA.) ― -b11- AlHibaAlu fiY Als~aAqi, (K,) or HibaAlu Als~aAqayoni, (M,) (assumed tropical:) The sinews of the two shanks. (M, K.) ― -b12- AlHibaAlu fiY Al*~akari, (K,) or HabaAy^ilu↓ Al*~akari, (M,) (assumed tropical:) The veins (Euruwq) of the penis. (M, K.) ― -b13- AlHabolu also signifies The station of the horses collected for a race, before they are let go. (K.) [Probably it was marked by an extended rope; and for that reason was thus called.] ＝ -A2- Also Heaviness; weight, or weightiness; ponderousness; syn. viqalN. (Az, K.)

HubolN Hbl
: see HubolapN.

HibolN Hbl
A calamity, or misfortune; (S, K;) as also HabuwlN↓: (K:) pl. HubuwlN. (S, K.) ISd cites as an ex. the saying of El-Akhtal,
wa kunotu saliyma Alqalobi Hat~aY A^aSaAbaniY
mina All~aAmiEaAti AlmuboriqaAti Hubuwlu
[And I was sound of heart until calamities befell me from the resplendent females, exhibiting their beauty]. (TA.) ― -b2- rajulN HibolN (assumed tropical:) A learned, sagacious, intelligent man. (IAar, K. *) [And HibolN also signifies (assumed tropical:) Very intelligent, or very cunning. Pl. A^aHobaAlN.] You say, A_in~ahu laHibolN mino A^aHobaAlihaA, meaning (tropical:) Verily he is one who possesses much intelligence, or much cunning: and verily he is a gentle manager of cattle. (ISd, K, TA.)

HabalN Hbl
: see HabalapN. ＝ -A2- It is also an inf. n.; i. e., of Habilato. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) ＝ -A3- And it is also a simple subst.: (K, TA: [in the CK, wAsomu jamoEK is erroneously put for wA@somN:]) [i. e.] it also signifies The fœtus in the womb: (Mgh:) pl. A^aHobaAlN. (K.) It is said in a trad., nahaY Eano Habali AlHabalapi↓, (S, Mgh,) or nahaY Eano bayoEi Habali AlHabalapi, (Msb, K,) i. e. He forbade the selling of the offspring of the offspring (S, Msb, K) in the belly (Msb, TA) of the she-camel &c.; (Msb;) [i. e.,] the offspring of the fœtus (A'Obeyd, S, Msb) in the belly of the she-camel [&c.]; (A'Obeyd, Msb;) [i. e.,] what the fœtus will bring forth, if it be a female; (Mgh;) the p in AlHblp being the sign of the fem. gender; (A'Obeyd, Mgh, Msb;) or a sign of intensiveness of the signification: (IAmb, TA:) for the Arabs in the Time of Ignorance used to sell the offspring of the offspring in the bellies (T, M, Msb, TA) of pregnant beasts, (T, Msb,) or of sheep or goats: (M, TA:) or the meaning is, what is in the belly of the she-camel: (A'Obeyd, Esh-Sháfi'ee, K:) or the produce of the grape-vine before it has attained to maturity: (M, K:) but Suh disapproves of this last explanation, as a mistake occasioned by the p in AlHblp. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Anything that is in another thing: thus, for instance, the pearl is the Habal of the oyster-shell; and the wine is the Habal of the glass bottle. (A, TA.) ＝ -A4- (tropical:) Fulness; (ISd, K, TA; [see Habila;]) as also HubaAlN↓. (IAar, K.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Anger: (K, TA:) (tropical:) anger and grief; as in the saying bihi HabalN (tropical:) In him is anger and grief: (Az, ISd, K, TA:) from the same word as meaning the “ pregnancy ” of a woman. (Az, TA.) ＝ -A5- Habalo Habalo A cry by which sheep or goats are chidden. (Sgh, K.)

HabolapN Hbl Hblh Hblp
: see HabolapN.

HubolapN Hbl Hblh Hblp
The fruit, or produce, of the [kind of trees called] EiDaAhu, (S, K,) in general: (K:) or the pod, or receptacle of the seeds, of the samur and salam; [so accord. to AZ; as appears from a comparison of passages in art. bl in the T and TA;] that of other [trees of the kind called] EDAh being termed sinofapN: (TA:) or the fruit, or produce, of the samur, resembling the [species of kidney-bean called] luwbiyaA='; (IAar, TA;) or of the salam and sayaAl and samur, (M, K,) which is a curved thing, containing small black grains, resembling lentils: (M, TA:) or, accord. to AO, a species of tree; as is the samur: (Az, TA:) pl. HubolN↓, [or rather this is a coll. gen. n.,] and [the proper pl. is] HubalN. (K.) Hence, in a trad. of Saad, wa maA lanaA TaEaAmN A_il~aA AlHubolapu wa waraqu Als~amuri [We having no food except the Hblp and the leaves of the smr]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- A kind of ornament worn by women, (S, K, TA,) fashioned in the form of the fruit thus called, (TA,) and put upon necklaces, (S, TA,) used in the Time of Ignorance. (As, TA.) ― -b3- A certain herb, (baqolapN, ISd, K,) sweet, or pleasant, of the herbs termed *ukuwr: so says ISd: and in one place he says, a certain tree which [the lizards termed] DibaAb eat. (TA.) ― -b4- See also what next follows.

HabalapN Hbl Hblh Hblp
(M, A, K) and HabolapN↓, (M, A,) or HubolapN↓, (K,) (assumed tropical:) A grape-vine; (M, A, K;) its branches being likened to ropes, or cords: (A, TA:) or a stock of a grape-vine: (K:) the first of these words has the latter signification (Mgh, TA) accord. to As: (TA:) or it signifies a stock of a grape-vine having its branches spread upon its
trellises: (TA:) or the first and second signify a branch of a grape-vine: (S) or, accord. to Lth, Hblp [thus in the TA, without any syll. sign,] signifies a grape-vine: and also a TAq [app. here meaning an arch] of the branches of a grape-vine: so in the T: (TA:) and Habala↓ and HabolN↓ [are coll. gen. ns., and] signify grapevines. (K.) ― -b2- Habalapu EamorKw A sort of grapes of Et-Táïf, white, and pointed at the extremities. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also HabalN: ＝ -A3- and see what next follows.

HubolaY Hbl HblY Hbly Hblyy
Pregnant; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also HaAbilapN↓; (K;) and HabolaAnapN↓ also occurs in the same sense: (ISd, K) applied to a woman, (S, Mgh,) or, accord. to AZ, to any animal having a nail, (S,) or to any beast, as, for instance, a sheep, or goat, and a cat: (Msb:) pl. of the first HabaAlaY (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and HubolayaAtN (Msb, K) and HabaAlayaAtN, (S, TA,) which last is pl. of HabaAlaY: (TA:) and the pl. of HaAbilapN is HabalapN↓, (K,) which is extr. (TA.) One says, All~ayolu HubolaY lasota tadoriY maA talidu (assumed tropical:) [The night is pregnant: thou knowest not what it will bring forth]: meaning that the events of the night are not to be trusted. (TA.) ― -b2- See also HabolaAnapN.

HuboliY~N Hbl HblY Hbly Hblyy
and HubolawiY~N↓ Of, or relating to, one that is HubalaY, i. e. pregnant. (S, K.)

HabolaAnapN HblAn HblAnh HblAnp
: see HubolaY. ― -b2- [Hence,] HabolaAnu (tropical:) Full [of beverage, or wine, and of water; see Habila]; as also HubolaAn↓: fem. of the former HabolaY; and of the latter; HubolaY↓ [which is anomalous]: (AHn, ISd, K, TA:) and A^aHobalu↓ a man full of beverage or wine. (Z, TA.) ― -b3- And HabolaAnu (tropical:) Angry; (K, TA;) full of anger; EalaY fulaAnK against such a one: (TA:) fem. with p. (Ibn-'Arafeh, K, TA.)

HubolaAn Hbl HblAn
: see the next preceding paragraph. [By rule, it should be with tenween, like EuroyaAnN, and should form its fem. with p.]

HubolawiY~N HblwY Hblwy
: see HuboliY~N.

HubolaAwiY~N HblAwY HblAwy
: see HuboliY~N.

HubaAlN HbAl Hbl
: see HabalN. ＝ -A2- Also (assumed tropical:) Much hair. (Az, TA.)

HabuwlN Hbl Hbwl
: see HibolN.

Habiylu baraHK Hbyl brH
(assumed tropical:) One who stands in his place like the lion, not fleeing: (S:) or (tropical:) courageous: (K, TA:) and an appellation given to (tropical:) a lion; (K, TA;) as though he were prevented, as by a snare, or by a rope, from quitting his place; not quitting it, by reason of his boldness. (TA.)

HibaAlapN HbAlh HbAlp Hbl
(S, Msb, K) and A^uHobuwlapN↓ (Lth, Msb, K) and A^uHobuwlN↓ (Lth, K) A snare; or thing by means of which one takes, catches, or snares, game, or wild animals, or birds; (S, M, K;) of whatever kind it be; (M, TA;) a $arak, and the like: (Msb:) or HbAlp peculiarly applies to the cord (Habol) of him who takes, catches, or snares, game or the like: (Er-Rághib, TA:) pl. of the first HabaAy^ilu, (Msb, TA,) and of the second [and third] A^aHaAbiylu. (Msb.) It is said in a prov., xa$~i *uw^aAlapa biAlHibaAlapi [Frighten thou the wolf to catch him with the snare]; *w^Alp meaning the wolf: applied to him whose threatening is not cared for: i. e., threaten another than me; for I know thee. (Meyd, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Aln~isaA='u HabaAy^ilu Al$~ayoTaAni (assumed tropical:) [Women are the snares of the Devil]. (TA.) And HabaAy^ilu Almawoti (assumed tropical:) The causes of death. (K.) And huwa HibaAlapu AlA_ibili (assumed tropical:) He is one who takes good care of the camels, so that they do not escape from him. (TA.) ― -b3- For the pl. HabaAy^ilu, see also HabolN, in two places; in the first sentence, and near the end of the paragraph.

HaAbilN HAbl
One who binds, ties, or makes fast, a rope, or cord. (TA.) Hence, (TA,) yaA HaAbilu A@*okuro Hal~FA, a prov., (K, TA,) meaning O binder, or tyer, of the rope, bear in mind the time of untying. (TA.) ― -b2- The setter of the snare (HabaAlap) for game; (S, TA;) as also muHotabilN↓. (TA.) It is said in a prov., AixotalaTa AlHaAbilu biAln~aAbili (S) (assumed tropical:) The setter of the snare became confounded with the shooter of the arrows: (TA in art. xlT:) or, in this instance, (S,) AlHAbl signifies the warp; and AlnAbl, the woof. (S, K.) And in another prov., vaAra HaAbiluhumo EalaY naAbilihimo (assumed tropical:) They kindled mischief among themselves: (K, TA:) AlHAbl [properly] signifying the owner of the HibaAlap; and AlnAbl, the shooter with nabol, or the owner of nabol: i. e., their case became confused: and sometimes it is applied to a party whose case has become turned from its proper state, and who become roused, or stirred up, one against another. (Az, TA.) One says also, Haw~ala HaAbilahu EalaY naAbilihi (assumed tropical:) He turned it upside down. (K.) And AijoEalo HaAbilahu naAbilahu, and HaAbilahu EalaY naAbilihi, (assumed tropical:) Turn thou it upside down. (TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) An enchanter. (Sgh, K, TA.) ＝ -A2- A [lizard of the kind called] Dab~ that feeds upon the Hubolap [q. v.]; (S, M, K;) and so a gazelle. (TA.) ＝ -A3- HaAbilapN: see HubolaY.

HaAbuwlN HAbwl
A rope [in the form of a hoop] by means of which one ascends palm-trees; (S, M, K;) made of bark, or of [the fibres of the palmtree called] liyf. (Har pp. 544-5.)

A^aHobalu *
: see HabolaAnu, voce HabolaAnapN.

A^uHobuwlN *
and A^uHobuwlapN: see HibaAlapN.

maHobalN mHbl
The time of pregnancy: (K:) [or the time of one's mother's pregnancy: for] you say, kaAna *`lika fiY maHobali fulaAnK That was in the time of such a one's mother's being pregnant with him. (S, TA.) So in the saying of El-Mutanakhkhil El-Hudhalee:
xuT~a lahu *`lika fiY AlmaHobali
laA taqihi Almawota waqiy~aAtuhu
[His possessions by means of which he preserves himself shall not preserve him from death: that was written for him in the time when his mother was pregnant with him: or the last word is Almahobili: so in the TA in arts. hbl and wqY: see what here follows, in the next sentence]: or the meaning is that here following. (TA.) ― -b2- [The register of God's decrees; which is called] the first writing: (ISd, K:) but in the verse cited above, the last word, accord. to some, is AlmaHobil↓, (TA,) which means Almahobil, (K, TA,) and this is the reading best known, signifying the place of gestation in the womb. (TA.)

maHobilN mHbl
: see what next precedes.

muHab~alN mHbl
: see HabolN, first sentence. ― -b2- Also Hair crisped, or twisted and contracted: so accord. to the K; in which is added, $ibohu Aljavoli; but the right reading is $ibohu AlHaboli [like the rope or cord]: or having its locks twisted like ropes or cords: [thus many Ethiopian races, and some of the Arab women, twist their hair, like cords; and thus, generally, did the ancient Egyptians:] or, accord. to the M, i. q. maDofuwrN [meaning plaited, or twisted]. (TA.)

maHobuwlN mHbwl
A wild animal caught, or entangled, in a HabaAlap [or snare]: (S:) or one for which a HbAlp has been set, though he may not as yet have fallen into it: and muHotabalN↓ [in the CK erroneously muHotabil] one that has fallen into it, (ISd, K,) and been taken. (ISd, TA.)

muHotabalN mHtbl
: see what next precedes. ― -b2- Also [The place of the hobble; i. e.] (tropical:) the pastern of a beast: (T, TA:) or the pasterns of a horse: (S, K:) originally used in relation to a bird caught in a snare. (A, TA.)

muHotabilN mHtbl
: see HaAbilN.

1 Habina Hbn
, aor.
Habana
; (S, K;) and Hubina; inf. n. (of the former, TA) HabanN and (of the latter, TA) HabonN; (K;) He (a man) had the dropsy; as also AHtbn↓: (KL:) he had a disease in the belly, whereby it became large and swollen. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Habina Ealayohi, aor.
Habana
, (K,) inf. n. HabanN, (TA,) (tropical:) He became filled with anger against him. (K. TA.)

4 AHbnhu AHbnh AHbnp A^Hbn A^Hbnh
[It caused him, or his belly, to become large and swollen]: said of a disease [app. dropsy] that has befallen one; or of much eating. (TA.)

see 1.

HabonN Hbn
The tree called difolaY [q. v.]; as also HabiynN↓. (K.)

HibonN Hbn
and HibonapN↓ i. q. dum~alN [all which are applied in the present day to A boil]: (K:) and [small swellings or pustules, of the kind termed] xuraAj, (K,) like dum~al: (S K:) or a thing that comes upon the body, or person, generating pus, or thick purulent matter, and swelling: pl. [of the former] HubuwnN. (K.) ＝ -A2- Also, the former, An ape, or a monkey; syn. qirodN. (Kr, K.)

HabanN Hbn
The dropsy; (S;) a disease in the belly, whereby it becomes large and swollen. (K.) ― -b2- The yellow water [of the blood; i. e. the serum: a superabundant effusion of which, in the body, constitutes dropsy]. (TA.)

HibonapN Hbn Hbnh Hbnp
: see HibonN.

HabiynN Hbyn
: see A^aHobanu: ＝ -A2- and see also HabonN.

A^m~u HubayonK *
A certain small beast or reptile, (S, K,) well known; (K;) the EiZaAyap: (Mgh:) or a species of the [kind of lizards termed] EiZaA='; of stinking odour: (Msb:) so called because of the largeness of its belly; from A^aHobanu [q. v.]: also called Hubayonapu↓; (S, Msb, K;) and sometimes the article Al is prefixed to it, (S, Msb, K,) so that it is called A^um~u AlHubayoni, (S, Msb,) by poetic license: (TA:) it is of the form of the HirobaA=' [or chameleon], broad in the breast, and large in the belly: (TA:) or, accord. to some, (TA,) it is the female of the HirobaA=': (S and Msb and K in art. Hrb, and TA in the present art.:) accord. to Az, it is a small reptile resembling the [kind of lizard called] Dab~: (Msb:) or, as some say, a certain reptile of the size of a man's hand: or, accord. to Ibn-Ziyád, a dust-coloured reptile, with four legs, and of the size of a frog that is not large; and when the children hunt it, they say to it,
An~a AlA^amiyra naAZirN A_ilayoki
A^um~a AlHubayoni Auno$uriY burodayoki
[Umm-el-Hobeyn, spread forth thy two wings: verily the commander is looking at thee]: they hunt it until fatigue overcomes it, when it stops, standing upright upon its two kind legs, and spreads forth two wings that it has, of the same dust-colour; and when they hunt it further, it spreads forth wings that were beneath those two wings, than which nothing more beautiful in colour has been seen, yellow and red and green and white, in streaks, one above another, very many; and when it has done this, they leave it: no offspring of it is found; nor any genital organ: (TA:) the appellation A^um~u HubayonK is determinate, like Aibonu EirosK and Aibonu A=waY; (S, Msb;) and [so is Hubayonapu↓,] like A^usaAmapu; (S;) but determinate as a generic appellation: (S, Msb:) the suppression of the article does not render it indeterminate; which is contr. to rule: (S, K:) the pl. is A^um~u HubayonaAtK, [which is strange,] and A^um~aAtu HubayonK. (Msb.) ― -b2- The Arabs say, in one of their imprecations, Sab~a A@ll~`hu Ealayoka A^um~a HubayonK maAxiDFA meaning (assumed tropical:) [May God pour upon thee] the night. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA in art. mxS.)

Hubayonapu Hbynh Hbynp
: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

A^aHobanu *
Having the dropsy; (S, Mgh, Msb;) as also maHobuwnN↓ (KL) [and HabiynN↓; so in the Lex. of Golius; and so in the present day]: having a disease in the belly, whereby it becomes large and swollen: (K:) fem. HabonaA='u, (S, K,) applied to a woman: (S:) pl. HubonN. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) the fem., (tropical:) Big-bellied; (K, TA;) applied to a woman. (TA.) And (assumed tropical:) A foot (qadamN) having much flesh in the baxaSapN [app. here meaning the pulpy portion of the sole]; (K;) as though it were swollen. (TA.) And (assumed tropical:) A pigeon (HamaAmN) that does not lay eggs: pl. HubonN. (K.)

maHobuwnN mHb mHbwn
: see the next preceding paragraph.

muHobay^in~N *

Hat~aY HtY Hty
is a particle, used in three senses: (Mughnee:) it is a particle denoting the end of an extent; (Mughnee, K;) which is its predominant meaning; (Mughnee;) asserted by some to be always its meaning: (TA:) and denoting a cause, or motive: and syn. with A_il~aA as an exceptive; (Mughnee, K;) which last is the rarest, and is mentioned by few. (Mughnee.) ― -b2- It is used as a preposition governing the gen. case, in the same manner as A_ilaY (S, Mughnee) in respect of meaning and government, (Mughnee,) denoting the end of an extent; (S;) [signifying To, till, until, or to the time of;] but the word that it so governs must be a noun properly so called, not a pronoun except in a case of poetic license; and must signify the last part, or portion, of what is signified by that which precedes Ht~Y, as in the saying, A^akalotu Als~amakapa Hat~aY raA^osihaA [I ate the fish, even to its head]; or must be prefixed to the word signifying that part, or portion, as in the saying, [in the Kur xcvii. last verse,] salaAmN hiYa Hat~aY maTolaEi Alfajori [A night of peace, or of salutation, is it, until the time of the rising of the dawn]. (Mughnee.) It is also followed by a mansoob aor., as in sirotu Hat~aY A^adoxulahaA [I journeyed until I entered it, AdxlhA here virtually meaning daxalotuhaA], A^ano being here understood after Ht~Y, and the An together with the verb being rendered in grammatical analysis by an inf. n. governed in the gen. case by Ht~Y [so that Ht~Y An AdxlhA means Ht~Y duxuwliY A_iy~aAhaA]: this is one of the cases in which Ht~Y differs from A_ilaY; for one may not say, sirotu A_ilaY A^adoxulahaA [with A^ano understood after AlY]: and in the same sense it is used in the phrase, [in the Kur xx. 93,] Hat~aY yarojiEa A_ilayonaA muwsaY [Until Moses return to us]. (Mughnee.) ― -b3- It is also syn. with kaYo, denoting a cause or motive [of action &c., signifying To the end that, in order that, or so that], as in the saying, A^asolimo Hat~aY tadoxula Aljan~apa [Become a Muslim, to the end that, or in order that, or so that, thou mayest enter Paradise]; being in this case, likewise, followed by a mansoob aor. (Mughnee.) ― -b4- It is also used [as a preposition virtually governing the gen. case, A^ano being understood after it,] in the sense of A_il~aA, meaning Except, or unless, likewise followed by a mansoob aor., as in the following verse:
layosa AlEaTaA='u mina AlfuDuwli samaAHapF
Hat~aY tajuwda wamaA ladayoka qaliylu
[The giving of superfluities is not liberality: (giving is not liberality) except, or unless, (or here we may also say until,) thou be bountiful when little is in thy possession]. (Mughnee.) ― -b5- It is also a conjunction, like wa, [signifying And, or rather even,] (S, Mughnee,) but on three conditions: first, that the word following it and conjoined by it be a noun properly so called, not a pronoun: secondly, that this noun signify a part, or portion, of what is signified by that which precedes Ht~Y, as in qadima AlHuj~aAju Hat~aY Almu$aApu [The pilgrims arrived: even those on foot], and A^akalotu Als~amakapa Hat~Y raA^osahaA [I ate the fish: even its head]: thirdly, that the noun following it and conjoined by it denote either the greatest or the least [literally or figuratively] of what are included in the signification of the noun that precedes Ht~Y, as in maAta Aln~aAsu Hat~aY AlA^anobiyaA='u [Men have died: even the prophets], and zaAraka Aln~aAsu Hat~aY AlHaj~aAmuwna [The people visited thee: even the cuppers]. (Mughnee.) ― -b6- It is also used as an inceptive particle, (S, Mughnee,) preceding a nominal proposition, (Mughnee,) as in the following verse (of Jereer [so in a copy of the S]):
famaA zaAlati AlqatolaY tamuj~a dimaA='ahaA
bidijolapa Hat~aY maA='u dijolapa A^a$okalu
[And the slain ceased not to emit their blood into the Tigris, so that the water of the Tigris was of a mixed colour consisting of red and white]: (S, Mughnee:) and preceding a verbal proposition, of which the verb is a pret., as in the phrase, [in the Kur vii. 93,] Hat~aY EafawoA waqaAluwA [So that they became numerous, and said]: (Mughnee:) and preceding a marfooa aor., as in the phrase, [in the Kur ii. 210,] Hat~aY yaquwlu Alr~asuwlu [So that the Apostle said, or, as in the S, so that this was the case: the Apostle said], accord. to him who reads yaquwlu; (IHsh, in De Sacy's “ Anthol. Gramm. Ar., ” p. 82 of the Arabic text;) others reading yaquwla, which, as well as yaquwlu, here means qaAla. (Jel.) ― -b7- [Respecting the cases in which the mansoob aor. is used after HA~Y, and those in which the marfooa aor. is used, the following observations are made.] When Ht~Y precedes a future, the latter is mansoob, by reason of A^ano understood before it, as in the saying, sirotu A_ilY Alkuwfapi Hat~aY A^adoxulahaA [I journeyed to El-Koofeh until I entered it: see above]: (S:) it is not mansoob unless the verb is a future: if it is future with respect to the time of speaking, it must be mansoob, as in Hat~aY yarojiEa A_ilayonaA muwsaY [cited above]: if the verb is future with respect to what precedes, only, it may be mansoob, as in Hat~aY yaquwla Alr~asuwlu [mentioned above]; or it may be marfooa; but not unless [somehow] denoting a present time; (Mughnee;) and if present with respect to the time of speaking, it must be marfooa, as in the saying, sirotu A_ilaY Alkuwfapi Hat~aY A^adoxuluhaA [I have journeyed to El-Koofeh so that now I am entering it]; (S, Mughnee; *) but if not really present, it is not marfooa unless denoting a past event as though it were present, as in Hat~aY yaquwlu Alr~asuwlu [explained above]; nor may it be marfooa unless denoting an effect of what precedes it; so that you may not say, sirotu Hat~aY taToluEu Al$~amosu, nor maA sirotu Hat~aY A^adoxuluhaA unless the mA is regarded as prefixed to the entire affirmative phrase that follows it, nor halo sirota Hat~aY tadoxuluhaA; nor may it be marfooa unless it denote a complement to what precedes it, so that you may not say syorY Hat~aY A^adoxuluhaA, as the inchoative would in this case be without an enunciative. (Mughnee.) ― -b8- [The following verse of El-Farezdak is cited in the Mughnee as an ex. of Ht~Y used as an inceptive particle:
fawaAEajabaA Hat~aY kulayobN tasub~uniY
kaA^an~a A^abaAhaA naho$alN wamujaA$iEu
and it is there added that yasub~uniY Aln~aAsu must be understood in this verse before Ht~Y: but I rather think that Ht~Y is here a conjunctive particle, and
that the meaning is, And alas, my wonder! the people revile me: even Kuleyb revile me, as though their father were Nahshal and as though he were Mujáshi'.] ― -b9- It should be observed that Ht~uY may be used in three different ways in some sentences: thus you may say, using it as a preposition (in the sense of A_ilaY), A^akalotu Als~amakapa Hat~aY raA^osihaA [I ate the fish, even to its head]; and, using it as a conjunction, Hat~aY raA^osahaA [even its head]; and, using it as an inceptive particle, Hat~aY raA^osuhaA [for Hat~aY raA^osuhaA maA^okuwlN so that its head was eaten]. (Mughnee.) ― -b10- It is said in the K that Ht~Y renders makhfood and marfooa and mansoob; and that therefore Fr said, A^amuwtu wafiY nafosiY mino Hat~aY $aYo'N [“ I shall die with something respecting Ht~Y (remaining unsettled) in my mind ”]: this is said on the supposition that Ht~Y deviates in government from an established rule, which is, that a particle which governs one part of speech governs that only; those, for instance, which render mansoob and mejzoom governing verbs only, and the particles that govern nouns governing none but nouns: but the truth is, that Ht~Y governs only the gen. case; a marfooa noun or aor. after it would be so without it, as Ht~Y in this case is only an inceptive particle; and a mansoob aor. after it is rendered so by A^ano understood, so that Ht~Y in this case virtually governs a noun in the gen. case [as has been shown above]: therefore the remark quoted above from the K is faulty, and confounds things that should be distinguished. (MF, TA.) ― -b11- Some say that Ht~Y is [a noun] of the measure faEolaY, from AlHat~u↓ the ceasing from a thing, having finished it; or the becoming unoccupied by a thing; like $at~aY from Al$~at~u: but Az disapproves of this, because, were it so, the pronunciation termed A_imaAlap would be allowable in its case, and it is not so: Ht~Y, he says, is a particle, not a noun, nor a verb. (TA.) ― -b12- Hat~aAma is originally Hat~aY maA [Till when? until when? or how long?]: the A of mA is elided because the expression is used interrogatively, like as it is when any preposition is prefixed to it if used interrogatively, as in bima and fiyma and Eam~a. (S.) ― -b13- In the dial. of Hudheyl, Eat~aY is said for Hat~aY. (L.)

1 HavaA Alv~uraAba * and HavaY AltrAb
, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) the latter of which is the more usual, or more supported by authority, (TA,) aor. yaHovuw and yaHoviY, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. HavowN and HavoYN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and taHovaA='N, (S,) He poured dust (Msb, TA) with his hand; (Msb;) threw it, or cast it; (TA;) or seized it with his hand and threw it; (Mgh, Msb;) Ealayohi [upon him, or it], (K,) and fiY wajohihi [in his face]: (S, Msb:) AlHavoYu and Alhayolu both signify the pouring of dust; but the former, not without [first] raising it; and the latter, the sending forth, or down, without raising. (Ham p. 477.) [See an ex. in a verse cited in art. AY, conj. 6.] Accord. to IAth, the saying, in a trad., AuiHovuwA fiY wujuwhi Almad~aAHiyna Alt~uraAba means (assumed tropical:) [Repel ye with] disappointment [those who praise much]: but some make it to have its overt meaning [of throw ye dust in the faces of those who praise much]. (TA.) The verb is also used in relation to water; as in the saying, yakofiyhi A^ano yaHovuwa valaAva HavawaAtK↓, (Msb,) and kaAna yaHoviY valaAva HavayaAtK, (TA, [and the like is said in the Mgh,]) i. e. (assumed tropical:) [It is sufficient for him to throw, and he used to throw,] three handfuls [of water]. (Msb, TA.) ― -b2- HavaY said of a jerboa means He went so deep into his hole that he could not be dug out, the direction of his hole being unknown, and it being seen to be filled with dust, or earth, even with the rest of the ground. (TA in art. Hfr.) The jerboa throws up (yaHovuw) the dust, or earth, from his hole. (IAar, TA.) ― -b3- Havawotu lahu also means (assumed tropical:) I gave him something little in quantity, or paltry. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- You say also, HavaA Alt~uraAbu or HavaY, aor. yaHovuw and yaHoviY; (K;) so in the copies of the K, but correctly yaHovaA, [or rather yaHovaY,] which is extr., like jabaA [or jabaY], aor. yajobaA [or yajobaY], and qalaA [or qalaY], aor. yaqolaA [or yaqolaY]; i. e. The dust became poured; or thrown, or cast. (TA.)

Prov. ii. 920, AlmuHov`Y:)] said on the occasion of wishing to be in the condition of him of whom the honourable treatment that he receives is concealed, and of whom the contemptuous treatment that he receives is made apparent: originating from the fact that a man was sitting with a woman, and a man attached to her approached; so, when she saw him, she threw dust in his [the former's] face, to show this man who was sitting with her that he should not draw near to her, lest their case should become known. (TA.)

1 Haj~a Hj
, aor.
Haju3a
, (S, A, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. Haj~N, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) He repaired, or betook himself, to, or towards, syn. qaSada, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) a person (S, A, Mgh) [or place], in an absolute sense: or to, or towards, an object of reverence, veneration, respect, or honour: or, accord. to Kh, he repaired, or betook himself, much, or frequently, to, or towards, an object of this kind: and also he repaired to, betook himself to, or visited, a person: (TA:) and he went to, or visited, a person repeatedly, or frequently. (ISk, T, S, Mgh, K. *) You say also, Haj~a banuw fulaAnK fulaAnFA The sons of such a one continued long going repeatedly to visit such a one. (S.) ― -b2- Hence, (S, Mgh, Msb,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (S,) and inf. n. Hij~N also, (Sb, L,) or this is a simple subst., (S, Msb, K,) by a conventional usage, (S,) or predominantly, (Mgh,) or by restriction of its usage in the law, (Msb,) He repaired to Mekkeh, (S, K,) or to the Kaabeh, (Mgh, Msb,) to perform the religious rites and ceremonies of the pilgrimage; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) or for the purpose of the Eumorap [q. v.; but this latter meaning is very rare: the usual meaning is, he performed the pilgrimage to Mekkeh and Mount' Arafát, with all the rites and ceremonies prescribed to be observed at, and between, those two places]: (Msb:) or he repaired to the House [of God, at Mekkeh,] and performed the actions prescribed for that occasion by the law of the Kur-án and the Sunneh. (L.) [See Haj~N, below.] You say also, Haj~a Alayota, aor.
Haju3a
, inf. n. Haj~N, (T, S,) and AHtj~hu↓, (El-Hejeree, TA,) He performed the pilgrimage to the House [of God, at Mekkeh]; (T, S;) because people repair to it every year. (T, TA.) And Haj~uwA mak~apa [They performed the pilgrimage to Mekkeh]. (A.) And maA Haj~a wal`kin~ahu daj~a He did not repair to Mekkeh to visit the House of God, (Aboo-Tálib, Az,) or for the performance of the rites and ceremonies of the pilgrimage, (Msb,) but he journeyed for mercantile purposes. (Aboo-Tálib, Az, Msb. [See also art. dj.]) And hence, accord. to some, laj~a faHaj~a, a prov., which see below. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, (TA,) inf. n. Haj~N, (K,) He came, or arrived. (K, TA.) You say, Haj~a EalayonaA fulaAnN Such a one came to us. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, [aor., accord. to rule, as above,] inf. n. Haj~N, He shaved [his head; as one does on completing the performance of the rites and ceremonies of the pilgrimage: see Haj~N, below]. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Also, (IAar, A, &c.,) aor.
Haju3a
, inf. n. Haj~N, (TA,) He probed a fracture of the head, (K,) or a wound, (A, TA,) with a miHojaAj, (A, K,) or miyl, (TA,) for the purpose of curing it: (TA:) or he probed a wound to know its depth: (IAar, TA:) or he examined a cleft in the head to know whether there were in it bone or blood: (ISh, TA:) or he dressed and cured a wound in the head reaching to the brain: or he poured boiled clarified butter upon a fracture of the head, in consequence of which the blood was mixed with the brain, until the blood appeared, which he took away with a little cotton: (TA:) or Haj~ahu, inf. n. Haj~N, signifies he probed a fracture of his head for the purpose of curing it: (S:) or he made a perforation in the bone [of his broken head] (qadaHa fiyhi) with an iron instrument, it being broken so that the brain was befouled with blood, and pulled off the skin that had dried up, and then cured it, so that it closed up with a [new] skin: it relates to a wound reaching to the brain. (L.) ― -b2- Also, aor.
Haju3a
, inf. n. Haj~N, He cut out and extracted a bone from a wound. (TA.) ＝ -A4- Also, (A, Msb,) aor.
Haju3a
, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. Haj~u, (K,) He overcame another in, or by, an argument, a plea, an alle-
gation, a proof, an evidence, or a testimony. (A, Msb, K.) See 3. It is said in a prov., laj~a faHaj~a (S, TA) He was pertinacious in litigation, dispute, or altercation, and overcame therein [as is implied in the S, and expressed in the TA]: or he persevered until he performed the pilgrimage [not having intended to do so when he set out: see Freytag's “ Arab. Prov. ” ii. 452]. (TA.) ＝ -A5- Also, (TA,) [aor., accord. to rule,
Haji3a
,] inf. n. Haj~N; (K;) and HajoHaja↓, (K,) inf. n. HajoHajapN; (TA;) He refrained, forbore, or abstained, (K, TA,) Eano $aYo'K from a thing. (TA.) [See also the latter verb below.]

, (S, A, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. muHaAj~apN (A, Msb, TA) and HijaAjN, (TA,) He contended with him in, or by, an argument, a plea, an allegation, a proof, an evidence, or a testimony. (S, Mgh, Msb, TA.) [inf. n. of tHAj~wA] The contending, one with another, in a litigation, a dispute, or an altercation; (S, K;) the adducing arguments, pleas, allegations, proofs, evidences, or testimonies, one with another. (KL.)

see 1. ＝ -A2- [AHtj~ bi$aYo'K He adduced, or urged, or defended himself by adducing or urging, a thing as an argument, a plea, an allegation, a proof, an evidence, or a testimony.] You say, AHtj~ EalaY xaSomihi biHuj~apK $ahobaA='a [He argued against his adversary with a strong, or a difficult, argument, plea, &c.]. R. Q. 1 HajoHaja HjHj
, inf. n. HajoHajapN: see 1, last signification. ― -b2- Also He retired, or drew back; or did so in fear: (S, K:) or he lacked power, or ability. (TA.) One says, HamaluwA EalaY Alqawomi HamolapF vum~a HajoHajuwA They made a single charge, or assault, upon the party, and then retired, or drew back; or drew back in fear: (S, TA:) or lacked power, or ability. (TA.) ― -b3- He refrained from saying what he desired, or was about, to say; (S, K;) like majomaja: (S:) or he did not reveal, or manifest, what was in his mind. (M, TA.) It is said in one of the provs. of Meyd, nafosuka bimaA tuHajoHiju A^aEolamu Thou thyself knowest better than others [what thou refrainest from uttering, or] what is in thy mind. (TA.) ― -b4- He remained, stayed, abode, or dwelt, (K, TA,) bimakaAnK in a place; not quitting it; as also taHajoHaja↓. (TA.)

: see what next precedes.

Haj~u Hj
and Hij~N↓, the former an inf. n., and the latter a simple subst., (S, Msb, K,) or the latter also is an inf. n., (Sb, L,) [both used as substs.,] The pilgrimage to Mekkeh, (S, K,) or to the Kaabeh, (Msb,) to perform the religious rites and ceremonies prescribed to be observed on that occasion: (S, Msb, K:) Ks makes no difference between these two words: some say that the former is employed to signify the religious rites and ceremonies of the pilgrimage because they follow the repairing to Mekkeh, or because they are completed by shaving [the head], or because people continue long going to and fro to perform them: accord. to Az, it signifies the performance of the religious rites and ceremonies of the pilgrimage of one year; and some say Hij~N↓ and Hij~apN↓: (TA:) or this last signifies a single pilgrimage, for the performance of its appointed religious rites and ceremonies; deviating from rule; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) for by rule it should be Haj~apN↓, (S, Mgh, K,) which, Th says, has not been heard from the Arabs: (Mgh, Msb:) Ks says that Hajajotu Hij~apF↓ and raA^ayotu ruw^oyapF are the only deviations from the model of faEalotu faEolapF in all the language of the Arabs: but El-Athram and others are related to have said, We have not heard from the Arabs Hajajotu Hij~apF nor raA^ayotu riy^oyapF; they saying only Hajajotu Haj~apF↓: (L, TA:) whence it appears that Haj~apN↓ and Hij~apN↓ were both used: (TA:) the pl. of the latter is HijajN: (Mgh, Msb:) so in the saying, na*ara xamosa HijajK [He made a vow to perform five pilgrimages]. (Mgh.) Hence, *uw AlHij~api↓ (S, Mgh, Msb) and *w AlHaj~api↓, (Msb, TA,) which latter is said by Kz and 'Iyád and Ibn- Kurkool to be the more common, (TA,) [or, accord. to Fei, the contr. is the case, for he says,] some pronounce it in the latter manner, (Msb,) [The last month of the Arabian calendar;] the month of the pilgrimage; (S, Mgh, Msb;) so called because the pilgrimage to Mekkeh, and the religious rites and ceremonies thereof, are performed in it: (TA:) pl. *awaAtu AlHj~hi: (S, Msb:) they did not say *awuw AlHaj~pi agreeably with the singular. (S.) [Hence also,] waHaj~api↓ A@ll~`hi laA A^afoEalu [By the pilgrimage which is the ordinance of God, I will not do this or that thing]: a form of oath used by the Arabs. (S, K.) What is commonly termed AlHaj~u is sometimes termed AlHaj~u AlA^akobaru [The greater pilgrimage]: AlEumorapu [q. v.] being termed AlHaj~a AlA^aSogaru [the minor pilgrimage]. (Kull p. 168.) ― -b2- See also HaAj~N.

Hij~u Hj
: see Haj~u, in two places: ― -b2- and see also HaAj~N.

Haj~apN Hj Hjh Hjp
: see Haj~N, in five places. ＝ -A2- Also, (IAar, K,) and Hij~apN↓, (S, K,) the former of which is the word commonly known, (IAar in a marginal note in a copy of the S,) and HaAj~apN↓, which is a subst. like kaAhilN and gaAribN, (L,) The lobe of the ear. (S, L, K.) ― -b2- And the first, The bore, or perforation, of the lobe of the ear. (AA, TA.) ― -b3- And A bead, or a pearl, that is hung in the ear; (K;) sometimes called HaAj~apN↓. (IDrd, TA.)

Huj~apN Hj Hjh Hjp
