And na$aA^a fiY Hijorihi↓ and Hajorihi (assumed tropical:) He grew up in his care and protection. (K.) ― -b2- Also HijorN↓ (T, K) and HajorN (T, TA) [The bosom as meaning] the fore part of the garment; or the part, thereof, between one's arms. (T, K.) ― -b3- See also HajorapN: ― -b4- and maHojiru AlEayoni. ＝ -A3- Also An extended gibbous tract of sand. (K.)

HujorN Hjr Hjrp
: see HijorN, in three places: ＝ -A2- and HajorN: ― -b2- and maHojiru AlEayoni.

HijorN Hjr Hjrp
(S A, Mgh, Msb, K) and HujorN↓ (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and HajorN↓, (S, K,) of which the first is the most chaste, (S,) and maHojarN↓ (S, K) and HaAjuwrN↓ (K) [and maHojuwrN↓], Forbidden, prohibited, unlawful, inviolable, or sacred. (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K.) Each of the first three forms occurs in different readings of the Kur vi. 139. (S.) You say, h`*aA HijorN Ealayoka This is forbidden, or unlawful, to thee. (A.) In the time of paganism, a man meeting another whom he feared, in a sacred month, used to say, HijorFA maHojuwrFA↓, meaning It is rigorously forbidden to thee [to commit an act of hostility against me] in this month: and the latter, thereupon, would abstain from any aggression against him: and so, on the day of resurrection, the polytheists, when they see the punishment, will say to the angels, thinking that it will profit them: (Lth, S: *) but Az says that I' Ab and his companions explain these words [occurring in the Kur xxv. 24] otherwise, i. e., as said by the angels, and meaning, the joyful annunciation is forbidden to be made to you: and accord. to El-Hasan, the former word will be said by the sinners, and the latter is said by God, meaning it will be forbidden to them to be granted refuge or protection as they used to be in their former life in the world: but Az adds, it is more proper to regard the two words as composing one saying: (TA:) and the latter word is a corroborative of the former, like maAy^itN in the expression mawotN maAy^itN. (Bd.) The same words in the Kur xxv. 55 signify A strong mutual repugnance, or incongruity; as though each said what one says who seeks refuge or protection from another: or, as some say, a defined limit. (Bd.) A man says to another, “ Dost thou so and so, O such a one?” and the latter replies HijorFA, or HujorFA↓, or HajorFA↓, meaning [I pray for] preservation, and acquitment, from this thing; a meaning reducible to that of prohibition, and of a thing that is prohibited. (Sb.) The Arabs say, on the occasion of a thing that they disapprove, lahu HujorFA↓, with damm, meaning, May it be averted. (S.) ― -b2- Homeyd Ibn-Thowr says,
fahamamotu A^ano A^ago$aY A_ilayohaA maHojarFA
walamivoluhaA yugo$aY A_ilayohi AlmaHojaru
meaning, And I purposed doing to her a forbidden action: and verily the like of her is one to whom that which is forbidden is done. (S, K.) maHojarN↓ is also explained as signifying HuromapN; [app. meaning a thing from which one is bound to refrain, from a motive of respect or reverence;] and to have this meaning in the verse above. (Az.) ― -b3- Also, the first of these words, Any HaAy^iT [i. e. garden, or walled garden of palm-trees,] which one prohibits [to the public]. (S.) ― -b4- And AlHijoru That [space] which is comprised by [the curved wall called] the HaTiym, (S, A, Mgh, K,) which encompasses the Kaabeh on the north [or rather north-west] side; (S, A, K;) on the side of the spout: (Mgh:) or the HTym [itself], which encompasses the Kaabeh on the side of the spout. (Msb.) [It is applied to both of these in the present day; but more commonly to the former.] ― -b5- Also, HijorN, The anterior pudendum of a man and of a woman; and so HajorN↓: (K, TA:) the latter the more chaste. (TA.) ― -b6- A mare; the female of the horse: (S, A, Msb, K:) and a mare kept for breeding; (A;) as though her womb were forbidden to all but generous horses: (T:) but in the latter sense the sing. is scarcely ever used; though its pl., the first of the following forms, (as well as the second, A,) is used to signify mares kept for breeding: (K:) HijorapN↓, as a sing., is said by F and others to be a barbarism: it occurs in a trad.; but perhaps the p is there added to assimilate it to bagolapN, with which it is there coupled: (MF:) the pl. [of pauc.] is A^aHojaArN (Msb, K) and [of mult.] HujuwrN (A, Msb, K) and HujuwrapN. (K.) A poet says,
A_i*aA xarisa AlfaHolu wasoTa AlHujuwri
waSaAHa AlkilaAbu waEaq~a Alwalado
When the stallion, seeing the army and the gleaming swords, is mute in the midst of the mares kept for breeding, and does not look towards them, and the dogs bark at their masters, because of the change of their appearances, and children behave undutifully to their mothers whom fear diverts from attending to them. (A.) ― -b7- Relationship [that prohibits marriage]; nearness with respect to kindred. (Msb, K.) ― -b8- Understanding, intelligence, intellect, mind, or reason: (S, A, Msb, K:) so in the Kur lxxxix. 4: (S, Bd:) thus called because it forbids that which it does not behoove one to do. (Bd.) One says, fiY *`lika EiborapN li*iy HijorK In that is an admonition to him who possesses understanding, &c. (A.) ＝ -A2- See also HajurN, in three places.

HajarN Hjr Hjrp
[A stone; explained in the K by SaxorapN; but this means “a rock,” or “a great mass of stone” or “of hard stone”]; (S, K, &c.;) so called because it resists, by reason of its hardness; (Mgh;) and A^uHojur~N↓ signifies the same: (Fr, K:) pl. (of pauc., of the former, S) A^aHojaArN (S, Mgh, K) and A^aHojurN (K) and (of mult, S) HijaArN and [more commonly] HijaArapN, (S, K,) which last is extr. [with respect to rule], (S,) or agreeable with a usage of the Arabs, which is, to add p to any pl. of the measure fiEaAlN or of that of fuEuwlN, as in the instances of *ikaArapN and fiHaAlapN and *ukuwrapN and fuHuwlapN. (AHeyth.) And (metonymically, TA) (tropical:) Sand: (IAar, K;) pl. A^aHojaArN. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] A^aholu AlHajari The people of the desert, who dwell in stony and sandy places: occurring in a trad., coupled with A^aholu Almadari. (TA.) ― -b3- AlHajaru AlA^asowadu, and simply AlHajaru, The [Black] Stone of the Kaabeh. (K, TA.) El-Farezdak applies to it, in one instance, the pl. AlA^aHojaAru, considering the sing. as applicable to every part of it. (TA.) ― -b4- One says, fulaAnN Hajaru AlA^aroDi, meaning (assumed tropical:) Such a one is unequalled. (TA.) And rumiYa fulaAnN biHajari AlA^aroDi (tropical:) Such a one has had a very sagacious and crafty and politic man made to be an assailant against him. (K, * TA.) El-Ahnaf Ibn-Keys said to 'Alee, when Mo'á- wiyeh named 'Amr Ibn-El-'Ás as one of the two umpires, qado rumiyta biHajari AlA^aroDi faA@joEalo maEahu A@bona Eab~aAsK faA_in~ahu laA yaEoqidu EuqodapF A_il~aA Hal~ahaA (assumed tropical:) Thou hast had a most exceedingly sagacious and crafty and politic man made to be an assailant against thee: so appoint thou with him Ibn-'Abbás; for he will not tie a knot but he shall untie it: meaning one that shall stand firm like a stone upon the ground. (L from a trad.) One says also, rumYa fulaAnN biHajarihi, meaning (tropical:) Such a one was coupled [or opposed] with his like: (A:) [as though he
had a stone suited to the purpose of knocking him down cast at him.] ― -b5- liloEaAhiri AlHajaru, occurring in a trad., means (assumed tropical:) For the fornicator, or adulterer, disappointment, and prohibition: accord. to some, it is meant to allude to stoning; [and it may have had this meaning in the first instance in which it was used;] but [in general] this is not the case; for every fornicator is not to be stoned. (IAth, TA.) [See also art. Ehr.] ― -b6- AlHajaru Gold: and silver. (K.) Both together are called AlHajaraAni. (S.)

HajirN Hjr Hjrp
[Stony; abounding with stones]. You say A^aroDN HajirapN [so in several copies of the K; in the CK HajorapN;] Land abounding with stones; as also HajiyrapN↓ and mutaHaj~irapN↓. (K.)

HujurN Hjr Hjrp
The flesh surrounding the nail. (K.)

HajorapN Hjr Hjrh Hjrp
A severe year, that confines men to their tents, or houses, so that they slaughter their generous camels to eat them. (L in art. nbt, on a verse of Zuheyr.) ＝ -A2- A side; an adjacent tract or quarter; (ISd, K;) as also HajorapN↓: (EM p. 281:) pl. of the former HajorN↓, [or rather this is a coll. gen. n., of which the former is the n. un.,] and HajaraAtN (S, K) and HawaAjiru↓: (K:) the last is mentioned by ISd as being thought by him to be a pl. of HajorapN in the sense above explained, contr. to analogy. (TA.) Hence, HajorapN qawomK The tract or quarter adjacent to the abode of a people. (S.) And HajorataA AlT~ariyqi The two sides of the road. (TA.) And HajorataA EasokarK The two sides of an army; (A, TA;) its right and left wings. (TA.) And qaEada HajorapF He sat aside. (A.) And saAra HajorapF He journeyed aside, by himself. (TA.) And maHojarFA↓ is also said to signify the same, in the following ex.: taroEaY maHojarFA wataboruku wasaTFA She (the camel) pastures aside, and lies down in the middle. (TA.) It is said in a prov., yarobiDu HajorapF wayarotaEiY wasaTFA He lies down aside, and pastures in the middle: (S:) or fulaAnN yaroEaY wasaTFA wayarobiDu HajorapF Such a one pastures in the middle, and lies down aside: (TA:) applied to a man who is in the midst of a people when they are in prosperity, and when they become in an evil state leaves them, and lies down apart: the prov. is ascribed to Gheylán Ibn-Mudar. (IB.) Imra-el--Keys says, [addressing Khálid, in whose neighbourhood he had alighted and sojourned, and who had demanded of him some horses and riding-camels to pursue and overtake a party that had carried off some camels belonging to him (Imra-el-Keys), on Khálid's having gone away, and returned without anything,]
fadaEo Eanoka nahobFA SiyHa HajaraAtihi
wal`kino HadiyvFA maA Hadyvu Alr~awaAHili
[Then let thou alone spoil by the sides of which a shouting was raised: but relate to me a story. What is the story of the riding-camels?]: hence the prove., AlHukomu lil~hi
wadaEo Eanoka nahobFA SiyHa fiY HajaraAtihi
[Dominion belongeth to God: then let thou alone &c.]; said with reference to him who has lost part of his property and after that lost what is of greater value. (TA.) [And hence the saying,] qadi A@nota$arato Hajoratuhu (assumed tropical:) His property has become large, or ample. (S.) ― -b2- See also HajorN.

HujorapN Hjr Hjrh Hjrp
An enclosure (HaZiyrapN) for camels. (S, K.) ― -b2- [And hence,] The Hujorap of a house; (S;) [i. e.] a chamber [in an absolute sense, and so in the present day]; syn. bayotN: (Msb:) or an upper chamber; syn. gurofapN: (K:) pl. HujarN and HujuraAtN (S, Msb, K) and HujaraAtN and HujoraAtN. (Z, Msb, K.) ― -b3- See also HajorapN.

HijorapN Hjr Hjrh Hjrp
: see HijorN.

HujoriY~N Hjr HjrY Hjrp Hjry Hjryy
and HijoriY~N A right, or due; a thing, or quality, to be regarded as sacred, or inviolable; (K;) a peculiar attribute. (TA.)

A^aroDN HajiyrapN *
: see HajirN.

HaAjirN HAjr
The part of the brink ($afap) of a valley that retains the water, (S, K,) and surrounds it; (ISd;) as also HaAjuwrN↓: pl. of the former HujoraAnN. (S, K.) High land or ground, the middle of which is low, or depressed; (K;) as also maHojirN↓: (TA:) and maHaAjiru↓ [pl. of the latter] low places in the ground, retaining water. (A.) A fertile piece of land, abounding with herbage, low, or depressed, and having elevated borders, upon which the water is retained. (AHn.) A place where water flows, or where herbs grow, surrounded by high ground, or by an elevated river. (T, TA.) A place where trees of the kind called rimov grow; where they are collected together; and a place which they surround: (M, K:) pl. as above. (K.) ― -b2- A wall that retains water between houses: so called because encompassing. (TA.)

HaAjuwrN HAjwr
: see HijorN: ― -b2- and HaAjirN. ― -b3- Also A refuge; a means of protection or defence: analogous with EaAvuwrN, which signifies “a place of perdition:” whence,
waqaAla qaAy^iluhumo A_in~aY biHaAjuwri
And their sayer said, Verily I lay hold on that which will protect me from thee and repel thee from me; mutamas~ikN being understood. (TA.)

HawaAjiru HwAjr
: see HajorapN.

HanojarapN Hnjr Hnjrh Hnjrp
and HunojuwrN↓, (S, K,) each with an augmentative n, (S, Msb,) [The head of the windpipe; consisting of a part, or the whole, of the larynx: but variously explained; as follows:] the windpipe; syn. HuloquwmN: (S, K:) or the former [has this meaning, i. e.], the passage of the breath: (Mgh, Msb:) or the extremity of the Hlqwm, at the entrance of the passage of the food and drink: (Bd in xxxiii. 10:) or [the head of the larynx, composed of the two arytenoides;] two of the successively-superimposed cartilages of the Hlqwm (TabaqaAni mino A^aTobaAqi AlHuloquwmi), next the galoSamap [or epiglottis], where it is pointed: or the inside, or cavity, of the Hlqwm: and so HunojuwrN↓: (TA in art. Hnjr:) or ↓the latter is syn. with HaloqN [q. v.]: (Msb:) pl. HanaAjiru. (K.)

HunojuwrN Hnjwr
: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places. ― -b2- Also A small safaT [or receptacle for perfumes and the like]. (K.) ― -b3- And A glass flask or bottle (qaAruwrap), (K, TA,) of a small size, (TA,) for *ariyrpa [q. v.]. (K, TA.)

A^uHojur~N *
: see HajarN.

maHojirN mHjr
: see HijorN, in four places. ― -b2- Also, (S,) or maHojirN↓ and miHojarN↓, (K,) The tract surrounding a town or village: (S, K:) [pl. maHaAjiru.] Hence the maHaAjir of the kings (A^aqoyaAl) of ElYemen, which were Places of pasturage, whereof each of them had one, in which no other person pastured his beasts: (S, K:) the mHjr of a qayol of El-Yemen was his tract of land into which no other person than himself entered. (T.) ― -b3- See also HajorapN. ― -b4- And see maHojru AlEayoni.

maHojirN mHjr
(S, K) and miHojarN↓ (K) A garden surrounded by a wall; or a garden of trees; syn. HadiyqapN: (S, K:) or a low, or depressed, place of pasture: (T, TA:) or a place in which is much pasture, with water: (A, * TA:) pl. maHaAjiru. (S, A.) See also HaAjirN for the former word and its pl.: and see maHojarN. ― -b2- maHojiru AlEayoni (S, K, &c.) and maHojaruhaA↓ (TA) and miHoHaruhA↓ (K) and simply AlmHjr (Msb, TA) and AlHajoru↓ (K) and AlHujoru↓, which occurs in a verse of El-Akhtal, (IAar,) [The part which is next below, or around, the eye, and which appears when the rest of the face is veiled by the niqaAb or the buroquE:] that part [of the face, next below the eye,] which appears from out of the [kind of veil called] niqaAb (T, S, A, Msb, K) of a woman (A, Msb, K) and of a man, from the lower eyelid; and sometimes from the upper: (Msb:) or the part that surrounds the eye (Msb, K) on all sides, (Msb,) and appears from out of the [kind of veil called] buroquE: (Msb, K:) or the part of the bone beneath the eyelid, which encompasses the eye: (TA:) and mHjr AlEyn means also what appears from beneath the turban of a man when he has put it on: (K: [accord. to the TA, the turban itself; but this is a meaning evidently derived from a mistranscription in a copy of the K, namely, EimaAmatuhu for EimaAmatihi:]) also mHjruAlwajohi that part of the face against which the nqAb lies: and AlmHjr the eye [itself]: (T, TA:) the pl. of mHjr is maHaAjiru. (A, Msb.)

miHojarN mHjr
: see maHojarN: ― -b2- and see also maHojirN, in two places.

maHojuwrN Ealayohi mHjwr Elyh mHjwr Elyp
, for which the doctors of practical law say maHojuwrN only, omitting the preposition and the pronoun governed by it, on account of the frequent usage of the term, A person prohibited [by a kádee] from using, or disposing of, his property according to his own free will: (Msb:) or prohibited from consuming, or wasting, or ruining, his property. (Mgh.) ― -b2- See also HijorN, in two places.

HijozN Hjz
: see HujozapN, in two places.

HajozapN Hjz Hjzh Hjzp
A severe year, that confines men to their tents or houses, so that they slaughter their generous camels to eat them. (L in art. nbt, on a verse of Zuheyr.)

Hujozapu AlA_izaAri Hjzp AlAzAr
The place [or part] of the AzAr where it is tied [round the waist]; (S, Msb, K, TA;) the place where the end of the AzAr is folded, or doubled, in wrapping it round: (Lth, TA:) and [in like manner] Hujozapu Als~araAwiyli [the tuck, or doubled upper border, of the trousers, through which passes the waist-band, i. e., the band or string that binds them round the waist;] the part of the trousers in which is the tik~ap [or waist-band]; (S;) the place of the tik~ap: (K:) pl. HujazN (Msb, TA) and HujuzaAtN and HujazaAtN: (TA:) and hence HujozapN is applied to the garment called A_izaAr itself; as also HijozN↓; of which latter the pl. is HujuzN, with two dammehs, [app. contracted into HujozN,] and pl. pl. And it is said in a trad. of 'Alee, when he was asked respecting the BenooUmeiyeh, humo A^a$ad~unaA HujazFA, or HajozapF, accord. to different relations, (tropical:) They are the most patient of us in difficulty. (TA.) ― -b3- You say also rajulN T~y~ibu AlHujozapi, (A, TA,) and kariymu AlHujozapi, and kariymu AlHujozi, [app. a contraction of AlHujuzi,] (TA,) (tropical:) He is one who abstains from what is unlawful and indecorous [especially with respect to women]; like Tay~ibu AlA_izaAri. [But this admits of another meaning, as will be seen, under the word HadadN, below.]) ― -b2- [Hence,] A restrictive ordinance, or statute, of God, respecting things lawful and things unlawful: pl. HuduwdN. (L.) The Huduwd of God are of two kinds: first, those ordinances prescribed to men (T, Mgh, L) respecting eatables and drinkables and marriages &c.; what are lawful thereof and what are unlawful: (T, L:) the second kind, castigations, or punishments, prescribed, or appointed, to be inflicted upon him who does that which he has been forbidden to do; (T, Mgh, L;) as the Hd~ of the thief, which is the cutting off of his right hand for stealing a thing of the value of a quarter of a deenár or more; and that of the fornicator or fornicatress, which is flogging with a hundred stripes and banishment for a year; and that of the adulterer or adulteress, which is stoning; and that of the person who [falsely] charges an honest or a married woman with adultery, which is flogging with eighty stripes [as is also that of the person who has committed the crime of drunkenness]: (T, L:) the first kind are called Hdwd because they denote limits which God has forbidden to transgress: the second, because they prevent one's committing again those acts for which they are appointed as punishments; (T, Mgh, L;) or because the limits thereof are determined: (Mgh:) the latter kind of Hd~ is also explained as being that [castigation, or punishment,] which prevents the criminal from returning to his crime, and prevents others from committing his crime. (L, K. *) lawo raA^ayotahu EalaY Had~K, in a saying of ' Omar, means Hadst thou seen him engaged in an affair requiring the infliction of the Hd~. HuduwdN. (L.) ― -b4- A limit, or boundary, of a land or territory: pl. as above. (L.) Hence the saying, waraA='aki bunoduqap HidaA^a HidaA^a↓, (S, K, TA,) for which the vulgar say, HadaA HadaA, (S,) [accord. to some, meaning O kite, O kite, a bullet is behind thee: accord. to others, O Ḥidà, O Ḥidà, Bunduḳah is behind thee:] Esh-Sharḳee (Ibn-El-Ḳuṭámee, Ta) Says, (S,) HidaA^N and bunoduqapu were two tribes, descendants of HidaA^u bonu namirapa and bunoduqapu bonu maZ~apa, (S, K, *) and both of saEodu AlEa$iyrapi; (S, TA;) the former in El-Koofeh, and the latter in El-Yemen: the former attacked the latter, and obtained spoil from them; and then the latter attacked the former, and destroyed them: (TA:) and hence this saying: (S, K, TA:) or HidaA^a is here an apocopated form of HidaA^ap: (S, K:) so says ISk: (S:) and AO says that by it is here meant the bird [i. e. the kite]; and by bndqp, the thing with which one shoots [from a cross-bow, namely, a bullet]; and the prov. is used to caution a person: accord. to Ibn-El-Kelbee, it is applied to him who esteems himself cunning in an affair, and is outwitted therein by another: accord. to the A, to him who is threatened with an evil near at hand. A novelty, or new thing; an innovation; a thing not known before: and particularly relating to El-Islám [i. e. to matters of religious doctrine or practice or the like]: (Mgh:) [and so A^amorN muHodavN↓; for] muHodavaAtu AlA^umuwri (pl. of muHodavN, TA) signifies innovations of people of erroneous opinions, (Msb, TA,) inconsistent with the doctrines, or practices, of the just of preceding times: or what is not known in revealed scripture, nor in the Sunneh, nor in the general conventional tenets of the doctors of the law: and HadavN, [in like manner,] an innovation that is disapproved, not agreeable with custom, or usage, and not known in the Sunneh. (TA.) A=waY muHodavFA↓, occurring in a trad., means He entertained an innovation; [i. e. he embraced, or held, it;] or he was content, or pleased, with it; or he bore it patiently: or, as some say, it is A=waY muHodivFA↓, meaning he entertained, or harboured in his dwelling, a criminal, or an offender, and protected him from retaliation. HaAdivapN↓ and HadavaAnN↓ [in some copies of the S HidovaAn↓] and HudovaY↓ [signifying An accident, an event, a hap, or a casualty: and generally an evil accident or event, a mishap, a misfortune, a disaster, a calamity, or an affliction]: (S:) [the most common of these words is HaAdivapN↓; and its pl., HawaAdivu, is more common than the sing.:] the pl. of HadavN is A^aHodaAvN. , [aor., app.,

,] inf. n. HadosN, He threw, cast, or shot. (TA.) You say, Hadasotu bisahomK I shot an arrow. (S.) And Hadasotuhu bika*aA I threw, cast, or shot, at him with such a thing. (A.) ＝ -A2- Hence, Hadosu AlZ~an~i The conjecturing without evidence or proof. (TA.) You say, Hadasa, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
Hadisa
(S, Msb, K) and
Hadusa
, (K,) inf. n. HadosN, (S, A, Msb, K,) He opined: (S, A, K:) or he formed a confirmed opinion: (Msb:) he formed a surmise, or an opinion; or he spoke conjecturally, or surmising: (S, A, K:) he surmised respecting the meanings of speech or language, (A, K,) and things. (K.) And huwa yaHodisu He says a thing according to his opinion. (S, TA.) And balaganiY Eano fulaAnK A^amorN wa A^anaA A^aHodisu fiyhi A thing has been told me of such a one, and I speak of it conjecturally, or surmising. (TA.) And Hadasotu Ealayohi Zan~iY I formed my opinion of it, not being certain of it; as also nadasotu. (TA.) And Hadasa AlkalaAma EalaY EawaAhinihi He spoke without anything to guide him, and without caution. (TA.) And Hadasa Al$~aYo'a He computed by conjecture the quantity, measure, or the like, of the thing. (A.) And qaAlahu biAlHadosi [generally meaning He said it conjecturally, or surmising: but also meaning] he said it by means of intuition. (A, TA.) [HadosN is also explained in the A as signifying naZarN xaAfK: in the TA naZarN xafiY~N: both app. meaning An obscure, or an occult, mode of judging of a thing.] ― -b2- HadosN is also syn. with qaSodN, (K,) used transitively, (T, K,) [app. signifying The aiming at a thing,] by, or with, whatever thing it be; [app. meaning by any mental operation;] by opinion, or by judgment, or by intelligence or cunning sagacity. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Hadasa fiY AlA^aroDi, (El-Umawee, Msb,) aor.
Hadisa
, (El-Umawee, TA,) inf. n. HadosN, (S,) He went away, (S, Msb, TA,) or journeyed, (TA,) into, or in, or through, the country, or land, without guidance: (S, Msb, TA:) or simply he went away into, or in, the country, or land; as also Eadasa. (El-Umawee, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, app., the phrase Hadasa fiY SadoriY $aYo'N, which seems to mean A thing came at random into my mind. of the eye, (Har p. 221,) A_ilayohi at him: (Mgh, Msb:) and HadolaqapN↓, with an augmentative l, is like taHodiyqN; [the verb of which it is the inf. n., namely,] Hadolaqa↓, said of a man, signifying he rolled the black of his eye in looking. (S.)

Thus you say, Ealayohi $aAmapN sawodaA='u qado A^aHodaqa bihaA bayaADN [Upon him is a black mole which whiteness has surrounded]. (TA.) And A^aHodaqato bihi Almaniy~apu (tropical:) Death encompassed him. (TA.) ― -b2- A^aHodaquwA bihi AlA^aHodaAqi, a phrase used by El- Hareeree, means They made the blacks of the eyes to surround him. (Har p. 186.) ＝ -A2- AHdqti Alr~awoDapu, (K,) or AHdqt AlrwDp Eu$obFA, (Zj, TA,) i. e. [The meadow] became a Hadiyqap [q. v.], (Zj, K,) [by producing herbs such as are termed E$b; for] without E$b it is a rwDp. (Zj, TA.)

Arab., p. 47), solanum cordatum]: (IAar, Az, K:) [a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p: likened to the blacks of the eyes of the [species of antelope called] mahaA: in the handwriting of 'Alee Ibn-Hamzeh, written H*q, with the dotted *; but this is not known. (TA.)

HadaqapN Hdq Hdqh Hdqp
(S, Msb, K, &c.) and Hunoduwqapu↓ and HinodiyqapN↓, (K,) but IDrd doubts the correctness of this, (TA,) The black of the eye; (IDrd, Msb, K;) i. e. the round part in the middle of the eye; (TA;) the greater black of the eye; (S, TA;) the smaller being the naAZir [or pupil], in which is what is termed A_inosaAnu AlEayoni, for it is like a mirror, in which one facing it sees his figure; (TA;) [the part, of the eye, that is surrounded by the white; the iris, together with the whole of the anterior chamber of the eye;] what is in the middle of the white of the eye: (Zj in his “Khalk el-Insán:”) or, as some say, externally, the black of the eye; and internally, its xarazap [or lens]: (TA:) [and sometimes the eye, absolutely; as, for instance, in a phrase mentioned voce *aAba, in art. *wb:] pl. HadaqN↓, (S, Msb, K) [or rather this is a coll. gen. n.,] and [the pl. is] A^aHodaAqN [a pl. of pauc.] (K) and HadaqaAtN (Msb) and HidaAqN; (S, Msb, K;) which last is applied by Aboo-Dhu-eyb to the Hadaqap together with what surrounds it. (TA.) [Hence,] takal~amotu EalaY Hadaqi↓ Alqawomi I spoke while the people, or party, looked at me. (TA.) And rumaApu AlHadaqi↓ Those who hit the mark in throwing or shooting. (TA.) And nazaluwA fiY mivoli Hadaqapi AlbaEiyri (tropical:) They alighted, or alighted and abode, in a tract abounding with herbage; likened to the Hdqp of the camel because this is plentifully supplied with moisture. (TA from a trad.)

A walled garden; a garden surrounded by a wall: (S, Msb, TA:) of the measure faEiylapN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN: (Msb:) or any round piece of land surrounded by a fence or the like, or by elevated land: (TA:) or whatever is surrounded by building: (K:) and, by extension of its application, a garden, though without a wall: (Msb:) or a meadow, or garden, (rawoDap,) having trees: (S, K:) or a garden of palm-trees and of other trees, (Zj, IDrd, K,) dense and luxuriant, (Zj, IDrd, TA,) and, as some say, fruit-bearing: (TA:) or a garden (jan~ap) of palmtrees and grape-vines: (TA:) or a distinct collection of palm-trees: (K:) or a plot of seedproduce: (Kr, TA:) or a hollow in a valley, that retains water: and any depressed place in a valley, that retains water, thought water be not in its bottom: (TA:) pl. HadaAy^iqu. (S, Msb, K.) Hence the saying, wa rada EalaY~a kitaAbuka fatanaz~ahotu fiY bahojapi HadaAy^iqihi (tropical:) [Thy letter has come to me, and I have recreated myself in contemplating the beauty of its garden-like phrases]. Hdlq) A large Hadaqap [or black of the eye]: (S, K:) a meaning which shows the l to be augmentative: (TA:) or some part of the body that is unknown: (K:) one says, A^akala Al*~iy^obu mina Al$~aApi AlHudaliqapa [the wolf ate, of the sheep, or goat, the Hdlqp]: A'Obeyd says, it is some part of the body thereof, but I know not what it is: (S:) or the eye: (S, K:) so says Lh; (S;) and so Kr: (TA:) As heard an Arab of the desert, of the Benoo-Saad, say that it means its galoSamap [or epiglottis]. (IB, TA.) ― -b2- EayonN HudaliqapN An eye of which the ball, or globe, is prominent, or large and prominent; or of which the black is prominent; syn. jaAHiZapN. (TA.)

Hmd,) signifies the same as AHtdm, (AZ, S ubi suprà, TA,) from which it is formed by transposition. (S ubi suprà.) And AHtdm He suffered vehement heat from the sun, and form fire. (Msb.) And AHtdmt Alqidoru The cooking-pot boiled vehemently. (AZ, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AHtdm Al$~araAbu (tropical:) The wine, or beverage, estuated, or fermented; syn. galaY. (Mgh, TA.) And AHtdm Sadoru fulaAnK gayoZFA (S) (tropical:) The bosom of such a one burned with anger, wrath, or rage. (TA.) And AHtdm Ald~amu (tropical:) The blood became intensely red, so as to be [nearly] black; (S, Msb, K, TA;) and became vehemently burning. (Msb. [See also the part. n., below.])

and HadamN↓ The vehement burning of fire, (K,) and of heat: or, accord. to the T, Hdm [app. HadomN] signifies the vehement heating of a thing by the sun, and by fire: [see 1:] accord. to AZ, zaforu Aln~aAri signifies “ the flaming, or blazing, of fire; ” and $ahiyquhaA and HadomuhaA and HamoduhaA and kaloHabatuhaA have all one meaning [app. the third of the meanings assigned below to HadamapN]. 1 HadaA AlA_ibila HdA AlAbl
, (S, Mgh,) or Hada biAlA_ibili, (Msb,) or both, (K) and HudaA='N (S, K) and HidaA='N, (K,) He drove the camels; (S, Mgh, K;) and chid them: (K:) [and AHtdAhA↓ app. has the former signification:] and he sang to them: (S:) or he urged, or excited, the camels by singing to them, which
is termed HudaA='N↓: (Msb:) or HadaA lahaA signifies he sang to them. (Mgh.) The Arabs in driving their camels used commonly to sing verses of the kind termed rajaz. (TA in art. rjz.) [It is said that] HudaA='N↓ originated from the fact of a DesertArab's beating his young man, or boy, and biting his fingers; whereupon he went along saying daYo daYo, meaning yaA yadaY~a [“ O my two hands! ”]; and the camels went on at his cry; therefore his master bade him keep to it: (K in art. dY:) so says IAar. (TA in that art. [Other (similar) accounts of its origin are mentioned by MF in remarking on this passage of the K.]) HadaA signifies also He raised his voice with [the singing termed] AlHudaA='. (Har p. 576.) [And He breathed short (anhelavit), and sent forth a voice or sound. (Golius, from a gloss in the KL.)] ― -b2- You say also of the north wind, taHoduw Als~aHaAba, i. e. (assumed tropical:) It drives along the clouds. (S.) ― -b3- And HadaAhu EalaY ka*aA (assumed tropical:) He urged him, incited him, or put him in motion or action, to do such a thing. (Msb, TA.) ― -b4- And HadaAhu (assumed tropical:) It followed it; namely, the night the day; (K;) as also AHtdAhu↓: (AHn, K:) and so the [wild] he-ass his she-asses; and anything any other thing. (TA.) Hence the saying, laA A^afoEaluhu maA HadaA All~ayolu Aln~ahaAra (assumed tropical:) I will not do it as long as the night follows the day]. (TA.) ― -b5- See also 5.

5 tHd~Ahu A^Hd Hd tHdAh tHdAp tHdY
, in its primary sense, is form AlHudaA='u, and signifies He (a driver of camels) vied, competed, or contended for superiority, with him, or emulated him, (namely, another driver,) in driving camels, or urging them by singing to them; each of them desiring to elicit the ability of the other in doing so. (Z, TA.) ― -b2- [And hence,] He vied, or competed, and contended for superiority, with him, (S, K, * mentioned in the K in art. HdY,) in an action or a work [of any kind]. (S.) You say, taHad~ayotu Aln~aAsa AlquroA=na I sought to elicit the ability of the people in order that it might be known which of us was most skilled in reading or reciting [the Kur-án]: it means like as does the saying of a person contending with others for the superior glory of his people, “ Bring ye a people like my people, or like one of them. ” (Msb.) It is said of Mohammad, in a trad., taHad~aY AlEaraba biAlquroA=ni [He vied, or contended, with the Arabs by means of the Kur-án]. (TA.) And one says, taHad~aY SaAHibahu AlqiraA='apa, and AlS~iraAEa, [He vied, or contended, with his companion in reading, or reciting, and in wrestling,] in order that it might be seen which of them was the superior reader or reciter, and the superior wrestler. (TA.) ― -b3- Also He aimed at it; made it his object; sought, endeavoured after, pursued, or endeavoured to reach or attain or obtain, it; intended or purposed it; (AA, and K * and TA in art. HdY;) as also HadaAhu↓, (AA, TA,) and AHdAhu↓. (Sgh, and K ib.) Hence the saying of Mujáhid, kunotu A^ataHad~aY AlquroA=na faA^aqoraA^u [I used to aim at reading, or reciting, the Kur-án, and so to read, or recite]. (AA, TA.)

Hjw.]) ＝ -A2- [One who vies, or competes, and contends for superiority.] You say, A^anaA Huday~aAka bih`*aA AlA^amori [I am he who vies, &c., with thee in this affair], meaning come forth to me as an adversary, by thyself alone, (T, S, * K, * TA,) and compete, or contend, with me [in this affair]. A^aHa*~u *
Deprived of an arm, or a hand, &c., by amputation: fem. Ha*~aA='u: [pl. Hu*~N:] thus A^aHa*~u Alyadi means having the arm, or hand, amputated: and [hence] (assumed tropical:) not having the means of acquiring eminence, or nobility. (L.) [Hence, also,] A^aSuwlu biyadK Ha*~aA='a, in a trad. of 'Alee, means (assumed tropical:) Shall I assault the enemy with a short arm, that will not attain to that which I desire? or, accord. to one reading, it is ja*~aA='a, meaning amputated: alluding to his companions' falling short of their duty, and keeping back from the war. (L in arts. H* and j*.) [Another meaning of A^aHa*~u Alyadi will be found below.] ― -b2- A light-tailed camel: (S, L:) a horse light, or scanty, in the hair of the tail: (A, L:) or having it (the tail, Msb) cut off: (A, Msb:) a short-tailed ass. (L.) qaTaApN Ha*~aA='u A bird of the kind called qaTFA having a light, or scanty, tail; having a tail of which the feathers have become light, or scanty; (S, L;) having few feathers in the tail: (A:) or short-tailed: (L:) or (assumed tropical:) light and quick in flight. (A, * L.) And liHoyapN Ha*~aA='u A light, or scanty, beard. (L.) ― -b3- Lean, lank, or light of flesh; or slender; or lank in the belly. (K.) ― -b4- Smooth; (Kh, Msb;) a thing to which nothing clings, or attaches. (Msb, * TA.) wal~ati Ald~unoyaA Ha*~aA='a, in a xuTobap of 'Otbeh Ibn-Ghazwán, means (tropical:) The world hath retired, passing away quickly, (A, * L, K *) nothing clinging to it [so as to retard it]: (L, K:) or the people thereof not clinging to aught of it [so as to retard it]: (A:) or quickly; its latter part being cut off. (Az, L.) ― -b5- A sword quick in cutting. (A.) ― -b6- (tropical:) Light-handed; (S, A, L, K;) quick-handed; (L;) i. e. thievish; or quick in
getting, or attaining: (A:) [and so A^aHa*~u Alyadi, as is implied in the S and L.] El-Farezdak uses the expression A^aHa*~a yadi AlqamiySi, (S, L,) meaning thereby A^aHa*~a Alyadi. (L.) naAqapN Ha*~aA='u (assumed tropical:) A she-camel quick in pace. (A.) ― -b7- qalobN A^aHa*~u (assumed tropical:) A sharp, quick, active mind. (L.) ― -b8- sayorN A^aHa*~u (tropical:) A very quick, unpleasant journey or pace. (A.) See also Ha*oHaA*N. ― -b9- A^amorN A^aHa*~u (tropical:) An affair, or event, quick in passing: (L:) or decisive and quick: (TA:) or severe and abominable; (A, L, K;) without a parallel: (A:) or as though it eluded every one, so that he could not attain to it, and was not sufficient for it: (A:) pl. Hu*~N. (L, K.) ― -b10- yamiynN Ha*~aA='u (tropical:) An oath which a man takes quickly: (S, K:) or an abominable, severe oath, whereby one decides a right, or due: (A, L:) some say ja*~aA='u. (S.) It is said in a prov., tazab~adahaA Ha*~aA='a (tropical:) He swallowed it [i. e. took it, namely, an oath, hastily,] like as one swallows butter. (TA.) ― -b11- EaziymapN Ha*~aA='u (tropical:) An energetic and effective resolution, from which one does not turn to anything. (A.) ― -b12- HaAjapN Ha*~aA='u (tropical:) A light want, quickly accomplished. (A, L.) ― -b13- raHimN Ha*~aA='u (tropical:) A bond of relationship [cut, or severed, or] not made close by affection; expl. by A_i*aA lamo tuwSalo: (Fr, S, K:) as also ja*~aA=' [q. v.]. (Fr, S.) ― -b14- A^aHa*~u A^aba*~u: see ba*~N.

1 Ha*ira *
, aor.
Ha*ara
, inf. n. Ha*arN; and AHt*r↓; (Msb, K;) He was cautious, wary, or vigilant; was on his guard; took care; (K, TA;) was in a state of preparation; (Msb;) was in fear; feared. (TA.) [You say, Ha*ira mino A^amorK and AHt*r↓ minohu He was cautious, &c., of a thing, or an event. And Ha*ira Ealayohi mino ka*aA and AHt*r↓ He was cautious, &c., for him, of such a thing. And both verbs are also trans.: for you say,] Ha*irahu, (S, A, Msb,) aor. and inf. n. as above; (S;) and AHt*rhu↓, (TA,) and HA*rhu↓; (A;) He was cautious of it; guarded, or was on his guard, against it; (S, A;) prepared, prepared himself, or was in a state of preparation, against it; (TA;) feared it. (Msb, TA.) [And Ha*ira A^ano yafoEalahu and AHt*r↓ He was cautious of doing it; or he feared doing it.] And Hu*ira Al$~aYo'u faHa*irahu The thing was an object of fear, and so he feared it. (Msb.) And Hu*ira Almawoti [Death was an object of fear]: and Almawota HA*r↓ [He feared death]. (A.)

2 taHo*iyrN *
[The cautioning another; putting him on his guard; making him to be cautious or wary or vigilant, to be on his guard, to take care, or to be in a state of preparation;] the making to fear, or be in fear. (S, TA.) [You say, H*~rhu mino A^amorK He cautioned him against a thing. And the verb is also doubly trans.: you say,] H*~rhu AlA^amora [He cautioned him against, or made him to fear, the thing, or event]. (TA.) And A^aHa*~irukahu [I caution thee against him, or it]. (K.) And it is said in the Kur [iii. 27 and 28], yuHa*~irukumu A@ll~`hu nafosahu God maketh you to fear Himself. (TA.)

3 HaA*araA *
, (TK,) inf. n. muHaA*arapN (S, K) and Hi*aArN, (S,) They two were cautious, or in fear, each of the other; were on their guard, or in a state of preparation, each against the other. (TK.) Hi*aArN is syn. with muHaA*arapN, (S,) and muHaA*arapN is between two. (K.) ― -b2- See also 1, in two places.

8 A_iHota*ara
see 1, in five places.

11 AHdAr~ AHdAr
He was angry, (K,) and prepared himself to do mischief, (TA,) and drew himself together (taqab~aDa): so in some copies of the K and in other lexicons: or became enraged (tagay~aZa): so in other copies of the K. (TA.)

Hi*orN *
: see what next follows, in two places.

Ha*arN *
and Hi*orN↓, (S, A, Msb, K,) the former an inf. n., (S, Msb,) and the latter a simple subst., (Msb,) Caution, wariness, vigilance, guard, or care; (S, A, K;) as also maHo*uwrapN↓; (K;) or a state of preparation; (Msb;) or fear; (Mgh, * TA;) and so maHo*uwrapN↓: (S, Msb, K:) [pl. A^aHo*aArN.] You say, A^axa*a Hi*orahu↓ He took care; was cautious, or vigilant. (Bd in iv. 73 and 103.) And huwa A@bonu A^aHo*aArK (tropical:) He is a son [i. e. a person] of resolution, or determination, and caution, or wariness. (S, K.) And Ha*araka zayodFA: see Ha*aAri. ― -b2- A^abuw Ha*arK The male chameleon: (K:) because of its frequent changes. (TA.)

Ha*urN *
, and its pl.: see what next follows.

Ha*irN *
(S, A, Msb, K) and Ha*urN↓ (S, A, K) Cautious; wary; vigilant; on his guard; careful; (S;) or in a state of preparation; (Msb;) as also HaA*irN↓; (S, A, Msb;) and fearful: (S:) or very cautious or wary or vigilant or careful; as also HaA*uwrapN↓ (K) and Hi*oriyaAnN↓: (A, K:) or this last signifies very fearful and cautious &c.: (S:) pl. of the first Ha*iruwna and Ha*aAraY. (S, K.) Sb cites, as an ex. of Ha*irN used transitively,
Ha*irN A^umuwrFA laA tuxaAfu wa A=minN
maA layosa munojiyhi mina AlA^aqodaAri
[Cautious, or very cautious, of things not to be feared, and trusting in that which will not save him from the decrees of destiny]: but this is extr.; for an epithet of the measure faEilN is not [regularly] trans., so as to govern an objective complement. (S, TA.) In the Kur xxvi. 56, some read HaA*iruwna↓; and some, Ha*iruwna and Ha*uruwna↓: HA*rwn signifying in a state of preparation; (Zj, S;) or fully equipped with arms: (Sh:) and H*rwn, in a state of fear; (S;) or in a state of preparation; (TA;) or in a state of preparation with the accoutrements of war; (Ibn-Mes'ood;) or cautious, or vigilant. (Zj.)

Hi*oriyapN *
A rugged piece of ground: (S, K:) or the top of a mountain, when it is hard and rugged, but level: (Aboo-Kheyreh:) and rough ground: (TA:) and a rugged [hill such as is termed] A^akamap; as also Hi*oriyaA='u↓: (K:) pl. Ha*aAraY and Ha*aArK. (S.) ＝ -A2- Also The Eiforiyap [or feathers of the back of the neck] of a cock: (S, K:) pl. as above. (K)

Hi*oriyaA='u *
: see what next precedes.

Hi*oriyaAnN *
: see Ha*irN.

AlHu*ur~aY *
, [like Albu*ur~aY,] What is false, vain, or ineffectual; syn. AlbaATilu. (K.)

Ha*aAri *
[an imperative verbal noun] meaning Beware; be cautious, wary, or on thy guard; or take care. (S, A, K.) The poet (Abu-n-Nejm, TA) says,
Ha*aAri mino A^aromaAHinaA Ha*aAri
Beware of our spears: beware. (S, A.) And you say, sumiEato Ha*aAri fiY Easokarihimo [The cry “ Beware ” was heard in their army]. (TA.) When the word is repeated, the second is sometimes with tenween: (K:) but this is only in poetry, when required by the metre, as in the following verse, cited by Lh:
Ha*aAri Ha*aArK mino fawaArisi daArimK
A^abaA xaAlidK mino qaboli A^ano tatanad~amaA
[Beware, beware of the horsemen of Dárim, O Aboo-Khálid, before that thou repent]. (TA.) You say also, Ha*aArika, [with the k of allocution,] meaning Beware thou. (Lh, TA.) And when you caution a person [against another], Ha*araka↓ zayodFA [Beware thou of Zeyd]; (K, * TA;) and Ha*aArayoka zayodFA, (K,) which latter means Beware thou, and beware thou again, of Zeyd: both then [also] being verbal nouns. (TA.)

Ha*iyrN *
[A cautioner]. You say, A^anaA Ha*iyruka minohu i. e. muHa*~iruka [I am thy cautioner against him, or it]; (TA;) or A^uHa*~irukahu [I caution thee against him, or it]: (K:) known to As as heard only from Lth. (TA.) [See also what next follows.]

Hu*aAriyaAtN *
Persons who make others to fear: (K:) or rather, as others than F explain it, muno*iruwna [cautioners, or warners, &c.]. (TA.)

HaA*irN *
and HaA*iruwna: see Ha*irN.

HaA*uwrapN *
: see Ha*irN.

A^aHo*aru *
[More, and most, cautious, wary, vigilant, careful, or fearful]. You say, A^aHo*aru mina AlguraAbi More fearful [or cautious, &c.] than the raven: a prov. (Mgh.)

maHo*uwrN *
A thing that is feared. (Msb.) One says, waqaAka A@ll~`hu kul~a maHo*uwrK [May God preserve thee from everything that is feared]. (A.)

maHo*uwrapN *
A calamity that is feared, or regarded with caution: (K:) or a troop of horse making a hostile attack, or incursion, upon a people: or i. q. SayoHapN [app. as meaning a hostile attack, or incursion, when it comes upon a tribe suddenly, or unexpectedly; or it may here mean a punishment, or chastisement; or a crying-out, which is the primary signification]: (A:) and war. (K.) ― -b2- See also Ha*arN, in two places.

1 Ha*afahu *
, (S, * Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
Ha*ifa
, (Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. Ha*ofN, (S, Mgh, Msb,) He cut
it off: (Mgh, Msb:) or he cut it [so as to lessen it] at its extremity; (TA;) he cut off somewhat from the extremity of it; he curtailed it; as, for instance, the tail of a beast: (Lth, TA:) and he made it to fall; dropped it; rejected it. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) One says, Ha*afotu mino $aEariY, (S,) or mn $aEarihi, (Msb, K, *) and mn *anabi Ald~aAb~api, (S, Msb,) [$ayoy^FA being understood,] I took, or cut off, [somewhat] from my hair, [or his hair,] and from the tail of the beast; (S, K; *) I clipped it. (Msb.) And Ha*afa Al$~aEara [He clipped the hair]: said of a cupper. (TA.) And AHt*f↓ Alv~awoba He cut off a piece from the garment, or cloth. (TA.) And Ha*afotu raA^osahu biAls~ayofi I cut off a portion of his head with the sword: (IF, Msb:) I struck his head with the sword and cut off a portion of it. (S.) ― -b2- Also, inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) He elided it, struck it off or out, or rejected it; namely, a letter, [and a syllable,] from a word: (MA, PS:) he omitted it. (MA.) [(assumed tropical:) He suppressed it; namely, a word of a proposition or sentence.] And Ha*afa Als~alaAma, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) (tropical:) He made the salutation to be light [of utterance], and concise; (K, TA;) i. e., the salutation in prayer. (TA.) And Ha*afa fiY qawolihi, (Msb,) and fY AlA^a*aAni, and AlqiraA='api, aor. and inf. n. as above, (Mgh,) (assumed tropical:) He was concise, (Mgh, Msb,) and quick, in his saying, (Msb,) and in the call to prayer, and the recitation, or reading. (Mgh.) ― -b3- Ha*afahu biAlEaSaA He struck him, or beat him, with the staff, or stick: (TA:) and he cast, or threw, at him the staff, or stick. (S, K, TA.) It is said in a prov. of the Arabs, mentioned by Sb, A_iy~aAkumo wa A^ano yaHo*ifa A^aHadukumu AlA^aronaba, i. e. [Beware ye] lest any one of you cast at, or shoot, the hare: because this animal is of evil omen. (TA. [But the reading there given is Ay~AY: an evident mistranscription.]) Or Ha*afahu, inf. n. as above, signifies He struck, or he cast at, or shot, him, or it, from one side. (Lth, TA.) ― -b4- [Hence,] Ha*afa fulaAnFA bijaAy^izapK (tropical:) He gave such a one a gift. (Z, K.) ― -b5- And Ha*afa bihaA (assumed tropical:) He broke wind. (Ibn- 'Abbád, TA.) ― -b6- Ha*afa fiY ma$oyatihi He moved about his side and his hinder parts (in the CK he moved about his hinder parts and his shoulderjoint) in his gait: and (in the CK “ or ”) he went with short steps. (En-Nadr, K, TA.)

2 H*~fhu *
, [inf. n. taHo*iyfN,] He clipped it much: he took, or cut off, from its lateral parts, whatever it was, so as to make it even: (Msb:) he (a workman, or an artificer,) made it (a thing) becomingly even; as though he cut off from it whatever required to be cut off, so that it became free from everything unseemly, and was nicely, neatly, or properly, trimmed. (A, TA.) taHo*iyfu Al$~aEari [or Alr~aA^osi] signifies The cutting of the hair so as to form a Tur~ap [q. v.], by taking from its sides so as to make it even [with the cut portion over the forehead]; (T, Mgh;) as is done by, or to, a girl: (Mgh:) or tH*yf AlrA^s is a custom of women, consisting in the removing of the hair from [the sides of] the head as far as a line upon the side of the face made by putting one end of a string, or thread, upon the top of the ear, and the other end upon the angle of the jabiyn [or part above the temple]: (Msb:) accord. to En-Nadr, the tH*yf of the Tur~ap is the making a [Tr~p such as is termed] sukayoniy~ap, [i. e., after the fashion of Sukeyneh the daughter of El-Hoseyn, as is shown in the S and K &c. in art. skn,] like as do the Christians. (L, TA.) ― -b2- Also, inf. n. as above, (tropical:) He prepared it; or put it into a right, or good, state; and made it; or made it skilfully, or well. (S, K, TA.)

[act. part. n. of 1]. ― -b2- You say, humo maA bayona HaA*ifK wa qaA*ifK, i. e. (S, K) and Hu*ofuwrN↓ (K) A side; or a lateral, or an adjacent, part; (S, K, TA;) of a thing: and the upper, or uppermost, part of a thing: (S:) pl. Ha*aAfiyru. (S, K.) : see above, in two places. ― -b2- Also A numerous congregation or assemblage. (K.) ― -b3- And An eminent, an elevated, or a noble, man: (K, TA:) pl. as above. , (Msb, K,) inf. n. Hu*uwqN, said of vinegar, (S, Msb, K,) and of milk, (TA,) (tropical:) It was, or became, sour, (S, Msb, K, TA,) in the utmost degree, (Msb,) so that it burned the tongue. (Msb, TA.) ― -b5- Ha*aqa AlquroA=na, and (so in the S, but in the K “ or ”) AlEamala, aor.

; (S, K;) or Ha*aqa fiyhi, and Ha*iqa; (TA;) inf. n. (of both, S) Hi*oqN and (of the former, S) Ha*oqN and Hi*aAqN and Ha*aAqapN (S, K) and Ha*aAqN and Hi*aAqapN; or ↓this last is a simple subst.; (K;) (tropical:) He (a boy) was, or became, skilled in the Kur-án, and the work; (S) or learned the whole of it, and was, or became, skilled in it: (K, TA:) from AlHa*oqu signifying “ the act of cutting. ” (Z, TA.) , [inf. n. of H*~qhu (assumed tropical:) He, or it, made, or rendered, him skilful,] from AlHi*oqu, rests upon analogy, not upon the authority of hearsay. (Mgh.)

: see 1.

Hu*aAqiY~N *
Sharpened: applied to a knife: (Ibn- 'Abbád, K:) and Hi*olaAqN↓ signifies the same, applied to a thing [of any kind]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also HaA*iqN. ― -b3- (tropical:) A man chaste, or eloquent, of tongue; (S, K, * TA;) perspicuous in language. (S.) ＝ -A2- A young ass; syn. Hajo$N. (K.)

Hi*oliqN *
(assumed tropical:) A loquacious man; who affects to be commended for, or glories in, that which he does not possess. (TA.)

Hi*olaAqN *
: see Hu*aAqiY~N.

HaA*iqN *
Cutting, or sharp: (S, K: *) applied to a knife [&c.]. (S.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Wine ($araAb) that has attained to its full maturity [of strength, so that it stings, bites, or burns; the tongue; see 1]: (AHn, TA:) likewise applied to vinegar [in the same sense; or as meaning sour, or sour in the utmost degree, so that it burns the tongue; see again 1]; as also Hu*aAqiY~N↓. (TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) Skilled, or skilful, and thoroughly learned, [so as to know abstrusities and niceties, (see 1,)] in an art, or a habitual work or occupation, and in the Kur-án: pl. Hu*~aAqN. (TA.) You say, fulaAnN fiY SanoEatihi HaA*iqN baA*iqN (S, TA) (tropical:) Such a one is skilled, or skilful, &c., in his art, or habitual work or occupation; (TA;) using the latter word as an imitative sequent. (S, TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) Bad, evil, wicked, mischievous, or the like; syn. xabiyvN. (TA.)

maHo*uwqN *
: see Ha*iyqN.

mutaHa*oliqN *
Feigning, or making a show of, skilfulness, cleverness, or ingeniousness: or desiring to exceed his due bounds. (L.) [See 5.]

div1.superEntry: H*lq For several words mentioned under this head in the K, see art. H*q.

superEntry.entry:
1 Ha*amahu *
, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
Ha*ima
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. Ha*omN, (S, Msb,) He cut it, or cut it off, (S, Msb, K,) in any manner: (TA:) or hastily, or quickly. (K.) ― -b2- And [He did it quickly: or] he was quick in it; [as also Ha*ama fiyhi;] i. e., in any action. (S, Msb.) You say, Ha*ama fiY ma$oyihi, (Msb,) and qiraA='atihi, fY (S, K,) He was quick [in his walking, or going, and in his reading, or reciting]: (S, Msb, K:) and so in other things: (K:) by “ other things ” being here meant walking and the like; for Ha*omN, of which the verb is Ha*ama, signifies the being quick in walking, app. with a stretching out of the arms backwards: (TA:) and a light, an active, or an agile, walking. (S, TA.) [See also Ha*amaAnN, below.] Hence, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) 'Omar said, (S, TA,) to the muw^a*~n of Jerusalem, (TA,) A_i*aA A^a*~anota qataras~alo waA_i*aA A^aqamota faA@Ho*imo, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, TA,) i. e. [When thou chantest the A^a*aAn, be moderate; not quick: and when thou chantest the A_iqaAmap,] cut short the lengthening of thine utterance; meaning, be quick in the AqAmp: (As, Mgh, TA:) another reading is said to have been given by Z, namely, [faA@xo*imo,] with x. (TA.)

Ha*amN *
The flight of a bird that has its wings clipt, (K, TA,) as the pigeon and the like. (TA.)

Ha*imN *
A sharp, or cutting, sword; as also Hi*oyamN↓, with kesr to the H, (K,) and with fet-h to the Y; (TA;) or Ha*iymN↓. (So in two copies of the S.)

Hu*amN *
and Hu*amapN↓ Short in stature and in step; (K;) applied to a man: (TA:) and the latter is likewise fem.; (S, K, TA;) applied to a woman as meaning short in stature. (S, TA.)

Hu*umN *
Swift hares. (IAar, K. [See also Hu*amapN.]) ― -b2- And Skilful thieves. (IAar, K.)

Hu*amapN *
; see Hu*amN. ― -b2- One says of the female hare, Hu*amapN lu*amapN tasobiqu AljamoEa biAlA^akamapi, i. e. Swift, persistent in running, she outstrips the company pursuing her upon the hill. (TA.)

Ha*amaAnN *
Quickness in walking or going: (K:) accord. to Aboo-'Adnán, a pace of the kind termed *amiylN, exceeding what is termed ma$oYN. (TA.) ― -b2- And Slowness (K, TA) in walking or going: so says Aboo-'Adnán on the authority of Khálid Ibn-Jembeh. (TA.) Thus it bears two contrary meanings. (K.)

Hu*aAmN *
an epithet applied to a slave: so in the saying, Ai$otaraY EabodFA Hu*aAma Alma$oYi He bought a slave slow [in gait], lazy, (K, TA,) devoid of good: so says Khálid Ibn-Jembeh. (TA.)

Ha*iymN *
: see Ha*imN.

Hi*oyamN *
Skilful (K, TA) in a thing. (TA.) ― -b2- See also Ha*imN.

1 Ha*aA Aln~aEola *
, [aor. yaHo*uw,] inf. n. Ha*owN and Hi*aA='N, He measured the sandal, or sole, or made it according to a measure; (K;) and cut it (T, K) according to a pattern: (T, TA:) or he made the sandal, or sole, liY for me. (Mgh.) And Ha*aA Aln~aEola biAlmivaAli He cut the sandal, or sole, by the pattern. (Mgh.) And Ha*aA Aln~aEola biAln~aEoli, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. Ha*owN, (S,) He measured the sandal, or sole, by the sandal, or sole; or made it according to the measure thereof; (S, Msb, K;) and cut it according to the pattern and measure thereof: (Msb:) and in like manner, Ha*aA Alqu*~apa biAlqu*~api He measured the feather for an arrow by the feather for an arrow; or made it according to the measure thereof. (K.) Hence the prov., (TA,) Ha*owa Alqu*~api [meaning (assumed tropical:) With like for like]. (S, TA.) And the saying, jazayotuhu HadowaAln~aEoli biAln~aEoli, meaning (assumed tropical:) I requited him [with like for like]. (Har p. 43. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 345.]) One says also, huwa jay~adu AlHi*aA='i He is good in respect of proportion, or conformation. (TA.) And [in like manner] a beast is said to be Hasanu AlHi*aA='i Goodly, or beautiful, in respect of proportion, or conformation. (TA in art. H*Y.) ― -b2- [And hence,] Ha*aAHa*owa zayodK (assumed tropical:) [He did as Zeyd did;] he did the deed of Zeyd. (K.) And mivaAlahu AHt*Y↓, (S, K,) or EalaY mivaAlihi, (T, TA,) (tropical:) He followed, or imitated, his example (T, S, K, TA) in his affair, or case: (TA:) or AHt*Y bihi he followed, or imitated, his example in his affairs: (Msb:) syn. AqtdY. (T, S, Msb, K.) ― -b3- See also 3, in three places. ― -b4- Ha*aAhu naEolFA He put on him (namely a man [i. e. on his foot]) a sandal; as also AH*Ahu↓: (K:) the former is authorized by As, but the latter is disallowed by him: Az explains the former by Hmlh ElY nEl [as though meaning he gave him a sandal upon which to walk; like as Hamalahu for Hamalahu EalaY daAb~apK means “ he gave him a beast upon which to ride ”]: and accord. to J, (TA,) naEolFA A^aHo*ayotuhu↓ signifies I gave him a sandal. (S, TA.) ― -b5- Ha*aA zayodFA, (K,) inf. n. Ha*owN, (TA,) He gave to Zeyd. (K, TA. [See also 4 in art. H*Y.]) ― -b6- Ha*aAminohu Hi*owapF He cut off from it a piece of flesh-meat. (TA.) ― -b7- Ha*aA Aljiloda, aor. yaHo*uw, i. q. qaw~arahu [He cut a piece out of the skin, generally meaning in a round form]. (TA.) ― -b8- Ha*aA lsaAnahu, (K,) aor.
as above, inf. n. Ha*uwN, (TA,) (tropical:) It (wine, or beverage,) bit his tongue; (AHn, K, TA;) a dial. var. of Ha*aY, aor. yaHo*Y, which is the word well known. (AHn, TA.) ＝ -A2- Ha*aA Alt~uraAba fiY wujuwhihimo i. q. HavaAhu [i. e. He poured with his hand, threw, or cast, the dust in their faces]. (IAth, K.)

3 HaA*aAhu *
, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. muHaA*aApN (Msb, TA) and Ha*aA='N, (Msb,) He, (Mgh, Msb,) and it, (Mgh,) was, or became, over against, or opposite to, him, or it; (S, Mgh, TA;) faced, or fronted, him, or it; (TA;) syn. A=zaAhu, (Msb, * K,) and qaAbalahu; (TA;) as also Ha*aAhu↓, aor. yaHo*uw, (Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. Ha*owN: (Msb:) [and] the latter, (S,) or each, (Har p. 43,) signifies he sat over against, or opposite to, him, or it. (S, and Har ibid.) raA^osahaAmina Al$~aEari walaA yasotarosilu maA yaHo*uw↓ means mA yuHaA*iyhi [i. e. What is against, or opposite to, her head, of the hair, and does not hang down below it]. (Mgh. [See another ex. in an explanation of A=xirapN.]) One also says, A^atayotu A^aroDFA baqoluhaA EalaY A^afowaAhi ganamihaA qado Ha*aA↓ I came to a land the herbs of which were opposite to the mouths of its sheep, or goats, not rising beyond them. (Sh, TA.) And biHi*aA='i h`*ihi Al$~ajarapi taHa*~a↓ Be thou over against, or opposite to, this tree. (TA.) ― -b2- HaA*atohaA, said of a girl, She matched her, namely, another girl; she was, or became, her match, fellow, or equal; syn. taArabatohaA. (A and TA in art. trb.) ― -b3- [Hence muHaA*aApN signifying A conformity, a mutual resemblance, or a correspondence, with regard to sound, of two words occurring near together; like AizodiwaAjN &c.: see art. zwj.]

4 A^aHo*awa
see 1, in two places. ― -b2- AH*Ahu also signifies He gave him a thing. (TA.) [See Hi*owap: and see 4 in art. H*Y.]

5 taHa*~awa
see 3.

6 taHaA*aA *
They were, or became, over against, or opposite to, each other; they faced, or fronted, each other. ― -b2- And They matched each other; each of them was, or became, the match, fellow, or equal, of the other.] ― -b3- Alt~aHaA*iY in selling and buying: see Alt~araAwuDu. [This, perhaps, may belong to art. H*Y.]

8 AHt*Y *
He wore, or put on, a sandal, or sandals. (S, TA.) Hence the saying, xayoru mani A@Hota*aY Aln~iEaAla [The best of those who have worn sandals]. (TA.) A rájiz says,
kul~a AlHi*aA='i yaHota*iY AlHaAfiY AlwaqiEo
[The barefooted whose sole is hurt by the rugged ground and stones will put on any sandal: a prov.]. (S. [See Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 317.]) ― -b2- See also 1.

10 AstH*Ahu *
He asked him to give him a sandal [or a pair of sandals]. (S, * TA.)

Hi*apN *
: see Hi*aA='N, in three places. ― -b2- You say also, jaA='a Alr~ajulaAni Hi*atayoni The two men came together, side by side. (TA.) [See also Hi*oyapN, in art. H*Y.]

Ha*owN *
[originally an inf. n. of 1, q. v.]: see Hi*aA='N, in three places.

Hu*owapa *
: see Hi*aA=': ＝ -A2- and see also Hu*aAwapN.

Hi*owapN *
A gift; (K, and Ham p. 596;) as also Hu*ay~aA↓; (TA;) or Hu*oyaA: (Mgh, and Ham ubi suprà:) or a portion that is given of spoil. (S.) [See also Hu*oyaA, in art. H*Y.] ― -b2- And A piece, (K,) or small piece, (TA,) of flesh-meat: (K, TA:) or a piece of flesh cut lengthwise; or so Hi*oyapN, accord. to some. (Mgh.) [See also Hi*oyapN, in art. H*Y.] ＝ -A2- See also Hi*aA='N, in three places.

Hi*aA='N *
A sandal, or sole; syn. naEolN; (S, Msb, TA;) vulgarly called H*wp: (TA [there written without any syll. signs]:) pl. A^aHo*iyapN. (Msb.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) The sole of a camel's foot and of the hoof of a horse (S, Msb, TA) or similar beast; (Msb;) as being likened to a naEol. (TA.) Hence the saying in a trad., (S, * Msb, * TA,) respecting a stray she-camel, (Msb, TA,) maEahaA Hi*aAw^uhaA wasiqaAw^uhaA (S, Msb, TA) (assumed tropical:) With her are her foot, with which she may defend herself from the smaller beasts of prey, and [her stomach, which, by her replenishing it, affords her means of long] endurance of the want of water: (Msb:) [or] it means that she has ability to traverse the land and to go to water. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A wife; because she is mawoTuwo'ap, like the naEol. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, [originally an inf. n.,] i. q. A_izaA='N [The front, as meaning the part, place, or location, that is over against, opposite, facing, fronting, or in front]. (S, K.) One says, jalasa biHi*aAy^ihi [He sat in the place over against, opposite to, facing, or fronting, him; or simply he sat over against, &c.]. (S.) And huwa Hi*aA='aka and Hi*owataka↓ and Hi*ataka↓ [in the CK, erroneously, Hi*owatuka and Hi*oyuka,] and muHaA*aAka↓ [He, or it, is over against, opposite to, facing, or fronting, thee]; (K;) and hw Hu*ay~aAka↓; i. e. biA_izaAy^ika. (K in art. H*Y.) And daAriY Hi*aA='a (S) and Hi*owapa↓ dArh (S, K) and dArh Hu*owapa↓ (S) and dArh Hi*apa↓ (S, K) and dArh Ha*owa↓ and dArh Hi*owapu↓ and dArh Hi*apu↓ and dArh Ha*owu↓ (K) i. e. A_izaA='ahaA [My house is over against, &c., his house]; (K;) and [so] biHi*aA='i dArh. (Msb.) And rafaEa yadayohi Ha*owa↓ A^u*unayohi and Hi*aA='a A*nyh [He raised his hands over against, or opposite to, not higher than, his ears]: (Mgh, * Msb:) both are correct expressions. (Mgh.) [Hence, EalaY Hi*aA='K waAHidK Corresponding to, or matching, one another; uniformly disposed.] ＝ -A3- See also art. H*Y.

Hu*aAwapN *
and Hi*aAwapN and Hu*owapN↓ What falls, and is thrown away, of skins, when they are pared and cut: whence the saying in a trad. respecting the bridal furniture of Fátimeh, that one of her two beds was stuffed with H*wp of the makers of sandals. (TA.)

Hu*ay~aA *
[perhaps belonging to this art., like as Huday~aA and Hujay~aA belong to arts. Hdw and Hjw]: see Hi*owapN, and art. H*Y: ＝ -A2- and see also Hi*aA='N.

Ha*~aA='N *
A maker of sandals: whence the prov.,
mano yaku Ha*~aA='F tajudo naEolaAhu
[He who is a maker of sandals, his pair of sandals is good]. (TA. [Freytag (Arab. Prov. ii. 665) gives it thus: mano yakuno A^abuwhu Ha*~aA='F tajudo naEolaAhu He whose father is a maker of sandals, his pair of sandals is good.])

HaA*K *
A man wearing a sandal [or a pair of sandals]. (TA.)

huwa muHaA*aAka *
: see Hi*aA='N.

1 Ha*ati Al$~aforapu AlnaEola *
, [aor. and inf. n. as below,] The shoemaker's knife cut the sandal, or sole. (S.) And Ha*aY yadahu He cut, or cut off, his arm, or hand, (T, S, K,) with a knife. (S.) And Ha*aY A^u*unahu He cut off a piece of his ear. (TA.) ― -b2- Ha*aY Aljiloda, aor. yaHo*iY, He, or it, wounded the skin. (TA.) And Ha*aY AlA_ihaAba, (K,) inf. n. Ha*oYN, (TA,) He rent, or tore, much, or he made many holes in, the skin, or hide. (K, TA.) ― -b3- Ha*aY lisaAnahu, (S, Mgh, K,) and faAhu (S) or famahu, (TA,) aor. as above, (S, Mgh, Msb,) and so the inf. n., (S, TA,) (tropical:) It, namely, vinegar, and wine, or beverage, (S, Mgh,) and [sour] milk, (Mgh, K,) &c., (K,) bit his tongue, (S, Mgh, K,) and his mouth; (S, TA;) had a burning effect upon it, like cutting. (Mgh.) ― -b4- Ha*aY fulaAnFA bilisaAnihi (tropical:) He spoke evil of such a one, saying of him what would grieve him if he heard it; reviled, vilified, or vituperated, him; (K, TA;) [as though] he cut him with his tongue. (TA.) A man who does so is termed miHo*aA='N↓. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also what next follows.

4 AH*Ahu *
; (S, Mgh, K;) as also Ha*aAhu↓, first pers. Ha*ayotu; (Mgh;) He gave him a thing, or somewhat: (Mgh:) he gave him a portion, or share, of spoil. (S, Mgh, K.) [See also 4 in art. H*w.] ― -b2- [Hence,] A^aHo*ayotuhu TaEonapF (tropical:) [I gave him a thrust, piercing thrust, or stab;] I thrust, pierced, or stabbed, him. (Lh, TA.)

6 tHA*Y Alqawomu fiymaA bayonahumo *
(tropical:) The party, or campany of men, divided among themselves (K, TA) water equally; like tSAfnwA. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 6 in art. H*w.

Hi*oYN *
: see Hi*oyapN.

Hu*oyapN *
, with damm, The diamond with which stones are cut and bored. (TA.)

Hi*oyapN *
A piece cut lengthwise (As, S, K) of flesh-meat: (As, S:) or a small piece (K) thereof. (TA.) [See also Hi*owapN, in art. H*w.] Hence the saying in a trad., A_in~amaA faATimapu Hi*oyapN min~iY yaqobiDuniY maA yaqobiDuhaA (assumed tropical:) [Fátimeh is only a piece of me: what distresses, or grieves, her, distresses, or grieves, me]. (TA.) ― -b2- jA='aA Hi*oyatayoni They two came side by side: (K, TA:) and so jaA='aA, mentioned in art. H*w. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A gift; as also Hi*oYN↓ (TA) and Hu*oyaA↓, (Mgh, and Ham p. 596,) or Hu*ay~aA↓, (TA in art. H*w,) and Hi*owapN. (K in that art., and Ham ubi suprà.) [See also Hu*ay~aA.]

Hu*oyaA *
: see what next precedes. ― -b2- Also A share,
or portion, of spoil; (S, K;) and so Hu*ay~aA↓ and Hu*aAyp (K) and Ha*iy~apN↓ (S, K) and Hi*owapN. (S.)

Hi*aA='N *
The gathering of the crop of grapes: or the time thereof: syn. qiTaAfN. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also art. H*w.

Hu*aAyapN *
: see Hu*oyaA.

Ha*iy~apN *
: see Hu*oyiA.

Hu*ay~aA *
A gift, or present, for bringing good news. (K, TA.) See also Hi*oyapN. You say, A^axo*ahu biyona AlHu*ay~aA waAlxulosapi He took it as something between a gift and a thing carried off by force. (ISd, K.) ― -b2- See also Hu*oyaA. ＝ -A2- huwa Hu*ay~aAka: see Hi*aA='N, in art. H*w.

miHo*FY *
A large, or broad, knife; or such as is used by a shoemaker or maker of sandals. (TA.)

miHo*aA='N *
: see 1.

Har~a Hr
, see. pers. Harirota, aor.
Hara3a
; (S, A, Msb, K;) and Har~a, sec. pers. Hararota, aor.
Hari3a
and
Haru3a
; inf. n. Har~N and HuruwrN (S, Msb, K) and HaraArapN, (S, K,) or this is a simple subst., (Msb,) and Hir~apN; (TA;) and AHr~↓, (S, K,) a dial. var. heard by Ks, (S,) and mentioned by Zj and IKtt; (TA;) It (a day, S, A, Msb, K, and food, Msb) was, or became, hot; (A, Msb, K;) or very hot. (TA.) And Har~ati Aln~aAru, sec. pers. Hariroti, aor.
Hara3a
, The fire burned up, and became fierce or hot. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also 10. ― -b3- Har~a, sec. pers. Harirota, aor.
Hara3a
, inf. n. Har~apN, He (a man, S) thirsted; was, or became, thirsty. (S, K.) Lh mentions Harirota yaA rajulu, aor.
Hara3a
, inf. n. Hir~apN [perhaps a mistake for Har~apN] and HaraArapN: [app. in the same sense:] ISd says, I think he means [from] AlHar~u, not AlHur~iy~apu. (TA.) And HararN [an inf. n. of the same verb] signifies The liver's becoming dry from thirst or grief. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Har~a, sec. pers. Harirota, aor.
Hara3a
, (S, A, * Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. HaraArN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) He (a slave, S) became free: (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K:) and tHr~r↓ in the same sense is agreeable with analogy. (Mgh.) ― -b2- And Har~a, sec. pers. and aor. as above, inf. n. Hur~iy~apN, He (a man) was freeborn, or of free origin. (S.) ＝ -A3- Har~a, [sec. pers. Hararota,] aor.
Haru3a
, inf. n. Har~N, He heated water (A, * K) &c. (A.) ＝ -A4- Har~a, aor.
Hari3a
, He cooked [what is termed] Hariyrap: (K:) and Har~ato she made Hryrp. (A.) Hence, in a trad., *ur~iY waA^anaA A^aHir~u laki Sprinkle thou the flour, and I will make of it Hryrp for thee. (TA.)

2 Hr~r Hrr
, inf. n. taHoriyrN, He freed, liberated, or emancipated, a slave. (A, Mgh, Msb.) And Hr~r raqabapF He freed a neck [i. e. a slave]. (S, K.) ― -b2- Also He set apart a child for the worship of God and the service of the mosque or oratory: (S, TA:) or he devoted him to the service of the church as long as he should live, so that he could not relinquish it while he retained his religion. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, inf. n. as above, (tropical:) He made a writing &c. accurate, or exact; (S, K;) he made a writing beautiful, or elegant, and free from defects, by forming its characters rightly, and rectifying its faults: (A:) he wrote a writing well, or elegantly, and accurately, or exactly; (TK;) he wrote well, or elegantly: (KL:) and he made an account, or a reckoning, accurate, without mistake, and without omission, and without erasure. (TA.) [And simply (tropical:) He wrote a letter &c.]

4 AHr~ AHr A^HAr A^Hr A^HrY HAr Hr HrY
: see 1. ― -b2- Also His (a man's) camels became thirsty. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- Also He (God) made a man's liver to become dry by reason of thirst or grief. (TA.) And He made a man's bosom thirsty; as in the saying, used by the Arabs in cursing a man, maA lahu A^aHar~a A@ll~`hu Sadorahu [What aileth him? May God make his bosom thirsty]: or the meaning is haAmatahu [app. here used as signifying the bird called haAmap, in the form of which the soul was believed to issue from a slain man, and to call incessantly for drink until the slaughter of the slayer]. (TA.)

5 taHar~a3a
see 1.

10 AstHr~ A^stHr AstHr {stHr
(S, K) and Har~a↓ (S, TA) (tropical:) It (slaughter) was, or became, vehement, (S, K,) and great in extent; (TA;) and the same is said of death. (TA.) ＝ -A2- AstHr~hA He asked, or desired, of her [that she should make what is termed] Hariyrap. (A.) [See 1, last signification.]

HirN H*r
: see Hir~N, below; and see also art. HrH.

HiriY~N Hr HrAn HrY Hry Hryy
: see art. HrH.

Har~N Hr
Heat; contr. of barodN; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also HaraArapN↓, (S, * Msb, * K,) contr. of buruwdapN; (S;) and HuruwrN↓ (S, * Msb, * K) and Hir~apN↓: (TA:) [see 1, first sentence:] pl. [of the first] HuruwrN and A^aHaAriru↓; (K;) the latter anomalous, both as to its measure and in the non-incorporation of the first r into the second: it is mentioned on the authority of AZ and others; but IDrd doubts its correctness; and the author of the Wá'ee mentions A^aHaAr~u as a pl. form, but apparently to avoid contrariety to rule: the pl. of HaraArapN↓ as a simple subst., or as an inf. n., but more probably as the former, is HaraAraAtN. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A burning of the heart, from pain and wrath and distress or affliction or trouble or fatigue. (TA.) [See also HaraArapN.] ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Difficulty, or severity, of work. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also HaAr~N: ＝ -A3- and Har~apN: ＝ -A4- and saAqu Hur~K, voce Hur~N.

Hur~N Hr
Free, ingenuous, or free-born; contr. of EabodN: (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K:) fem. Hur~apN: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) pl. masc. A^aHoraArN (Msb, K) and HiraArN; (IJ, K;) not HaraArN, as some say; nor is HiraArN an inf. n. as well as a pl., as others say: (MF:) pl. fem. HaraAy^iru, (Msb, K,) contr. to analogy, and, as Suh says, the only instance of the kind except $ajarN maraAy^iru as pl. of $ajarapN mur~apN; for the [regular] pl. of fuEolapN is foEalN; but Hur~apN has this form of pl. because it is syn. with kariymapN and EaqiylapN [as will be seen in what follows]; and mur~apN, because it means xabiyvapu AlT~aEomi. (Msb.) Omar said to the women who used to go forth to the mosque, laA^arud~an~akon~a HaraAy^ira [lit. I will assuredly make you to become free women]; meaning I will assuredly make you to keep to the houses: for the curtain is lowered before free women; not before slavewomen. (TA.) [See also Hur~iy~apN.] ― -b2- (tropical:) Generous, noble, or well-born; like as EabodN is used to signify “ ignoble, ” or “ base-born: ” (Mgh:) and so the fem. Hur~apN; (S, Mgh, K;) applied to a woman; (TA;) and to a she-camel: (S:) and so the masc. applied to a horse. (K, TA.) [Hence,] baAtato bilayolapi Hur~apK (tropical:) [She passed a virgin's night] is said of her whose husband has not been able to devirginate her (S, A, K) in the night when she has been first brought to him: (TA:) because the Hur~ap is modest and repugnant: (Har p. 418:) in the contr. case one says, bilayolapi $ayobaA='a: (S, L:) and one says also bilayolapK Hur~apK; and bilayolapK $ayobaA='a. (TA.) [And hence,] layolapu Hur~ap and layolapN Hur~apN signify also (assumed tropical:) The first night of the [lunar] month: (K:) its last night is called layolapu $ayobaA='a and layolapN $ayobaA='u. (TA.) You say also wajohN Hur~N (tropical:) [app. meaning An ingenuous countenance]. (A.) ― -b3- (tropical:) Generous, or ingenuous, in conduct: as in the saying of Imra-el-Keys,
laEamoruka maA qalobiY A_ilaY A^aholihi biHoro
[By thy life, my heart is not generous in conduct to its, or his, companion]; meaning that it is averse therefrom, and inclines to another. (Az, TA.) [Hence,] saHaAbapN Hur~apN (tropical:) A cloud bountiful with rain; (A;) or abounding with rain. (S, K.) ― -b4- (tropical:) A good deed or action. (K, TA.) You say, maAh`*aA minoka biHur~K (tropical:) This is not good, or well, of thee. (S, A.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) Anything good, or excel-lent; as poetry, &c. (TA.) You say kalaAmN Hur~N (tropical:) [app. meaning good, or excellent, speech or language]. (A.) ― -b6- (tropical:) Good earth, or clay, and sand: (K, TA:) or earth, or clay, in which is no sand: (S, A:) and sand in which is no earth or clay: (S:) or sand that has good herbage: (A:) you say ramolapN Hur~apN; (S, A;) and the pl. is HaraAy^iru: (S:) or sand in which is no mixture of any other thing: (Msb: [accord. to which, this is the primary meaning of the word, whence the meaning of “ free, ” i. e. the “ contr. of EabodN: ” but accord. to the A and TA, it is tropical:]) and A^aroDN Hur~apN (tropical:) land in which is no salt earth: (A:) or in which is no sand: as applied to that upon which no tithe is levied, it is post-classical. (Mgh.) ― -b7- (tropical:) The middle, (S, A, K,) and best part, (TA,) of sand, (S, K, TA,) and of a house. (S, A, TA.) ― -b8- (assumed tropical:) The best of anything; (K, TA;) as, for instance, of fruit. (TA.) ― -b9- Also sing. of A^aHoraAr in the term A^aHoraAru Albuquwli, (TA,) which means (tropical:) Herbs, or leguminous plants, that are eaten without being cooked; (S, A;) as also Albuquwli Hur~iy~apu↓: (A:) or such as are slender and succulent; and *ukuwru Albuquwli means “ such as are thick and rough: ” (AHeyth:) or the former are such as are slender and soft; and the latter, “ such as are hard and thick: ” (TA in art. E$b:) or the former are
such as are slender and sweet; and the latter, “ such as are thick, and inclining to bitterness: ” (TA in art. *kr:) or the former are such as are rough; and these are three, namely, Aln~afalu and AlHurobuvu and AlqafoEaA='u: or AlHur~u is applied to a plant of the kind called Aln~ajiyl, growing in salt grounds. (TA.) ― -b10- Hur~u Alwajohi (tropical:) What appears of the face: (K, TA:) or what appears of the elevated part of the cheek; (S;) [i. e.] the ball, or most prominent place, of the cheek; (W p. 28;) and AlHur~apu↓ signifies [the same, or] the elevated part of the cheek: (TA:) or the former is what fronts one, of the face: or the four tracks of the tears, from each corner of each eye. (TA.) One says, laTamahu EalaY Hur~i wajohihi (tropical:) [He slapped him on the ball of his cheek]. (S, TA. *) ＝ -A2- The young one of a gazelle. (S, K.) ― -b2- The young one of a serpent: (S, K:) or of a slender serpent: or it is a slender serpent, like the jaAn~, of a white colour: or a white serpent: or a serpent, absolutely. (TA.) ― -b3- The young one of a pigeon: (S, K:) or the male thereof. (TA.) ― -b4- saAqu Hur~K [is said to signify] The male of the qamaAriY~ [or kind of collared turtle-doves of which the female is called qumoriy~ap (see qumoriY~N)]: (S, Msb, K:) Homeyd Ibn-Thowr says,
wamaA haAja h`*aA Al$~awoqa A_il~aA HamaAmapN
daEato saAqa Hur~K taroHapF wataran~umaA
[And nothing excited this desire but a pigeon (see HamaAmN) that called sAq Hr~, sorrowing and warbling]: or, accord. to IJ, the right reading is
daEato saAqa Hur~K fiY HamaAmK taran~umaA
[that called sAq Hr~ among other pigeons, warbling]: but some say that AlsAq is the pigeon; and Hr~, its young one: or sAq Hr~ is the cry of the qmArY~, and is an onomatopœia: accord. to Aboo- 'Adnán, it is sAq Har~↓, and means the warbling of the pigeon: and Sakhr El-Gheí makes it a compound, and indecl.; using the phrase, tunaAdiY saAqa Hur~a [she calls sAq Hr~]: on which IJ observes, As says, sAq Hr~ is thought to mean the young one of the bird; but it is her cry: and he (IJ) adds, the fact that the poet [Sakhr] does not make it decl. is an evidence of the correctness of the assertion of As; for, were it decl., he would have said saAqa Hur~K if it consisted of two nouns whereof the former was prefixed to the other so as to govern it in the gen. case, or sAq Hur~FA if it were a compound; as it is indeterminate: and its being made decl. by Homeyd does not show it to be not significant of a sound; for sometimes an expression significant of a sound consists of two nouns whereof the former is prefixed to the latter so as to govern it in the gen. case, like xaAzu baAzK. (M, MF, TA.)

HarobN Hrb
War, battle, fight, or conflict; (Msb, TA;) contr. of silomN; (TA;) consisting, first, in shooting arrows, one at another; then, in thrusting, one at another, with spears; then, in combating one another with swords; and then, in grappling and struggling together: (Suh, TA:) it is [generally] fem.; (S, L Msb;) but its dim. is HurayobN↓, without p, (Kh, S, L, Msb,) contr. to rule, (L, Msb,) like *urayoEN, and quwayosN, and furayosN in a fem. sense, (L,) because originally an inf. n. [of which the verb (Haraba) seems not to have been used as meaning “ he waged, or contended in, war ”], (El-Mázinee, S,) or in order that it may not be confounded with the dim. of HarobapN: (Msb:) Seer makes its origin to be the epithet HarobN, which, however, is originally an inf. n.: (L:) sometimes it is masc.; (IAar, Mbr, S, Msb, K;) but this is extr.: (L:) the pl. is HuruwbN. (S, K.) You say, waqaEato bayonahumo HarobN [War happened between them]. (S.) And qaAmati AlHarobu EalaY saAqK The war, or battle, became vehement, so that safety from destruction was difficult of attainment. (Msb.) And making it masc., as meaning qitaAlN, you say HarobN $adiydN A vehement fight or battle. (Msb.) [Hence,] Aibonu HarobK A warrior: (Er-Rághib, TA in art. bnY:) and Aibonu AlHarobi [the warrior; or] he who suffices for war, and who defends. (Msb in that art.) And daAru AlHarobi The country, or countries, of the unbelievers, (Msb,) or of [those called by the Muslims] the polytheists, (K,) between whom and the Muslims there is not peace. (Msb, K.) In the saying of Aboo- Haneefeh, kaAnato mak~apu A_i*o *`Aka HarobFA, the meaning is daAra HarobK [Mekkeh was at that time a place of which the people were at war with the Muslims]. (Mgh.) ＝ -A2- It is also an epithet; originally an inf. n. (L.) You say rajulN HarobN, (K, TA,) [in the CK HaribN, but it is] like EadolN, (TA,) A man vehement in war, and courageous; as also miHorabN↓ and miHoraAbN↓: (K:) or miHorabN↓ signifies a man of wars; (S;) or a man of war, as also miHoraAbN↓; and a known, experienced warrior. (TA.) [Being originally an inf. n.,] HarobN as an epithet is used in the same form as masc. and fem. and sing. and pl.: (K:) so that one says AimoraA^apN HarobN and qawomN HarobN, (TA,) as also qawomN miHorabapN↓. (S, K.) ― -b2- Also An enemy, (S, K,) whether, or not, actually at war. (K.) So in the saying, A^anaA HarobN limano HaArabanaYi [I am an enemy to him who wars with me, or who is an enemy to me]. (S.) And fulaAnN Harobu fulaAnK Such a one is the enemy of such a one. (TA.) Some hold that HarobN is a pl. [or rather a quasi-pl. n.] of HaAribN or muHaAribN. (TA.)

(A, Mgh, Msb.) waAHarabaA is an ejaculation expressive of grief, lamentation, or regret, [meaning Alas, my spoliation! or my loss! or my grief!] (ISd, Mgh, TA,) used in an absolute manner, like waA A^asafaA, (ISd, TA,) or yaA A^asafaA, (Mgh,) from Harabahu “ he despoiled him of his wealth, or property: ” (K:) [or from Hariba, q. v.:] or it originated from the fact that Harb the son of Umeiyeh, when any one died, used to ask his family what they required to expend on the occasion, and used to supply them therewith; (TA;) and when he himself died, the people of Mekkeh and its neighbourhood bewailed him, saying, waA HarobaA, (Th, K, * TA,) or waA HarobaAho, (TA,) [Alas for Harb!] and then they changed the expression to waA HarabaA, (Th, K,) or waAHarabaAho, and it
became used in the case of bewailing any person who was dear, and in the cases of other calamities: but this account of the origin did not please ISd. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Perdition. destruction, or death. (Har p. 158.)

Hbn;]) a well-known animal: (TA:) or a certain reptile, like the EaZaA='ap, (K,) said to be larger than this latter, (Msb,) somewhat larger, (S,) that turns itself, (S, Msb,) or its head, (K,) towards the sun, (S, Msb, K,) turning with the sun as the sun turns, and assuming various colours (S, Msb) by reason of the heat of the sun: (S:) Az describes it as a reptile resembling in form what is called saAm~u A^aboraSa, with four legs, slender head, [which is not correct as applied to the chameleon,] and striped back; that all the day looks towards the sun; and he adds that its flesh is impure, and the Arabs never eat it: (TA:) [accord. to Freytag, the word, thus applied, is said (but I know not on what authority) to be from xurobaA, meaning HAfZ Al$ms (guardian of the sun):] the fem. is with p: (S:) and the pl. [The word HrbA' is used in passages cited in the TA as masc. and fem.; whence it seems that it may be written HirobaA='u as well as HirobaA='N.] The Arabs used the expression HirobaA='u tanoDubK or tanoDuba, like *y^obu gaDFA: (S:) [the latter word in each of these cases being the name of a tree:] the former is proverbially applied to a prudent man; because the HrbA' does not quit the first branch but to leap upon the second.
