Ha$ida
, inf. n. Ha$odN, (S,) or Hu$uwdN; (A;) and AHt$dwA↓, and tH$~dwA↓; (S, A;) They collected themselves together, or assembled, (S, A, Msb,) and came round about (Haf~uwA [but see what follows]) aiding one another: (A:) or Ha$aduwA signifies they were prompt, or active, [instead of Haf~uwA, in the K, I read xaf~uwA, as in the L,] in aiding one another: or they complied quickly, when called, or summoned: (L, K:) the verb is thus generally used in relation to a collective number: seldom in relation to one: (L:) or they collected themselves together, or assembled, for one thing or affair; as also AH$dwA↓, and AHt$dwA↓, and tHA$dwA↓. (L, K.) And H$dwA Ealayohi, (L,) and Ealayohi tHA$dwA↓, They collected themselves together, aiding one another against him. (A.) And Alqawomu lifulaAnK AHt$d↓ The people, or party, collected themselves together to such a one, and prepared, equipped, or furnished, themselves [for action]. (TA.) ― -b2- Ha$aduwA lahu They combined for him, [or on his account,] and took pains, or exerted themselves, in treating him with courtesy and honour; and so HafaluwA lahu. (Fr, L.) And They showed honour, and gave a hospitable entertainment, to him; namely, a guest. (L.)

4 A^aHo$ada
see 1.

5 taHa$~ada
see 1.

6 taHaAo$ada
see 1, in two places.

8 A_iHota$ada
see 1, in three places. ― -b2- AHt$d lahu fiY ka*aA He prepared himself for him [in such a case, or in such an affair]. (A.) ― -b3- AHt$d fiY AlD~iyaAfapi and lilD~iyaAfapi He strove, laboured, or exerted himself, in, and for, the entertainment of a guest or guests. (A.)

Ha$odN *
, (S, K,) originally an inf. n., (S,) and Ha$adN↓, (K,) An assembly, or a collected or congregated body or party, (S, K,) of men. (S.)

Ha$adN *
: see what next precedes.

Ha$idN *
One who does not leave [unemployed] any endeavour or aid or property that he possesses; as also muHota$idN↓; (L, K;) and HaA$idN↓, pl. Hu$udN. (L.) ― -b2- waAdK H$idN A valley similar to land such as is termed Ha$aAdN: (K:) a valley which a small and an inconsiderable quantity of water causes to flow. (TA.)

A^aroDN Ha$aAdN *
Land that does not flow with water save in consequence of much rain: (S:) or in
consequence of [lasting, or continuous, rain, such as is termed] diymap: (K:) or that flows with water in consequence of the least rain; (ISk, M, K;) as also zahaAdN and $aHaAHN and nazilapN: (ISk:) or such as is the quickest to flow with water: (AA in a marginal note in a copy of the S:) or Ha$aAdN signifies a water-course of which the ground is hard, quickly flowing with water, having many minor water-courses ($iEaAb) pouring into its bed and uniting one with another. (ISh.)

HaA$idN *
[A people collecting themselves together, or assembling, &c. (see 1)]: pl. Hu$~adN, occurring in a trad., followed by wuf~adN. (L.) ― -b2- jaA='a fulaAnN HaAfilFA HaA$idFA and muHotafilFA muHota$idFA↓ Such a one came [full of energy,] prepared, furnished, equipped, or accoutred. (S.) See also Ha$idN.

maHo$uwdN *
A man with whom is an assembly, or a collected body, or party, of men: (L:) or one to whom others collect themselves together; who is served, or waited on: (A:) or obeyed by others, (S, K,) among his people, (TA,) and whom they are prompt [instead of yaHif~uwna, in most of the copies of the K, I read yaxif~uwna, as in others and in the S,] to serve, (S, K,) and to whom they collect themselves together. (TA.)

maHaA$idu *
Places where people are collected to go forth: or it is a pl. of Ha$odN, contr. to rule, like ma$aAbihu [pl. of $abahN] and malAmiHu [pl. of lamoHapN]. (L from a trad.) [See maxaATibu.]

muHota$idN *
: see Ha$idN, and HaA$idN.

1 Ha$ara *
, aor.
Ha$ura
and
Ha$ira
, (S, Msb, K,) the former of which aors. is found in the seven readings of the Kur, (Msb,) inf. n. Ha$orN, (S, Msb, K,) He congregated, or collected together, (S, Msb, K,) men: (S, Msb:) or he congregated them, or collected them together, and drove them: (Msb, TA:) he made them to go forth, collected together, from one place to another: (Bd in lix. 2:) he, or it, compelled them to emigrate: (K, * TA: [in the CK AlxalaA='u is put by mistake for AljalaA'u, the explanation of the inf. n.:]) and [simply] he drove towards a place or quarter. (TA.) Hence yawomu AlHa$ori (tropical:) [The day of congregation, &c.; meaning] the day of resurrection: (S, * TA:) [see also maHo$irN:] and suwrapu AlHa$ori (tropical:) [The Chapter of the Compulsion to emigration; which is the fifty-ninth chapter of the Kur-an]. (TA.) It is said by most of the expositors of the Kur that the wild animals and other beasts, and even the flies, will be collected together (tuHo$aru) for retaliation; and they cite a trad. on this subject. (TA.) So in the Kur [lxxxi. 5], wa A_i*aA AlwuHuw$u Hu$irato And when the wild animals shall be collected together, (Bd, Jel,) from every quarter, (Bd,) after resurrection; (Jel;) or raised to life, (Bd,) for the purpose of their retaliating, one upon another; after which they shall return to dust: (Bd, Jel:) or the meaning is, shall die, (Az, S,) in the present world; accord. to some: (Az:) and thus says 'Ikrimeh, (S, TA,) on the authority of I'Ab, (TA,) as is related by Sa'eed Ibn-Masrook: (S, TA:) but accord. to some, the two meanings are nearly the same; for each denotes collection. (TA.) Ha$orN also signifies The going forth with a people fleeing or hastening or dispersing themselves in war; when used absolutely. (TA.) ― -b2- Ha$aratohumu Als~anapu, aor.
Ha$ura
and
Ha$ira
(Lth,) inf. n. Ha$orN, (K,) (tropical:) The year of dearth destroyed their camels and other quadrupeds; because it causes the owners to collect themselves from the various quarters to the cities or towns: (Lth:) or it caused them to go down to the cities or towns: (A:) or it distressed them; app., because of their collecting themselves together from the desert to the places of settled abodes: (Abu-t- Teiyib:) and Ha$arati Als~anapu maAla fulaAnK The year of dearth destroyed the camels &c. of such a one. (S, K. *) ＝ -A2- Ha$arahu, (S, A,) inf. n. Ha$orN, (S, K,) (tropical:) He made it (a spear-head, S, A) thin, or slender: (S, A, K:) he made it (a spear-head, and a knife,) sharp, or pointed, and thin, or slender: (TA:) he made it small, and thin, or slender: (Th:) he pared it; namely, a stick: (TA:) he pared it, and made it sharp, or pointed. (S.)

7 AnH$rwA *
They (people) became collected together from the desert to the places of settled abodes. (Abu-t-Teiyib.)

Ha$orN *
(tropical:) Anything thin, or slender, or elegant. (TA.) You say A^u*unu Ha$orN (tropical:) A thin, or an elegant, ear; (Lth, ISk, S, A, K;) as though it were pared, (Lth, S,) and made sharp: (S:) or small, elegant, and round: (Lth:) or thin at the end: (Th:) or sharp-pointed: (TA:) and the epithet is the same for the dual also and the pl.: (K:) [J says that] it does not admit the dual form nor the pl., because it is originally an inf. n., and the expression above mentioned is like maA='N gaworN and maA='N sakobN: but A*n Ha$orapN is sometimes said: (S:) and the pl. Hu$uwrN occurs in a verse of Umeiyeh Ibn-Abee-'Áïdh: (TA:) and you also say A*n maHo$uwrapN↓. (TA.) Ha$orN is also applied in the same sense as an epithet to other things. (S) You say qu*~apN Ha$orN (tropical:) A thin, or an elegant, feather of an arrow; (Lth, S, A, K;) as though it were pared: (Lth:) or sharp-pointed. (TA.) Also sinaAnN Ha$orN (tropical:) A thin, or slender, spear-head: (S, K:) or sharp, or sharp-pointed: and sik~iynN Ha$orN in like manner: and HarobapN Ha$orapN: (TA:) and sahomN Ha$orN, and sihaAmN Hu$orN: like jawonN and juwnN, and warodN and wurodN: (Akh, S:) or sahomN Ha$orN signifies an arrow having straight, or even, feathers; and so shm maHo$uwrN↓; and Ha$irN↓, of the same measure as katifN, an arrow having good feathers attached to it. (TA.) You also say baEiyrN Ha$oru AlA^u*uni (tropical:) A camel having a thin, or an elegant, ear. (TA.)

Ha$irN *
: see Ha$orN.

Ha$arapN *
and Ha$araAtN, (K,) each being a coll. n. without a sing.; (TA;) or the former is sing. of the latter; (S, Msb;) Any small animals that creep or walk upon the earth; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as jerboas and hedgehogs and lizards of the kind called Dab~ and the like: (TA:) or the former, (Msb,) or latter, (Mgh,) is applied to rats or mice, and jerboas, and lizards of the kind above mentioned, (Mgh, Msb,) colleted together: (Msb:) or any venomous or noxious reptiles or the like, such as scorpions and serpents; syn. hawaAm~u; (As, K;) as also A^aHoraA$N and A^aHonaA$N. (As.) ― -b2- Also the former, Whatever is captured, snared, entrapped, hunted, or chased, of wild animals or the like, birds, and fish, &c.; (K;) whether small or great: (TA:) or the great thereof: or what is eaten thereof: (K:) thus in all the copies of the K; but the pronoun [in the latter case] does not refer to the animals &c. above mentioned: it is expressly said in the T and M that the word signifies whatever is eaten of herbs, or leguminous plants, of the earth, such as the duEaAE and fav~. (TA.)

HaA$irN *
One who congregates, or collects together, people. (TA.) With the article Al, applied to Mohammad; (S, K;) because he collects people after him (S, IAth) and to his religion. (IAth.) ― -b2- A collector of spoils: (El-Hulwánee, Mgh:) and [its pl.] Hu$~aArN signifies collectors of the tithes and poll-tax. (TA.)

maHo$irN *
(S, K) and maHo$arN (K) A place of congregation: (S, K:) a term used when people are collected together to a town or country, and to an encampment, and the like. (TA.) Hence, yawomu AlmaHo$iri [The day of the place of congregation; meaning the day of judgment]. (TA.)

maHo$uwrN *
; and its fem., with p: see Ha$orN.

Q. 1 Ha$oraja *
, (TA,) inf. n. Ha$orajapN, (S, K, TA,) He rattled in the throat, in dying: he made his breath, or spirit, (nafasahu, or nafosahu, accord. to different copies of the S and K,) to reciprocate: (S, K:) said also of the chest: or he made the sound of his breath to reciprocate in his throat, or fauces, without uttering it with his tongue. (TA.) Also said of an ass, He made his voice to reciprocate in his throat: (S, K, TA:) or uttered his voice from his chest. (TA.)

Ha$orajN *
Water that is beneath the ground, unperceived, in the wide water-channels that contain small pebbles, and which, when one has dug to the depth of a cubit, gushes forth abundantly: waters of this description are called by the Arabs A^aHosaA='N [pl. of HisoYN] and kiraArN [pl. of kar~N] and Ha$aAriju: and sweet water, of the water of a HisoY: (Az, TA:) or water that runs, clear and shallow, over pebbles, or over small pebbles: (TA:) what is termed HisoYN, among pebbles: (ISk, S, K:) or what is termed HisoYN, having pebbles in it: (K accord. to the TA:) or what resembles that which is termed HisoYN, in which waters collect: or a small, or round, hollow, or cavity, in a mountain, in which water becomes clear, (Az, K, TA,) after collecting: (Az, TA:) or water in a small, or round, hollow, or cavity, in a mountain. (A.) ― -b2- Soft foraminous stones (ka*~aAn) of the ground: n. un. with p. (K.) ― -b3- A small, (A, TA,) or thin, (K,) and clean, (TA,) kuwz [or mug], (A, K, TA,) in which water is cooled, (A,) of the manufacture of El-Heereh. (K.) ― -b4- The cocoanut. (Kr, TA.)

Ha$orajapN *
inf. n. of Ha$oraja [q. v.]. ― -b2- [The rattles;] the voice of a sick person reciprocated in the throat, or fauces. (A.)

1 Ha$afa *
, said of a she-camel's dug, Its milk became drawn up or withdrawn or withheld, or it went away, from it. (IDrd, L, TA. [See also 4 and 10.])

2 H$~f Eayonahu *
, inf. n. taHo$iyfN, He (a man, TA) contracted his eyelids, and looked through the interstices of their lashes. (IDrd, K.)

4 AH$f *
, said of a she-camel's udder, It became contracted, and like an old worn-out water-skin or milk-skin. (TA. [See also 1 and 10.]) ― -b2- AH$ft Aln~axolapu The palm-tree bore dates such as are termed Ha$af. (S, Mgh, Msb.)

5 tH$~f *
He wore old and worn-out clothing, (O, L, KL, TA,) such as is termed Ha$iyf: (O, L, TA:) in the copies of the K, erroneously, AstH$f↓. (TA.)

10 AstH$f *
, said of an udder, (Jm, K,) It became contracted: (Jm:) or became dried up and contracted. (K. [See also 1 and 4.]) And AstH$ft AlA^u*unu The ear became dried up (Mgh, Msb, K) and contracted. (K.) And AstH$f AlA^anofu The cartilage of the nose became dried up from want of natural motion. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also 5.

Ha$ofN *
Dry bread. (K.)

Ha$afN *
The worst kind of dates; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) that dry up without ripening, so that they have no flesh: (Msb:) or dates without firmness, having no stones; (K;) like $iyS: (TA:) or dry, or tough, bad dates; (K;) for when they dry up, they become hard and bad, without taste and without sweetness: (TA:) or of which the lower portion has become bad and rotten, while in its place: (IAar, TA in art. x$w:) n. un. with p. (Msb.) [Hence,] A^aHa$afFA wa suwo'a kiylapK, a prov., (S, Meyd, O,) meaning Dost thou combine the worst of dates and bad measure? applied to him who combines two bad qualities. (Meyd, O.) ― -b2- A worn-out udder; (S, K;) as also Ha$ifN↓: (K:) or an udder of which the milk has dried up, so that it has become contracted. (EM p. 67.) ― -b3- A thing that is lean, and dry, or withered. (KL.)

Ha$ifN *
: see Ha$afN. — tamorN Ha$ifN Dates having many such as are termed Ha$af. (TA.)

Ha$afapN *
The head [or glans] of the penis: (TA:) or the part of the penis, (S, K,) [i. e.] the part of the head of the penis, (Mgh,) that is above [i. e. beyond] the place of circumcision: (S, Mgh, K:) [accord. to the latter explanation, somewhat more than the glans:] the mulct for the cutting off of which is the whole price of blood. (TA.)

Ha$iyfN *
Old, and worn-out: applied to clothing or a garment. (S, K, TA.)

naxolapN miHo$aAfN *
[A palm-tree that bears dates such as are termed Ha$af]. (S and L voce miEoraArN.)

mutaHa$~ifN *
A man clad in old and worn-out clothing [such as is termed Ha$iyf]: (S, TA:) a man in evil condition; slovenly in his person; threadbare, shabby, or mean, in the state of his apparel: or dried up, and shrivelled: or having his garment tucked up. (TA.)

1 Ha$akati Ald~ir~apu *
, aor.
Ha$ika
, inf. n. Ha$okN and Hu$uwkN; for the former of which, Ha$akN is used by poetic license: (S:) or Ha$ikat, aor.
Ha$aka
, (TA,) inf. n. Ha$akN (K, TA) and Hu$uwkN: (TA:) The flow of milk became full: (S:) or became vehement in the udder: or collected quickly therein: (K, TA:) but accord. to Lth, Ha$okN and Ha$akN↓ are like nafoDN and nafaDN, and naqoDN and naqaDN; the former being an inf. n., and the latter a subst. [in the proper sense of the term, app. signifying milk collected, or collected quickly, in the udder]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Ha$akati Als~aHaAbapu, (K,) aor.
Ha$ika
, inf. n. Ha$okN, (TA,) (tropical:) The cloud had much water. (K, TA.) And Ha$akati Als~amaA='u, aor.
Ha$ika
, inf. n. Ha$okN, (assumed tropical:) The sky let fall a rain such as is termed Ha$okapN. (AZ, S.) And Ha$aka AlwaAdiY, (assumed tropical:) The valley poured (dafaEa) with water. (TA.) ― -b3- And Ha$akati Aln~axolapu (tropical:) The palm-tree bore much fruit. (Yaakoob, S, K, TA.) ― -b4- And Ha$aka Alqawomu, (S, K,) inf. n. Ha$okN, or, accord. to Th, Ha$akN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) The people collected themselves together, or assembled. (Th, S, K.) ＝ -A2- Ha$akato labanahaA, inf. n. Ha$okN and Hu$uwkN, She (a camel) collected her milk. (K.) ― -b2- Ha$aka Aln~aAqapa, (S, K,) aor.
Ha$ika
, (K,) inf. n. Ha$okN, (TA,) He left milking the she-camel until her milk collected (S, K, TA) in her udder. (TA.)

Ha$akN *
: see 1.

Ha$akapN *
(assumed tropical:) A rain exceeding such as is termed bago$apN; like Hafo$apN and gaboyapN. (S).

jaAw^uwA biHa$akatihimo *
, (K,) or, as in the Moheet, jaA='a fulaAnN biHa$akatihimo, (TA,) means (assumed tropical:) [They came, or such a one came,] with their company. (K, TA.)

Hi$aAkN *
, (IDrd, S, Sgh,) thus correctly written, like kitaAbN, but in [most of] the copies of the K like saHaAbN, (TA, [in the CK like saHaAbapN,]) A piece of wood which is put in the mouth of a kid, (S, K,) across, (S,) and tied (S, K) at the back of his neck, (S,) to prevent him from sucking: (S, K:) also called $ibaAmN. (IDrd, S.)

Ha$uwkN *
A she-camel collecting milk in her udder (S, K) quickly. (S.)

HaA$ikN *
[act. part. n. of Ha$aka]. You say $aApN HaA$ikapN A sheep, or goat, abounding with milk. (TA in art. ljb.) [And hence,] naxolapN HaA$ikN (tropical:) A palm-tree bearing much fruit. (Yaakoob, S, K.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Consecutive, or uninterrupted. (Ibn- 'Abbád, K.)

1 Ha$ima *
, aor.
Ha$ama
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. Ha$amN, (Msb,) He was, or became, angry; (Msb, K;) as also AHt$m↓: (Msb:) or the latter signifies he became angered. (TA.) ― -b2- And He was, or became, confounded and stupified by shame; or ashamed and confounded or stupified, and remained speechless and motionless. (Msb.) See also 8. ＝ -A2- Ha$amahu, aor.
Ha$ima
, inf. n. Ha$omN; (Msb;) or Ha$imahu, aor.
Ha$ama
; (K;) He angered him; (Msb, K;) as also AH$mhu↓, (IAar, S, Msb, K,) and H$~mhu↓. (K.) And, accord. to AZ (S) and El-Fárábee, (Msb,) Ha$amahu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
Ha$ima
and
Ha$uma
, (K,) He annoyed him, (S, Msb, K,) and said to him what he disliked, (K,) and angered him; (S, Msb;) namely, a man sitting with him. (S, Msb, K.) An Arab of chaste speech is related to have said, baniY fulaAnK *`lika mim~aA yuHo$imu↓, meaning That is of the things that anger the sons of such a one. (S.) ― -b2- Accord. to IAar, (S,) Ha$amahu signifies He caused him to become confounded and stupified by shame; or to become ashamed and confounded or stupified, and to remain speechless and motionless; (S, K;) as also AH$mhu↓: (S, Msb, K:) and both signify it caused him to be affected with shame, shyness, or bashfulness; or to shrink; as in the saying, to one shrinking from food, maA Al~a*iY Ha$amaka, or A^aHo$amaka↓, What caused thee to be affected with shame, &c.? (TA.) ＝ -A3- Ha$ama, aor.
Ha$ima
, inf. n. Hu$uwmN, He became fat, or in a good condition of body, after leanness. (K.) And Ha$amati Ald~aAb~apu fiY A^aw~ali Alr~abiyEi, (K,) aor.
Ha$ima
, inf. n. Ha$omN, (TA,) or Hu$uwmN, (TK,) The beast obtained somewhat of the [herbage called] rbyE, in the beginning thereof, and became fat, and in good condition, and large in the belly, (K, TA,) and goodly: (TA:) or, as En-Nadr says, Ha$amati Ald~awaAb~u the beasts became in good condition. (S.) ― -b2- maA Ha$ama mino TaEaAminaA He ate not of our food (K, TA) aught. (TA.) ― -b3- maA Ha$ama AlS~ayoda He hit not, or obtained not, or found not, the game, or object of the chase. (K.) ＝ -A4- Ha$ama, inf. n. Ha$omN (TA) and Hu$uwmN, (K,) He was, or became, fatigued, tired, or wearied. (K, TA.) The Arabs say, AlHusuwmu yuwrivu AlHu$uwma Labour, or toil, occasions fatigue. (Yoo, TA.)

2 Ha$~ama
see 1.

4 A^aHo$ama
see 1, in four places.

5 taHa$~ama
see 8. ― -b2- You say also, huwa ytHa$~amu AlmaHaArima He guards against things forbidden. (TA.)

8 AHt$m *
: see 1. ― -b2- Also He felt, or had a sense of, or was moved or affected with, shame, or shyness, or bashfulness. (Msb.) AHt$m minohu (S, Mgh, K) and Eanohu, (K,) and AHt$mhu, (S, Mgh,) or this last is not allowable except when mino is meant to be understood, (TA,) signify the same; (S, Mgh;) i. e. He was ashamed of it, or abashed at him; or was ashamed to do it, or shy of doing it: (Mgh, K:) or it signifies, (Mgh,) or signifies also, (K,) he shrank from it, or him: (Mgh, K:) or, as some say, thus used it is vulgar; for Hi$omapN, with the Arabs, is only anger: (Mgh:) but IB cites, from Kutheiyir,
A_in~iY mataY lamo yakuno EaTaAw^uhumaA
EinodiY bimaA qado faEalotu A^aHota$imu
as meaning [Verily I, when the gift of them two
in my possession is not for what I have done,] am ashamed, or abashed: and in a trad. of 'Alee, respecting the thief, occurs the saying, A_in~iY laA^aHota$imu A^ano laA A^adaEa lahu yadFA, meaning Verily I am ashamed not to leave him a hand; and I shrink from it. (TA.) [And Ha$ama↓ app. signifies the same; for,] accord. to As, (TA,) [the inf. n.] Hu$uwmN signifies The act of shrinking. (K.) You say also, A_in~iY minohu laA^ataHa$~amu↓ Verily I abstain from it, or refrain from it, to shun blame, or through disdain and pride; disdain, or scorn, it; (A^ata*am~amu minohu;) and am ashamed of it. (K.) ＝ -A2- Also He was, or became, master of many Ha$am [or dependents &c.] and servants. (KL.)

Ha$amN *
A man's special dependents, consisting of his family and slaves [and others], or his neighbours, who are angry on his account (K, TA) when an event befalls him; (TA;) as also Hu$omapN↓; (Yoo, TA;) in the K, erroneously, Ha$amapN; (TA;) and A^aHo$aAmN; (K;) which IAar thinks to be pl. of Ha$amN used in a sing. sense; (TA;) [for] this word is applied to one [of such persons] as well as to a pl. number: (K:) you say, h`*aA AlgulaAmu Ha$amN liY [This young man, or slave, is a dependent of mine]: (IAar, TA:) or Ha$amN signifies, (ISk, Mgh, Msb,) or signifies also, (K,) a man's relations and household; (ISk, Mgh, Msb, K;) or his servants; (S, Msb;) and those who are angry on his account (ISk, S, Mgh, Msb) when an event befalls him; (Mgh, Msb;) for which reason they are thus called: (S:) or a man's followers; and those on whose account he should be angry: (Ham p. 614:) or the Ha$am of a man are those who are angry on his account; or those on whose account he is angry: (Har p. 164:) accord. to ISk, (Msb,) it is a word having a pl. signification, and having no proper sing.: (Mgh, Msb:) but some say that it has for its pl. A^aHo$aAmN: (Mgh:) and accord. to the K, Hu$amaA='u↓ [in the CK Ha$omaA'] signifies neighbours and guests; as though it were pl. of Ha$iymN, like as kuramaA='u is of kariymN: but [perhaps this should be A^aHo$aAmN; for] we find in the M, h`w^ulaA='i A^aHo$aAmiY, meaning These are my neighbours, and my guests: (TA:) and Hu$umN↓, with two dammehs, signifies slaves; (IAar, TA;) or, as some say, followers, whether slaves or free persons. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also An object of desire or quest; syn. TalabapN [in the CK Talabap]; and so Hu$uwmN↓. (K.) You say, huwa Ha$amuhu It is his object of desire or quest. (TK.)

Hu$umN *
Persons having, or possessing, (*awuw, as in the explanation of IAar, for which *uw is erroneously substituted in the copies of the K, TA,) consummate shame, shyness, bashfulness, or pudency. (IAar, K, TA.) ― -b2- See also Ha$amN.

Hu$omapN *
(in the K, erroneously, Ha$amapN, TA): see Ha$amN. ― -b2- Also [in the CK, erroneously, Hu$amap] A woman, or a wife; syn. maroA^apN. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- I. q. *imaAmN [app. as meaning protection, safeguard, or security of life and property]. (Yoo, K.) So in the phrase, lahu AlHu$omapu [Protection, &c., is due to him]. (Yoo, TA.) ― -b2- Relationship. (K.) So in the phrase, fiyhimo Hu$omapN [Among them is relationship]. (TA.) ＝ -A3- See also Ha$omapN.

Hi$omapN *
Anger. (As, S, Mgh, Msb, TA.) ― -b2- And Shame, shyness, bashfulness, or pudency; (S, Msb, K;) and a shrinking (Lth, Mgh, K, TA) from one's brother in a place of eating, and in seeking, or requesting, a thing that one wants. (Lth, Mgh, TA.) It has been asserted, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) on the authority of As, (Msb, TA,) that it signifies only “anger:” (Mgh, Msb, TA:) but several authors have refuted this assertion, by showing that it occurs in trads. as meaning “shame.” (MF, TA.) ― -b3- Also The act of annoying a person sitting with one, and saying to him what he dislikes; and so Hu$omapN↓. (K.)

Hu$amaA='u *
, in the CK Ha$omaA': see Ha$amN.

Hu$uwmN *
: see Ha$amN, last sentence but one. ＝ -A2- It is also an inf. n. of 1. (K.)

Ha$iymN *
, (S, K,) in some of the copies of the S Hi$~iymN, which is app. a mistake, (TA,) [thus I find it in one of my copies of the S,] i. q. muHota$amN↓; (S, K;) i. e. Regarded with reverence, veneration, respect, honour, awe, or fear; (TA;) applied to a man. (S.)

HaA$imN *
A man being, or becoming, fat, or in a good condition of body, after leanness. (TA.)

maHo$uwmN *
Angered. (TA.) [But it is implied in the S that it signifies Confounded and stupified by shame; or ashamed and confounded or stupified, and remaining speechless and motionless.] A poet says,
laEamoruka A_in~a quroSa A^abiY xubayobK
baTiYo'u Aln~uDoji maHo$uwmu AlA^akiyli
[By thy life, verily the round cake of bread of Aboo-Khubeyb is slow in becoming thoroughly baked: the eater is angered, or confounded and stupified by shame, &c.]. (S, TA.)

muHota$amN *
: see Ha$iymN.

A_in~ahu lamuHota$imN biA^amoriY *
Verily he is grieved and disquieted (muhotam~N) by my affair, or case. (AA, TA.)

1 Ha$aA *
, (S, Mgh, Msb, TA,) aor. yaHo$uw, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. Ha$owN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) He filled, (K, TA,) or stuffed, (KL, PS,) a pillow, or cushion, [and a garment, (see Ha$owN, below,)] &c., (S, Mgh, * Msb, K,) with a thing, (K,) with cotton, (Msb, TA,) and the like. (TA.) [And He stuffed a lamb, or a fowl, and a vegetable, &c., with rice &c.] ― -b2- Hence, Ha$aA AlgayoZa, aor. and inf. n. as above, (tropical:) [He stuffed wrath into a man's bosom: see an ex. in a verse cited in the first paragraph of art. HZl:] and Hu$iYa Alr~ajulu gayoZFA wa kiborFA (tropical:) [The man was stuffed with wrath and pride], and Hu$iYa Alr~ajulu biAln~afosi and Hu$iYa Aln~afosa (assumed tropical:) [The man was stuffed with pride, or self-magnification, or with disdain, or scorn]. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] SigaAru AlA_ibili taHo$uw AlkibaAra (assumed tropical:) The young camels enter, or occupy the spaces, among the old ones. (TA.) ― -b4- [rasama kitaAbFA wa lamo yaHo$uhu, a phrase occurring in the 1st nawoE of the Mz, means (assumed tropical:) He sketched out a book, and did not fill it up.] ― -b5- Ha$aAhu [also signifies He foisted it into a thing. ― -b6- And] He hit, or hurt, his Ha$FA [q. v., like Ha$aA^ahu]. (K.) You say, Ha$aAhu sahomFA, inf. n. as above, He hit, or hurt, his Ha$FA [with an arrow]. (TA.)

3 maA A^ajal~ahu wa laA HaA$aAhu *
He gave him not a jaliylap [i. e. a she-camel that had brought forth once] nor HaA$iyap [i. e. small, or young, camels]: (K:) or maA A^ajal~aniY wa laA A^aHo$aAniY↓ He gave me not a she-camel that had brought forth once nor gave he me a young, or small, camel. (S in art. jl.)

4 A^aHo$awa
see 3.

5 taHa$~awa
see 8. ― -b2- tH$~Y fiY baniY fulaAnK (assumed tropical:) He became received among the sons of such a one, and harboured, protected, or lodged, by them. (TA in art. H$Y [but belonging to the present art.].)

7 A_inoHa$awa
see 8. ― -b2- AnH$Y SawotN fiY SawotK [app. (assumed tropical:) A sound became blended in a sound], and HarofN fiY HarofK [a letter in a letter]: mentioned by Az. (TA in art. H$Y [but app. belonging to the present art.].)

8 AHt$Y *
It (a thing) became filled [or stuffed; as also AnH$Y↓]. (K.) And in like manner you say of a man, AHt$Y mina AlT~aEaAmi He became filled [or stuffed] with food. (TA.) And AiHota$ati Alr~um~aAnapu biAlHab~i The pomegranate became filled with the grains, or seeds. (TA.) ― -b2- AiHota$ato She (a musotaHaADap) stuffed her vulva (nafosahaA) with the [rags termed] mafaArim [in the CK, erroneously, maqaArim], (K, TA,) and the like: and in a similar sense AHt$Y is used as said of a man having the [disorder termed] A_iboridap. (TA.) And AiHota$ato biAlkurosufi (S, Mgh, TA) and Alkurosufa (Mgh, TA) She (a HaAy^iD, S, Mgh) stuffed her vulva with cotton, (Mgh, TA,) to arrest the blood. (S.) ― -b3- AiHota$ato Ha$iy~apF and biHa$iy~apK She (a woman) wore a Ha$iy~ap; (IAar, K;) as also taHa$~ato↓ [alone]. (Az, TA in art. H$Y.) A poet says,
laA taHota$iY A_il~aA AlS~amiyma AlS~aAdiqaA
[She will not wear any stuffing but that which is genuine and true]: meaning that she will not wear Ha$aAyaA because the largeness of her posteriors renders it needless for her to do so. (IAar, TA.)

Hi$apN *
, pl. Hi$uwna: see waHo$N.

Ha$FA *
The contents of the belly: (K:) or a bowel, or an intestine, into which the food passes from the stomach; syn. miEFY: (Msb:) pl. A^aHo$aA='N: (Msb, K:) and Hu$owapN↓ and Hi$owapN↓ signify the bowels, or intestines; [like A^aHo$aA='N;] syn. A^amoEaA='N: (Msb:) or these are called AlbaToni Hu$owapu↓ and Hi$owatuhu↓: (S, TA:) or H$wp signifies all that is in the belly except the fat; so accord. to Az and Esh-Sháfi'ee: or, accord. to As, the place of the food, comprising the A^aHo$aA=' and the A^aqoSaAb: (TA:) [see also maHo$FY:] AlHa$aA is the name of all the places of the food: (Zj in his “Khalk
el-Insán:”) [see also, for other meanings, its dial. var. Ha$FY, in art. H$Y:] the word belongs to this art. and to art. H$Y; the dual being Ha$awaAni and Ha$ayaAni. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A side, (Msb, TA,) region, quarter, or tract. (Msb.) You say, A^anaA fiY Ha$aA fulaAnK I am in the quarter and protection of such a one: pl. as above. (Har p. 61.) [See, again, Ha$FY, in art. H$Y.]

Ha$owN *
, like the inf. n., (TA,) Stuffing; (PS;) [i. e.] what is put into a pillow, or cushion, &c.: (K, TA:) and [hence] cotton: and the seeds used for seasoning food, [and the rice &c.,] with which the belly of a lamb is stuffed: pl. maHaA$K↓, deviating from rule. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) The soul of a man. (K, TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) [A parenthesis;] a redundant part, or portion, of speech, or of a sentence, (K, TA,) upon which nothing is syntactically dependent. (TA. [See Har pp. 85 and 86.]) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) [A digression.] ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) The portion of either hemistich of a verse that is comprised between the first and last foot. (KT, &c.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) Small, or young, camels, (S, K,) among which are no great, or old, ones; (S, TA;) as also HaA$iyapN↓: (S, K:) so called because they enter, or occupy the spaces, among the latter; or because they go against the sides of the latter: (TA:) accord. to ISk, (S,) AlHaA$iyataAni↓ signifies [the camel termed] Aibonu AlmaxaADi and [that termed] Aibonu All~abuwni: (S, and K in art. H$Y:) the pl. [of HaA$iyapN] is HawaA$K↓. (TA.) It is said in a trad. respecting the poorrate, A^amowaAlihimo Hu*o mino HawaA$iY↓, i. e., accord. to IAth, (assumed tropical:) Take thou of the small, or young, of their camels; such as those termed Abn AlmxAD and Abn Allbwn. (TA. [But see another explanation of this saying voce HaA$iyapN in art. H$Y.]) ― -b7- And Ha$owN and HaA$iyapN↓ signify also (assumed tropical:) The like of mankind; (S;) [i. e.] HaA$iyapN signifies (tropical:) the lower or lowest, baser or basest, meaner or meanest, sort, or the rabble, or refuse, of mankind, or of the people; (TA in art. H$Y, and Har p. 61;) as also Ha$owN [which is of frequent occurrence in this sense]; (KL;) and Hi$owapN↓; (S, TA;) such as servants and the like. (Har ubi suprà, in explanation of HA$yp. [See also this word in art. H$Y.]) You say, jaA='a fulaAnN maEa HaA$iyatihi↓ (assumed tropical:) Such a one came with those who were in his quarter and protection: but this may be from Ha$FA signifying “a region, quarter, or tract;” servants and followers being in the quarter and protection of their master. (Har ubi suprà.) And fulaAnN baniY fulaAnK mino Hi$owapi↓ (assumed tropical:) Such a one is of the lower or lowest, &c., of the sons of such a one. (S.) ― -b8- See also Hu$owapN. ＝ -A2- Also A stuffed garment. (Mgh.)

A^aroDN Ha$aApN *
(tropical:) Black land, in which is no good. (K, TA.)

Hu$owapN *
and Hi$owapN: for each, see Ha$FA, in two places: ― -b2- and for the latter, see also Ha$owN, in two places. ― -b3- You say also, maA A^akovara Hu$owapa A^aroDihi and Hi$owapa ArDh, i. e. Ha$owahaA↓ and dagalahaA [app. meaning (tropical:) How many are the thickets, or the like, that obstruct the tracts of his land!]. (Lh, K, TA.)

Ha$iY~N *
Herbage that has become dry in its lower part, and rotten: (IAar, K:) or dry: (As, S, K:) like xa$iY~N [q. v.]. (S, TA.)

Ha$iy~apN *
A stuffed bed: (K:) pl. Ha$aAyaA. (TA.) ['Antarah says that a saddle was to him what the Ha$iy~ap, or stuffed bed, is to others: see EM p. 229.] ― -b2- Also, (K,) and miHo$FY↓, (S, K,) A pillow, (K,) or the like, (S,) with which a woman makes her posteriors (S, K) or her body (K) to appear large: (S, K:) pl. of the former as above; (TA;) and of the latter maHaA$K. (S, TA. [In the S, it is only said of the former that it is the sing. of Ha$aAyaA.]) ― -b3- [Also the former, The pad of a raHol (or camel's saddle): see mirobaTapN.]

HaA$iyapN *
, and its dual and pl.: see Ha$owN, in six places. ― -b2- See also art. H$Y.

maHo$FY *
The place of the food in the belly. (K.) [See also Ha$FA, and maHo$aApN.]

miHo$FY *
: see Ha$iy~apN.

maHo$aApN *
[The rectum;] the lowest of the places of the food, (As, TA,) [i. e.] the portion of the intestines which is the lowest of the places of the food, (IAth, TA,) leading [immediately] to the place of egress; (As, TA;) in a beast, i. q. maboEarN: (TA: [explained in the K in art. H$, to which it does not belong:]) pl. maHaA$K. (IAth, TA.) Hence, A_iy~aAkumo wa A_itoyaAna Aln~isaA='i fiY maHaA$iyhin~a faA_in~a kul~a maHo$aApK HaraAmN. (TA.)

miHo$aApN *
A coarse [garment of the kind called] kisaA=', (As, S, TA,) that abrades the skin: (TA:) pl. maHaA$K. (As, S.) [But accord. to some, a garment of this kind is called miHo$aA^N or miHo$aA='N.]

[
maHo$uw~N *
and maHo$iY~N Filled, or stuffed..]

maHaA$K *
pl. of miHo$FY, (S, TA,) and of maHo$aApN, (IAth, TA,) and of miHo$aApN, (As, S,) and irreg. pl. of Ha$owN, q. v. (TA.)

1 Ha$iYa *
, [aor. yaHo$aY,] inf. n. Ha$FY, He (a man walking quickly, and one speaking with sharpness, or hastiness, of temper, TA) breathed short, or unintermittedly; panted for breath; or was out of breath. (S, K, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 3.

2 H$~Y *
, (TA,) inf. n. taHo$iyapN, (KL, TA,) He made a HaA$iyap to a garment, or piece of cloth. (KL.) ― -b2- And [hence,] (assumed tropical:) He wrote a note or comment, or notes or comments, upon the margin, or margins, of a book: (KL, TA:) in this sense it is vulgar [or post-classical]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- [Also, app., He, or it, caused one to breathe short or unintermittedly, to pant for breath, or to be out of breath: see muHa$~iyapu AlkilaAbi, below.]

3 HA$Ahu minohumo *
, (IAmb, K, &c.,) inf. n. muHaA$aApN, (KL,) He set him aside as excluded from the description of them; [excluded him from them;] did not include him among them: (IAmb, TA:) from Ha$FY meaning the “side” of a thing: (Az, TA;) he excepted him from them; as also tH$~Ahu↓. (Lh, K, TA.) You say, $atamotuhumo wa maA HaA$ayotu minohumo A^aHadFA and mA taHa$~ayotu↓, i. e. [I reviled them and] I did not say [of any one of them] HaA$aY lifulaAnK [Far is such a one from being included among those of whom I speak! or from any cause of reproach!]; or I did not except, of them, any one. (Lh, TA. [The same saying is repeated in the TA, in the supplement to this art. of the K, but with the substitution of H$yt for HA$yt; perhaps by a mistake of the copyist: or it may be inferred from a statement of Fr and IAmb, which will be found below, that one also says mA Ha$ayotu↓.]) And En-Nábighah [Edh-Dhubyánee] says, (Mbr, S.)
wa laA A^araY faAEilFA fiY Aln~aAsi yu$obihuhu
wa maA A^uHaA$iY mina AlA^aqowaAmi mino A^aHadi
[And I shall not see an actor among mankind resembling him; and I do not except, of the companies of men, any one]: which shows HaA$iY to be a verb perfectly inflected. (Mbr, S, Mughnee.) And hence the trad. of the Prophet, qaAl A^usaAmapu A^aHab~u Aln~aAsi A_ilaY~a maA HaA$aY faATimapa, i. e. [He said, Usámeh is the most beloved of men to me:] he did not except Fátimeh: mA being here a negative; not, as Ibn-Málik imagines, supposing this clause to be of the words of the Prophet, the mA which, with a verb following it, conveys the meaning of an inf. n. (Mughnee.) ― -b2- HaA$aY also denotes exception as a particle, or as a verb (S, Mughnee) having but one tense and no inf. n., (Mughnee,) according as it governs a gen. or an accus. case. (S.) You say, zayodK Darabotuhumo HaA$aY↓ [I beat them, except Zeyd], using it as a particle; and Drbthm HA$Y zayodFA, using it as a verb. (S, I 'Ak * p. 169.) And sometimes one says, qaAma Alqawomu maA HaA$aY zayodFA [The party stood, except Zeyd]; (Mughnee, I' Ak p. 169;) like maA xalaA; though Ibn-Málik [like Sb] disallows it: (I' Ak:) this being shown to be allowable by the saying of the poet,
raA^ayotu Aln~aAsa maA HaA$aY qurayo$FA
faA_in~aA naHonu A^afoDaluhumo faEaAlaA
[I have seen mankind, except Kureysh, that we are the most excellent of them in conduct]. (Mughnee, I' Ak p. 170.) The agent of HA$Y [used as a verb having but one tense and no inf. n.] is a pronoun implied, relating to the inf. n. of the preceding verb, or to its act. part. n., or to a portion of what is meant by the [preceding] general noun: so that when one says, qaAma Alqawomu HaA$aY zayodFA, the meaning is, [The party stood, but] their standing, or the stander of them, or a portion of them, was apart from Zeyd. (Mughnee.) [In the K, its use as a verb of this kind is not mentioned; but it is there said to govern the gen. case, like Hat~aY.] ― -b3- It also denotes remoteness from imperfection or the like, or freedom therefrom; as in the phrase ll~`hi HaA$aY↓ [I ascribe unto God remoteness from every imperfection or the like, or freedom therefrom; generally implying wonder or admiration, so that it may be rendered, how
far, or how free, is God from every imperfection!]: (Mughnee:) or this phrase means maEaA*a A@ll~`hi [I seek protection by God; or, as often used by late writers, and in the present day, God forbid!]; as also ll~`hi HaA$a↓; (S, K;) the former being the original expression: (S:) it occurs, read in both these ways, in the Kur xii. 31 and 51; where it implies wonder at the power of God as manifested in the creation of such a person as Joseph. (Ksh, Bd.) Mbr and IJ and the Koofees hold that it is a verb; and that, in the [latter] verse the meaning is, Joseph hath kept aloof from disobedience for the sake of God; but such an interpretation as this is not suitable in the case of [the former verse,] HaA$a ll~`hi maA h`*aA ba$arFA: the truth is, that it is a noun, syn. with Altanoziyh or AlbaraA='ap, [accord. to different copies of the Mughnee, meaning tanoziyhFA or baraA='apF,] as is shown by another reading, ll~`hi HaA$FA↓, with tenween, like baraA='apF ll~`hi; and by the reading of Ibn-Mes'ood, A@ll~`hi HaA$a↓, like maEaA*a A@ll~`hi: some assert that it is a verbal noun, meaning A^atabar~aA^u [I assert myself to be free, or clear, to God], or tabar~aA^otu [I have asserted myself &c.]; but its being decl. in some dials. contradicts this. (Mughnee.) One says also, HaA$aAka↓ and laka HaA$aY↓ [Far art thou from being included among those of whom I speak! or from any cause of reproach! or the like]; both meaning the same. (S, K.) And some of the Arabs say Ha$aY↓, (Fr, IAmb, TA,) dropping the A (IAmb, TA.) ― -b4- Sb says, (S, Mughnee,) with most of the Basrees, (Mughnee,) that it is only a particle governing the gen. case, (S, Mughnee,) syn. with A_il~aA; (Mughnee;) because, if it were a verb, it would be allowable to make it a connective to maA, like xalaA; and this he asserts to be not allowable. (S.) Mbr says that it is sometimes a verb; as is shown by the verse of En-Nábighah cited above; and by the saying HaA$aY lizayodK, because a particle cannot be made to precede immediately another particle; and because it suffers elision, as in the phrase HaA$a lizayodK, seeing that elision takes place in nouns and verbs only, exclusively of particles: (S, Mughnee *:) and IJ and the Koofees say the like: but Mbr also holds, in common with El-Jarmee and El-Mázinee and Zj and Akh and AZ and Fr and Aboo-'Amr EshSheybánee, that it is often a particle governing the gen. case, and seldom a trans. verb having but one tense and no inf. n., because syn. with A_il~aA. (Mughnee.) ＝ -A2- See also 5, in two places.

5 tH$~Y *
[He went aside, apart, or aloof, or he removed, withdrew, or retired to a distance,] is from AlHaA$iyapu; like tanaH~aY from Aln~aAHiyapu: (TA:) and [tHA$Y↓ has a similar meaning:] you say, taHaA$ayotu mino ka*aA I kept aloof from, shunned, or removed myself far from, such a thing; from AlHa$aA [or AlHa$aY] meaning Aln~aAHiyapu. (Har p. 194.) ― -b2- And tH$~Y minohu; (IAar, K;) and minohu HA$Y↓, (Har p. 294,) inf. n. muHaA$aApN; (KL;) He abstained, or refrained, (IAar, K, KL, Har,) from him, (IAar, K, Har,) or it, (IAar, KL,) through disdain and pride; or he disdained, or scorned, or was ashamed of, him, or it. (IAar, K, Har.) ― -b3- And laA yataHa$~aY, (El-Báhilee, TA,) and lA yuHaA$iY↓, (Har p. 294,) He will not care, mind, heed, or regard. (El-Báhilee, Har, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 3, in two places, first and second sentences.

6 taHaAo$aYa
see 5.

Ha$aY *
, for HaA$aY: see 3.

Ha$FY *
, [in some copies of the S written with a final A (see Ha$FA in art. H$w,)] The contents of the ribs; or what the ribs enclose: (S:) or the contents of the belly, below the HijaAb [or diaphragm], consisting of the liver and the spleen and the kari$ [or stomach, properly that of a ruminant, but also applied to that of a man,] and what succeeds to this: or the portion between the shortest rib, which is in the extremity of the side, and the hip, or haunch: or the exterior of the belly: (K: [in the CK, Aw ZAhiri AlbaToni is erroneously put for Aw ZAhiru AlbaToni:]) and, accord. to the copies of the K, the HiDon: [in the CK, wAlHiDoni:] but correctly, the xaDor [or waist]: (TA:) the dual is Ha$ayaAni, (Az, TA,) and the dual of Ha$FA is Ha$awaAni: (TA in art. H$w:) and the pl. [of both these sings.] is A^aHo$aA='N [generally meaning the bowels, or intestines]. (S, TA.) [It is often used as meaning The belly: and the waist.] You say rajulN xamiySu AlHa$aY A man lank in the belly. (S and K in art. xmS.) And huwa laTiyfu AlHa$aY He is slender in the waist: and of a woman, hiYa DaAmirapu AlHa$aY: and of women, hun~a DawaAmiru AlA^aHo$aA='i. (TA.) ― -b2- A side, quarter, region, or tract: (S, K:) a vicinage, or neighbourhood: shelter, or protection. (Z, K, * TA.) You say, A^anaA fiY Ha$aAhu I am in his quarter, vicinage, or protection: (Z, K:) [see also Ha$FA, in art. H$w:] and h`w^ulaA='i HaA$iyatahu↓ These are in his quarter, or vicinage, and shadow, or protection. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also inf. n. of Ha$iYa [q. v.]. (S, * K.)

Ha$K *
A man having a complaint of his Ha$FY [q. v.]. (Az, TA.) ― -b2- Also, and Ha$oyaAnu↓, Breathing short, or unintermittedly; panting for breath; or out of breath; (S, K, TA;) applied to a man; S;) in walking quickly, and in speaking with sharpness, or hastiness, of temper: (TA:) fem. [of the former] Ha$iyapN and [of the latter] Ha$oyaA, (K,) of the measure faEolaY. (TA.)

Ha$oyaAnu *
: see what next precedes.

HaA$a ll~`hi *
and HaA$FA ll~`hi and HaA$a A@ll~`hi: see 3.

HaA$aY *
as a particle, and as a noun; as in HaA$aY zayodK and ll~`hi, and HaA$aAka and HaA$aY laka: see 3, in four places.

HaA$iyapN *

[verse 28] of the Kur, is read by all muHoSanaAt↓, (A 'Obeyd, TA,) meaning having husbands; (A 'Obeyd, Mgh, Msb, TA;) because when such women are made captives, their marriage-tie is cut: but in other instances, some read thus, understanding it in the sense last explained; and others read muHoSinaAt↓, as meaning that have become Muslimehs: (A 'Obeyd, TA:) in the Kur iv. 29, it means free women: and in the Kur v. 7, continent, or chaste, women: (Mgh: [in the Msb, it is said to have the latter of these last two meaning in iv. 29, and the former of them in v. 7:]) muHoSanaAt↓ is the more common in the language of the Arabs. (Fr, TA.) ― -b2- HaSaAnN also signifies A pearl, or a large pearl; syn. dur~apN: (K:) because it is protected in the interior of the shell that contains it. (TA.)

HiSaAnN HSAn
A generous, or high-bred, horse, (Msb, K,) of whose seed one is niggardly: (K:) or a male horse: (Mgh, K:) or this latter is a secondary meaning, originating from frequency of usage: (S, Msb:) or a stallion horse; or one fit to cover: (TA voce raAHa:) the HiSaAn is. so called because he preserves his rider: (TA:) or because his back is like the HiSon to his rider; (Mgh, Msb;) wherefore horses are called HuSuwnN: (Mgh:) or because one is niggardly of his seed, so that he is not made to cover any but a generous mare: (S, Mgh, Msb:) pl. HuSunN. (Mgh, Msb, K.)

, applied to a place, (Msb, TA,) or to a HiSon [or fortress], (S,) Inaccessible, or unapproachable, or difficult of access; syn. maniyEN; (Msb, K; *) [unattainable, by reason of its height; fortified, or protected against attack, so that one cannot gain access to what is within it; (see HaSuna, of which it is the part. n.;)] a building that protects him who has recourse to it for refuge. (Sb, TA.) ― -b2- huwa AlHaSiynu A^ano yuraAma, meaning mino A^ano yuraAma A^aHoSanu↓: see (near its end) the first paragraph in art. Al. ― -b3- diroEN (K) and HaSiynapN (Sh, K) A coat of mail firmly, strongly, or compactly made: (K:) or trusty, or trusted in, having the rings [for Alxlq in the L and TA, I read AlHalaq,] near together; such that weapons produce no effect upon it: (Sh, L, TA:) so called because it is [as] a HiSon to the body. (Er-Rághib, TA.)

And A man married, or having a wife; (S, Msb, K;) as also muHoSinN↓: (Zj, Msb:) the former anomalous [if A^uHoSina be not allowable as meaning, like A^aHoSana, “ he married, ” or “ took a wife: ” but see 1 and 4]. (K.) ― -b2- The piece of iron that extends upwards upon the nose of the horse, having its base in the kiEaAmap, which is the iron thing that embraces, or clasps, (talotaqimu,) the muzzle of the horse. (IDrd in his book on the Saddle and Bridle, pp. 8-9.) [Jac. Schultens, as cited in Freytag's Lex., explains it as Ferramentum quoddam in fræno equi et frænum ipsum.] ― -b3- A [basket of the kind called] zabiyl: (K:) one should not say miHoSanapN. (TA.)

superEntry.entry:
1 HaSaA HS HSA
, (S, TA,) [aor. yaHoSuw,] inf. n. HaSowN, i. q. manaEa [as meaning He denied, or refused]: (S, K:) doubly trans., as in the phrase HaSawotaniY Haq~iY [Thou deniedst me, or refusedst me, my right, or due]. (S, TA.) ＝ -A2- HaSayotuhu, (K, TA,) inf. n. HaSoYN, (TK,) I cast a pebble, or small stone, at him, or it: (TA:) or I smote him, or it, with a pebble, or small stone. (K.) ＝ -A3- HaSiyati AlA^aroDu, (K,) aor. taHoSaY, (TA,) [inf. n. HaSFY,] The land, or ground, abounded with pebbles, or small stones. (K.) ＝ -A4- HaSiYa [He had a stone in his bladder or kidneys: or] he had a hardening of the urine in the bladder so that it became like a pebble, or small stone: (Lth, K:) said of a man: part. n. maHoSiY~N↓. (Lth, TA.)

4 AHSAhu AHSAh AHSAp A^HS A^HSAh A^HSY
, (inf. n. A_iHoSaA='N, TA,) He numbered, counted, calculated, reckoned, or computed, it: (S, Msb, K:) or he reached the last number thereof: (Ham p. 297:) or he collected it into an aggregate by numbering: from HaSFY; because they used pebbles in numbering like as we use the fingers; (Er-Rághib;) or because they used to divide a thing upon the pebbles, and when nothing remained they said, A^aHoSayonaA, i. e. We have come to the pebbles; or because they used to reckon the spoils, and to divide among themselves, and then to take the pebbles, and put marks upon them, and when they ended the reckoning, and came to the marks, they said, A^aHoSayonaA: (Ham ubi suprà:) or he retained it in his memory: (K, * TA:) or he understood it. (K.) ― -b2- He registered, or recorded, its number: (Ksh and Bd in xvi. 18, and TA:) and [simply] he registered it, or recorded it. (Bd and Jel in xxxvi. 11 and lxxviii. 29.) ― -b3- He was able to number it, and to register it or record it: (TA:) and he was able to do it. (Msb, TA.) ― -b4- He comprehended it, or knew it altogether: (TA:) or [simply] he knew it. (Msb.) You say of God, A^aHoSaY kul~a $aYo'K biEilomihi He hath comprehended everything by his knowledge, nothing escaping Him thereof, small or great. (TA.) And you say [of a man], A^aHoSaY Eilomahu [He had, or attained, a comprehensive and complete knowledge of it]. (K in art. HwT. [In the CK, erroneously, Eilomuhu.])

HaSFY HS HSY HSy
Pebbles, or small stones: (K:) things that one throws, like the dung of sheep or goats: (ISh, TA:) n. un. HaSaApN: (S, Msb, K:) pl. HaSayaAtN (S, K) and HuSaY~N (K) and HiSiY~N, thus, also, in [some of] the copies of the K. (TA.) [Hence,] Taroqu AlHaSaY [Pessomancy; also termed AlD~arobu biAlHaSaY;] a certain kind of divination. (Har p. 655.) And bayoEu AlHaSaApi The bargaining by one of the two persons' saying, When I throw the pebble to thee, the sale is binding, or settled, or concluded: or by his saying, I sell to thee, of the commodities, that upon which thy pebble shall fall when thou throwest it: or I sell to thee the portion of the land extending to the place which thy pebble shall reach: all of which practices are forbidden. (TA. [See also 3 in art. nb*.]) And HaSaApu Alqasomi A pebble which is put into a vessel, into which is then poured as much water as will cover it; this being done when they are journeying and have but little water, which they thus apportion. (K in art. qsm.) ― -b2- HaSaY lubaAnK is a vulgar term for Easalu All~abonaY, (K in art. Esl,) i. e. AlmayoEapu [generally applied to Storax, or styrax], which is sometimes used for fumigation. (TA in art. lbn.) [In the present day, pronounced HaSaY libaAn, and applied to Frankincense: or the coarser tears thereof; manna thuris. Also to The officinal rosemary; rosmarinus officinalis.] ＝ -A2- A number: (S, K:) or a great number; (K;) as being likened to the pebbles in multitude. (TA.) You say, naHono A^akovaru minohumo HaSFY We are more than they in number. (S.)

HaSaApN HSAh HSAp HSY
n. un. of HaSFY [q. v.]. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- Also [A stone in the bladder or kidneys: or] a hardening of the urine in the bladder so that it becomes like a pebble, or small stone. (K.) ― -b3- HaSaApu misokK A hard piece that is found in the vesicle of musk: (S, TA:) or any piece of musk. (Lth, TA.) ＝ -A2- Intelligence, or understanding, (S, K,) and judgment, or mental perception; (K;) as also A^aSaApN. (TA.) You say, fulaAnN *uw HaSaAhK Such a one possesses intelligence, or understanding, (S, TA,) and judgment, or mental perception: (TA:) [or] is prudent, or discreet, and wont to conceal his secret. (As, TA.) Or HaSaApN was used by the Arabs not as meaning intelligence, or understanding; but as meaning Gravity, staidness, and forbearance, or clemency. (Har p. 537.) And HaSaApu All~isaAni means Gravity, or staidness, in respect of the tongue. (TA.) ＝ -A3-
The act of numbering, counting, calculating, reckoning, or computing: a subst. from AlA_iHoSaA='u. (Az, IB, TA.)

nahorN HaSawiY~N nhr HSwY nhr HSwy
: see A^aroDN maHoSaA=pN.

: see A^aroDN maHoSaApN.

Possessing full, sound, and strong, intelligence or understanding. (K, * TA.)

HaSaAwiY~N HSAwY HSAwy
Bread made upon the pebbles: but this is a vulgar term. (TA.)

AlmuHoSiY AlmHSY AlmHSy mHSy
one of the [ninety and nine] best names of God; He who comprehendeth everything by his knowledge; nothing escaping Him thereof, small or great. (TA.)

maHoSiY~N mHSY mHSy
: see 1, last sentence.

A^aroDN maHoSaApN *
A land containing pebbles, or small stones: (S:) or abounding therewith; (K;) as also A^aroDN HaSiyapN↓: and in like manner, nahorN HaSawiY~N↓ a river, or rivulet, or the like, abounding therewith. (TA.)

1 HaD~ahu HD HDh HDp
, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
HaDu3a
, (Msb,) inf. n. HaD~N (S, Msb, K) and HuD~N↓, (IDrd, K,) or this latter is a simple subst., (S, K,) and HiD~iyDaY↓, (K,) or this also is a simple subst., (S, TA,) and HuD~iyDaY↓, (K,) or this also is a simple subst., and is the only instance of the measure fuE~iylaY; and of these last two, the former is the more approved; (TA;) [both of these, accord. to some, have an intensive signification;] He excited, incited, urged, or instigated, him; syn. Hav~ahu; (T, S, A, K;) or Hamalahu; (Msb;) and roused him to ardour; (K;) Ealayohi to do it; (K;) i. e. EalaY AlA^amori to do the thing; (Msb;) or EalaY Alxayori to do good; (T, A;) or EalaY AlqitaAl to fight; (S;) or it is used as relating to pace, and to driving, and to any other thing; (M, TA;) and El-Hareeree says, on the authority of Kh, that Hav~ahu is used peculiarly in relation to pace, or journeying, or marching: (TA in art. Hv:) and HD~Dhu↓, (T, S, K,) inf. n. taHoDiyDN, (T, Msb,) signifies the same; (K;) or has a more intensive signification; (Msb;) or i. q. Har~aDahu [which is equivalent to Hav~ahu with the addition given above from the K]; (T, S;) and this is used as relating to fighting: (T, TA:) or taHoDiyDN signifies the asking, or requiring, with urgency. (Mughnee voce A^alaA.) It is said in the Kur [lxxxix. 19], accord. to the reading of the people of El-Medeeneh, walaA yaHuD~uwna EalaY TaEaAmi Almisokyni; and accord. to that of El-Hasan, taHuD~uwna; [Nor do they, or ye, excite one another to feed the poor, or destitute]: (TA:) or nor do they, or ye, command to feed the poor, &c.: (Fr, TA:) and there are other readings thereof: see 3 and 6. (TA.) The grammarians apply to the particles hal~aA and A^al~aA and lawolaA and lawomaA the term Huruwfu Alt~aHoDiyDi↓ [Particles of exciting]; and say that when they are followed by a future, they denote exciting to an action, and seeking or desiring or demanding the performance of it; and when followed by a preterite, reproof for not doing a thing. (Msb.)

2 HD~Dhu HDD HDDh HDDp HDyD
, inf. n. taHoDiyDN: see 1, in two places.

, (TK,) inf. n. muHaAD~apN, (S, K,) He excited him, &c., as above, being excited, &c., by him. (S, K, TK.) In the Kur ubi suprà, among the various readings are these two: walaA yuHaAD~uwna and wlA tuHaAD~uwna, meaning, accord. to Fr, Nor are they, or ye, mindful. (TA.)

6 tHAD~wA tHADwA
They excited, &c., one another. (S, K.) In the Kur ubi suprà, some read walaA taHaAD~uwna (Fr, S, TA) Nor do ye excite one another. (Fr.)

, said to be a subst.: see 1.

HaDiyDN HDyD
A depressed piece (qaraAr) of ground at the place where a mountain ends; (S;) or a depressed piece (qrAr) of ground at, or by, the safoH [i. e. foot, or bottom, or lowest part,] of a mountain; or in, or at, the lower, or lowest, part thereof, (fiY A^asofalihi,) the sfH being behind the HDyD; the HDyD being in the part next the sfH, and the sfH being duwna *`lika [which seems to be virtually a repetition, signifying behind that part, or it may mean above that part]: (TA:) or i. q. safoHN: (K in art. sfH:) or a depressed piece (qrAr) of ground: (A:) or a tract (HijzN [in the CK, erroneously, Hajar]), and a depressed piece (qrAr), in land or ground: (K:) and any low piece (saAfilN) of land or ground: (TA:) and the ground [in an absolute sense]: (S:) pl. [of pauc.] A^aHiD~apN and [of mult.] HuDuDN. (K.) It has the last of the above-mentioned significations in a certain trad., in which it is related that a present being brought to Mohammad, he, not finding anything upon which to put it, said, DaEohu biAlHaDiyDi, meaning biAlA^aroDi; [i. e. Put thou it upon the ground;] adding, for I am only a servant; I eat as the servant eateth. (S.)

HiD~iyDaY HDyD HDyDY HDyDy HDyDyy
and HuD~iyDaY, said to be substs.: see 1.

1 HaDaA^a Aln~aAra *
, (S, K,) aor.
HaDaAa
, (K,) He lighted, or kindled, the fire; or made it to burn, burn up, burn brightly or fiercely, blaze, or flame: (S, K:) or he opened it, (K,) i. e. stirred it, (TA,) in order that it might blaze, or flame; as also AHtDA^hA↓. (K.) It is also without '. (S. [See art. HDw.]) ＝ -A2- HaDaA^ati Aln~aAru The fire became lighted or kindled; or it burned, burned up, &c. (K.)

see above.

A^aboyaDu HaDiYo'N *
, (K,) so accord. to the correct copies of the K, but in some copies HaDiY~N, (TA,) Very white. (K.)

A stick, or piece of wood, with which a fire is stirred; as also maHoDaA='N; (S, K;) the latter accord. to those who pronounce the verb without '. (S.)

1 HaDara HDr
, aor.
HaDura
; (S, A, Msb, K, &c.;) and HaDira, (AA, Kh, Lth, Fr, S, Msb, K, &c.,) aor. as above, (Kh, Lth, Fr, Az, S, Msb, &c.,) not
HaDara
, as is implied in the K; but the latter form of the pret. is disallowed by some; (MF;) and, with its aor., is an instance of the intermixture of dialects; (Msb;) and is like faDila, aor.
HaDura
, and naEima, aor.
HaDura
; which are said by IKoot to be the only instances of the kind; (MF;) inf. n. HuDuwrN (S, Msb, K) and HaDaAra; (K;) and AHtDr↓, and tHD~r↓; (K;) He was, or became, present; contr. of gaAba: (S, K:) he came after having been absent. (Msb.) ― -b2- HaDarati AlS~alaApu, (Lth, A, L, Msb,) and, as the people of El-Medeeneh say, HaDirat, but all say taHoDuru, (Lth, L,) originally HaDara waqotu AlS~alaApi, (tropical:) The time of prayer came, or arrived. (Msb.) ― -b3- [HaDara also signifies (assumed tropical:) He, or it, was, or became, ready, or prepared. See 4; and see also HADirN.] ＝ -A2- HaDarahu, (AA, Fr, A, Mgh, K, &c.,) and HaDirahu, (AA, Fr, &c.,) aor. and inf. ns. as above; (TA;) and AHtDrhu↓, (Mgh, TA,) and tHD~rh↓; (K;) He was, or became, present with him; attended him; came into his presence; came to him: (K, &c.:) and he was, or became, present at it, or in it; namely, a place. (Mgh.) One says, HaDarati AlqaADiYa A@moraA^apN, (Az,) and HaDirat, (Fr, S,) and HaDira, in which the t is elided because AlqADY intervenes between the verb and AmrA^p, (Sh,) but the first is the most approved, (Az,) [A woman came into the presence of, or presented herself before, or came to, the judge.] And HaDarotu majolisa AlqaADiY, aor.
HaDura
, inf. n. HuDuwrN, I was present at, or attended, the court of the judge. (Msb.) [And HaDara darosFA He attended a lecture.] And HaDaruwA AlmiyaAha They stayed, or dwelt, by the waters. (S. [See HaADirN.]) ― -b2- A^aEuw*u bika rab~i A^ano yaHoDuruwni [in the Kur xxiii. 100] means [I seek thy protection, O my Lord,] from their (the devils') bringing evil upon me: (S:) or [from their being present with me: or] hovering around me. (Ksh, Bd.) ― -b3- Aljin~u taHoDuru All~abana, (S, K,) or taHotaDiruhu↓, (T, TA,) (assumed tropical:) [The jinn, or genii, come to, and taint, the milk.] ― -b4- HuDira, (A,) and AuHotuDira↓, (A, Mgh, K,) i. q. HaDarahu Almawotu, (A, K,) i. e. (tropical:) [He was visited by the angel of death;] he became at the point of death; in the agony of death; as also Almawotu AiHotaDarahu↓: (Msb:) or he was visited by death, or by the angels of death; meaning he died: (Mgh:) or AuHotuDira↓ means he died a youth. (S and TA voce A^ajozara, q. v.) ― -b5- HaDaronaA Eano maA='i ka*aA (tropical:) We removed from such a water. (K, TA.) ― -b6- HaDarotu AlA^amora (tropical:) I was present at the affair, or event. (A.) ― -b7- HaDarotu AlA^amora bixayorK (tropical:) I formed a right opinion, or judgment, respecting the thing, or affair. (A.) ― -b8- HaDarahu Alham~u, and AHtDrhu↓, and tHD~rhu↓, (tropical:) [Anxiety befell him.] (S, A.) ― -b9- HaDaraniY ka*aA (assumed tropical:) Such a thing occurred to my mind. (Msb.) And quwluwA maA yaHoDurukumo (assumed tropical:) [Say ye what is in your minds; or] what is ready with you. (TA from a trad.) ＝ -A3- HaDara,
(Msb,) inf. n. HiDaArapN, (AZ, S, K,) or HaDaArapN, (As, S, A,) or both, (Msb,) [see badaA, the contr. of HaDara, in art. bdw,] He resided, dwelt, or abode, in a region, district, or tract, of cities, towns, or villages, and of cultivated land; (S, Msb, K;) [as also tHD~r↓: or this latter signifies he became an inhabitant of such a region, district, or tract:] you say badawiY~N yataHaD~aru↓ [an inhabitant of the desert who becomes an inhabitant of a region, district, or tract, of cities &c.]; and [contr.] HaDariY~N yatabad~aY. (A.) [See also 8.]

, (A, TA,) inf. n. muHaADarapN, (TA,) I witnessed it; saw it, or beheld it, with my eye. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- muHaADarapN between people is One's giving to another the answer, or reply, that presents itself to him: and HADr AljawaAba signifies He gave the answer, or reply, readily, or presently. (Har p. 189.) ― -b2- HaADarotuhu, (S,) inf. n. as above, (K,) [also] signifies I sat with him, with my knee to his knee, each of us sitting upon his knees, in contending or disputing, (jaAvayotuhu, S, K, *) in the presence of the Sultán: (S, K:) the meaning is similar to that of mugaAlabapN and mukaAvarapN, (S,) or mukaAbarapN [which seems to be the right reading]. (TA.) ― -b3- [And HADrhu bika*aA He disputed, debated, or bandied words, with him respecting such a thing.] ― -b4- And HADrhu biHaq~ihi, (Lth, TA,) inf. n. as above, (Lth, K,) He contended, or disputed, with him for his (the latter's) right, or due, and overcame him, and went off with it: (Lth, K:) and mujaAladapN, also, [which is one of the explanations assigned to muHaADarapN in the K,] is syn. with muHaADarapN as the inf. n. of the verb in this sense [unless it be a mistranscription for mujaAdalapN, which I think not improbable]. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Also HaADarotuhu, (S, A,) inf. n. as above, (K,) I ran with him: (S, K:) or I vied, or contended, with him in running; syn. EaAdayotuhu; from AlHuDoru. (A.)

Ed.) ＝ -A2- AHDr, (S,) inf. n. A_iHoDaArN; (S, A, K, &c.;) and AHtDr↓; (S;) He (a horse, S, K, and a man, Kr) ran; syn. EadaA: (S:) or rose in his running; [app. meaning trotted;] syn. The intruding uninvited at feasts. (IAar, K.)

HuDorN HDr
(Az, S, K) and [in poetry] HuDurN↓ (Ham p. 277) and HDaArN↓ (Az, TA) A run, or running; syn. EadowN: (S:) or the rising of a horse in running; [app. meaning trotting;] syn. AirotifaAEu farasK fiY Eadowihi: (K:) or vehement running. (Ham p. 277, in explanation of HuDurN.) It is said in a trad., A^aqoTaEa A@bona Alz~ubayori HuDora farasihi biA^aroDi Almadiynapi [He assigned to Ibn-Ez-Zubeyr the extent of his horse's run in the land of El-Medeeneh]. (TA.)

HaDarN HDr
: see HaDorapN. ＝ -A2- Also, (S, A, Msb, K,) and HaADirapN↓ (S, A, K) and HaDorapN↓ and HiDaArapN↓ and HaDaArapN↓, (K,) [or the last two are app. only inf. ns. of HaDara as contr. of badaA,] A region, district, or tract, of cities, towns, or villages, and of cultivated land; (S;) contr. of badowN (S, A, Msb) and baAdiyapN: (S, K:) pl. [of the second] HawaADiru. (A.) You say, huwa mino A^aholi AlHaDari (A) and AlHaADirapi↓ (S, A) and AlHawaADiri (A) He is of the people of the region, or regions, &c., of cities, towns, or villages, and of cultivated land; (S, A; *) contr. of mino A^aholi AlbaAdiyapi. (S.) ― -b2- And the first signifies also Residence at home; contr. of safarN. (M and K in art. sfr.)

HaDurN HDr
: see HaDirN: ― -b2- and HaADirN.

HaDirN HDr
One who intrudes uninvited at feasts; a smell-feast; a spunger; (TA;) one who watches for the time of (yataHay~anu) the feeding of others, in order that he may attend it; as also HaDurN↓, (K,) and HuDurN↓. (IAar, K, TA.) ＝ -A2- A man unfit for journeying: (T, S:) or one who does not desire journeying: or i. q. HaDariY~N. (K.)

HuDurN HDr
: see HaDiru: ＝ -A2- and HuDorN.

HaDorapN HDr HDrh HDrp
, originally an inf. n., signifying Presence: and afterwards applied to signify (tropical:) a place of presence [as also the several forms occurring in the following phrases]. (MF.) You say, kal~amotuhu bHiaDorap fulaAnK, (S, A, * Msb,) and kaAna *`lika baHaDoratihi, (K, * TA,) and HuDoratihi↓ and HDorataha↓ (S, K) and HaDarihi↓ (Yaakoob, S, Msb, K) and HaDaritaha↓ (K) and maHoDarihi↓, (S, A, Msb, K,) all syn. expressions, (K,) meaning (tropical:) [I spoke to him, and that was or happened,] in the presence, i. e. the place of presence, of such a one. (S, A, Msb.) And fulaAnN Hasanu AlHiDorapi↓ (S, M, A, K) and AlHuDorapi↓ (S, M) (tropical:) Such a one is a person whose presence is attended by good. (K.) And gaT~i A_inaA='aka biHaDorapi Al*~ubaAbi (tropical:) [Cover thy vessel in the presence of the flies, lest they taint it.] (A, TA. [Or perhaps this is a mistranscription, for yaHoDurohu Al*~ubaAbu, meaning, if thou do not, the flies will come to it, and taint it.]) ― -b2- It is also applied as a title, by writers of letters and the like, to any great man with whom people are wont to be present; [and sometimes to God; and meaning (tropical:) The object of resort;] as in the phrase, AlHaDorapu AlEaAliyapu taA^omuru bika*aA (tropical:) [The exalted object of resort commands such a thing]. (MF.) [It is similar to AljanaAbu; but is generally considered as implying greater respect than the latter. It is often prefixed to the name of the person to whom it is applied, or to a pronoun: as HaDorapu fulaAnK (tropical:) The object of resort, such a one: and HaDoratuka (tropical:) The object of resort, thyself.] ― -b3- Also (tropical:) The vicinity of a thing, (T, A,) and of a man. (S. [So accord. to two copies of the S; but Alr~ajuli is there an evident mistranscription, for Alr~aHoli, “ of the house, ” or “ abode: ” see what follows.]) You say, kunotu biHaDorapi Ald~aAri (tropical:) I was in the vicinity of, or near to, the house. (T, A.) And kun~aA biHaDorapi maA='K (tropical:) We were by a water. (TA from a trad.) And biHaDorapi AlmaA='i (tropical:) In the vicinity of, or near to, the water. (A.) ― -b4- Also The finaA=' of a rajul. (S. [So accord. to two copies of the S; where it is said, HaDorapu Alr~ajuli qurobuhu wafinaAw^uhu: but the right reading is evidently Alr~aHoli: so that the second of the two meanings thus explained is, The court, or yard, in front, or extending from the sides, of a house, or an abode.]) ＝ -A2- And (tropical:) Apparatus for building, such as baked bricks, and gypsum-plaster: so in the saying, jamaEa AlHaDorapa yuriydu binaA='a daArK (tropical:) [He collected the apparatus, such as the baked bricks, &c., desiring to build a house]. (A.) ＝ -A3- See also HaDarN.

HuDorapN HDr HDrh HDrp
: see HaDorapN, in five places.

HiDorapN HDr HDrh HDrp
: see HaDorapN, in five places.

HaDarapN HDr HDrh HDrp
: see HaDorapN, in five places.

HaDariY~N HDr HDrY HDry
An inhabitant of a region, district, or tract, of cities, towns, or villages, and of cultivated land; (S, A, * Msb;) opposed to badawiY~N. (S, A.) [See also HaDirN.]

HaDaAri HDAr
[an imperative verbal n.] Be thou present. (A.) ＝ -A2- Also A certain star, (S, K,) upon the right hoof of Centaurus: upon his other fore leg is Alwazonu. (Kzw.) It is said, HaDaAri waAlwazonu muHolifaAni [Hadári and El-Wezn are two causes of swearing]: they are two stars that rise before Canopus (Suheyl); and when either of them rises, it is thought to be Canopus, because of their resemblance to it: (AA, S: *) they are termed mHlfAn because of the disagreement of their beholders when they rise; one swearing that the one rising is Canopus, and another swearing that it is not. (AA, TA.) Th says that it is a dim, distant, star; and cites this verse:
A^aray naAra layolaY baAlEaqiyqi kaA^an~ahaA
HaDaAri A_i*aA maA A^aEoraDato wafuruwduhaA
I see the fire of Leylà, in El-'Akeek, dim in the distance, as though it were Hadári, when it appears, with its Furood, which are dim stars around Hadári. (TA.) ＝ -A3- HaDaArN: see what next follows.

HiDaArN HDAr
(S, K) and HaDaArN↓ (K) White: (Sh, T:) or excellent and white: (S, K:) or red: (K:) but this requires consideration: (TA:) applied to camels, and to a single camel: (S, K:) or having no sing. (K.) And the former, A she-camel combining strength with excellence of pace: (El-Umawee, T, S, K:) but Sh says that he had not heard it used in this sense; and that it only signifies “ white, ” as applied to camels. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also HuDorN.

HaDiyrN HDyr
(tropical:) One who always forms right opinions, or judgments, respecting things, or affairs. (A.) ＝ -A2- See also HaDiyrapN, in three places.

HaDaArapN HDArh HDArp
and HiDaArapN: see HaDarN.

HaDiyrapN HDyrh HDyrp
The collective body of a people: (Fr, K:) so in the following ex., (Fr,) from a poem of Selmà El-Juhaneeyeh, in which she bewails the death of her brother As'ad, and celebrates his praises: (S:)
yaridu AlmiyaAha HaDiyrapF wanafiyDapF

nfyDp A^fAD fAD nfyDh nfyDp
signifying the same: (Fr:) [so that the meaning is, Coming to the waters in a collective and congregated body:] or the former signifies waters by which people are dwelling, or staying; and the latter, “ by which there is not any one: ” (IAar, Sh:) or the former, people dwelling, or staying, by the waters; and the latter, men “ going before an army as scouts, or explorers: ” (As:) but what IAar says, mentioned above, is better: (Az:) or the former, a company of seven, or eight, men; and the latter, “ one; ” and also men “ who explore a place thoroughly: ” (A'Obeyd:) or the former, a company of four, or five, men, (S, K,) engaged in a warring and plundering expedition: (S:) or seven: (TA:) or eight: or nine: (K: in some copies of the K “ seven; ” but the former is the right reading: TA:) or ten: or a company of men not more than ten (nafarN) with whom one goes on a warring and plundering expedition: (K:) or, accord. to AAF and the M and K, the foremost, or preceding, portion of an army: and accord. to IB, nfyDp signifies “ a party sent to a place to discover whether there be there an enemy or any cause of fear: ” (TA:) pl. HaDaAy^iru. (S.) ＝ -A2- A place where dates are dried: (ElBáhilee, ISk, Az, Mgh, Msb, K:) because frequented: pl. as above. (Mgh.) [See also HaSiyrapN and HaZiyrapN.] ＝ -A3- Also, (S,) or HaDiyrN↓, (K, TA,) What collects in a wound, (S, K,) of thick purulent matter. (S.) ― -b2- And the former What collects in the membrane that encloses the fœtus, of the [fluid called] suxod, (S,) and the like. (TA.) You say, A^aloqati Al$~aApu HaDiyratahaA The ewe, or she-goat, ejected her suxod and water and blood, after having brought forth. (S.) ― -b3- And What a woman emits after childbirth and [after] the stopping of her blood: and HaDiyrN↓ is its pl. [or a coll. gen. n.]. (K. [Or, accord. to some copies of the K, and the TA, The stopping of her blood, or its ceasing to flow, is a signification distinct from what precedes it.)] ― -b4- And What a she-camel emits after bringing forth: or, accord. to AO, the membrane that envelops the fœtus. (TA.) ― -b5- And (K, TA, [in the CK “ or ”]) ↓the latter signifies Thick blood which collects in the membrane that encloses the fœtus. (K, * TA.)

HaADirN HADr
A man present: (A, K:) pl. [HaADiruwna and] HuD~arN and [more commonly] HuDuwrN, (S, K,) which last is originally an inf. n. (S.) You say, faEalotuhu wafulaAnN HaADirN I did it such a one being present. (A.) And hawa mino HaADiriY Almaliki [He is of those who are in the presence of the king]. (A.) ― -b2- So, too, applied to a time: and you say, AlS~alaApu HaADirapN, for waqotuhaA HaADirN, (tropical:) The time of prayer is come. (Msb.) ― -b3- [Also (assumed tropical:) Ready, or prepared: often used in this sense in the lexicons &c., as in modern Arabic. See 4.] You say, quwluwA maA huwa HaADirN Einodakumo (assumed tropical:) Say ye what is ready with you [or in your minds]. (TA.) And huwa HaADirN biAljawaAbi (tropical:) [He is ready with the answer, or reply]; and biAln~awaAdiri (tropical:) [with rare words or expressions]; (A;) as also HaDurN↓: (TA:) which latter word, alone, signifies a man having the quality of perspicuity of speech, and intelligence; syn. *uw AlbayaAni waAlfiqohi. (K.) ― -b4- A visiting angel: and HaADirapN↓ is applied to a class or company [of visiting angels]. (TA.) ― -b5- One coming to a region, district, or tract, of cities, towns, or villages, and of cultivated land; contr. of baAdK; (S, K;) as also muHotaDirN↓. (S.) ― -b6- A man staying, residing, dwelling, or abiding, bamawoDiEK in a place. (S.) ― -b7- [A man, or people,] staying, or dwelling, by water; (S, * TA;) contr. of baAdK: (K:) pl. HuDuwrN (TA) and HuD~aArN and HaDarapN: (S:) one says, maA EalaY AlmaA='i HaADirN [There is not any one staying, or dwelling, by the water]: and h`w^ulaA='i qawomN HuD~aArN and maHaADiru [which is pl. of maHoDarN↓, a syn. of xaADirN in this sense; i. e. These are a people staying, or dwelling, by water]: (S:) or HaADirN signifies any people that have alighted and taken up their abode by a constant source of water, and do not remove from it in winter nor in summer, whether they have alighted and taken up their abode in towns or villages, and cultivated land, and houses of clay, or pitched their tents by the water, and remained there, and sustained their beasts with the water and herbage around them: (TA:) or HaY~N HaADirN, without p, signifies a tribe that has alighted and is abiding by a constant source of water: (T, TA:) and HaADirapN↓ and HaADiruwna, a people staying, or dwelling, by waters; alighting there in the hottest time of summer: when the weather becomes cool, they migrate from the constant sources of water, and go into the desert, seeking the vicinity of herbage; and then they are termed baAdiyapN and baAduwna. (T in art. bdw.) ＝ -A2- Also A great tribe (S, K) or company of men: (TA:) or a tribe, (ISd,) or company of men, (Mgh,) when staying, or dwelling, in the abode which is their place of assembling; (ISd, Mgh;) as also HaADirapN↓. (Mgh.) One says HaADiru TaY~i'K The great tribe of Teiyi. (S.) It is a pl., (S,) or coll. n., (ISd,) [or quasipl. n.,] like saAmirN and HaAj~N (S, ISd) for sum~aArN and Huj~aAjN. (S.) ＝ -A3- Also, of the measure faAEilN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, (TA,) A place where people are present; or where people stay, or dwell, by waters: syn. makaAnN maHoDuwrN: one says, nazalonaA HaADira baniY fulaAnK [We alighted and took up our abode, or sojourned, at the place where the sons of such a one were present; or were staying, or dwelling, by waters]. (El-Khat- tábee.) [See also maHoDarN.]

HaADirapN HADr HADrh HADrp
: see HaADirN, in three places: ＝ -A2- and see HaDarN, in two places.

maHoDarN mHDr
A place where people are present, or assembled. (K, * TA.) See also HaDorapN. ― -b2- A place to which people return (marojiEN [here a n. of place, agreeably with analogy,]) to the waters, (S, K;) or to the constant sources of water; (T, TA;) contr. of mabodF Y: (T and S in art. bdw:) a place to which one goes (ma*ohabN) in search of herbage is called munotajaEN; and every such place is called mabodF Y, of which the pl. is mabaAdK: watering-places (manaAhil) are called maHaADiru [pl. of maHoDarN] because of the congregation and presence of men at them. (T, TA.) [See also HaADirN, last signification.] ＝ -A2- [People present, or assembled; an assembly: so in the present day.] ― -b2- A people dwelling, or staying, by waters: (K, * TA:) [pl. maHaADiru:] see HaADirN. ＝ -A3- The record of a kadee (or judge), in which his sentence is written, syn. sijil~N: (S, K:) or what is written when a person brings a charge against another: when the latter makes his reply, and proves it, it [the writing] is [called] tawofiyqN; and when judgment is given, sijilN. (Kull p. 352.) This is thought by MF to be a recent conventional term; but it has been heard from the Arabs [of the classical times], and is mentioned by ISd and others. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A signature (xaT~N) that is written at the end of the record of the signatures (xuTuwT) of the witnesses, in testimony of the truth of the contents of what precedes. (K. [In the CK, waAqaEapK is erroneously put for waAqiEapi; and xuTuwTu, for xuTuwTi.]) But this is a recent conventional application. (MF, TA.) ＝ -A4- fulaAnN Hasanu AlmaHoDari (assumed tropical:) Such a one is a person who speaks well of the absent. (S.)

miHoDaArN mHDAr
: see miHoDiyrN.

maHoDuwrN mHDwr
[pass. part. n. of HaDarahu]. [Hence,] All~abanu maHoDuwrN, (S, A, K,) and muHotaDarN↓, (S, A,) fagaT~i A_inaA='aka, (S,) (tropical:) Milk is much subject to taint, or much tainted; [lit.] come to [and tainted; i. e.,] by the jinn, or genii, (As, T, S, K,) and beasts, &c.; (As, T;) [therefore cover thou thy vessel.] And (in like manner [one says], K) Alkunufu maHoDuwrapN (assumed tropical:) [Privies are haunted by jinn, or genii]. (S, K.) It is said in a trad., A_in~a h`*ihi AlHu$uw$a muHotaDarapN↓ (assumed tropical:) [Verily these privies are haunted by jinn]. (TA.) And in another trad., A_in~ahaA ma$ohuwdapN maHoDuwrapN Verily it (the prayer of daybreak) is attended by the angels of the night and the day. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, (Msb,) and muHotaDarN↓, (Mgh, Msb,) (tropical:) At the point of death; in the agony of death: (Msb:) [visited by death; or by the angel, or angels, of
death: (see 1:)] or the latter, near to death. (Mgh.)

miHoDiyrN mHDyr
, applied to a horse, (S, A, K, &c.,) and to a mare, (S, M,) That runs much, or vehemently; syn. kaviyru AlEadowi, (S,) or $adiydu AlHuDori; (M;) as also miHoDaArN↓, applied without p to a mare; (M;) or this latter is not allowable; (S, K;) or is of weak authority: (K:) pl. [of both] maHaADiyru. (A.)

muHotaDarN mHtDr
: see maHoDuwrN, in three places. Also (assumed tropical:) A man afflicted by demoniacal possession, or insanity, or madness. (TA.) kul~u $irobK muHotaDarN, in the Kur liv. 28, Every share of the water shall be come unto in turn, means, the water shall be come to by the people on their day, and by the she-camel on her day: (Jel:) or it means, the people shall come to their shares of the water, and the she-camel shall come to her share thereof. (K.)

muHotaDirN mHtDr
: see HaADirN.

, (K,) aor.
HaDuna
, (TA,) inf. n. HaDonN and HiDaAnapN, He put the child in his HiDon [i. e. under his arm, or in his bosom]: or he nourished him, reared him, fostered him, brought him up, (K, TA,) and took care of him; (TA;) as also AHtDnhu↓. (K, TA.) And HaDanato waladahaA, (S, Mgh,) aor.
HaDuna
, (Mgh, TA,) inf. n. HiDaAnapN, (Mgh,) said of a woman, (S, Mgh, TA,) She put her child in her HiDon, and [thus] carried him [under her arm,] on one of her two sides: (TA:) it has a similar meaning to the phrase next following: (S:) or it means she had charge of her child, and carried him, and reared him, or fostered him. (Mgh.) ― -b2- HaDana bayoDahu, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and EalaY bayoDihi, (TA,) aor.
HaDuna
, (S, Msb,) inf. n. HaDonN (Mgh, Msb) and HiDaAnapN (Msb, K) and HiDaAnN and HuDuwnN, (K,) said of a bird, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) He pressed, or compressed, his eggs (S, Msb) to himself, (S,) beneath his wing, (S, Msb,) or beneath his two wings; (so in some copies of the S;) he sat upon his eggs, protecting them with his two sides (biHiDonayohi); (Mgh;) he brooded upon his eggs to hatch them: (K:) as also AHtDn↓. (KL.) ― -b3- HaDana bayoDapF taHota dajaAjapK lahu Hat~aY A^aforaxato, meaning He put an egg beneath a hen belonging to him, and made her to sit [or brood] upon it [until it became hatched], if remembered to have been heard [from any of the Arabs of pure speech], is a tropical usage of the verb, like as when one says ” The Emeer built the city: “ otherwise, it is correctly [HaD~ana↓,] with teshdeed. (Mgh.) ― -b4- HaDanahu Eano ka*aA, inf. n. HaDonN and HiDaAnapN, (tropical:) He made him to turn away, withdraw, or retire, from such a thing, and had it to himself exclusively; (S, K, TA;) as though he put him aside from it, or by its side: he excluded him from participation in it; in which sense minohu A^aHoDanahu↓ is disapproved: (TA:) he impeded him, or debarred him, from it. (ISd, TA.) It is related in a trad. of Ibn-Mes'ood that, when he made his will, he said, wa laA tuHoDanu zayonabu Eano *`lika, meaning (assumed tropical:) And Zeyneb (his wife) shall not be precluded from looking into that and executing it; namely, his will: or shall not be precluded from it, nor shall any matter [relating to it] be decided without her. (TA.) And you say also, HaDanahu Eano HaAjatihi He withheld him from the object of his want; as also AHtDnhu↓. (S, ISd, K.) And HaDana maEoruwfahu, (K,) and Hadiyvahu, (TA,) Eano jiyraAnihi, (K,) and maEaArifihi, (TA,) inf. n. HaDonN, (K,) (assumed tropical:) He turned his beneficence, (K, TA,) and his discourse, (TA,) from his neighbours, (K, TA,) and his acquaintances, to others: on the authority of Lh. (TA.) ＝ -A2- HaDanato, aor.
HaDuna
, inf. n. HiDaAnN, (K,) or this is a simple subst., (A 'Obeyd, TA,) She (a ewe [or goat], and a camel, and a woman,) had one of her teats, or breasts, larger than the other. (K.) [See HaDuwnN.]
