HamiymapN Hmym Hmymh Hmymp
: see HamiymN. ― -b2- Also Heated milk. (K.) ＝ -A2- Also, (S, K,) as well as Ham~N↓, (K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, Hum~,]) sing. of HamaAy^imu signifying (tropical:) Such as are held in high estimation, precious, or excellent, or the choice, or best, (S, K, TA,) of cattle or other property, (S,) or of camels: (K:) and accord. to Kr, the sing. is used as a pl. in this sense: (ISd, TA:) HamaAmapN↓, likewise, signifies the choice, or best, of cattle or other property; and so HaAm~apN↓, of camels: (K:) or you say A_ibilN HaAm~apN, meaning excellent, or choice, camels. (S.)

HumayomapN Hmym Hmymh Hmymp
; accord. to the K, HumayomaAtN, but this is the pl.; (TA;) A live coal; syn. jamorapN: (K, TA:) or redness; syn. HumorapN: (CK, and so in a MS. copy of the K:) [in Freytag's Lex., the pl. is explained as meaning redness of the skin; and so HumaAmaY↓.]

HumaAmaY HmAm HmAmY HmAmy
: see what next precedes.

HamaAmiY~N HmAm HmAmY HmAmy
One who flies pigeons (HamaAm), and sends them [as carriers of letters] to various towns or countries. (TA.)

Hum~Y Hm HmY Hmp Hmy
, (S, K, &c.,) a subst. from Hum~, (Lh, L, K,) imperfectly decl., because of the fem. alif [which terminates it], (Msb,) A fever; a disease by which the body becomes hot: from AlHamiymu: said to be so called because of the excessive heat; whence the trad., AlHum~aY mino fayoHi jahan~ama [Fever is from the exhalation of Hell]: or because of the sweat that occurs in it: or because it is of the signs of AlHimaAm [i. e. the decreed, or predestined, case of death]; for they say, AlHum~aY raAy^idu Almawoti [Fever is the messenger that precedes death], or bariydu Almawoti [the messenger of death], or baAbu Almawoti [the gate of death]: (TA:) and Hum~apN↓ signifies the same: (K, TA:) pl. of the former Hum~ayaAtN. (Msb.)

Hum~aA='u HmA='
: see HumaAmN.

Ham~aAmN HmAm
[A hot bath;] a certain structure, (S,) well known; (Msb;) so called because it occasions sweating, or because of the hot water that is in it; accord. to ISd, derived from AlHamiymu; (TA;) i. q. dayomaAsN: (K:) of the masc. gender, (Mgh, K,) and fem. also, (Mgh,) generally the latter; (Msb;) but some say that it is a mistake to make it fem., (MF, TA,) though IB cites a verse in which a fem. pronoun is asserted to refer to a Hm~Am: (TA:) pl. Ham~aAmaAtN; (S, Mgh, K;) accord. to Sb, [not because the sing. is fem., but] because, though masc., it has no broken pl. (TA.) See also HamiymN.

Ham~aAmiY~N HmAm HmAmY HmAmy
The owner [or keeper] of a Ham~aAm [or hot bath]. (Mgh.)

HumoHumN HmHm
: see A^aHam~u.

HimoHimN HmHm
: see A^aHam~u, in two places.

HaAm~apN HAm HAmh HAmp
The xaAS~ap [or particular, or special, friends, or familiars], (S, K,) consisting of the family and children (K) and relations, (TA,) of a man. (K.) You say, kayofa AlHaAm~apu waAlEaAm~apu [How are the particular, or special, friends, &c., and the common people?]. (S.) And h`w^ulaA='i HaAm~apu Alr~ajuli These are the relations of the man. (Lth, S.) [See Hum~apN, and A^aHm~u.] ― -b2- See also HamiymapN. ― -b3- Also
i. q. EaAm~apN. (K.) [It would seem that this signification might have been assigned to it in consequence of a misunderstanding of the words in the S, waAlHaAm~apu AlxaAS~apu yuqaAlu kayofa AlHaAm~apu waAlEaAm~apu: but accord. to the TK, one says, jaAw^uwA HaAm~apF, meaning EaAm~apF, i. e. They came generally, or universally.]

A=lu HaAmiyma A=l HAmym
and *awaAtu HaAmiyma, (K,) or A=lu H`m=↓ and *awaAtu H`m=, (S,) A=l being prefixed in this case in like manner as in A=lu fulaAnK, (Fr, S,) Certain chapters of the Kur-án (S, K) commencing with HAmym [or H`m=], (K,) [namely, the fortieth and six following chapters,] called by Ibn-Mes'ood diybaAju AlquroA=ni: (S:) one should not say HawaAmiym: (K:) this is vulgar: (S:) but it occurs in poetry. (S, K.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) accord. to I'Ab, H`m=↓ is One of the names of God; (Mgh;) or it is the most great name of God; (K;) occurring in a trad., in which it is said, A_ino buy~it~umo faquwluwA H`m= laA yanoSaruwna, meaning If ye be attacked by night, say ye H`m=; and when ye say this, they shall not be made victorious: (Mgh:) or the meaning is, [say ye] O God, they shall not be made victorious; not being an imprecation; for were it so, it would be laA yunoSaruwA: (IAth, TA:) or it is an oath; (Mgh, K;) and the meaning of the trad. is, [say ye] By God, they shall not be made victorious: but H`m= is not among the numbered names of God: it has therefore been deemed preferable to understand it as here meaning the seven chapters of the Kur-án commencing therewith: (Mgh:) or it is an abbreviation of Alr~aHom`nu, wanting the letters Alrn to complete it: (Zj, K:) or, as some say, it means [Hum~a maA huwa kaAy^inN, i. e.] quDiYa maAhuwa kaAy^inN [What is taking place has been decreed]. (Az, TA.) It is imperfectly decl. because determinate and of the fem. gender; or because it is of a foreign measure, like qaAbiylu and haAbiylu, (Ksh, Bd,) and determinate. (Ksh.)

A^aHam~u *
Black; (S, K;) applied to anything; as also yaHomuwmN↓, (K,) and HmiHimN↓, (As, K,) or this signifies intensely black, (S,) and HumoHumN↓, (K,) which IB explains as a black hue of dye: (TA:) [the fem. of the first is Ham~aA='u: and the pl. Hum~N: and] the pl. of ↓the second is yaHaAmiymu, and by poetic license yaHaAmimu. (Sb, TA.) You say, rajulN A^aHam~u A black man. (S.) And rajulN A^aHam~u Almuqolatayoni A man having black eyes. (TA.) And kumayotN A^aHam~u [A blackish bay horse]: pl. kumotN Hum~N; which are the strongest of horses in skin and hoofs. (S.) And $aApN HimoHimN↓ A black sheep or goat. (TA.) And layolN A^aHam~u Black night. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AlHam~aA='u The anus (saAfilap, S, or Aisot, K) of a human being: (S:) pl. Hum~N. (S, K.) ― -b3- And A^aHam~u An arrow before it has been furnished with feathers and a head; syn. qidoHN. (K.) ― -b4- Ham~aA='u applied to a lip ($afapN) and to a gum (livapN) means Of a colour between duhomapN and kumotapN. (M, TA. [See Hum~apN.]) ― -b5- Accord. to some, (TA,) A^aHam~u also signifies White: thus having two contr. meanings. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A more, or most, particular, or special, and beloved, friend or the like. (Az, TA. [See Hum~apN, and HamiymN, and HaAm~apN.])

muHim~N mHm
: see maHam~apN: ＝ -A2- and see also HamiymN.

miHam~N mHm
i. q. qumoqumapN: (Mgh, Msb;) i. e. A vessel of copper [or brass], in which water is heated, (KL, and Msb in art. qm,) having a long and narrow neck: (KL:) or a small qumoqum [here meaning the same as qumoqumap], in which water is heated. (S.)

maHam~apN mHm mHmh mHmp
, applied to food [&c.], (TA,) Any cause of fever; or a thing from the eating of which one is affected with fever: (K, * TA:) such, for instance, the eating of fresh ripe dates is said to be. (TA.) And A^aroDN maHam~apN (S, M, K) and muHim~apN↓, (M, K,) mentioned by AAF, but not known by the lexicologists except as agreeable with analogy, [see its verb, 4,] (M, TA,) A land in which is fever: (S, K:) or in which is much fever. (K.)

maHomuwmN mHmwm
Fevered, or affected with fever, or sick of a fever. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) ＝ -A2- Applied to water, like mavomuwdN [q. v.]. (Az, TA.) ＝ -A3- Decreed, or appointed. (S, TA.)

muHaAm~N mHAm mHAmy
Keeping constantly, firmly, steadily, steadfastly, or fixedly, EalaY A^amorK to an affair. (AZ, K. *)

musotaHam~N mstHm
, (TA,) or musotaHam~apN, (Mgh,) A place in which one washes with hot water. (Mgh, * TA.)

yaHomuwmN yHmwm
: see A^aHam~u, in two places. ― -b2- Also Smoke: (S, M, K:) or black smoke: (Bd in lvi. 42:) or intensely black smoke. (Jel ibid. and TA.) ― -b3- A black mountain: (K:) or a certain black mountain in Hell. (TA.) ― -b4- The canopy, or awning, that is extended over the people of Hell: so, as some say, in the Kur lvi. 42. (TA.) ― -b5- A certain bird: (K:) so called because of the blackness of its wings. (TA.) ― -b6- nabotN yaHomuwmN A plant, or herbage, green, full of moisture, and black. (TA.)

1 HamaA^a Albiy^ora *
, (S, K,) aor.
HamaAa
, (K,) inf. n. Hamo'N, (S,) He cleansed the well of its HamoA^ap [or black, fetid mud]. (S, K.) In the T, this signification is assigned to Alby^r AHmA^↓; and the signification assigned below to the latter is given to HmA^: but As says that he does not find this authorized by usage. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Hamiy^a, aor.
HamaAa
, inf. n. Hamo'N and HamaA^N, It (water) was, or became, mixed with black, fetid mud, and so rendered turbid, (K, TA,) and altered in odour. (TA.) And Hamiy^ati Albiy^oru, inf. n. HamaA^N, The well had in it black [fetid] mud (S, Msb) in abundance: (S:) and the like is also said of a spring. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Hamiy^a Ealayohi He was angry with him; (El-Umawee, S, K;) as also HamiYa. (Lh, TA.)

4 AHmA^ Albiy^ora *
, (ISk, S, K,) inf. n. A_iHomaA='N, (ISk, S,) He threw HamoA^ap [or black, fetid mud] into the well. (ISk, S, K.) ― -b2- See also 1.

Hamo'N Hm'
and HamN and Hamuw [only used as a prefixed n. governing the gen. case (see HamN in art. Hmw)] and HamFA (S, Msb, K) and HamaA^N↓ (K) A woman's husband's father; (IF, Msb, K;) and a man's wife's father: (IF, Msb:) or a man's wife's father or wife's brother or wife's paternal uncle: (M, Msb:) or any one of a woman's husband's [male] relations, (S, O, K,) as the brother and the father (S, O) and the paternal uncle; (O, TA;) and of a man's wife's relations: (K:) pl. A^aHomaA='N: (S, K:) the fem. is HamaAopN. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also HamoA^apN.

HamaA^N *
: see Hamo'N: ＝ -A2- and see also what next follows.

HamoA^apN *
(S, Msb, K) and HamaA^N↓, (S, K,) but accord. to some, the latter is the pl. [or rather quasipl. n.] of the former; and sometimes, by poetic license, it is written Hamo'N↓; (TA;) Black mud: (S, Msb:) or black fetid mud. (K.) ＝ -A2- Also, the former, A certain plant, (K,) that grows in Nejd, in the sands, and in plain, or soft, land. (TA.)

Hamiy^u AlEayoni *
A man of an evil eye, (Fr, K,) who injures with his eye him whom he sees and admires: no verb belonging to it has been heard. (Fr, TA.) ＝ -A2- Hamiy^apN A well (biy^or) or a spring (Eayon) foul with black, fetid mud. (TA.)

1 Hamidahu Hmd Hmdh Hmdp
, aor.
Hamada
, inf. n. HamodN (S, L, Msb, K) and maHomadN and maHomidN (L, K) and maHomadapN (S, L, K) and maHomidapN; (L, K, and so in a copy of the S;) the last of these inf. ns. [and the third also] extr.; (L;) or the last is an inf. n. and the last but one signifies “ a praiseworthy quality, ” or “ a quality for which one is praised; ” (ElFenáree, MF;) or the last may be a simple subst.; (Har p. 392;) He praised, eulogized, or commended, him; spoke well of him; mentioned him with approbation; (Akh, S, L, Msb;) EalaY ka*aA for such a thing; (L, Msb;) contr. of *am~ahu: (S, L:) accord. to IAmb, formed by transposition from madaHa: (marginal note in a copy of the MS:) but it is of less common application than the latter verb; (Msb in art. mdH;) signifying he praised him, &c., for something depending on his (the latter's) own will: thus, the describing a pearl as clear is not HamodN, but it is madoHN: (Kull p. 150:) or i. q. $akarahu: (Lh, K:) but it differs [sometimes] from this; (Msb;) for $ukorN is only on account of favour received; whereas HamodN is sometimes because of favour received, (Th, Az, Msb,) and sometimes from other causes; (Th;) [and thus] the latter is of more common application than the former; (S;) therefore you do not say, $akarotuhu EalaY $ajaAEatihi; but you say, Hamidotuhu ElY $jAEth I praised him, &c., for his courage. (Msb.) Hmd also implies admiration: and it implies the magnifying, or honouring, of the object thereof; and lowliness, humility, or submissiveness, in the person who offers it; as in the saying of the afflicted, AlHamodu lil~`hi Praise be to God; since in this case there is no worldly blessing, favour, or
benefit. (Msb.) This last phrase is generally pronounced as it is written above: but some of the Arabs are related to have pronounced it AlHamoda lil~`hi, putting the former word in the accus. case as the absolute complement of the verb A^aHomadu understood: and others, AlHamodilil~`hi; assimilating the final vowel of the former word to the vowel immediately following it: and others, AlHamodu lul~`hi; assimilating the first vowel in ll~`h to the vowel immediately preceding it: Zj, however, disapproves of the latter two modes of pronouncing it: some of them also said, badaA^otu biAlHamodu lil~`hi, meaning I began with the saying Praise be to God. (L.) [See also HamodN below.] You say, A^aHomadu A_ilayoka A@ll~`ha I praise God (Az, A, * L, K) to thee, or in thy presence: (L:) or with thee: (Kh, Az:) or I praise to thee God's benefits, and his blessings, or favours; or I praise to thee God's blessings, or favours, and discourse to thee of them. (L.) And Hamida lahu A^amorFA (tropical:) He approved of a thing for him. (L, K. *) And Hamida A_ilayohi A^amorFA (tropical:) He approved of a thing for him, and commanded, or enjoined, him to do it. (L.) And jAwarotuhu famaA Hamidotu jiwaArahu (tropical:) [I became his neighbour, and did not approve of being so]. (A.) See also 4. ― -b2- Also, (aor. and inf. n. as above in the beginning of this art., K,) He recompensed, or requited, him: he gave him, or paid him, his due. (L, K.) ＝ -A2- Hamida Ealayohi, aor.
Hamada
, (L, K, *) inf. n. HamadN, (TA,) He was angry with him. (L, K.)

2 Hm~d Hmd
, inf. n. taHomiydN, has a more intensive signification than Hamda; (S;) [He declared the praises of God: or] he praised God much, with good forms of praise (biAlmaHaAmidi AlHasanapi): (T, L:) or repeatedly; or time after time. (L, K.) tHmyd [used as a simple subst.] has a pl., namely, taHaAmiydu. (A.) [See an ex. voce xaAtamN, in the latter part of the paragraph.]

4 AHmd AHmd A^Hmd Hmd
He (a man, S) came to a state, or result, such as was praised, or commended, or approved; properly, his affair, or case, came to such a state or result: (S, L, K:) or (so in the K, but in the L “ and ”) he did, or said, that for which he should be praised, or commended; or that which was praiseworthy, or commendable; (A, L, K; *) contr. of A^a*am~a. (A.) And AHmd A^amoruhu (assumed tropical:) His affair, or case, was, or became, praiseworthy, or approvable, in his estimation: (K:) or AHmd A^amorahu (as in the L) he esteemed his affair, or case, praiseworthy, or approvable. (L [agreeably with what next follows].) ＝ -A2- AHmdhu He found him (a man, A, L) [or it] to be such as is praised, commended, or approved; or praiseworthy, commendable, or approvable; (S, A, L, Msb;) contr. of A^a*am~ahu: (TA in art. *m:) he made it manifest that he was worthy of praise, eulogy, commendation, or approbation: (L:) he approved of his action, and his course of conduct, or his tenet or tenets, and did not expose it, or them, to others. (K.) And A^aHomadotu SaniyEahu (tropical:) [I found his action to be praiseworthy, or commendable, or approvable]. (A.) And AHmd AlA^aroDa (tropical:) He approved the land as a dwelling-place: (A:) or he found the land to be such as is praised, commended, or approved; as also HamidahaA↓; (L, K;) but the former verb is the more chaste in this sense. (L.) And AHmd mawoDiEFA (tropical:) He found a place to be such as is praised, commended, or approved, and convenient, or suitable, so that he approved it as a dwelling-place, or for its pasture. (S, L.)

5 tHm~d Hmd tHmd
He affected, or made a show of, (takal~afa,) praise. (A.) You say, wajadotuhu mutaHam~idFA↓ muta$ak~irFA [I found him affecting, or making a show of, praise and thanks]. (A.) ― -b2- He praised himself. (KL.) [Golius assigns this meaning to AHtmd↓, as on the authority of the KL; but it is not assigned to this verb in my copy of the KL.] ― -b3- fulaAnN yataHam~adu Aln~As [app. a slight mistranscription, for liln~aAsi, i. q. A_ilaY Aln~aAsi, as in an ex. in the next sentence but one,] Such a one pretends to men, or shows them, that he is praiseworthy, bijuwdihi for his liberality. (L.) ― -b4- tHm~d Ealayohi He reproached him for a favour, or benefit, which he (the former) had bestowed, or conferred; or recounted his gifts, or actions, to him; syn. Aimotan~a. (S, L, K.) One says, mano A^anofaqa maAlahu EalaY nafosihi falaA yataHam~ado bihi EalaY Aln~aAsi [Whoso expends his property upon himself, he shall not reproach men therewith as for favours, or benefits, bestowed]: (S, A:) or flA ytHm~d bih A_ilaY Aln~aAsi [he shall not pretend to men that he is praiseworthy on account of it]: a prov., meaning that a man is not praised for his beneficence to himself, but for his beneficence to others. (L.)

6 tHAmdwA tHAmdwA
(tropical:) [They praised, or commended, a thing, one to another]. You say, Alr~uEaA='u yataHaAmaduwna AlkalaA^a (tropical:) [The pastors praise, or commend, one to another, the herbage]. (A.)

8 AHtmd AHtmd
: see 5. ＝ -A2- Said of heat, [It burned, or burned fiercely; or was, or became, vehement:] formed by transposition from AHtdm. (S.)

entry.key: AisotaHomidi A@ll~`ha A_ilaY xaloqihi biA_iHosaAnihi A_ilayohimo wA_inoEaAmihi

superEntry.entry:
10 AisotaHomidi A@ll~`ha A_ilaY xaloqihi biA_iHosaAnihi A_ilayohimo wA_inoEaAmihi *
Ealayohimo [so I find it written, as though meaning Demand thou, of his creatures, the praising of God, by reason of his beneficence to them, and his bounty to them: but I think that we should read AisotaHomada A@ll~`hu, and that the meaning is, God hath demanded praise of his creatures by his beneficence, &c.]. (A.)

HamodN Hmd
Praise, eulogy, or commendation; &c. (S, &c. [For further explanations of this word, and respecting the phrase AlHamodu lil~`hi and its variations, see 1: and see also $akara.]) suboHaAnaka A@ll~`hum~a wabiHamodika, said by a person praying, means [I extol, or celebrate, or declare, thy remoteness, or freedom, from every impurity, or imperfection, &c., O God, (see art. sbH,)] and I begin with praising Thee; A^abotadiy^u being understood: (Az, L, Msb:) or by bHmdk is meant AlHamodu laka praise be to Thee: and nearly the same is said in explanation of the phrase in the Kur [ii. 28], nusab~iHu biHamodika, that by bHmdk is meant HaAmidiyna laka: [see, again, art. sbH:] or by the expression wbHmdk is meant, accord. to Aboo-'Othmán ElMázinee, and by praising Thee I extol thy remoteness, or freedom, from every impurity, &c.; sab~aHotuka being understood: or the w is redundant, as it is in the phrase, rab~anaAwalaka AlHamodu [O our Lord, praise be to Thee], in which the w is sometimes omitted: or, accord. to Aboo-'Amr Ibn-El-'Alà, the w is corroborative, as in the phrase, wahuwa laka, for huwa laka. (Msb.) liwaA='u AlHamodi biyadiY yawoma AlqiyaAmapi [The standard of praise shall be in my hand on the day of resurrection (said by Mohammad)] means that he shall be singularly distinguished by praise, or praising, on that day. (L.) ― -b2- See HamaAdi: ― -b3- and HumaAdaAka. ＝ -A2- See also HamiydN. ＝ -A3- It is also said to signify The young one of the kind of bird called qaTFA: so in the prov.,
Hmodu qaTaApK yasotamiY AlA^araAniba
A young one of a katà desires to make the hares its prey: applied to a weak man who desires to insnare a strong one. (Meyd, TA.) ＝ -A4- See also what next follows.

HamadapN Hmd Hmdh Hmdp
The sound of the flaming, or blazing, of fire; (S, K;) as also HadamapN [from which it is formed by transposition: see 8: and HamodN↓ app. signifies the same: see HadomN]. (TA.)

HumadapN Hmd Hmdh Hmdp
: see Ham~aAdN.

HamaAdi lahu HmAd lh HmAd lp
Praise, and thanks, be to him: (S, L, K:) i. e., to such a one: (S, L:) contr. of jamaAdi lahu [q. v.]. (S and A in art. jmd.) HamaAdi is indecl., with kesr for its termination, because it deviates from its original, which is the inf. n. [AlHamodu↓]: (S, L:) [i. e.,] it is [a quasi-inf. n., (see Aisomu maSodarK in art. Sdr,) being] a proper name for AlmaHomadapu [as syn. with AlHamodu]. (Sharh Shudhoor edh-Dhahab.)

HamuwdN Hmwd
: see what next follows.

HamiydN Hmyd
and maHomuwdN↓ (S, A, L, K) and HamuwdN↓ (as in copies of the K, but this seems to be an intensive epithet,) Praised, eulogized, or commended; spoken well of; mentioned with approbation; approved; such as is praised, &c.; praiseworthy, laudable; commendable, or approvable: (S, L, K: [in which, as well as in numberless exs., all these significations are clearly indicated, though not so clearly explained; the Arabic words to which they apply exactly agreeing with the Latin “ laudatus, ” which means both “ praised ” and “ praiseworthy: ”]) the fem. of the first is with p, (L, K,) because the signification, though properly that of a pass. part. n., nearly agrees with that of an act. part. n.: (L:) you say, [hiYa HamiydapN She is praised, &c.; and] A^afoEaAluhu HamiydapN (tropical:) [His actions are praised, &c.]. (A.) HamodN↓, also, [originally an inf. n., like its contr. *am~N,] used as an epithet applied to a man, is syn. with maHomuwdN; (K;) and as an epithet applied to a woman, syn. with maHomuwdapN, (TA,) as is also HamodapN: (K, TA:) and you likewise say manozilN HamodN (K) and manozilahN HamodapN (Lh) (assumed tropical:) A place where one alights, sojourns, or abides, such as is praised, or approved, (K, TA,) and convenient, or suitable.
(TA.) AlHamiydu, meaning He who is praised, or praiseworthy, in every case, is an epithet applied to God; one of the names termed AlA^asomaA='u AlHusonaY. (L.) AlmaqaAmu AlmaHomuwdu↓ [mentioned in the Kur xvii. 81] means (assumed tropical:) The station in which its occupant shall be praised by all creatures [on the day of resurrection] because of his being quickly reckoned with, and relieved from long standing: or it is the station of the intercessor. (L.)

HumaAdaAka A^ano tafoEala ka*aA *
(S, L, K *) and Hamoduka↓ (L) The utmost of thy power, or of thine ability, [or the utmost of thy praiseworthy actions, (see an ex. of the pl. in what follows,) will be] thy doing such a thing; syn. mabolagu jahodika, (L,) or quSaAraAka, (S, L,) and gaAyatuka: (S, L, K:) and in like manner, HumaAdiY The utmost of my power, &c. (K.) HumaAdayaAtu Aln~isaA='i gaD~u AlT~arofi, said by Umm-Selemeh, means The utmost of the praiseworthy qualities of women is the lowering of the eye. (L.)

Ham~aAdN HmAd

A^aHomaru *
[Red: and also brown, or the like:] a thing of the colour termed HumorapN: (Msb, K:) it is in animals, and in garments &c.; and, accord. to IAar, in water [when muddy]: and so yaHomuwrN↓: (K:) fem. of the former HamoraA='u: (Msb:) pl. HumorN and HumoraAnN: (K:) or when it means dyed with the colour termed HumorapN, the pl. is HumorN (S, Msb) and HumoraAnN; for you say viyaAbN HumorN and HumoraAnN [red garments]: (TA:) but if you apply it as an epithet to a man, [in which case it has other meanings than those explained above, as will be shown in what follows,] the pl. is A^aHaAmiru (S) and HumorN: (TA:) or if it means a thing having the colour termed HumorapN, the pl. is A^aHaAmiru, because, in this case, it is a subst., not an epithet. (Msb.) A^aHomariY~N↓ also signifies the same as A^aHomaru: (Ham p. 379:) or, as some say, it has an intensive sense. (TA voce karuwbiy~uwna.) It is said in the S, in art. dk, that HamoraAwaAtN is a pl. of HamoraA='u, like as dak~aAwaAtN, is of dak~aA='u; but it is not so. (IB in that art.) ― -b2- Applied to a camel, Of a colour like that of saffron when a garment is dyed with it so that it stands up by reason of [the thickness of] the dye: (TA:) or of an unmixed red colour; (As, S in art. kmt, and TA;) and so the fem. when applied to a she-goat. (TA.) It is said that, of she-camels, the HamoraA=' is the most able to endure the summer midday-heat; and the waroqaA=', to endure nightjourneying; and that the SahobaA=' is the most notable and the most beautiful to look at: so said Aboo-Nasr En-Na'ámee: and the Arabs say that the best of camels are the Humor and the Suhob. (TA.) [Hence,] Humoru Aln~aEami signifies (assumed tropical:) The high-bred, or excellent, of camels: and is proverbially applied to
anything highly prized, precious, valuable, or excellent. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b3- Applied to a man, (AA, Sh, Az,) White (AA, Sh, Az, K) in complexion; (Az;) because A^aboyaDu might be considered as of evil omen [implying the meaning of leprosy]: (AA, Sh:) or, accord. to Th, because the latter epithet, applied to a man, was only used by the Arabs as signifying “ pure, ” or “ free from faults: ” but they sometimes used this latter epithet in the sense of “ white in complexion, ” applied to a man &c.: (IAth:) fem., in the same sense, HamoraA='u: the dim. of which, HumayoraA='u↓, occurs in a trad., applied to 'Áïsheh. (K, * TA.) So, accord. to some, in the trad., buEivotu A_ilaY AlA^aHomari waAlA^asowadi, (TA,) i. e. I have been sent to the white and the black; because these two epithets comprise all mankind: (Az, TA:) [therefore, by the former we should understand the white and the red races; and by the latter, the negroes: but some hold that by the former are meant the foreigners, and] by the latter are meant the Arabs. (TA.) One says also, [when speaking of Arabs and more northern races,] A^ataAniY kul~u A^asowada minohumo waA^aHomara, meaning Every Arab of them, and foreigner, came to me: and one should not say, in this sense, A^aboyaDa. (AA, As, S.) AlHamoraA='u, also, is applied to The foreigners (AlEajamu) [collectively]; (S, A, K;) because a reddish white is the prevailing hue of their complexion: (S:) or the Persians and Greeks: or those foreigners mostly characterized by whiteness of complexion; as the Greeks and Persians. (TA.) You say, layosa fiY AlHamoraA='i mivoluhu There is not among the foreigners (AlEajam) the like of him. (A.) And accord. to some, AlA^aHomaru waAlA^aboyaDu means The Arabs and the foreigners. (TA.) AlHamoraA='u [so in the TA, but correctly A^abonaA='u AlHamoraA='i,] is an appellation applied to Emancipated slaves: and Aibonu HamoraA='i AlEijaAni, meaning Son of the female slave, is an appellation used in reviling and blaming. (TA.) ― -b4- Also (tropical:) A man having no weapons with him: pl. HumorN (A, K) and HumoraAnN. (K.) ― -b5- AlHusonu A^aHomaru means Beauty is in AlHumorap [app. fairness of complexion; i. e. beauty is fair-complexioned]: (TA:) or (assumed tropical:) beauty is attended by difficulty; i. e. he who loves beauty must bear difficulty, or distress: (IAth:) or the lover experiences from beauty what is experienced from war. (ISd, K.) ― -b6- AlA^aHomaru A sort of dates: (K:) so called because of their colour. (TA.) ― -b7- AlA^aHomaru waAlA^aboyaDu Gold and silver. (TA.) And AlA^aHomaraAni Flesh-meat and wine; (S, A, K;) said to destroy men: (S:) so in the saying, naHonu mino A^aholi AlA^asowadayoni laA AlA^aHomarayoni We are of the people of dates and water, not of flesh-meat and wine: (A:) or the beverage called nabiy* and flesh-meat. (IAar.) Also Wine and [garments of the kind called] buruwd. (Sh.) And Gold and saffron; (Az, ISd, K;) said to destroy women; i. e. the love of ornaments and perfumes destroys them: (Az:) or these are called AlA^aSofaraAni; (AO, TA;) and milk and water, AlA^aboyaDaAni; (TA;) and dates and water, AlA^asowadaAni. (A, TA.) And AlA^aHaAmirapu Flesh-meat and wine and [the perfume called] Alxaluwq: (S, K:) or gold and flesh-meat and wine; as also AlA^axaADiru: (TA in art. xDr:) or gold and saffron and Alxaluwq. (ISd, TA.) ― -b8- Almawotu AlA^aHomaru (assumed tropical:) Slaughter; (L, K;) because it occasions the flowing of blood: (TA:) and [so in the L, but in the K “ or ”] (tropical:) violent death: (S, A, L, K:) or death in which the sight of the man becomes dim by reason of terror, so that the world appears red and black before his eyes: (A 'Obeyd:) or it may mean (assumed tropical:) recent, fresh, death; from the phrase next following. (As.) ― -b9- waToA^apN HamoraA='u (tropical:) A new, or recent, footstep, or footprint: opposed to dahomaA='u. (As, S, A.) ― -b10- sanapN HamoraA='u (tropical:) A severe year; (S, K;) because it is a mean between the sawodaA=' and the bayoDA=': or a year of severe drought; because, in such a year, the tracts of the horizon are red: (TA:) when Aljabohapu [the tenth Mansion of the Moon (see manaAzilu Alqamari in art. nzl)] breaks its promise [of bringing rain], the year is such as is thus called. (AHn.) ― -b11- See also HamoraA='u voce HamaAr~apN. ― -b12- jaA='a biganamihi Humora AlkulaY, and, in like manner, suwda AlbuTuwni, (tropical:) He brought his sheep or goats, in a lean, or an emaciated, state. (A, * TA.)

Hamila
, inf. n. HamolN, a phrase often used in lexicology and grammar, (assumed tropical:) He made, or held, a word, or an expression, to accord in form, or in meaning, or syntactically, with another word, or expression. One says, yuHomalu EalaY AlA^akovari (assumed tropical:) It (a word) is made to accord in form with those words with which it may be compared that constitute the greater number: thus one says of raHomaAnu, which is made to accord in form with words of the measure faEolaAnu, though it has not a fem. of the measure faEolaY, in preference to faEolaAnN, because words of the measure faEolaAnu are more numerous than those of the measure faEolaAnN. And yuHomalu EalaY naqiyDihi (assumed tropical:) It (a word) is made to accord in form with its contrary in meaning: thus EijaAfN, an anomalous pl. of A^aEoHafu, is made to accord. in form with simaAnN, a regular pl. of samiynN. And yaHmalu EalaY AlmaEonaY (assumed tropical:) It (a word) is made to accord syntactically with its meaning: and yuHomalu EalaY All~afoZi (assumed tropical:) It is made to accord syntactically with its grammatical character: the former is said when, in a sentence, we make a mase. word fem., and the contrary, because the meaning allows us to substitute a fem. syn. for the masc. word, and a masc. syn. for the fem. word: for ex., it is said in the Kur vi. 78, falam~aA raA^aY Al$~amosa baAzigapF qaAla h`*aA rab~iY “ And when he saw the sun rising, he said, This is my Lord: ” here (by saying bAzgp) Al$ms is first made to accord syntactically with its grammatical character (tuHomalu EalaY All~afoZi); and then (by saying h`*aA instead of h`*ihi) it is made to accord syntactically with its meaning (tuHomalu EalaY AlmaEonaY), which is Aljirom or the like: this is allowable; but the reverse in respect of order is of weak authority; because the meaning is of more importance than the grammatical character of the word. (Collected from the Kull pp. 156 and 157, and other works.)] ― -b21- Hamalahu A^aHosana maHoyalK (assumed tropical:) [He put the best construction upon it; namely, a saying: mHml being here an inf. n.]. (TA.) ― -b2- Applied to a woman, (tropical:) Pregnant; (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.;) as also HaAmilapN: (S, Msb, K:) the former as being an epithet exclusively applied to a female: the latter as conformable to its verb, which is Hamalato; (S, Msb;) or as being used in a tropical [or doubly tropical] manner, meaning pregnant in past time or in future time; (Msb;) or as a possessive epithet [meaning having a burden in the womb]: (TA:) [see an ex. of the latter in a verse cited in the first paragraph of art. mxS:] accord. to the Koofees, the former, not being applied to a male, has no need of the sign of the fem. gender: but the Basrees say that this [rule] does not uniformly obtain; for the Arabs say rajulN A^ay~imN and AimoraA^apN A^ay~imN, and rajulN EaAnisN and AimoraA^apN EaAnisN; and that, correctly speaking, HaAmilN and TaAliqN and HaAy^iDN and the like are epithets masc. in form applied to females, like as raboEapN and raAwiyapN and xujaA^apN are epithets fem. in form applied to males. (S.) It is also applied to a she-camel [and app. to any female] in the same sense. (Mgh.) ― -b3- Applied to trees ($ajarN), (assumed tropical:) Bearing fruit: (TA:) fem. with p. (K.) ― -b4- See also HamiylN. ― -b5- [Respecting this epithet, and the phrases HaAmilu AlA^amaAnapi and muHotamilu AlA^amaAnapi, see also A^amaAnapN, last sentence but one.] ― -b6- Hamalapu AlquraA=ni (assumed tropical:) [Those who bear in their memory the Kur-án, knowing it by heart]. (S, TA.)

fem. of HaAmilN [q. v.]. (S, Msb.) ― -b2-
HawaAmilu is its pl.: and signifies The legs; (M, K;) because they bear the man. (TA.) ― -b3- And The sinews, or tendons, of the foot and of the fore arm; (M, K;) and the [veins called the] rawaAhi$ thereof. (M, TA. [See Alwariydu.]) ― -b4- See also maHomilN.

maHomilN mHml
[of which the primary signification is A place of bearing or carrying], (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) or miHomalN↓ [which primarily signifies An instrument for bearing or carrying], (M, Mgh,) or the latter is allowable, (Msb,) The [kind of vehicle called] hawodaj; (Msb;) as also HimolN↓: (M, K:) or the large hwdj termed Haj~aAjiY~N: (Mgh:) or a pair of dorsers, or panniers, or oblong chests, ($iq~aAni,) upon a camel, in which are borne two equal loads, (K,) [and which, with a small tent over them, compose a hwdj;] first made use of by El-Hajjáj Ibn-Yoosuf Eth-Thakafee: (TA:) one of the maHaAmil of the pilgrims: (S:) maHaAmilu being the pl. (K.) Hence, maHaAmiliY~N↓ A seller of maHaAmil. (K.) [What is now particularly termed the mHml (vulgarly pronounced maHomal) of the pilgrims is an ornamented hwdj, which is borne by a camel, but without a rider, and is regarded as the royal banner of the caravan; such as is described and figured in my work on the Modern Egyptians. (See also maHaArapN, in art. Hwr.)] Its application to (tropical:) The camel that bears the mHml is tropical. (Mgh.) [See also HimolN. The assertion that it signifies also the silk covering that is sent every year for the Kaabeh is erroneous. This covering is sent from Cairo, with the baggage of the chief of the Egyptian pilgrim-caravan.] ― -b2- Also maHomilN, (K,) or miHomalN↓, (M,) A basket (zinobiyl) in which grapes are carried to the place where they are to be dried; and so HaAmilapN↓. (K.) ― -b3- One says also, maA EalaY fulaAnK maHomilN (assumed tropical:) There is no ground of reliance upon such a one; syn. muEotamadN: (S:) or no relying, or reliance: (MA:) or no ground (lit. place) for imposing upon such a one the accomplishment of one's wants. (M, TA.) And maA EalaY AlbaEiyri maHomilN mino viqali AlHimoli (assumed tropical:) [There is no ground of reliance, or no relying, upon the camel, by reason of the heaviness of the load.] (TA.)

muHomilN mHml
A woman, (S, M, K,) and a she-camel, (S, M,) who yields her milk without being pregnant. (S, M, K.)

: see maHomilN, in two places. ― -b2- The EilaAqap of a sword (S, Msb, * K) &c.; (Msb;) i. e. its suspensory thong [or cord or shoulder-belt], by which the wearer hangs it upon his neck; (S, TA;) as also HimaAlapN↓ (S, Msb, K) and HamiylapN↓: (IDrd, K:) and the HimaAlap↓ of the bow is similar to that of the sword: the wearer throws it upon his right shoulder, and puts forth his left arm from it, so that the bow is on his back: (AHn, TA:) the pl. of miHomalN is maHaAmilu: (Az, Msb:) and that of HimaAlapN, (S, Msb,) or of HamiylapN, (Kh, TA,) is HamaAy^ilu↓; (Kh, S, TA;) or, accord. to As, HamaAy^ilu has no proper sing., its sing. being only miHomalN. (S.) ― -b4- maHaAmilu Al*~akari and HamaAy^iluhu↓ (assumed tropical:) The veins in the root and skin of the penis. (M, K.)

, (S, K,) inf. n. HamolaqapN, (Har p. 273,) said of a man, (S, TA,) and of a lion, (TA,) He opened his eyes, and looked hard: (S, K:) or he opened his eyes: and Hmlq A_ilayohi He looked at him, or it: or he looked hard at him, or it. (TA.)

, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) like A^abN, originally HamawN, as is shown by its pl., which see below, (S,) and HamFA↓, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and Hamuw↓, (S, Msb, K,) like A^abuw, (S, Msb,) used only as a prefixed n. governing the gen. case, except in poetry, (S, TA,) and HamowN↓, (K,) and Hamo'N [mentioned in art. HmA^, as well as HamaA^N], (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) A woman's husband's [male] relation, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) whoever he be, (S, Msb,) such as his father, (S, Msb, K,) and brother, (S, Msb.) and paternal uncle, (Msb,) &c.: (TA:) the fem. is HamaApN↓, (K,) signifying a woman's husband's mother; and having no dial. var.: (S, Msb:) and the pl. is A^aHomaA='N: (S, Mgh, K:) and Alr~ajuli Hamuw↓, (M, Msb,) or Alr~ajuli Hamowu↓, (K,) signifies the man's wife's father, (IF, M, Msb, K,) or wife's brother, or wife's paternal uncle; (M, Msb, K;) so that Hmw applies to a relation on either side, like SihorN: (Msb:) and A^aHomaA='N means a husband's people: (Mgh:) or the A^aHomaA=' are peculiarly of the wife; (K;) and the A^axotaAn are of the man [or husband]: (TA:) or [in other words] the AHyA=' are [the woman's relations] on the side of the husband; (As, TA;) and the AxtAn are [the husband's relations] on the side of the wife; (As, S, Msb, TA;) and those of both sides are included by the term [A^aSohaArN, pl. of] SihorN: (As, S, TA:) and A^aHomaA='u fulaAnapa is said to mean such a woman's husband's people. HamiYa
, (K,) inf. n. HimaAyapN (S, Mgh, K [but said in the Msb to be a simple subst., though afterwards there mentioned as an inf. n.,]) and HamoYN and maHomiyapN, (K,) He prohibited it, or interdicted it; or he protected it, defended it, or guarded it, from, or against, encroachment, invasion, or attack. (S, * Mgh, K, * TA.) You say, HamaY AlkalaA^a, inf. n. HamoYN and Hamiy~apN and HimaAyapN and HamowapN, [the last irreg.,] He prohibited, or interdicted, &c., the herbage, or pasture. (K, * TA.) And HamaY AlmakaAna mina Aln~aAsi, aor.
HamiYa
, inf. n. HamoYN and HimoyapN [and HimaAyapN, though here, in the Msb, said to be a simple subst.], He prohibited, or interdicted, the place; or he protected, defended, or guarded, it; from the people [in general]: (Msb:) and, accord. to IB, AHmAhu↓ signifies the same as HamaAhu: (TA:) or AlmkAn AHmY↓ signifies he made the place to be what is termed HimFY, (S, Msb, K,) not to be approached (Msb, K) nor ventured upon, or attempted: (Msb:) or it signifies, (K,) or signifies also, (Msb,) he found it to be what is termed HimFY: (Msb, K:) or AlHimaY AHmY↓ signifies he made the HmY to be refrained from by people, and to be acknowledged as a HmY: and HamaAhu, he prohibited, or interdicted, it; or he protected it, defended it, or guarded it, from, or against, encroachment, invasion, or attack: (AZ:) accord. to Suh, in the R, AHmAhu↓ is of weak authority; but both these verbs are chaste. (TA.) [Hence,] HamaY Zahorahu [He prohibited, or interdicted, his back to be used for bearing a rider or any burden], said of a stallion-camel when he is termed HaAmK, q. v. (Fr, S, K.) You say also, HamaAhu mina Al$~aYo'i and HamaAhu Al$~aYo'a [He protected, defended, or guarded, him from the thing]. (TA.) And Eanohu HaAmayotu↓, inf. n. muHaAmaApN and HimaA='N, (S, K,) I protected, defended, or guarded, him. (K.) One says, Eano waladihaA AlD~aruwsu tuHaAmiY↓ [The biting she-camel defends her offspring]. (S.) And fulaAnN EiroDahu AHmY↓ [Such a one defended his honour, or reputation]. (TA.) And Hamayotu Alqawoma, inf. n. HimaAyapN, I aided [and defended] the people, or party. (Msb.) And Hamayotu AlmariyDa (S, Msb, K) AlT~aEaAma, (S,) or maA yaDur~uhu, (K,) inf. n. HimoyapN (S, Msb) and HimowapN, (S, TA,) [the latter irreg.,] I prohibited, or interdicted, the sick man, (K,) or ordered him to abstain, (PS,) from the food, (PS,) or from what would injure him. (K.) ＝ -A2- HamiYa, said of the day, and of an oven, (S,) and Hamiyato, said of the sun, and of fire, aor.
HamaYa
, (K,) inf. n. HamoYN (S, K) and HumiY~N (K) and Humuw~N [originally HumuwYN], (Lh, K,) It was, or became, vehemently hot. (S, K.) And HamiYa AlmisomaAru, inf. n. HamoYN and Humuw~N, The iron nail was, or became, hot. (K.) And Hamiyati AlHadiydapu The piece of iron was, or became, vehemently hot by means of fire. (Msb.) ― -b2- HamiYa AlwaTiysu [lit. The oven became vehemently hot;] means (assumed tropical:) the war, or fight, became vehement; (S and K in art. wTs;) and is used as a prov., relating to a severe case or event. (As, TA in that art.) ― -b3- HamiYa Alfarasu, inf. n. HimFY [and app., accord. to the TA, HamoYN also], The horse was, or became, hot, and sweated. (K.) ― -b4- Hamiytu fiY AlgaDabi [I was, or became, hot in anger], inf. n. HamiY~N. (Lh, TA.) And gaDabFA AHtmY↓ [He became hot by reason of anger]. (A in art. lgd.) And Hamiytu Ealayohi, accord. to El-Umawee, [Hamiy^otu,] with hemz, I was, or became, angry with him. (S, TA.) And HamiYa A^anofuhu He became vehemently angry, or enraged. (IAth, TA in art. Anf.) And HamiYa Eanohu, (S,) or minohu, (K,) or both, (TA,) aor.
HamaYa
, (K,) inf. n. Hamiy~apN (S, Mgh, * Msb, * K) and maHomiyapN, (S, Mgh, * K,) i. q. A^anifa [He disdained it; scorned it; &c.]; (S, Mgh, * Msb, * K;) he was ashamed, and he disdained, or scorned, to do it. (S, TA.) And HamiYa mino *`lika A^anofFA He was seized, or affected, thereat, or by reason of that, with disdain, scorn, or indignation. (TA, from a trad.) And HamiYa also signifies He refused to bear, endure, or tolerate, wrongful treatment. (TA.) ＝ -A3- See also 4.

HimFY Hm HmY Hmp Hmy
A thing prohibited, or interdicted; (S, K;) as also HimaA='N↓ and HimoyapN↓; (K;) and not to be approached: (S:) [and, as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant,] a place of herbage, or pasture, (Lth, Mgh, Msb, * TA, and Ham p. 539,) and of water, (Ham ibid.,) prohibited to the people, [i. e. to the public,] (Lth, Mgh, and Ham ubi suprà,) so that they may not pasture their beasts in it, (Lth, Mgh,) nor approach it, (Mgh, Msb,) nor venture upon it: (Msb:) it was a custom of the noble among the Arabs, in the Time of Ignorance, when he alighted in a district [that pleased him], among his kinsfolk, to incite a dog to bark, and to prohibit for his own special friends or dependents the space throughout which the bark of the dog was heard, so that none else should pasture his beasts there; while he shared with the people in the other places of pasture, around it: but the Prophet forbade this: (Esh-Sháfi'ee, TA:) he said, “ There shall be no HmY except for God and for his Apostle; ” (Esh-Sháfi'ee, S, Mgh, TA;) meaning, except for the horses employed in war against the unbelievers and for the camels taken for the poor-rate: (Esh-Sháfi'ee, Mgh, TA:) afterwards, the term was applied in a general sense: (Esh-Sháfi'ee, TA:) the pl. is A^aHomaA='N (S
and K in art. Hjr) and A^aHomiyapN: (Ham p. 496:) and the dual is HimayaAni and HimawaAni; (ISk, S, Msb, TA;) the latter irreg., (TA,) heard by Ks, but be preferred the former. (S.) You say, h`*aA $aYo'N HimFY This is a thing prohibited, or interdicted; not to be approached. (S.) And kalaA^N HimFY Herbage, or pasture, that is prohibited, or interdicted. Q. 1 HanoZalati Al$~ajarapu *
The tree became bitter in its fruit [like the HanoZal]. (AHei, TA.)

HanoZalN HnZl
[The colocynth; cucumis colocynthis;] a certain bitter plant; (Msb;) [and its fruit;] well known; (K;) i. q. $aroYN: (S:) n. un. with p: (S, Msb, K: *) [accord. to Freytag (who refers to Avic. p. 175, and Sprengel. hist. rei herb. vol. i. p. 269,) applied also to the momordica elaterium, or cucumis prophetarum:] there is a male species, and a female; the former fibrous; the latter soft, or easily broken, white, and easy to swallow: (TA:) the choice sort of it is the yellow; (K;) or, accord. to the “ Kánoon ” of the Ra-ees [Ibn-Seenà, from which the description of its properties and uses, in the K and TA, is, with some slight variations, taken], the white, very white, and soft; for the black and the hard are bad, and it is not plucked until it becomes yellow, and the greenness has completely gone from it; (TA:) its pulp attenuates the thick phlegmatic humour that flows upon the joints (K, TA) and tendons, (TA,) when swallowed (K, TA) in the dose of of twelve keeráts, (TA,) or used in the manner of a cluster: it is beneficial for melancholy, and epilepsy, and the [sort of doting termed] wasowaAs, and alopecia (daA=' Alv~aEolab), and elephantiasis (Alju*aAm), (K, TA,) and [the disease of the tumid leg, termed] daA=' Alfiyl; for these three used by rubbing; and for the cold niqoris [i. e. arthritis, or gout], (TA,) and for the bite of vipers, and the sting of scorpions, especially its root; (K, TA;) for this last being the most beneficial of medicines; a drachm of its root, administered to an Arab stung by a scorpion in four places, being said to have cured him on the spot: that which is plucked green relaxes [the bowels] excessively, and produces excessive vomiting: so in the “ Kánoon: ” (TA:) it is also beneficial for the tooth-ache, by fumigating with its seeds; and for killing fleas, by sprinkling what is cooked thereof; and for the sciatica, by rubbing with what is green thereof: (K, TA:) its root is cooked with vinegar, and one rinses the mouth with it for the tooth-ache; and the vinegar is cooked in it in hot ashes: when cooked in olive-oil, that oil, being dropped [into the ear-hole], is beneficial for ringing in the ears: it is beneficial also for the moist and flatulent colic: and sometimes it attenuates the blood: administered as a suppository in the vagina, it kills the fœtus: (TA:) when the plant bears a single fruit, this is very deadly. (K, TA.) [See also habiydN.] Accord. to [many of] the leading authorities among the Arabs, (TA,) the n in this word is augmentative; (Msb, TA;) because of their saying, HaZila AlbaEiyru, meaning “ the camel became sick from eating HanoZal; ” and J and Sgh [and Fei and others] have mentioned it in art. HZl: but ISd says that this is not an evidence of its being radically triliteral; and that HaZila is
like DagobapN (as an epithet applied to a woman) from AlD~agaAbiysu, which must be acknowledged to be radically quadriliteral. (TA.)

(tropical:) A man rendered firm, or sound, in judgment, by means of experience; (K, TA;) as also muHan~akN↓ and muHonakN↓ (S, K) and muHotanikN↓ (K) and muHotanakN↓ (TA) and HunukN↓, q. v.: (Fr, K:) or mHnk [i. e. either muHan~akN↓ or muHonakN↓], accord.
to Lth, signifies a man whom the management of affairs has rendered experienced so that nothing that he does is despised: and muHotanakN↓, a man whose intellect and age have reached the utmost degree [of maturity]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) An old man. (IAar, TA.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) Niggardly, tenacious, or avaricious. (AA, TA.) ― -b4- And HaniykapN A good eater; applied to a daAb~ap [or beast]; (K;) to a she-camel, and to a sheep or goat. (TA.)

And fulaAnN mim~ano laA tuHonaY Ealayohi AlA^aSaAbiEu [Such a one is of those at the mention of whom the fingers are not bent; (see a portion of the first paragraph of art. vnY, commencing with the second sentence;)] i. e. such a one is not counted among the brethren. (Th, TA.) And [hence] a poet says,

waA^alaE~a minoka biHayovu tuHnaY AlA_iSobaEu
[Time, or fortune, bore upon them with its weight, and was pressing in its exactions from thee, so that the finger was bent]; meaning that it took the best, those that were counted [with the fingers]. (IAar, TA.) ― -b2- HanaAqawosFA, inf. n. HanowN, (K,) He strung, or braced the string of, a bow; because, in doing so, one bends it: (TA:) or he made a bow. HinowN Hnw
(S, Mgh, K) and HanowN↓ (K) Anything in which is a bending, curving, or crookedness, (K,) and the like; (TA;) of the body, (K,) such as the bone beneath the eyebrow, (K, * TA,) and the jaw-bone, and a rib; and of other things, such as the [high ground termed] quf~, and the [tract of sand termed] Hiqof, (K,) and the bend of a valley [like maHoniyapN &c.]: (TA:) see maHoniyapN: and any curved piece of wood, (K,) such as any of the curved pieces of wood of the horse's saddle, and of the [camel's saddle called] qatab, (S, * CK, TA,) and of the [camel's saddle called] raHol: (CK, TA:) each of [the curved pieces of wood called] the qarobuwsaAni, the anterior and the posterior, of the horse's saddle: (Mgh:) and a bending, curving, or crookedness, of anything: whence, HinowN Aljabali [the bend of the mountain]: (S:) pl. [of pauc.] A^aHonaA='N (S, Mgh, K) and [of mult.] HiniY~N, [in the CK, erroneously, HaniY~N,] and HuniY~N [originally Hunuw~N, first altered to HuniY~N, and then, because of the kesreh, to HiniY~N]. (K, TA.) ― -b2- [The dual] HinowaAni signifies The two curved pieces of wood, with a net upon them, by means of which wheat is conveyed to the heap that is collected together in the place where it is trodden out. (K.) ― -b3- And the pl. A^aHonaA='N, i. q. jawaAnibu [as meaning (assumed tropical:) Sides, regions, quarters, or the like; and limits, bounds, or boundaries]; like A^aEonaA='N. (S.) (assumed tropical:) Straiten thou the limits, or bounds, of thy levity, (alluding to the restraining of birds from flight,)] on the right and left, and before and behind; by Tyrk being meant xif~atika and Tayo$ika. (S, TA.) ― -b4- A^aHonaA='u AlA^umuwri (assumed tropical:) Dubious affairs: (K, * TA:) or, as some say, it means A^aToraAfuhaA wanawaAHiyhaA [(assumed tropical:) the ends, and limits, or bounds, of affairs]. (TA.)

HanowapN Hnw Hnwh Hnwp
A stooping of the head, and bowing of the back, in prayer. (TA.)

HinaA='N HnA='
The desire of a ewe, and of a wild cow, for the male. (S.) [See also HiromapN.]

(TA.) ＝ -A2- And HaAniyapN, applied to a woman, That undertakes the care and maintenance of her children, (AZ, S, TA,) or acts affectionately towards them, (TA,) and does not marry again, after [the loss of] their father: (AZ, S, TA:) pl. HawaAnK and HaAniyaAtN; the latter applied in a similar sense to she-camels. Hwn]; (Msb, TA;) called by the people of El-'Irák maAxuwrN: (TA:) the first of these words (i. e. HAnwt) is said to be of the measure faEaluwtN, (AAF, Msb, TA,) like malakuwtN and rahabuwtN; the w [of the root] being changed into A, as in TaAluwtN and jaAluwt and the like: (Msb:) or originally faEaluwtN, and then falaEuwtN, like TaAguwt: (Mgh:) or it is originally HaAnuwpN, like taroquwapN: (Mgh, Msb: [but the former is said in the Mgh to be the right opinion:]) or it is originally of the measure faAEuwlN; (M, Msb;) so says El-Fárábee; (Msb;) from HanawotN; what is so called being likened to the building termed Haniy~apN; the t being a substitute for w, as is said by AAF, (M,) and being originally p, changed into t because of the quiescent letter before it: (Msb:) Az says that the t is augmentative: (TA:) the word is fem. and masc.: (Mgh, Msb, TA:) accord. to Zj, when masc., meaning bayotN: (Msb:) pl. HawaAniytu. (Msb, TA.) ― -b2- Also The vintner himself: (K in art. Hnt:) [like HaAniY~N &c.]

[fem. of HaAnK, q. v.] ― -b2- The pl. AlHawaAniY [as a subst.] signifies The longest of the ribs; (K;) four in number; two on either side. , (As, S, K,) [like AiroEawaY, originally AiHowaw~a, of the measure AifoEal~a, then AiHowawawa, and then AiHowawaY,] aor. yaHowawiY, inf. n. AiHowiwaA='N, said of a horse, (As, S,) He was, or became, of the colour termed Huw~apN [q. v. infrà]; as also AiHowaAwaY↓, (As, S, K,) [originally AiHowaAw~a, of the measure AifoEaAl~a, then AiHowaAwawa, and then AiHowaAwaY,] aor. yaHowaAwiY, inf. n. Huw~apN, (As, S,) or HawFY; (K;) this last verb mentioned by As as used by some of the Arabs. (S.) And AlA^aroDu AiHowaAwati↓ The land was, or became, green; as also AiHowaw~at↓; (K;) [or the latter is correctly AiHowawat:] IJ says that AiHowaAwat↓ is of the measure AifoEaAl~at, [originally AiHowaAw~at, then AHowaAwawat. and then AiHowaAwat,] and that the Koofees say AiHowaAw~at and AiHowaw~at↓; but ISd says that their usage is wrong, for the Arabs say AiHowawaY, like AiroEawaY, and do not say AiHowaw~a. Huw~apN Hwh Hwp
[A brown colour;] redness inclining to blackness: (As, S, K:) or a colour intermixed with [the blackish red termed] kumotapN, like the rust of iron: (S:) or blackness inclining to greenness. (K.) In the lip, [The brownish colour termed] sumorapN; (S;) [i. e.] a colour resembling [that termed] All~aEasu and All~amaY: (T, TA:) or a blackness in the lips; which is approved. (Ham p. 386.)

A^aHowaY *
Of the colour termed Huw~apN [q. v. suprà]: and also black: (K:) or black by reason of [intense] xuDorap [by which may be here meant either greenness, or dark, or ashy, dust-colour]: (TA:) applied to a horse, i. q. kumayotN [i. e. bay] overspread with blackness; (TA;) or red in the back; (En-Nadr, TA;) or more yellow than, but nearly the same as, such as is termed A^aHam~u, so that one swears, of such a horse, that he is A^aHam~: (AO, TA: [see muHolifN:]) applied to a camel, whose xuDorap [here meaning dark, or ashy, dust-colour] is intermixed with blackness and yellowness: (S:) applied to a man, having [a brownish colour such as is termed] sumorapN in the lip; (S;) or having a blackness in the lips, which is approved; (Ham p. 386;) fem. Haw~aA='u, applied to a woman, (S,) and also to a lip ($afapN) as meaning red inclining to blackness: (K:) applied to a plant, inclining to blackness by reason of its intense greenness; (K;) and such is the softest of plants: (TA:) the pl. is Huw~N; occurring in a trad., in which the best of horses are said to be those thus termed: (TA:) the dim. of A^aHowaY is A^uHayowK↓, in the dial. of him who says A^usayowidu [instead of A^usay~idu, dim. of A^asowadu]; but there is a difference of opinion as to the form with idghám: 'Eesà Ibn-'Omar says A^uHaY~N↓, making it perfectly decl., which Sb pronounces a mistake: 'Amr Ibn-El-'Alà, or Aboo-'Amr Ibn-El-'Alà, (accord. to different copies of the S,) says A^uHaY~K↓, after the manner of A^uHayowK, which, also, Sb disallows: Yoo says A^uHaY~u↓, and this, says Sb, is the regular and right form. (S.) [Hence,] bakorapN Haw~aA='N A sheave of a pulley formed of black wood. (TA.) And namolN Huw~N Red ants; called namolu sulayomaAna. (TA.) fajaEalahu guvaA='F A^aHowaY, in the Kur [lxxxvii. 5], means, accord. to Fr, And hath made it (the herbage mentioned before) dried up, black by reason of oldness: or it may mean and hath made it to become gvA=' [or decayed, or dried-up, leaves and stalks,] after it has been green. (TA.)

A^aHowiY~N *
rel. n. of A^aHowaY. (TA.)

A^uHaY~u *
and A^uHaY~N and A^uHaY~K: see A^HowaY.

A^uHayowK *
: see A^aHowaY.

HaA='N H*A='
The name of the letter H, q. v.; as also HaA: (S and K and TA in bAb AlAlf All~ynp:) it is called HA in a case of pause, and HaA='N when made a noun: and when it is not called a letter, [i. e. when one does not prefix to it the word Harof,] it is [properly] fem.: its dim. is Huyay~apN, meaning a H written small, or indistinct: (Lth, TA ubi suprà:) and its pl. is A^aHowaA='N and A^aHoyaA='N and HaAA=tN. (TA ubi suprà.)

HaAy^iY~N *
and HaAwiY~N and HawiY~N [a mistranscription for HayawiY~N, like bayawiY~N and tayawiY~N,] rel. ns. of HaA='N and HaA the names of the letter H. (B, TA ubi suprà.)

1 HaAba HAb
, (Msb, K,) sec. pers. Hubotu, (S,) aor. yaHuwbu, (S, Msb,) inf. n. HawobN (S, Msb, K) and HawobapN and HiyaAbapN, (S, K, accord. to one copy of the K HiyaAbN,) and HiybapN (TA) and HuwbN; (K;) or this last is a simple subst.; or, as some say, it and HawobN are two dial. vars.; that with damm, of the dial. of El-Hijáz; and that with fet-h, of the dial. of Temeem; (Msb;) accord. to Zj, that with damm signifies “ sin, or crime; ” and that with fet-h, the “ act ” of a man; [i. e. the “ act of committing a sin, or crime; ”] (TA;) He sinned; committed a sin, or crime; did what was unlawful; (S, Msb, K;) bika*aA [by such a thing]. (S, K.) ― -b2- Also, aor. as above, [inf. n. not mentioned,] He, or it, became in an evil condition, or state. (TA.) ― -b3- He slew [another]: of the dial. of the tribe of Asad. (TA.) ＝ -A2- HawobN also signifies The act of chiding a male camel [by the cry Hawobi]. (Lth, TA.) [See also 2.]

2 Hw~b biAlA_ibili Hwb bAlAbl
, (S, K, *) inf. n. taHowiybN, (K,) He chid the camels (S, K) by the cry Hawobi Hawobi. (S.) [See also 1.]

4 A^aHowaba *
He pursued a course that led him to sin, or crime. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- maA A^aHabotuhu for maA A^aHobabotuhu: see 4 in art. Hb.

5 tHw~b tHwb
He abstained from, shunned, or avoided, sin, or crime; put it away from himself: (A 'Obeyd, S, K, TA:) he applied himself to acts, or exercises, of devotion; became devout, or a devotee. (IJ, TA.) Here the form tafaE~ala is deprived of the radical signification, as in the cases of the syn. words taA^av~ama and taHan~ava; though its property is oftener to confirm the radical signification. (TA. [See tHn~v.]) You say, tHw~b mino ka*aA He abstained from such a thing as a sin, or crime. (A 'Obeyd, S, TA. [See also another explanation below.]) ― -b2- He humbled himself in his prayer, or supplication. (TA.) ― -b3- He expressed pain, grief, or sorrow; lamented, or complained. (S, K, * TA.) And tHw~b mino ka*aA He was enraged, and expressed pain or grief or sorrow, or lamented, or complained, by reason of such a thing. (TA. [See another explanation above.]) ― -b4- He cried out, expressing pain or grief or sorrow, or lamenting, or complaining: he cried aloud, or vehemently, in prayer, or supplication. (TA.) (S, K, &c.) and HaAy^ijapN↓, (AA, IDrd, &c.,) of which latter the former is a contraction, (Kh in the 'Eyn, TA,) or the latter word is unused [except as an epithet, as will be seen below], and HawojaA='u↓, (S, K, &c.,) are syn. words, of which the meaning is well known: (S, K, TA:) Want; need; necessity, or necessitude; exigency: (TA:) [whence,] Aibonu HaAjapF one who is constantly in want, or need: (Har p. 143:) HaAjapN is a more general term than faqorN; or each of these terms is more general than the other in some respects, and more particular in others: (TA:) and the former signifies also a thing wanted, needed, or required; an object of want, of need, or of exigence; a want; a needful, or requisite, thing, affair, or business: (A, TA:) [and a thing to be done, an affair, or a business:] pl. [Hence,] xafiyfu AlHaA* ‡ A man light of back; (S, A, L, Msb;) as also xafiyfu AlHaAli; (A;) meaning having little property: and also having a small family to maintain: (L:) or having little property and a small family to maintain: (L, K:) like xafiyfu AlZ~ahori. And hence, (tropical:) Quick in everything that he undertakes: quick, sharp, and active in affairs: (L:) active and skilful: (K:) active in a thing by reason of his skilfulness: (AA, S, L:) applied [as meaning active by reason of expertness] to the wing of a bird of the kind called qaTFA, by a poet. (L.) And A^aHowaziY~N signifies the same. (S and K &c. in art. Hwz.) ― -b2- It is applied by a poet to thick water (maA='N mina AlT~avorapi) as meaning (assumed tropical:) Quick in moving the bowels. , aor. yaHuwru, (S,) inf. n. , inf. n. HawarN; (K;) and Hawirato, aor. and inf. n. as above; (Msb;) and AHw~r↓, (K,) inf. n. AiHowiraArN; (TA;) and AHw~rt; (S, K; *) He, (a man, K, TA,) and it, (an eye, S, Msb, K, * TA,) was, or became, characterized by the quality termed HawarN as explained below. (S, Msb, K, TA.)

, inf. n. taHowiyrN, He made him, or it, to return. , (A, Mgh, Msb,) and HAwrhu AlkalaAma, (TA in art. rjE, &c.,) inf. n. muHaAwarapN (S, Mgh, K) and HiwaArN, (A, Mgh,) He returned him answer for answer, or answers for answers; held a dialogue, colloquy, conference, disputation, or debate, with him; or bandied words with him; syn. jaAwabahu, (S, and Jel in xviii. 35,) and raAjaEahu AlkalaAma, (A, Mgh, Msb,) or raAjaEahu fiY AlkalaAmi, (Bd in xviii. 32,) or, of the inf. n., muraAjaEapu Aln~uToqi. HaworN A^Hwr Hwr Hwryp
inf. n. of HaAra. (S, A, Msb, K.) [Hence,] naEuw*u biA@ll~`hi mina AlHawori baEoda Alkawoni, (TA on the authority of 'Ásim, and so in a copy of the S,) a trad., (TA,) meaning We have recourse to God for preservation from decrease, or defectiveness, after increase, or redundance: (S:) or mina AlHawori baEoda Alkawori, (TA, and so in copies of the S,) meaning as above: (S, TA:) or (assumed tropical:) from a bad state of affairs after a good state; from HaworN signifying the “ untwisting ” a turban: (TA:) or from returning and departing from the community [of the faithful] after having been therein; [from HaAra “ he untwisted ” his turban, and] from kaAra “ he twisted ” his turban upon his head. (Zj, TA. [See also kaworN.]) fiY maHaArapK↓ HuwrN↓, (S, K,) and HaworN, (K,) Deficiency upon deficiency, (S, K,) and return upon return, (TA,) is a prov., applied to him whose good fortune is retiring; (S, K;) or to him who is not in a good state; or to him who has been in a good state and has become in a bad state: (K:) or the saying is, fulaAnN HaworN fiY maHaArapK↓ [Such a one is suffering deficiency upon deficiency: HaworN being used in the sense of HaAy^irN, like baworN in the sense of baAy^irN]: so heard by IAar; and said by him to be applied in
the case of a thing not in a good state; or to him who has been in a good state and has become in a bad state. (TA.) One says also, AlbaATilu fiY HaworK What is false, or vain, is waning and retreating. (TA.) And wabuwrK A_in~ahu fiY HuwrK↓, (K,) or HuwrK buwrK, (K in art. Hyr,) Verily he is engaged in that which is not a skilful nor a good work or performance: (fiY gayori SanoEapK walaA A_ijaAdapK: so in the L: in the K, for AHAdp is put A_itaAwapK [which is evidently a mistake]: TA:) or he is in a bad state, and a state of perdition: (TA in art. Hyr:) or in error. (K. [See also buwrN: and see baAy^irN, in art. bwr; where it is implied that bwr is here an imitative sequent of Hwr.]) And *ahaba fulaAnN fiY waAlbawaAru AlHawaAri↓ Such a one went away in a defective and bad state. (L, TA.) ― -b2- See also HawiyrN. ＝ -A2- What is beneath the [part called] kaworN of a turban. (K.) ＝ -A3- The bottom of a well or the like. (K.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) huwa baEiydu AlHawori (assumed tropical:) He is intelligent; (K;) deep in penetration. (TA.)

HuwrN A^Hwr Hwr Hwryp
: see HaworN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also [app. A return of flour for the loan of a hand-mill; like EuqobapN (a subst. from A^aEoqaba) signifying some broth which is returned with a borrowed cooking-pot:] a subst. from AHArt in the phrase TaHanato famaA A^aHaArato $ayoy^FA [q. v. suprà]. (S, K.)

HawarN A^Hwr Hwr Hwryp
Intense whiteness of the white of the eye and intense blackness of the black thereof, (S, Msb, K,) with intense whiteness, or fairness, of the rest of the person: (K:) or intense whiteness of the white of the eye and intense blackness of the black thereof, with roundness of the black, and thinness of the eyelids, and whiteness, or fairness, of the parts around them: (K:) or blackness of the whole [of what appears] of the eye, as in the eyes of gazelles (AA, S, Msb, K) and of bulls and cows: (AA, S:) and this is not found in human beings, but is attributed to them by way of comparison: (AA, S, Msb, K:) As says, I know not what is AlHawaru in the eye. (S.) ― -b2- Also [simply] Whiteness. (A.) ＝ -A2- Red skins, with which [baskets of the kind called] silaAl are covered: (S, K:) [a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p: (S:) pl. HuwraAnN: (K, TA: in the CK HawarAnN:) or (so in the TA, but in the K “ and ”) a hide dyed red: (K, TA:) or red skins, not [such as are termed] qaraZiy~ap: pl. A^aHowaArN: (AHn:) or skins tanned without qaraZ: or thin white skins, of which [receptacles of the kind called] A^asofaAT are made: or prepared sheep-skins. (TA.) [In the present day, pronounced Hawor, applied to Sheep-skin leather.] ＝ -A3- A certain kind of tree: the people of Syria apply the name of HaworN to the plane-tree (dulob); but it is HawarN, with two fet-hahs: in the account of simples in the Kánoon [of Ibn-Seenà], it is said to be a certain tree of which the gum is called khrbA': (Mgh:) [by the modern Egyptians (pronounced Hawor) applied to the white poplar:] a certain kind of wood, called AlbayoDaA='u, (K,) because of its whiteness. (TA.) ＝ -A4- AlHawaru The third star, [e,] that next the body, of the three in the tail of Ursa Major. (Mir-át ez-Zemán, &c. [In the K it is incorrectly said to be the third star of banaAtu naEo$K AlS~ugoraY. See AlqaAy^idu, in art. qwd.])

[A quarter of a city or town; generally consisting of several narrow streets, or lanes, of houses, and having but one general entrance, with a gate, which is closed at night; or, which is the case in some instances, having a by-street passing through it, with a gate at each end:] a place of abode of a people, whereof the houses are contiguous: (Msb:) any place of abode of a people whereof the houses are near [together]: (K in art. Hyr:) a spacious encompassed tract or place; syn. musotadaArN mino faDaA='K: (A:) pl. HaAraAtN. (A, Msb.)

fem. of A^aHowaru [q. v.]. ― -b2- Also A round, or circular, burn, made with a hot iron; (K;) [around the eye of a camel; (see 2;)] so called because its place becomes white. (TA.)

HawarowarapN Hwrwrh Hwrwrp

, (S, K, &c.,) and sometimes with kesr [HiwaArN↓], (K,) but this latter is a bad form, (Yaakoob,) A young camel when just born: (T, K:) or until weaned; (S, K;) i. e. from the time of its birth until big and weaned; (TA;) when it is called faSiylN: (S:) fem. with p: (IAar:) pl. HiwaArN HArp HwAr
: see HawiyrN: ＝ -A2- and see also HuwaArN.

(S, K,) and HawiyrapN↓, (S, and so in some copies of the K,) or HuwayorapN↓, (so in other copies of the K and in the TA,) and HawaArN↓ (S, K) and HiwaArN↓ (K) and maHuwrapN↓ (S, K, TA, in the CK maHowurapN) and maHowarapN↓ and muHaAwarapN↓ [originally an inf. n. of 3] and HiyrapN↓ (K) and HaworN↓, (TA,) An answer; a reply. HawaAriY~N HArp HwAr HwArY HwAry HwAryy
One who whitens clothes, or garments, by washing and beating them. (S, M, Msb, K.) Hence its pl. HawaAriy~uwna is applied to The companions [i. e. apostles and disciples] of Jesus, because their trade was to do this. (S, M, Msb.) [Or it is so applied from its bearing some one or another of the following significations.] ― -b2- One who is freed and cleared from every vice, fault, or defect: [or] one who has been tried, or proved, time after time, and found to be free from vices, faults, or defects; from HaAra “ he returned. ” (Zj, TA.) ― -b3- A thing that is pure, or unsullied: anything of a pure, or an unsullied, colour: and hence, ― -b4- One who advises, or counsels, or acts, sincerely, honestly, or faithfully: (Sh:) or a friend; or true, or sincere, friend: (TA:) or an assistant: (S, Msb, K:) or a strenuous assistant: (TA:) or an assistant of prophets: (K:) or a particular and select friend and assistant of a prophet: and hence the pl. is applied to the companions of Mohammad also. (Zj.) ― -b5- A relation. (K.) ― -b6- And HawaAriy~apN A white, or fair, woman; (A;) as also HawarowarapN↓; (T, K;) and so HaworaA='u↓, without implying HawarN of the eye: (TA:) pl. of the first HawaAriy~aAtN: (A:) or this pl. signifies women of the cities or towns; (K;) so called by the Arabs of the desert because of their whiteness, or fairness, and cleanness: (TA:) or women clear in complexion and skin; because of their whiteness, or fairness: (TA:) or women inhabitants of regions, districts, or tracts, of cities, towns, or villages, and of cultivated land: (Ksh and Bd in iii. 45:) or [simply] women; because of their whiteness, or fairness. (S.)

Huw~aAraY HArp HwAr HwArY HwAry HwAryy
White, applied to flour: (A, * K:) such is the best and purest of flour: (K, TA:) and in like manner applied to bread: (A:) or whitened, applied to flour; (S;) and, in this latter sense, to any food. (S, K.) [See also samiydN: and see muHaw~arN.]

rajulN HaAy^irN baAy^irN *
A man in a defective and bad state: (S, TA:) or perishing, or dying. (S.) [See the same phrase in art. Hyr: see also HaworN: and see baAy^irN, in art. bwr; where it is said that bAy^r is here an imitative sequent of HAy^r.] ＝ -A2- See also maHaArapN.

A^aHowaru *
, (K,) applied to a man, (TA,) Having eyes characterized by the quality termed HawarN as explained above: (K:) and so HaworaA='u, [the fem.,] applied to a woman: (S, Msb, K: *) pl. HuwrN. (S, K.) And Huwru AlEiyni, applied to women, Having eyes like those of gazelles and of cows. (AA, S.) See also HawaAriy~apN, under HawaAriY~N. ― -b2- TarofN A^aHowaru An eye of pure white and black. (A.) ― -b3- AlA^aHowaru A certain star: (S, K:) or (K) Jupiter. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- Also (tropical:) Intellect: (ISk, S, K:) or pure, or clear, intellect; like an eye so termed, of pure white and black. (A.) A^aHowariY~N *
A man (TA) white, or fair, (S, K,) of the people of the towns or villages. (TA.) [See also HawaAriY~N; of which the fem. is applied in like manner to a woman.]

maHaArN mHAr
: see maHaArapN, in two places.

miHowarN mHwr
The pin of wood, or, as is sometimes the case, of iron, on which the sheave of a pulley turns; (S;) the iron [pin] that unites the bent piece of iron which is on each side of the sheave of a pulley, and in which it [the mHwr] is inserted, and the sheave itself: and a piece of wood which unites (tajomaEu) the sheave of a large pulley
[app. with what is on each side of the latter; for it seems to mean here, also, the pivot]: (K:) some say that it is so called because it turns round, returning to the point from which it departed: others, that it is so called because, by its revolving, it is polished so that it becomes white: (Zj:) pl. maHaAwiru. (A.) One says, qaliqato maHaAwiruhu, meaning (tropical:) His circumstances, (A,) or affair, or case, (K,) became unsettled: (A, K:) from the state of the pin of the sheave of a pulley when it becomes smooth, and the hole becomes large, so that it wabbles. (A.) ― -b2- Also A thing (K) of iron (TA) upon which turns the tongue of a buckle at the end of a waist-belt. (K.) ― -b3- And An iron instrument for cauterizing [app. of a circular form: see 2]. (K.) ― -b4- And The wooden implement (S, K) of the baker, or maker of bread, (S,) with which he expands the dough, (K,) and prepares it, and makes it round, to put it into the hot ashes in which it is baked: (TA:) so called because of its turning round upon the dough, as being likened to the mHwr of the sheave of a pulley, and because of its roundness. (T.)

maHaArapN mHAr mHArh mHArp
: see HaworN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also A place that returns [like a circle]: or in which a return is made [to the point of commencement]. (K.) ― -b2- A mother-of-pearl shell; an oyster-shell: (S, IAth, Msb, K:) or the like thereof, of bone: (S, K:) pl. maHaAwiru and [coll. gen. n.] maHaArN↓. (L.) ― -b3- And hence, A thing in which water is collected; as also HaAy^irN↓. (IAth.) ― -b4- [Hence also,] An oyster [itself]; expl. by daAb~apN fiY AlS~adafayoni. And one says also, Taw~ala EalayonaA fulaAnN biA@loHawozi waA@lT~alaqi qabola Alqarabi (assumed tropical:) [Such a one was prolix, or tedious, to us with this and that discursion before coming to the point]. i. q. Hay~izN, as pointed out in two places below. (S, Msb, &c.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) A thing that is in one's possession or occupation; a thing that is one's property: so in the saying of a certain woman, waA^aHomiY Hawozapa AlgaAy^ibi (assumed tropical:) And I guard from encroachment the property of the absent: meaning her faroj, which was the property of her husband by the marriage-contract: whence it appears that, if this saying be the only ground upon which Az has asserted that one of the significations of HawozapN is the faroj of a woman, [as is also said in the K,] his assertion requires consideration; for a woman's frj is her own when she has no husband; and when she is married, it is her husband's property. (TA.) In like manner, a poet says,
HamaY HawozaAtihi faturikona qaforFA
He guarded from encroachment his tracts of pasture-land [so that they were left deserted]. (Fr, TA.) And it is said in a trad., faHamaY HawozapF AlA_isolaAmi (tropical:) And he defended, or protected, or guarded, from encroachment, or invasion, or attack, the limits, [meaning, what the limits comprised, i. e., the territory,] and the tracts, or regions, of El-Islám [meaning, of the Muslims]. (TA.) Hawozapu Almuloki signifies [in like manner] bayoDatuhu [i. e. (assumed tropical:) The seat of regal power: or the heart, or principal part, of the kingdom]. Hay~izN Hyz
, (S, Mgh, Msb,) of the measure fayoEilN, (Mgh, Msb,) from AlHawozu, (S, * Mgh,) as signifying “ the drawing, collecting, or gathering, together, ” (Mgh,) originally HayowizN, (TA,) and also contracted into HayozN, (S, Msb, TA,) like hay~inN and hayonN, and lay~inN and layonN; (S, TA;) [The continent, or container, or receptacle, of anything; like bayoDapN; as also HawozapN↓, q. v.:] any place in which a thing is: (Mgh:) in scholastic theology, the imaginary portion of space occupied by a thing having extent, as a body; or by a thing not having extent, as an indivisible atom: in philosophy, the inner surface of a container, which is contiguous [in every part] to the outer surface of the thing contained: and [hence,] AlHay~izu AlTabiyEiY~u [the proper natural place of a thing;] that in which the nature of a thing requires it to be. (KT.) ― -b2- A quarter, tract, region, or place, considered relatively, or as part of a whole; or a part, or portion, of a place; syn. naAHiyapN; (S, Mgh, Msb;) as also HawozapN↓: (S, Msb, K:) so the authors on practical law mean by Hay~izN; such, for instance, as a room, or an apartment, of a house: (Mgh:) pl. A^aHoyaAzN, (S, Msb, TA,) which is extr., (TA,) being from the contracted form [HayozN]: (Msb:) by rule it should be A^aHowaAzN, (Az, Msb, TA,) like A^amowaAtN, pl. of may~itN [and mayotN]: (Az, TA:) or by rule [if from the uncontracted form Hay~izN] it should be HayaAy^izu, with hemz, accord. to Sb; or HayaAwizu, with w, accord. to Abu-l-Hasan. (TA.) Hay~izu Ald~aAri, (S, Msb, TA,) as also Ald~Ari Hawozu↓, (TA,) signifies What is annexed to the house, (S, TA,) or appertains thereto, (Msb,) of the maraAfiq (S, Msb, TA) and manaAfiE (TA) and nawaAHK; (Msb;) [i. e., of the conveniences thereof, such as the privy and the kitchen and the like, and other parts or apartments;] such are termed collectively A^aHoyaAzu Ald~aAri; (Msb;) and each part or apartment (naAHiyap), by itself, is termed Hay~izN. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence the saying,] A^anaA fiY Hay~izihi wakanafihi (tropical:) [I am in his quarter and protection]. (A, TA.) ― -b4- [And hence also the saying,] fiY Hay~izi Alt~awaAtiru (tropical:) In the manner, and place, of [that kind of transmission which is termed] AltwAtr [which is “ transmission by such a number of persons as cannot be supposed to have agreed to a falsehood: ” as explained in the Mz, 3rd nwE]. (Mgh.) ― -b5- And SaAra fiY Hay~izihi: see HawozapN. ― -b6- [And EalaY Hay~izihi By himself or itself.]
