, (S, M, K,) inf. n. muHaAwalapN (M, K, KL) and HiwaAlN, (M, K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, HawAl,]) He desired it: (S, KL:) he sought it: (M, K, KL:) or he sought it by an artful contrivance or device; or by artful, or skilful, management; by turning over, or revolving, thoughts, ideas, schemes, or contrivances, in his mind, so as to find a way of attaining his object; syn. Talabahu biHiylapK, (A,) or biA@loHiylapi. (Har p. 326.) Aboo-Heiyeh En-Numeyree says,
wamano yuHaAwilu $ayoy^FA fiY fami AlA^asadi
[And who will seek to get a thing in the mouth of the lion?] (Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 714.) And one says, HAwl minohaA AljimaAEa [He desired, or sought, of her, copulation, using blandishment, or artifice, for that purpose]. (T in art. rwd, bika A^uHaAwilu occurring in a trad., means bk A^uTaAlibu [app. By means of Thee I seek, or demand, that which I want]. (Az, M, A, TA.) One says also, HaAwalotuhu A^ano yafoEala AlA^amora [I sought, or endeavoured, to induce him to do the thing], and A^ano yatorukahu [to leave it]. (A in art. dwr.) And, of water, HAwl A^ano yajomuda (L and K in art. jmd) (assumed tropical:) It was about to congeal, or freeze; was at the point of congealing, or freezing. (TK in that art.) ― -b2- HaAwalotu lahu baSariY I looked sharply, or intently, at him; I cast my eyes at him. (ISd, K.)

4 AHAl AHAl A^HAl
, as an intrans. v.: see 1, in eighteen places. ― -b2- tajan~aba rawoDapF waA^aHaAla yaEoduw [He withdrew from a meadow, and set to running,] is a prov., meaning he forsook abundance of herbage, or of the goods and conveniences and comforts of life, and preferred to it straitness, or difficulty. (S.) ― -b3- AHAl Ealayohi biAls~awoTi He set upon him with the whip, (S, MA, K,) yaDoribuhu [striking him]: (S:) or he desired to strike him with the whip: or he struck him with the whip: (MA:) and A^aHalotuhu biAls~awoTi, and biAlr~umoHi, [if AHlth be not a mistranscription for A^aHalotu Ealayohi, in the MS. from which I take this, as it may be inferred to be from what here precedes and follows,] I aimed at him with the whip, and with the spear, and set upon him with it: whence the saying, of him who has struck one at the point of death, and killed him, yuHiylu Almawota EalaY AlD~arobi, i. e. (assumed tropical:) He makes death [as it were] to hang upon, and cleave to, striking; like as the spear is made to cleave to the muHaAl Ealayoh, who is the person thrust, or pierced. (Msb.) El-Farezdak says, (S, TA,) addressing Hubeyreh Ibn-Damdam, (TA,)
wakunota ka*iy^obi Als~awo'i lam~aA raA^aY damFA
biSaAHibihi yawomFA A^aHaAla EalaY Ald~ami
i. e. [And thou mast like the wicked wolf: when he saw blood upon his companion, one day,] he set upon the blood. (S, TA.) ― -b4- [Hence, perhaps,] HAl Ealayohi He reckoned him, or esteemed him, weak. (K.) ― -b5- AHAl All~ayoli Night poured upon the earth; (K;) and came on. (TA.) [See also 1, last sentence but one.] ― -b6- AHAl bifulaAnK Alxubozu The bread fattened such a one; and in like manner one says of anything by which one becomes fat. (AA, TA.) ― -b7- And AHAl He did, or said, what was muHaAl [i. e. absurd, inconsistent, self-contradictory, unreal, or impossible]. (S, Sgh, K. *) ― -b8- And His camels did not conceive, or become pregnant, (AA, S, K,) during a year, or two years, or some years, (K,) having been covered. (S.) ＝ -A2- As a trans. v.: see 2, in three places. ― -b2- AHAl Algariyma He referred the creditor, from himself, [for the payment of what was due to him,] to another. (M, K.) And A^aHalotuhu bidayonihi I transferred his debt [i. e. the debt due to him from me] by making another person than myself responsible for it. (Msb.) And A^aHalotu zayodFA bimaA kaAna lahu EalaY~a EalaY rajulK I referred, or turned over, Zeyd, for the payment of what was due to him from me, to a certain man, transferring the responsibility for the debt to the latter: in which case, I am termed muHiylN↓; and Zeyd is termed muHaAlN↓; and the other man, Ealayohi muHaAlN↓, and Elyh muHotaAlN↓, and HawiylN↓; and the property, bihi muHaAlN↓: (Mgh:) and Hay~ilN↓, [originally HawiylN or HayowilN,] also, is applied to him to whom the reference is made; and to him who accepts the reference; both together being termed Hay~ilaAni. (Aboo-Sa'eed, TA.) And you say, AHAl Ealayohi bidayonihi [He referred a person to him for the payment of his debt]. (S.) And AHAl [alone] He transferred the debt for which he was responsible to the responsibility of another. (Har p. 59.) And A^aHalotu AlA^amora EalaY zayodK [I turned over the affair to Zeyd;] I made the performance of the affair to be required restrictively of Zeyd. (Msb.) ― -b3- AHAl Ealayohi AlmaA='a He poured out the water upon it: (K:) or AHAl AlmaA='a mina Ald~alowi he poured forth the water from the bucket, and turned over the latter. (S.) ― -b4- AHAl A@ll~`hu Ealayohi AlHawola [God made the year to pass over him, or it]: (Lh, TA:) or AHAl All~`h AlHawola God made the year complete. (K, TA.) ― -b5- AHAl Alr~ajulu A_ibilahu AlEaAma [The man made his she-camels to pass the year without becoming pregnant; or] the stallion did not cover the man's she-camels during the year. (Lh, TA.) ― -b6- A^aHowala Eayonahu, (Ks, Lh, S,) or A^aHaAlahaA, and Hw~lhA↓, (K,) He made his eye to be HawolaA='a [i. e. squinting, &c.]. (Ks, Lh, S, K.) [See 1, last sentence.] ― -b7- AHAl kalaAmahu He made his speech muHaAl [i. e. absurd, inconsistent, or self-contradictory]. (S. [See also 2.]) ＝ -A3- maA A^aHowala Hiylaka How fluctuating, and shifting, and varying, are thy evasions, wiles, artifices, or artful contrivances or devices! (Har p. 309.) ― -b2- And maA A^aHowalahu How surpassing is he in the practice of evasions, shifts, wiles, artifices, or artful contrivances or devices; or in turning over, or revolving, thoughts, ideas, schemes, or contrivances, in his mind, so as to find a way of attaining his object! (Fr, S, K;) as also mA A^aHoyalahu. (Fr, S in art. Hyl, and K.)

5 tHw~l HAl Hwl tHwl {Hwl
: see 1, first sentence, in three places. [Hence,] tHw~l mubotadiEFA [He turned innovator]. (O and K in art. bdE.) ― -b2- It shifted, or removed,

And Almajar~apu Haw~alati↓ The Milky Way became in the midst of the sky; which it does in the summer, (Sh, K, TA,) when the season of heat comes on. And tHw~l AlkisaA='i He put a thing in the [garment called] ksA', and then carried it on his back. You say, AHtAl zayodN bimaA kaAna lahu EalaY~a EalaY rajulK Zeyd was referred, or turned over, for the payment of what was due to him from me, to a certain man, to whom the responsibility for the debt was transferred. (Mgh.) ― -b2- AHtAl said of a year; see 1. ― -b3- AHtAl (S, MA, Msb, K, KL) and tHw~l↓ (S, K) and tHy~l (K) signify the same, (S, K,) from AlHiylapu [q. v.]; (S;) and HaAla↓, (Ham p. 652,) inf n. maHaAlN and HiylapN, (Ham ib. and K, *) also signifies the same as AHtAl; (Ham ib.;) which means He practised Hiylap [i. e. an evasion or elusion, a shift, a wile, an artifice, or an artful contrivance or device, a machination, a trick, a plot, a stratagem, or an expedient, &c.]: (MA, KL:) or he exercised art, artifice, cunning, ingenuity, or shill, and excellence of consideration or deliberation, and ability to manage according to his own free mill, (K, TA,) with subtilty: (TA:) or he sought AlHiylap i. e. [means of evading, or eluding, a thing, or of effecting an object, by] the exercise of art, artifice, cunning, ingenuity, or skill, in the management of affairs; by the turning over, or revolving, thoughts, ideas, schemes, or contrivances, in his mind, so as to find a way of attaining his object. (Msb.) You say, AHtAl fiY AlA^amori and tHw~l↓ [&c., He practised an evasion or elusion, &c., in the affair]. (K.) [And AHtAl Ealayohi He practised an artifice, or an artful contrivance or device, &c., against him. And AHtAl liEiyaAlihi He exercised art, artifice, cunning, ingenuity, or skill, in the management of affairs, for his family, or household.] ＝ -A2- AiHotawaluwhu They encompassed, or surrounded, him; or made him to be in the midst of them. (M, O, K.)

(TA.) And AstHAl AljahaAma He looked at [the waterless clouds, or the clouds that had poured forth their water, to see if they changed or moved]. 11 AHwAl~t AlA^aroDu *

HaAlN HAl
The state, condition, or case, (Sifap,) of a thing; [considered as subject to change;] (Msb, Er-Rághib, TA;) as also HaAlapN↓: (Msb:) or the quality, or manner of being, and state, or condition, of a man, (K, TA,) in respect of good or evil; (TA;) as also HaAlapN↓: (K:) or the particular case, or predicament, of a man &c., in respect of changing events, in the soul and the body and the acquisitions: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and in the coventional language of the logicians, a fleeting, or quickly-transient, quality, such as accidental heat and cold and moisture and dryness; as also HaAlapN↓: (TA:) anything changing: (Ham p. 288:) the time in which one is; (Lth, K;) [the present time;] the end of the past, and the beginning of the future: and as a conventional term, [in grammar, the present tense: and (tropical:) the future: and also] a denotative of state of the agent or of the objective complement; [the former termed HaAlN mina AlfaAEili; and the latter, HaAlN mina AlmafoEuwli; and each said to be manoSuwbN EalaY AlHaAli, i. e. put in the accus. case as a denotative of state, unless expressed by a complete proposition;] as [qaAy^imFA] in the phrase zayodN fiY Ald~aAra qaAy^imFA [Zeyd is in the house, standing], and in Darabotu zayodFA qaAy^imFA [I beat Zeyd standing]: (Ibn-El-Kemál, TA:) it is fem., like HaAlapN; (Msb;) and mase.; (Msb, K;) but mostly fem.: (TA:) the pl. is A^aHowaAlN and A^aHowilapN, (K,) [both properly pls. of pauc., but the former often used as a pl. of mult., and often signifying circumstances,] the latter anomalous: (TA:) the pl. of HaAlapN↓ is HaAlaAtN: (TA:) or HAlp↓ is the n. un. or sing. of HaAlN and A^aHowaAlN [and HaAlaAtN], used in relation to a man. (S, O.) You say HaAlN HasanN and HasanapN [A good state or condition &c.; as also HaAlapN↓ HasanapN]. (Msb.) And Ald~ahori HaAlaAtu↓ and A^aHowaAluhu The changes, or vicissitudes, of time or fortune. (K.) [And AifoEalohu HaAlFA and fiY AlHaAli Do thou it now, or immediately. And EalaY kul~i HaAlK In any case: a phrase of frequent occurrence. The phrase qaAla lisaAnu AlHaAli (assumed tropical:) The tongue of the case said, (often used by late writers,) means the case seemed to say.] ＝ -A2- A load, or burden: (Ham p. 299:) [whence, perhaps, xafiyfu AlHaAli (which see in what follows) as meaning (assumed tropical:) having a small family to maintain:] and hence, (Ham ib.,) a bundle, or bundle of clothes, (kaArapN,) which is carried on the back (S, Ham ib.) by a man: (S:) or a thing that a man carries on his back, (ISd, O, K,) whatever it be. (ISd, TA.) ― -b2- A [garment of the kind called] kisaA=' in which one collects, or seeks and collects, dry herbage: (O, K:) or a garment, or piece of stuff, of which two ends are tied in a knot behind the flanks, and the other two ends over the head; in which one collects dry herbage; also called $ukobaAnN. (TA in art. $kb.) ＝ -A3- A child's go-cart, by means of which he practises walking; (S, K *, TA;) resembling a small Eajalap; (S;) also called dar~aAjapN [q. v.]. (S, TA.) ＝ -A4- The part of a horse that is the place of the libod [or saddle-cloth]: or the line along the middle of the back: (K, TA:) or HaAlu matoni Alfarasi signifies the middle of the back of the horse; the place of the libodi. (S.) [See also its syn. HaA*N.] xafiyfu AlHaAli signifies the the same as xafiyfu AlHaA*i, (A in art. Hw*,) which means (tropical:) A man light of back; (S, A, L, Msb, all in art. Hw*;) i. e. having little property: and also having a small family to maintain; (L in that art.;) or having little property and a small family to maintain; (L and K in that art.;) like xafiyfu AlZ~ahori. (A, L, Msb, all in that art.) ＝ -A5- Black mud: (S, K:) from HaAla “ it became altered, or changed. ” (TA.) It is said in a trad. that the HAl of El-Kowthar is musk: (TA:) and in another, that Gabriel took of the HAl of the river [Nile] and put it into the mouth of Pharaoh; (S, TA;) but here it has the meaning next following. (TA.) Black fetid mud; syn. HamoA^apN. (K, and Ham p. 288.) And Soft earth. (K, and Ham ib.) ― -b2- And hence, (tropical:) Weakness, and softness. (Ham ib.) ― -b3- Stinking flesh-meat. (Ham ib.) ― -b4- Hot ashes (IAar, K, and Ham ib.) ― -b5- The leaves of the samur [acacia, or mimosa, gummifera,] beaten and shaken off into a garment, or piece of cloth. (K.) ― -b6- Milk. (M, K.) ＝ -A6- In the dial. of Hudheyl, (IAar, TA,) A wife. (IAar, K.)

HawolN Hwl
A year; (S Msb, K, Er-Rághib, &c.;) so termed in consideration of its changing, and of the revolution of the sun in its places of rising and setting; (Er-Rághib, TA;) or as being the period in which [certain] plants attain their complete strength: (El-Harállee, TA:) and even if it has not passed; because it will be [properly speaking] a Hawol: an inf. n. used as a simple subst.: (Msb:) pl. [of pauc., but also used as a pl. of mult.,] A^aHowaAlN (M, Msb, K) and [of mult.] Huw^uwlN and HuwuwlN, (M, K,) the former with ' and the latter with w. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Strength, power, might, or force; syn. quw~apN; (S, TA;) as also HiylapN↓ [originally HiwolapN] (TA) and HawolapN↓, (K, TA,) or this last is a n. un. from HawolN: (TA:) it is in the soul and the body and the acquisitions: and hence the saying, in a trad., laA Hawola wa laA quw~apa A_il~aA biA@ll~`hi AlEaliY~i AlEaZiymi [There is no strength nor power but in, or by means of, God, the High, the Great]: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or it here signifies motion; [see also HawolapN;] and the meaning is, there is no motion nor power,
or ability, but by the will of God: (AHeyth, TA:) or, as some say, the meaning is, there is no Hwl [i. e. changing, or turning, or receding,] from disobedience, nor qw~p [i. e. power] to obey, but by the accommodating, or disposing, of God. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also HiylapN. ＝ -A3- Hawolu $aYo'i The lateral, or adjacent, part to which a thing may shift, or remove: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or the environs [of a thing]. (Msb.) You say, qaEaduwA Hawolahu, (S, K, *) or qaEadonaA Hawolahu, the noun being in the accus. case as an adv. n. of place, i. e., [They sat, or we sat, around him, or it, or] in his, or its, environs; (Msb;) and HawaAlahu↓, and Hawolayohi, (S, K,) dual of Hawol, (TA,) and HawaAlayohi↓, (S, Msb, K,) dual of HawaAl, (TA,) and A^aHowaAlahu, (ISd, K,) pl. of Hawol, and used to give intensiveness to the meaning: (ISd, TA:) but you should not say HawaAliyhi. (S, Sgh.) And walaA EalayonaA Aall~`hum~a HawaAlayonaA↓ [O God, be Thou around us as our protector, and not against us,] occurs in a trad. respecting prayer. (TA.) It is said, in the Expos. of the exs. cited as testimonies by Sb, that one sometimes says HawaAlayoka↓ and Hawolayoka, meaning Around thee, in every direction; dividing the surrounding parts into two; like as one says, A^aHaATuwA bihi mino jaAnibayohi, not meaning that any of the surrounding parts remained vacant. (TA.) [See also an ex. voce danodana.]

HawalN Hwl
inf. n. of Hawilato Eayonuhu. (S, K. [See 1, last sentence.]) ＝ -A2- See also HaAy^ilN.

HawilN Hwl
: see Huw~alN: ― -b2- and see also 1, last sentence.

HuwalN Hwl
: see Huw~alN: ― -b2- and HaAy^ilN: ― -b3- and HiyaAlN.

HiwalN Hwl
Removal from one place to another, in a passive sense; a subst. from taHaw~ala: (S, O, K:) and in an active sense; a subst. from Haw~alahu; (K;) accord. to ISd, it is the latter [only]; (TA;) as also HawiylN↓. (K.) Hence, in the Kur [xviii. 108], laA yaboguwna EanohaA HawolFA [They shall not desire removal from it]
Hawula
(S, M, O, K:) or, as some say, it here means HiylapF↓; i. e. they shall not [desire to] practise, or seek to practise, any evasion from it to another abode. (TA.) ― -b2- See also HiyalpN [of which it is said to be both a syn. and a pl.]. ― -b3- And see HuwlapN. ＝ -A2- Also A furrow, or trench, in the ground, in which palm-trees are planted in a row. (ISd, K.)

HaAlapN HAl HAlh HAlp
; pl. HaAlaAtN: see HaAlN, in seven places.

HawolapN Hwl Hwlh Hwlp
Motion, or removal, (taHar~ukN or taHaw~ulN, accord. to different copies of the K, the former being the reading in the TA,) and change of state. (K.) [See also HawolN. And see HaAla EalaY Alfarasi, of which it is the inf. n.] ― -b2- See also HiylapN. ― -b3- And see HawolN, as meaning quw~apN.

HuwlapN Hwl Hwlh Hwlp
: see Huw~alN: ― -b2- and HiylapN. ― -b3- Also A wonder, or wonderful thing; pl. HuwlN. (K: [but probably this should be HuwalN, as below.]) ― -b4- [It is also used as a pl., signifying Wonders.] You say, h`*aA mino Huwlapi Ald~ahoi This is of the wonders of the age, or of time, or fortune; as also mn HawalaAnihi↓, and Hiwalihi↓ [pl. of HiylapN↓], and HuwalaAy^ihi↓. (K, TA: the last, in one copy of the K, HuwalaAnihi↓, and in the CK HuwolAnhi↓.) ― -b5- An evil, or abominable, event or accident; (K, * TA;) a calamity, or misfortune: pl. HuwalN: as in the saying, huwa HuwlapN mina AlHuwali It is a calamity of calamities. (S, TA.) It is also used as an epithet; so that one says, jaA='a biA^amorK HuwlapK [He did, or brought to pass, an evil, or abominable, thing]. (M, TA.)

HiylapN Hyl Hylh Hylp
, (S, M, Msb, K, &c.,) originally HiwolapN, (Er-Rághib, TA,) [said to be an inf. n., (see 8,)] and HawolN↓ (S, M, K) and HayolN and HiwalN↓, (M, K,) which is also a pl. of the first, (K,) and HawolapN↓ (K) and HuwlapN↓ (Ks, TA) and HawiylN↓ (M, K) and HaAy^ilapN↓ (Ham p. 652) and maHaAlapN↓ (S, K) and maHaAlN↓, (M, K,) [said to be an inf. n., (see 8,)] and maHiylapN↓, (Sgh, TA,) i. q. AiHotiyaAlN and taHaw~ulN and taHay~ulN; (M, K; [see 8;]) [or A mode, or manner, of changing from one state to another, or of shifting from one thing to another; HiylapN being of the measure fiEolapN from HaAla, like jilosapN &c. from jalasa &c.; or from taHaw~ulN as syn. with HaAla; (see what follows;) a mode, or means, of evading or eluding a thing, or of effecting an object; an evasion or elusion, a shift, a wile, an artifice, or artful contrivance or device, a machination, a trick, a plot, a stratagem, or an expedient;] a means of effecting one's transition from that which he dislikes to that which he likes; (KT, in explanation of the first word;) art, artifice, cunning, ingenuity, or skill, (Msb, K,) in the management of affairs; i. e. the turning over, or revolving, thoughts, ideas, schemes, or contrivances, in the mind, so as to find a way of attaining one's object; (Msb;) and excellence of consideration or deliberation; and ability to manage according to one's own free will, (K, TA,) with subtilty: (TA:) accord. to Er-Rághib, HiylapN signifies a means of attaining to some state concealedly; and it is mostly used of that in which is sin, or offence, or disobedience; but sometimes of that in the exercise of which is wisdom; and hence God is described as $adiydu AlmaHaAli↓, meaning strong in attaining, concealedly from men, to that in which is wisdom: accord. to Abu-l-Bakà, it is from Alt~aHaw~ulu; because by it one shifts from one state to another, by a species of forecast, and gentleness, or delicacy, so as to change a thing from its outward appearance: (TA:) the pl. of HiylapN is HiwalN and HiyalN [which latter is the most common form, and also, as well as HiwalN, said to be syn. with the sing.,] and HiylaAtN. (K.) One says, laA Hiylapa lahu [He has no mode, or means, of evading &c.]. (TA.) [And maA biyadiY HiylapN I have no mode, or means, of evading &c.]. And Almaro'u yaEojizu laA maHaAlapa↓ [Man becomes impotent: there is no avoiding it]. (S.) minohu laA maHaAlapa↓ means laA bud~a [There is no avoiding it, or escaping it]. (S, * K.) One says, Almawotu A=tK laA maHaAlapa↓ [Death comes: there is no avoiding it]. (S.) See also HiwalN. ― -b2- And see HuwlapN: ― -b3- and HawolN. ― -b4- [Eilomu AlHiyali The science of mechanics.]

HuwalapN Hwl Hwlh Hwlp
: see Huw~alN, in two places.

[masc. HawaAliY~N; and] fem. Hawoliy~aAtN. (S, K.) HawoliY~N AlgaDaA Young trees of the kind called gaDFA. (TA.)

HiyaliY~N Hyl HylY Hylp Hyly
: see Huw~alN.

HuwalaA='u HwlA='
and HiwalaA='u, the latter like EinabaA='u and siyaraA='u, which are the only other words of this measure, (S, K,) accord. to Kh, (S,) [The membrane that encloses the she-camel's fœtus in the womb;] to the she-camel, like the ma$iymap (K, TA) to the woman; (TA;) i. e., (K,) a skin (S, K) of a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour (xaDoraA='), full of water, (K,) which comes forth with the fœtus, containing A^agoraAs [pl. of giros, q. v.], and having lines, or streaks, which are red, and of a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour (xuDor): (S, K:) or it comes forth after the fœtus, in the first salaY; and is the first thing that comes forth therefrom: so says ISk: and the word is sometimes used in relation to a woman: (TA:) or, accord. to AZ, the water that comes forth upon the head of the fœtus, [i. e.] at the birth: (S:) or a membrane like a large bucket, which is full of water, and bursts when it falls upon the ground: then comes forth the salaY; and a day, or two days, after that, the SaA='ap. (TA.) Hence the saying, nazaluwA fiY mivoli Huwal=A'i Aln~aAqapi, (K,) and fY mvl Hwl=A' Als~alaY, (TA,) (tropical:) They alighted amid abundance of water and green herbage. (K, * TA.) And raA^ayotu A^aroDFA mivola AlHwl=A'i (tropical:) I saw land having dark green herbage. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also HuwlapN.

HawalaAn HwlAn
and HuwalaAn and HuwolaAn: see HuwlapN.

HuwlalN Hwll
: see HaAy^ilN, in four places.

HawalowalN Hwlwl
: see Huw~alN, in two places.

: see HaAy^ilN, in two places.

HiyaAlN HyAl
[in the CK, erroneously, HayAl] The front of a thing, as meaning the part, place, or location, that is over against, opposite, facing, fronting, or in front; syn. qubaAlapN. (K, and Mgh in art. Hyl.) You say, qumotu HiyaAlahu I stood in front of him; in the part, place, or location, that was over against him, opposite to him, &c.; syn. qubaAlatahu. (Msb in art. Hyl.) And qaEada HiyaAlapN
and biHiyaAlihi He sat in front of him, over against him, opposite to him, facing or fronting him; syn. biA_izaAy^ihi. (S, K.) And h`*aA HiyaAla kalimatika This is opposite to thy saying; syn. muqaAbalapa; in the accus. case, as an adv. n. of place: thus related by IAar from the Arabs: but one may also say HiyaAlu kalimatika [the opposite of thy saying], making the phrase to consist of an inchoative and an enunciative: so says ISd. (TA.) It is originally with w [in the place of the Y]. (S, O.) ― -b2- EalaY HiyaAlihi [By himself or itself; independently]. You say, A^aEoTi kul~a waAHidK minohumo EalaY HiyaAlahu Give thou to every one of them by himself; syn. ElY Hidatihi; (S in art. wHd;) or biA@nofiraAdihi. (Mgh in art. Hyl.) And faEalotu kul~a $aYo'K EalaY HiyaAlihi I did everything by itself; syn. biA@nofiraAdihi. (Msb in art. Hyl.) ＝ -A2- Also A string that is tied from the camel's biTaAn [or belly-girth] to his Haqab [or hind girth], to prevent the Haqab from going against the sheath of his penis: (K:) so, too, in the M: but in the O, as on the authority of AA, HuwalN↓, like SuradN, signifies the string that is between the Haqab and the biTaAn. (TA.)

HawiylN Hwyl
: see 4, in the latter half of the paragraph. ― -b2- [Hence,] One who is responsible, or answerable. (K.) ― -b3- And A witness. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also HiwalN: ― -b2- and HiylapN. ― -b3- Also [Desire: or a seeking: or a seeking by an artful contrivance or device, or by artful or skilful management, to find a way of attaining an object:] a subst. from HaAwalahu. (S, O, K.)

HawaAlapN HwAl HwAlh HwAlp
The effecting a transition of one river, or rivulet, to another. (M, K.) [This is what is meant by the HwAlp in AlmuzaAraEap, mentioned in the Mgh, as “ customary in the cases of certain plants, as rice, and the baA*inojaAn, and in planting. ”] ― -b2- The transfer of a claim, or of a debt, by shifting the responsibility from one person to another: (Mgh:) the transfer of a debt by shifting the responsibility of him who transfers it to him to whom it is transferred: (KT:) [a reference made by a debtor, of his creditor, to a debtor of the former, for the payment of what is owed by the former to the latter: an order for the payment of a debt, or of a sum of money, given by one person, upon another, to a third person: so in the present day:] a subst. (S, K) from A^aHaAli Ealayohi bidayonihi, (S,) or from A^aHalotuhu bidayonihi, (Msb,) or from A^aHaAla Algariyma. (K.) [See 4.] ― -b3- A responsibility; accountableness. (K.)

HawaAliY~N HwAl HwAlY HwAly
and HuwaAliY~N: see the next paragraph.

Huw~alN Hwl
, applied to a man, signifies baSiyru bitaHowiyli AlA^umuwri [i. e. Knowing, skilful, or intelligent, in turning affairs over, or about, in his mind, considering what may be their results, and so managing them]; (S, TA;) as also Huw~alN qul~abN, (TA, and so in copies of the S,) and qul~abN Huw~aliY~N↓, (TA, and so in a copy of the S,) and qul~abiY~N Huw~aliY~N↓, and Haw~aAlN↓; (TA;) and HuwalapN↓ signifies muHotaAlN↓ [i. e. one who exercises art, artifice, cunning, ingenuity, or skill, and excellence of consideration or deliberation, and ability to manage according to his own free will, with subtilty; &c.; see the verb (8) of which muHotaAlN is the part. n.]: (S:) or Huw~alN and HuwalN↓ and HuwalapN↓ and HuwolapN↓ and Huw~aliY~N↓, [in the CK, erroneously, Hawol`Y,] like suk~ariY~N, [in the CK like sakorY`,] and HaAliY~N↓ and HuwaAliY~N↓ and HawalowalN↓, signify $adiydu AlAiHotiyaAli [i. e. one who exercises great art, artifice, &c.]: (Sgh, K:) all of these forms are mentioned by ISd, except HuwolapN and Huw~aliY~N: (TA:) accord. to some, qul~abN Huw~alN signifies experienced, or expert, in affairs; or one who has been tried, or proved, and strengthened by experience in affairs: (Har p. 312:) and HawilN↓ signifies the same as Huw~alN; (Ham p. 34;) having much Hiylap [i. e. art, artifice, &c.]: accord. to analogy, it should be [HaAlN,] like maAlN and SaAtN as epithets applied to a man: (Idem pp. 530 and 531:) Hay~aAlN, also, [in like manner,] signifies SaAHibu HiylapK [i. e. one who exercises art, artifice, &c., as above]; and so HiyaliY~N↓ [from HiyalN, pl. of, or syn. with, HiylapN]: (TA:) and HawolowalN↓ [mentioned above (in the CK, erroneously, in this instance, HawAwil)] signifies also cunning, or intelligent, or skilful and knowing; and quick and sharp or vigorous or effective; syn. munokarN kamiy$N; (K, TA;) applied to a man. (TA.)

Hay~ilN Hyl Hylp
: see 4, in the latter half of the paragraph.

Huw~aliY~N Hwl HwlY Hwly
: see Huw~alN, in three places.

: see Huw~alN.

HaAy^ilN *
Altering, or being transmuted, or changing; or altered, or transmuted, or changed; [in any manner; and particularly] in colour; (K, TA;) and becoming, or become, black; applied to a bone, and any other thing. (TA.) ― -b2- Anything [shifting, or moving, or] that has shifted, or moved, in fiY [app. a mistranscription for mino from]) its place. (TA.) ― -b3- A she-camel, and any female, not conceiving, or not becoming pregnant, during a year, (M, K,) or two years, (K,) or some years: (M, K:) or a she-camel not pregnant (S, Msb, K) after having been covered by the stallion; (S, K;) because denoting a change from what is usual; (Er-Rághib, TA;) and in like manner applied to a ewe, or she-goat; (TA;) and to a woman: (Msb:) pl. HiyaAlN and HuwlN (S, K) and Huw~alN, (K,) and HuwlalN↓ (M, K) is a quasi-pl. n.: (M, TA:) [whence,] HaAy^ilu HuwlK and HuwlalN↓ used as intensive epithets: or HaAy^ilN signifies not conceiving in one year, (K, TA,) when she has been covered: (TA:) and HaAy^ilu HuwlK and HuwlalK↓, not conceiving during two years; (K;) not conceiving in the first year after having been covered, nor in the next following year; like EaAy^iTu EuwTK and EiyTK and EuwTaTK: (S in art. EwT:) one says also, laqiHato EalaY HuwlK and HuwlalK↓ [app. meaning She conceived after having failed to do so for two years; for it seems that in this case Hwl and Hwll are inf. ns., or that the latter is a subst. having the sense of an inf. n.: see 1, and see also EuwTaTN]: (TA:) and muHaw~ilN↓ signifies the same as HaAy^ilN. (K.) Also A palm-tree (Msb, K) that bears one year, and not another year: (K:) or not bearing. (Msb.) ― -b4- The female young one of a camel, at the time of her birth: the male is termed saqobN: (S, K:) pl. HuwlN and HawaAy^ilu. (TA.) One says, nutijati Aln~aAqapu HaAy^ilFA HasanapF [The she-camel brought forth a beautiful female young one]. (S.) And laA A^afoEalu *aAka maA A^arozamato A^um~u HaAy^ilK [I will not do that as long as a mother of a female young camel utters her gentle yearning cry]. (S.) ＝ -A2- Also, (Lth, Mgh, O, TA,) and HiwaAlN↓ (Lth, K) and HuwalN↓ and HawalN↓, (K,) A thing that intervenes as a separation, a partition, a fence, a barrier, or an obstacle, or obstruction, between two other things. (Lth, Mgh, * O, K.) One says, bayonahumaA h`*aA HiwaAlN↓, i. e. HaAy^ilN [This is a thing intervening as a separation, &c., between them two]; like HijaAzN and HaAjizN. (Lth, O, TA.)

HaAy^ilapN *
: see HiyalpN.

A^aHowalu *
; and its fem. HawolaA='u: see 1, last sentence. ― -b2- A^aHowalu mino bawoli Aljamali [More wry than the urine of the he-camel]: because it does not come forth straight, but [backwards, and] inclining to one side: a prov. (TA.) ― -b3- huwa A^aHowalu minoka He is one who has more Hiylap [meaning art, artifice, cunning, ingenuity, or skill, in the management of affairs, &c.,] than thou; (Fr, S, K;) as also A^aHoyalu↓. (K.) And Aln~aAsi huwa A^aHoyalu↓ [He is the most artful, cunning, ingenious, or skilful, of men]; originally A^aHowalu. (MF in art. rwd: see A^arowadu.)

; and muHaAlN Ealayohi; and muHaAlN bihi: see 4, in the latter half of the paragraph. ― -b2- muHaAlN also signifies [Absurd; inconsistent; self-contradictory;] comprising two contradictories; as when one speaks of one body in two places in one case [or time]: (Er-Rághib, TA:) that cannot be conceived as existing in reality: (TA:) i. q. baATilN [as meaning untrue, or unreal]; (Msb, TA;) impossible; that cannot be: (Msb:) perverted; turned from its proper way or manner of being; (K;) applied to speech; (S, K;) as also musotaHiylN↓. (K.)

muHowilN mHwl
: see muHiylN: ― -b2- and see also HawoliY~N, in two places.

: see 4, in the latter half of the paragraph. ― -b2- Also A woman that brings forth a boy next after a girl; or the reverse: and in like
manner applied to a she-camel; as also muHowilN↓ and muHaw~ilN↓: (Ks, Sgh, K:) and accord. to some, mutaHaw~ilN↓ [if not a mistranscription for muHowilN or muHaw~ilN] signifies a she-camel that brings forth one year a male, and another year a female. (TA.) ― -b3- See also HawoliY~N.

: see HiylapN, in four places. ― -b2- Also A machine (manojanuwn, Lth, K) over which [passes the rope whereby] water is drawn: (Lth, TA:) and, (K,) or as some say, (TA,) a great bakorap [or sheave of a pulley], (S in art. mHl, and K,) by means of which camels draw water: (S ubi suprà and TA:) [see saAniyapN:] pl. maHaAwilu and [coll. gen. n.] maHaAlN↓. (K.) ― -b3- The vertebræ; as also maHaAlN↓: (K: [in the CK, AlfaqaAri is erroneously put for AlfaqaAru:]) or the latter has this meaning; and the former signifies a single vertebra: and the m may be radical: (M, TA:) pl. maHaAlaAtN. (T in art. mlH.) ― -b4- The middle (waAsiT, as in the M and O; in the K, erroneously, waAsiTap, TA) of the back; (M, O, K;) as also maHaAlN↓: but accord. to some, the m is radical. (TA.)

maHiylapN mHyl mHylh mHylp
: see HiylapN.

muHaw~ilN mHwl
: see HaAy^ilN: ― -b2- and muHiylN.

A man who says much that is muHaAl [or absurd, inconsistent, self-contradictory, unreal, or impossible]. (Lth, K. *)

muHotaAlN mHtAl
: see 4, in the latter half of the paragraph. ― -b2- A^aroDN muHotaAlapN (tropical:) Land upon which rain has not fallen. (TA.) ― -b3- See also Huw~alN.

[pass. part. n. of taHaw~alahu. ＝ -A2- Also] an inf. n. of taHaw~ala. (Ham p. 503.) ＝ -A3- And A place to which one shifts, removes, or becomes transferred. (Idem ib.)

musotaHiylN mstHyl
; fem. with p: see the paragraph next preceding, in two places: ― -b2- and see also muHaAlN. ＝ -A2- Also Full. (K.)

, inf. n. HawolaqapN: see Q. Q. 1 in art. Hlq.

, (S, Msb, K,) Hawola AlmaA='i, (S, Msb,) or EalaY Al$~aYo'i, (K,) aor. yaHuwmu, (S,) inf. n. HawamaAnN (S, Msb, K) and HawomN, (S, K,) said of a bird, or flying thing, (S, Msb, K,) &c., (S,) It went, [or hovered,] or circled, (S, Msb, K,) round about the water, (S, Msb,) by reason of thirst, (TA,) or round about the thing: (K:) and in like manner HaAmato, said of camels. (K, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] it is said in a trad., mano HaAma Hawola AlHimaY yuw$ika A^ano yaqaEa fiyhi, meaning (assumed tropical:) He who approaches acts of disobedience is near to falling therein. (Msb.) And you say, huwa yaHuwmu Hawola garaDK lahu (tropical:) [He hovers about an object of aim, or desire, that he has]. (TA.) And HAm fulaAnN EalaY AlA^amori, inf. n. HawomN and HiyaAmN and Huw^uwmN, (K, TA,) the second with kesr [to the H, and therefore with Y in the place of w, but written in the CK with fet-h], (TA,) (tropical:) Such a one desired, or sought, the thing. i. q. AisotadaAma (tropical:) [app. as meaning (assumed tropical:) He paused, and acted with deliberation, or in a patient or leisurely manner, or he waited in expectation, in the affair, or case, like one who hovers about a thing]. (K, TA.)

jayo$u HaAmK *
[lit. The army of Ham, the son of Noah; meaning, because of its blackness,] (tropical:) the night. (TA.)

, applied to wine, (TA,) That circulates [or produces a sensation of circular motion] in the head. (K.) ― -b2- Accord. to As, so applied, it signifies Much in quantity. (TA.)

The main part or portion, (S, K,) of water, (S,) or of the sea, (K,) and of sand, and of a fight, &c.: (S, K:) the part where is most water, of the sea; (Ham p. 329, and TA;) the deepest part thereof: (TA:) and in like manner, of a watering-trough: (Ham ibid., and TA:) or a copious, or deep, part of water: (Lh, TA:) and hence, the vehemence of war or fight: (Ham p. 329:) or a place of fight; because the opposing parties go round about it: (Ham p. 492:) or the most vehement part [or the thickest] of a fight: (K, * TA:) pl. HawomaAtN. (Ham p. 329.) [See also HawobapN, last signification.]

HaAmiY~N HAmY HAmy HAmyy
A black, or negro, boy or young man, (S, K,) or slave: (S:) so termed in relation to HAm [or Ham, the son of Noah], the father of the blacks, or negroes. (S, K.)

HaAy^imN *
Thirsty, and going, [or hovering,] or circling, round about the water: (Ham p. 753:) and hence, (Id. p. 317,) whatever is thirsty: (Id. ibid., and K:) [fem. with p: pl. masc. Huw~amN:] pl. fem. And it is said in a trad., respecting the prayer for rain, Aall~`hum~a A@roHamo bahaAy^imanaA AlHaAy^imapa O God, have mercy upon our beasts that are going about the water and not finding any to which they may come to drink. (TA.) You say also haAmapN HaAy^imapN A thirsty head: (TA:) or a head of which the brain is thirsty. (T, TA.) ― -b2- Also (tropical:) Desiring, or seeking: pl. Huw~amN, (K, TA,) [in the CK HawamN, but it is] like suk~arN. (TA.)

, mentioned in the K in arts. Hnt and Hyn and Hnw: see HaAnapN, above; and see also art. Hnw [to which several words allied to this are to be regarded as belonging]. : see art. Hnw.

: see art. Hnw.

Wine; (S and K in art. Hyn, [in the CK, erroneously, HAy^nap,] and K in art. Hnw;) a rel. n. from HaAnapN: (S, TA:) or vintners; (K in art. Hnw;) [from HaAniY~N; or] a rel. n. from HaAniyapN. (TA in art. Hnw.)

, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. [inf. n. of Hw~Y] signifies The act of drawing together, or contracting: and the state of drawing together, or contracting; or being drawn together, or contracted; as also taHaw~K [inf. n. of tHw~Y↓]: (Lh, K:) or, in the opinion of ISd, taHowiyapN has the former signification; and taHaw~K↓, the latter.
