Possessing, after deserving, or after becoming entitled. (IAar, K.) ＝ -A2- A small wateringtrough, or tank, (K, TA,) which a man makes for his camel; called also marokuw~N. (TA.) [See also the next paragraph.]

Hawiy~apN Hwyh Hwyp
: see HawFY. ＝ -A2- Also A winding, or circling, or coiled, gut or intestine; and so HaAwiyapN↓ and HaAwiyaA='u↓: (K:) [also called qitobN:] or the [kind of gut, or intestine, termed] daw~aArap in the belly of the sheep or goat; as also HaAwiyapN↓: (IAar:) Hawiy~apN AlbaToni and AlbaToni HaAwiyapN↓ and AlbaToni HaAwiyaA='u↓ all signify the same: (S:) the pl. is HawaAyaA; (K;) or this is the pl. of Hawiy~apN, signifying the A^amoEaA=' [or intestines into which the food passes from the stomach]; and the pl. of HaAwiyapN and HaAwiyaA='u is [said to be] HawaAwK; (S;) but IB says that this latter pl. is not held to be allowable by Sb, and that HawaAyaA is the pl. of all the three sings., [originally] of the measure faEaAy^ilu as pl. of the first, and fawaAEilu as pl. of the second and third [though in these two cases it should be by rule HawaA='K]: AHeyth says that HawaAyaA as pl. of HaAwiyapN is like zawaAyaA as pl. of zaAwiyapN: and ISk mentions AlHaAwiyaAtu as pl. of AlHaAwiyapu and AlHaAwiyaA='u, [in the latter case like qaASiEaAtN as pl. of qaASiEaA='u,] and explains it as signifying banaAtu All~abani [app. meaning the small guts, or intestines, in which originate the lacteals]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also sing. of HawaAyaA signifying Winding excavations or hollows, which the rain fills, and in which it remains a long time because the soil at the bottom thereof is cohesive and hard, retaining the water: the Arabs call them [also] A^amoEaA=', likening them to the HawaAyaA of the belly: accord. to AA, the pl. signifies i. q. masaATiHu [pl. of misoTaHN], made by collecting earth and stones upon smooth and hard rock, to confine thereby water: accord. to IB, on the authority of IKh, wells that are dug in the district of Kelb, in hard ground, whereby is confined the water of the torrents, which they drink throughout the year: accord. to Nasr, a certain construction with masses of rock in the form of a pool, on the way to Et-Teghlibeeyeh, near Ood: accord. to ISd, the sing. signifies a smooth and hard rock which is surrounded with stones and earth, in which water collects. (TA.) ― -b3- Also A [garment of the kind called] kisaA=', stuffed [with vumaAm or the like], which is wound round the hump of the camel; (S, K; *) i. q. sawiy~apN, except that the former is only for camels, and the latter is sometimes for other animals: pl. HawaAyaA: (S:) a subst. from 2 in the last of the senses assigned to it above: (IAth:) [the same is app. meant by what here follows:] a certain thing that is prepared for a woman to ride upon. (TA. [But it was also used by men.]) 'Omeyr Ibn-Wahb El-Jumahee said, on the day of Bedr, when he computed the number of the companions of the Prophet, raA^ayotu AlHawaAyaA EalayohaA AlmanaAyaA [meaning I saw the HwAyA with the men of courage upon them]: (S:) [for] maniy~apN [sing. of mnAyA] means (assumed tropical:) “ a man of courage upon his saddle. ” (TA.)

Huway~apN Hwyh Hwyp
[a dim. of Hay~apN]: see what next follows.

rajulN Haw~aA='N rjl HwA='
A man who collects serpents (Hay~aAt); and so HaAwK↓: [which latter, vulgarly pronounced HaAwiY, is also now applied to a serpent-charmer; and a juggler who performs various tricks with serpents &c.:] (K in art. HY:) or the latter, (S in that art.,) or both, (T in that art.,) an owner of serpents; (T, S;) and so HaAYK: (T:) the pl. of HaAwK is HuwaApN. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AlHaw~aA='u AlHuway~apu↓ (assumed tropical:) The constellations Serpentarius and Serpens. (Kzw.)

HaAwK HAw HAwy
: see what next precedes.

HaAwiyapN HAwy HAwyh HAwyp
: see Hawiy~apN, in three places.

HaAwiyaA='u HAwyA='
: see Hawiy~apN, in two places.

HaAwiY~N HAwY HAwy HAwyy
: see HaAy^iY~N, in art. HwA^.

Hay~apN Hy Hyh Hyp
[meaning A serpent] is said by some to be from taHaw~aY, because what is so termed gathers itself together, and winds, or coils, itself; (ISd, * K, * TA;) and to be originally HawoyapN; (TA in art. HY;) and their opinion is strengthened by the forms and meaning of the words Haw~aA='N and HaAwK (TA) [and by the form and meaning of the word maHowaApN]: or the Hy~p is so called because of the length of its life (liTuwli HayaAtihaA). (K. [See the next art.])

A^aHowaY *
: see art. Hw.

A^aHowiY~N *
: see art. Hw.

mHwY mHw mHwY mHwy
[app. maHowFY]: see HiwaA='N.

A^aroDN maHowaApN *
A land abounding with Hay~aAt [or serpents]: (TA:) or containing serpents; as also maHoyaApN. (Ibn-Es-Sarráj, S in art. HY.)

maHowiY~N mHw mHwY mHwy
pass. part. n. of HawaAhu. (Msb.)

muHaw~FY mHw mHwY mHwy
: see HiwaA='N.

mHtwY mHtwY mHtwy mHtwyy
[app. muHotawFY]: see HiwaA='N.

superEntry.head: HY: or HY and Hyw
superEntry.entry:
1 HayiYa Hy HyY Hyy Hyyy
, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and HaY~a, (S, K,) which latter is the more common, (Fr, S,) [like mal~a, originally malila,] dual HayiyaA, and Hay~aA, (Fr,) pl. HayuwA, (Fr, S,) like xa$uwA, (S,) and Hay~uwA, (Fr, S,) as some say, (S,) aor. yaHoyaA, (S, Msb, K,) and yaHaY~u, (Fr, K,) [like yamal~u, originally yamolalu,] occurring in poetry, but improper, and disallowed by the Basrees, (Fr,) inf. n. HayaApN [q. v. infrà], (IB, Mgh, Msb,) or HayaA='N, (K,) and HiY~N and HayawaAnN, (IB,) which last has an intensive signification, like its contr. mawataAnN, (Msb,) He, or it, lived; or was, or became, in the state termed HayaApN, explained below. (S, K.) [The inf. n. HayawaAnN (q. v. infrà) suggests the supposition that HayiYa may be originally Hayiwa; but I find no authority for this supposition; and if it be the case, this verb presents the only instance of a root of which the medial radical letter is Y and the final w.] ― -b2- HayuwA, said of a people, or company of men, (assumed tropical:) They were, or became, in good condition: (AA, S:) or they were, or became, fat, by having the means of subsistence, baEoda huzaAlK [after leanness]. (AZ. [See also 4.]) ― -b3- You say also, Hay~ati Aln~aAru, inf. n. HayaApN and HayaA='N, (assumed tropical:) [The fire was, or became, alive, or burning,] like as you say, maAtat. (AHn.) ― -b4- HayiYa AlT~ariyqu (assumed tropical:) The road, or way, was, or became, apparent, or distinct. (K.) One says, A_i*aA HayiYa laka AlT~ariyqu faxu*o yamonapF (assumed tropical:) [When the road, or way, becomes apparent, or distinct, to thee, take to the right]. (TA.) ― -b5- HayiYa and HayiYa minohu, aor. yaHoyaA, inf. n. HayaA='N: see 10, in two places. ＝ -A2- HaY~a Alxamosiyna: see 2.

2 Hy~Ahu Hy HyA HyAh HyAp
, inf. n. taHiy~apN, (Mgh, Msb, K,) in its primary sense, i. q. AHyAhu↓. (Mgh.) You say, Hay~aAka A@ll~`hu, (S, K,) meaning May God preserve thee alive; prolong thy life; or make thee to continue in life; syn. A^aboqaAka; (Fr, Selemeh Ibn- 'Ásim, K;) as also AHyAk↓; (Selemeh Ibn-'Ásim, TA;) or Eam~araka: (Aboo-'Othmán El-Mázinee, Mgh, TA:) or may God save thee; or make thee to be free from evil, or harm, or the like: (Fr, TA:) or may God make thee to have dominion: (Fr, S, K:) or may God honour thee, and benefit thee. (Ham. p. 489.) And Hay~aAka A@ll~`hu wabay~aAka [explained in art. bY]. (TA.) And Hay~aA A@ll~`hu wajohaka [May God preserve thy face: see muHay~FA]. (Ham p. 23.) ― -b2- Also He said to him Hay~aAka A@ll~`hu, explained above: (Mgh:) originally, he prayed for his life: and then, he prayed for him, absolutely: (Msb:) he saluted him; (K, TA;) and so Hy~Ahu taHiy~apa Almuw^omini: (Lh, TA:) as used in the language of the law, he said to him, salaAmN Ealayoka. (Msb.) ― -b3- [See also taHiy~apN, below.] ＝ -A2- Hy~A Alxamosiyna [in the CK (erroneously) Alxamosiyna HaY~a↓] He approached [the age of] fifty. (IAar, K, TA.) ＝ -A3- Hay~ayatu HaA='F HasanpF and HasanFA [I wrote a beautiful H]. (TA in bAb AlAlf All~ynp.)

3 HaAyayotu Aln~aAra HAyyt AlnAr
, (inf. n. muHaAyaApN, TA,) i. q. A^aHoyayotuhaA↓ [i. e. (assumed tropical:) I gave life to, enlivened, or revived, the fire] by blowing. (K.) [See also 2 in art. rhb; where a similar meaning is assigned to the former verb; but perhaps it is there a mistranscription.] muHaAyaApN also signifies Nourishment (gi*aA=' [which is properly speaking a subst., but seems to be here used as an inf. n.,]) for, or of a child, (K, TA,) with that whereby is his life, or, as in the M, because thereby is his life. (TA.)

4 AHyAhu AHyAh AHyAp A^HyAh A^HyY
, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) inf. n. A_iHoyaA='N, (TA,) said of God, (S, Msb,) He made him alive, to live, or be a living being; quickened, endued with life, vivified, [revivified, revived, or resuscitated,] him. (S, * Msb, * K.) Hence, in the Kur [lxxv. last verse], A^alayosa *`lika biqaAdirK A^ano yuHoyiYa AlmawotaY, (S, TA,) i. e. Is not That Doer of these things (Jel) [able to quicken the dead?]. ― -b2- See also 2, in two places. ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) He (God) endued him with the intellectual faculty: as in the saying, in the Kur [vi. 122], A^awamano kaAna may~itFA faA^aHoyayonaAhu (assumed tropical:) [And is he who was intellectually dead and whom we have endued with the intellectual faculty...?]. (Er-Rághib.) ― -b4- See also 3. ― -b5- AHyA AlA^aroDa (assumed tropical:) He (God) revived the earth, or land, by the rain, so as to produce in it plants, or herbage. (TA.) And A^uHoyiyati AlA^aroDu (assumed tropical:) The land was tilled, and made productive. (AHn.) And AHyA AlmawaAti (tropical:) He turned to use the unowned and unused and uncultivated land by walling it round or sowing it or building upon it and the like. (TA.) ― -b6- Also (assumed tropical:) He (a man) found the land to be fruitful, or abundant in herbage, (S, K,) with fresh herbage. (K.) ― -b7- AHyA All~ayola (assumed tropical:) He passed the night in religious service, worship, adoration, or devotion, abstaining from sleep: (TA:) or [simply] he remained awake during the night. (W p. 9.) And AHyA layolatahu He passed his night awake. (MA.) ＝ -A2- AHyt Aln~aAqapu The she-camel had living offspring; (S, K;) her offspring seldom, or never, died. (S.) ― -b2- AHyA Alqawomu The people, or company of men, had their cattle living: (K:) or had their cattle in good condition: (AA, S, K:) or had rain, so that their beasts obtained herbage to such a degree that they became fat: (AZ:) or they (themselves) became in a state of abundance of herbage, or plenty. (S, K. [See also 1.])

5 tHy~A minohu tHyA mnh tHyA mnp
(assumed tropical:) He shrank from it: taken from AlHayaA='u [or AlHayaApu]; because it is of the nature of the living to shrink: or it is originally taHaw~aY; the w being changed into Y; or [in other words] from AlHaY~u “ the act of collecting, ” [inf. n. of HawaAhu,] like taHay~aza from AlHawozu. (TA.) [See also 10.]

6 taHaAyaA tHAyA tHyp
as quasi-pass. of 3, He quickened, enlivened, or revived, himself. See an ex. voce ruwHN.]

10 AstHyAhu AstHyAh AstHyAp {stHyAh {stHyY
He spared him; let him live; or left him alive; (S, Msb, K, TA;) did not slay him; (Msb;) in which sense the verb has but one form: (Msb, TA:) or he left him; let him alone; or forbore from him. (Mgh.) ― -b2- Hence, as some say, (K,) A_in~a A@ll~`ha laA yasotaHoyiY A^ano yaDoriba mavalFA, (S, K,) in the Kur [ii. 24], i. e. laA yasotaboqiY [meaning Verily God will not spare to propound, or refrain from propounding, a parable, or as a parable]. (S.) [Hence, also,] A_in~a A@ll~`ha yasotaHoyiY mino *iY Al$~ayobapi Almusolimi A^ano yuEa*~ibahu, i. e. [Verily God] forbears from punishing [the hoary Muslim]. (Er-Rághib.) ― -b3- [AisotaHoyaY, or AisotaHoyaA, which latter is the more proper mode of writing it, also signifies He felt, or had a sense of, or he was, or became, moved or affected with, shame, shyness, or bashfulness; and particularly, but not always, honest shame, or pudency, or modesty; or his soul shrank from foul things; as also AisotaHaY; and HayiYa↓, inf. n. HayaA='N.] AstHyY is of the dial. of El-Hijáz; and AstHY, with a single Y, is of the dial. of Temeem; (Akh, S, Msb;) the former being the original, (Akh, S,) and that which is used in the Kur: (Msb:) in the latter, the first Y [of the original] is suppressed, [and its vowel is transferred to the H,] to facilitate the pronunciation, because of the occurrence of the two Y s together: this is the opinion of Sb; and with it agrees that of Aboo-'Othmán [ElMázinee]: the opinion ascribed to Sb in the S, namely, that AisotaHayotu is changed from AisotaHoyayotu in like manner as AisotabaEotu is changed from AisotabNyaEotu, is that of Kh, and is disallowed by El-Mázinee. (IB.) You say, AstHyY mnh, (S, K, [in the CK, erroneously, Eanohu,]) or AstHyA mnh, (Mgh, Msb,) and AstHY mnh, and AstHyAhu, (S, Msb, K, TA,) and AstHAhu; (TA, [and so in the CK in the place of AstHyAhu;]) as also mnh HayiYa↓, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor. yaHoyaA, (S,) inf. n. HayaA='N; (S, * Mgh, Msb, K;) He was ashamed of it or on account of it, or ashamed to do it, or shy of doing it; [generally meaning a foul thing;] he was ashamed for himself, or of himself, or was bashful, or shy, with respect to it, or him; he was abashed at, or shy of, it, or him; (K;) he shrank from it, or him: (Msb, K: *) and AstHyY mino ka*aA [or AstHyA] He disdained, or scorned, such a thing; abstained from it, or refused to do it, by reason of disdain and pride; he dislike, or hated, it, and his soul was above it; he shunned it, avoided it, or kept himself far from it; syn. A^anifa minohu. (TA.)

HaY~a HY Hy
a verbal noun, (S, M, Mgh, TA,) and therefore immediately followed by EalaY, (M, TA,) used as an imperative [addressed to a single person, male or female, and to more than one]; (S;) used in calling, or summoning, or inviting, and urging; (Lth, T, TA;) and having no verb derived from it [alone, for HayoEala is derived from HaY~a and EalaY together]; (Lth, T, Msb, TA;) meaning Come: (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K, TA, &c.:) or come quickly: or hasten. (Mgh, TA.) Hence, HaY~a EalaY AlS~alaAhN (in the A^a*aAn, TA) Come to prayer: (IKt, S, M, Msb, K:) or come ye to prayer: or come ye quickly: or hasten ye. (TA.) And HaY~a EalaY AlfalaAHo [in the same: see art. flH]. (Mgh, TA.) And HaY~a EalaY AlgadaA='i [Come to the morning-meal]: and ElY AlEa$aA='i [to the evening-meal]: (Msb:) and ElY Alv~ariydi [to the crumbled bread moistened with broth]: (S:) and ElY Alxayori [to good, good fortune, prosperity, &c.]. (Lth, T, TA.) The saying of Ibn-Ahmar,
HaY~a AlHumuwla faA_in~a Alr~akoba qado *ahabaA
means Keep thou to the loads [for the riders upon the camels have gone]. (TA.) ― -b2- In the phrase HaY~a hala, and HaY~a halFA, followed by EalaY ka*aA and A_ilaY ka*aA, and HaY~a halaA, (K,) which last is used in a case of pausation, but is bad in other cases, (S in art. hl,) and HaY~a halo, and Hay~ahol, [so in the copies of the K,] with the h quiescent, (K,) and HY~ hln [app. HaY~a halano, for HaY~a halFA, or perhaps a mistranscription for HaY~a halaka], (TA,) [the most common rendering of HaY~a hala &c. is like that of HaY~a alone, namely, Come: or] HY~ signifies hasten thou; and [hl or] hlA, come to it, or reach it; [so that the meaning is hasten thou: come to such a thing:] or HY~ signifies come; and [hl or] hlA, quickly (HaviyvFA), or be thou quick; [so that the meaning is come quickly to such a thing:] or [hl or] hlA signifies be thou quiet; and the meaning is A^asoriEo Einoda *ikorihi waA@sokuno Hat~aY yanoqaDiYa [Speed thou at the mention thereof, and be quiet until it is finished]. (K.) Accord. to Abu-lKhattáb, the Arabs used to say, HaY~a hala AlS~alaApa, meaning Come thou to prayer. (TA.) And one says, HaY~a halo bifulaAnK, (IAar, and so in the CK,) and HaY~a halFA bflAn, (IAar, and so in MS. copies of the K,) and HaY~a hala bflAn, meaning Hasten thou with such a one: (IAar:) or keep thou to such a one, and call him. (K.) It is said in a trad.,
A_i*aA *ukira AlS~aAliHuwna fiHaY~a hala biEumara, (S in art. hl,) or faHay~ahalFA biEumara, (TA,) i. e. [When the good, or righteous, are mentioned, then] keep thou to 'Omar, and call 'Omar, (S ubi suprà, and TA,) and begin with him, and be quick in mentioning him; (TA;) for he is of such. (S ubi suprà.) Accord. to some of the grammarians, (TA,) when you say HaY~a halFA, with tenween, it is as though you said Hav~FA; and without tenween, it is as though you said AlHav~a; the tenween being made a sign of indeterminateness; and the omission of it, a sign of determinateness: and so it is in all compounds of this kind. (K.) [See also art. hl.]

HaY~N HY Hy
Living, having life, alive, or quick; contr. of may~itN [or mayotN]; (S, Mgh, * Msb, * K;) and HayawaAnN↓ is syn. with HaY~N [as meaning having animal life]: (IB:) dim. of the former HuyaY~N↓: (Msb:) and pl. A^HoyaA='N. (Msb, K.) When you say of a person, layosa biHaY~K, you mean that he is dead: (Lh:) but minohaA Duriba DarobapF layosa biHaAYK↓, (Lh, K,) [in the CK Daraba, and] in [some of] the copies of the K, erroneously, biHaA='K, (TA,) means [He was struck a blow] in consequence of which he will not live: (Lh, K: *) like as the saying laA taA^okulo ka*aA faA_in~aka maAriDN means Thou wilt be sick if thou eat such a thing. (Lh, K.) Accord. to ISh, one says, A^ataAnaA HaY~u fulaAnK, meaning Such a one came to us in his life [-time]: and samiEotu HaY~a fulaAnK yaquwlu ka*aA, meaning I heard such a one say thus in his life [-time]: (TA:) [or the former may mean Such a one himself came to us: and the latter, I heard such a one himself say thus: for] HY [i. e. HaY~ as a prefixed noun] is sometimes redundant, like A=l and *uw: (Ham p. 308:) [and] IB says that HaY~u fulaAnK means Such a one himself. (TA.) And they say, A^aholika kayofa A^anota waHay~apu↓, i. e. How art thou, and those remaining alive of thy family? (TA.) ― -b2- Applied to God, Deathless. (Er-Rághib.) ― -b3- Possessing the faculty of growth, as an animal, and as a plant: (Er-Rághib:) and, applied to a plant, fresh, juicy, or succulent, and growing tall. (TA.) ― -b4- [Sensitively alive;] possessing the faculty of sensation. (Er-Rághib.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) [Intellectually alive;] possessing the faculty of intellect. (Er-Rághib.) [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) A Muslim; like as may~itN means an unbeliever. (TA.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) Lively, as meaning free from grief or sorrow. (Er-Rághib.) ― -b7- (assumed tropical:) Whole, sound, or unbroken. (L and TA in art. SA^b.) ― -b8- A^araDN Hay~apN (assumed tropical:) Fruitful land; or land abounding with herbage; (K, TA;) like as ArD mayotapN means unfruitful land. (TA.) ― -b9- Al$~amosu Hay~apN (assumed tropical:) The sun is, or was, of a clear colour, unaltered by approaching the place of setting; as though its setting were regarded as death: (TA:) or still bright and white: or still hot and powerful: but the former of these two meanings is the more probable. (Mgh.) ― -b10- naArN Hay~apN (assumed tropical:) [A live, or burning, fire. (AHn.) ― -b11- TariyqN HaY~N (assumed tropical:) An apparent, or a distinct, road or way: (K:) pl. A^aHoyaA='N. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also Hay~apN, first sentence. ＝ -A3- [A tribe] of the Arabs: (S:) the children, or descendants, of one father or ancestor, whether many or few: and a $aEob comprising qabaAy^il: (Az, TA:) or a qabiylap of the Arabs: (Msb:) or a baTon of the buTuwn of the Arabs: (K, TA:) pl. A^aHoyaA='N. (S, Msb, K.) ＝ -A4- The vulva, or external portion of the organs of generation, of a woman. (Az, K. See also HayaA='N, of which HaY~N is also said to be a pl.) Hence, saEafu AlHaY~i, applied by an Arab of the desert to The paraphernalia of a bride. (Az, TA.) ＝ -A5- laAHaY~a Eanohu means laAmanoEa minohu, (Ks, K, *) i. e. [There is no forbiddance of him; or] nothing is forbidden him. (Fr.) ＝ -A6- laA yaEorifu AlHaY~a mina All~aY~i He knows not, or will not know, what is true from what is false; (IAar, K, Har p. 236;) and so AlHaw~a mn All~aw~i: (TA:) or the Hawiy~ap [or winding gut, &c.,] from the twisting of the rope: (K:) or overt speech from covert: or the living from the dead: or the act of turning round, or winding, [see HawaAhu, (in art. HwY,) of which HaY~N is an inf. n.,] from the act of twisting. (Har ubi suprà.) ＝ -A7- The act of collecting. (TA. [But in this and some other senses it is an inf. n. of HawaY: see 1 in art. HwY.]) ＝ -A8- A^aHoyaA='N as pl. of HaA='N: see art. HwA^.

HiY~N HY Hy
: see HayaApN, of which it is said to be a syn.: and of which it is also said to be a pl.: ＝ -A2- and see HayaA='N, of which, also, it is said to be a pl.

Hay~apN Hy Hyh Hyp
[A serpent;] a certain thing well known: (K, TA:) [improperly explained in the Msb as syn. with A^afoEFY:] applied to the male and the female; (S, Msb;) the p being added to denote one of a kind, as in baT~apN and dajaAjapN; [although HaY~N is not used as a coll. gen. n.; and] although the saying EalaY Hay~apK raA^ayotu Hay~FA↓, as meaning [I saw] a male [serpent] upon a female [serpent], is related as having been heard from the Arabs: (S:) but Hay~uwtN↓ is also applied to the male; (Az, S, K;) the t being augmentative; for the word is originally Hay~uw [or Hay~uw~N]: (Az, TA:) it is said that it does not die unless by an accident: and they say of a long-lived man, maA huwa A_il~aA Hay~apN [He is none other than a serpent]; and in like manner they say of a woman; as though it were called Hy~p because of its long life: [for] some, including Sb, say that it is derived from HayaApN, as the rel. n. is HayawiY~N, not HawawiY~N: and to him who objects that one says rajulN Haw~aA='N [meaning “ a man who collects serpents ”], it is replied that Hay~apN and Haw~aA='N are of different roots, like luw^oluw^N and laA^~lN, &c.: but it may be from taHaw~aY, because of its winding, or coiling, itself; and some say that it is originally HawoyapN; some, that it is originally HayowapN: (TA:) [the dim. is Huyay~apN↓:] the pl. is Hay~aAtN (K) and HayowaAtN, (K, TA,) or HayawaAtN. (So in some copies of the K [agreeably with the dial. of Hudheyl].) Hence the prov. huwa A^aboSaru mino Hay~apK [He is more sharp-sighted than a serpent]; because of the sharpness of its sight: and A^aZolamu mino Hay~apK [more wrongful in conduct than a serpent]; because it comes to the burrow of the [lizard called] Dab~, and eats its young one, and takes up its abode in its burrow. (TA.) And saqaAhu A@ll~`hu dama AlHay~aAti [May God give him to drink the blood of the serpents]; i. e., (assumed tropical:) destroy him. (TA.) And laA talidu AlHay~apu A_il~aA Huyay~apF↓ [The serpent does not bring forth anything save a little serpent]: a prov. applied to the cunning and mischievous, or malignant. (TA.) And fulaAnN Hay~apu AlwaAdiY, or AlA^aroDi, or Albaladi, or AlHamaATi, (assumed tropical:) Such a one is cunning and mischievous, or malignant, (IAar, K,) and intelligent, in the utmost degree: (IAar:) [or] flAn Hy~p AlwAdY means (assumed tropical:) such a one is strong in resisting, a defender of his possessions. (TA.) And Hay~apu AlwaAdiY is also an appellation applied to (assumed tropical:) The lion; (K, TA;) because of his cunning, or craftiness. (TA.) One says also, humo Hay~apu AlA^aroDi, meaning (assumed tropical:) They are cunning, guileful, malignant, or mischievous, and strong, not neglecting to take blood-revenge: so in a saying of Dhu-l-Isba' El-'Adwánee cited voce Ea*iyrN. (TA.) And fulaAnN Hay~apN *akarN (S, TA) (assumed tropical:) Such a one is courageous and strong. (TA.) And raA^osuhu raA^osu Hay~apK (assumed tropical:) He is clever, or ingenious; acute, or sharp; intelligent. (TA.) And raA^ayotu fY kitaAbihi Hay~aAti waEaqaAriba (assumed tropical:) I saw in his letter slanders, or calumnies, addressed to the ruling power, in order to cause the object thereof to fall into embarrassment from which escape would be difficult. (TA.) ― -b2- AlHay~apu is also a name of (assumed tropical:) [The constellation Draco; commonly called Alt~in~iynu;] certain stars [partly] between the faroqadaAni [or B and y of Ursa Minor] and banaAtu naEo$K [meaning the stars in the tail of Ursa Major]: (K:) so called by way of comparison. (TA.) ― -b3- And Hay~apN also signifies (assumed tropical:) A certain mark made with a hot iron upon the neck, and upon the thigh, of a camel, twisting, or winding, like the Hay~ap [properly so called]. (Ibn- Habeeb, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also HaY~N.

HayFA Hy HyA
Rain; (S, Msb, K;) as also HayaA='N↓: (K:) or much rain: (Har p. 185:) as being the means of giving life to the earth: (TA:) and (assumed tropical:) plenty; or abundance of herbage, (S, K,) and the means of giving life to the earth and to men; as being caused by the rain; and so HayaA='N↓: (TA:) or [simply] herbage; because produced by the rain: and fat, and fatness; because produced by the herbage: (Ham p. 662:) dual. HayayaAni: (S:) and pl. A^aHoyaA='N. (TA.) HayaA Alr~abiyEi means The rain [called rbyE, or of the season thus called,] that gives life to the earth. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also the next paragraph.

HayaA='N HyA='
an inf. n. of HayiYa in the first of the senses explained in this art. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] syn. with HayFA, in two senses: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places. ― -b3- Also inf. n. of HayiYa as syn. with AisotaHoyaY; (S, * Mgh, Msb, K;) i. q. AisotiHoyaA='N; (S;) Shame; a sense of shame; shyness, or bashfulness; [and particularly, but not
always, honest shame, or pudency, or modesty;] syn. Hi$omapN; (K;) a shrinking of the soul from foul conduct, (Bd in ii. 24, and Er-Rághib,) through fear of blame; (Bd ibid.;) a languor that affects the animal faculty, (Bd ibid, and Mgh, *) and turns it back from its actions: (Bd:) and repentance; syn. tawobapN. (K.) ― -b4- And hence, as being a thing that should be concealed, and of which one is ashamed to speak plainly, (TA,) The vulva, or external portion of the female organs of generation, (faroj, El-Fárábee, Msb, K, or raHim, [which here means the same,] S,) of a camel, (El-Fárábee, S, Msb, K,) or an animal having feet like those of the camel, and of a cloven-hoofed animal, and of a beast of prey: (K:) accord. to AZ, the dubur [here meaning the same as faroj] of any of these and of other animals: (Msb:) accord. to IAar, it is of the ewe or she-goat, the cow, and the gazelle: (ISd, TA:) and [sometimes] the faroj of a girl, (El-Fárábee, Msb,:) or of a woman: (Zj in his “ Khalk el-Insán: ” [see also HaY~N:]) and HayFA↓ signifies the same; (K;) but accord. to Az, this is not allowable except in poetry, in a case of necessity: (TA:) pl. A^aHoyaA='N (AZ, IJ, K) and A^aHoyiyapN (As, Sb, S, K) and, by contraction, A^aHiy~apN, (Sb, IB, TA,) which is said to be preferable, (TA,) and [quasi-pl. n.] HaY~N↓ and HiY~N↓ [which two have been mistaken by Freytag for syns. of taHiy~apN, immediately following them in the K]. (Sb, K.)

HayaApN Hy HyA HyAh HyAp
, or Hay`wp↓, (as in different copies of the K, in the latter manner in copies of the S,) written with w in the Kur, to show that w follows Y in the pl. [HayawaAtN, like SalawaAtN], or because the sound of the A is inclined towards that of w, (ISd, TA,) and HayawopN↓, with sukoon to the w, (K,) which is substituted for the A of HayaApN, as is done by the people of El-Yemen in the case of every A that is changed from w, as in SalaApN and zakaApN, though the final radical letter of the verb of HayaApN is Y, (TA,) an inf. n. of HayiYa in the first of the senses explained in this art.; (IB, Mgh, Msb;) Life; contr. of mawotN; (S, K;) as also HayawaAnN↓ and HiY~N↓, (K,) or this last is asserted to be a pl. of Hay`wpN, (S,) and as also maHoyFA↓, (S, * Har pp. 25 and 350,) of which the pl. is maHaAYK: (S:) HayaApN signifies the faculty of growth, as in an animal, and in a plant: and the faculty of sensation: and (assumed tropical:) the faculty of intellect: and (assumed tropical:) freedom from grief or sorrow: and everlasting life in the world to come; to which one attains by that HyAp which is intelligence and knowledge: and the HyAp that is an attribute of God. (Er-Rághib.) yaA layotaniY qad~amotu liHayaAtiY, in the Kur [lxxxix. 25], means [O, would that I had prepared, or laid up in store,] for my everlasting state of existence. (Er-Rághib.) And faA_in~a Ald~aAra AlA=xirapa lahiYa AlHayawaAnu↓, in the Kur [xxix. 64], means [And verily the last abode is] the abode of everlasting life: (TA:) or AlHywAn here means the life that will not be followed by death: or much life; like as mawataAnN signifies much death: (Msb:) and it is also the name of a certain fountain in Paradise, [the water of] which touches nothing but it lives, by permission of God. (TA.) AlHay`wpu AlT~ay~ibapu, accord. to I'Ab, explaining xvi. 99 of the Kur, (TA,) means Lawful means of subsistence (K, TA) in the present world: (TA:) or Paradise. (K, TA.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Advantage, or profit; or a cause, or means, thereof: whence the saying, layosa lifulaAnK HayaApN There is not, in such a one, profit, nor good: and so it is said to mean in the Kur [ii. 175], walakumo fiY AlqiSaASi Hay`wpN (assumed tropical:) [And there is to you, in retaliation, an advantage]: (TA:) or this means that the knowledge of the law of retaliation restrains from slaughter, and so is a cause of life to two persons; and because they used to slay one who was not the slayer, retaliation upon the slayer is a cause of saving the lives of the rest: or the meaning is life in the world to come; for when the slayer has suffered retaliation in the present world, he is not punished for his act in the world to come. (Bd.) ― -b3- HayaApu Al$~amosi means (assumed tropical:) The remaining of the light and whiteness of the sun: or the remaining of its heat and power: but the former of these two meanings is the more probable. (Mgh. [See Al$~amosu Hay~apN, voce HaY~N.])

Hay`wpN Hy`wh Hy`wp
and HayawopN: see the next preceding paragraph.

HayiY~N Hy HyY Hyy Hyyy
Having HayaA=' [i. e. shame, shyness, bashfulness, pudency, or modesty]; (K;) part. n. of HayiYa as syn. with AstHyY; of the measure faEiylN: (Msb:) fem. Hayiy~apN. (TA.) The saying of I'Ab, Aall~`hu HayiY~N, means God is one who acts with others in the manner of him who has HayaA='; for HayaA=' in its proper sense is not ascribable to Him: (Mgh:) or one who leaves undone evil deeds, and does good deeds. (Er-Rághib.)

HuyaY~N Hy HyY Hyy Hyyy
: see HaY~N, of which it is the dim.

Huyay~apN Hy Hyy Hyyh Hyyp
: see Hay~apN, (of which it is the dim.,) in two places. ＝ -A2- And dim. of HaA='N, q. v. in art. HwA^. (Lth, TA in bAb AlAlf Ally~np.)

HayawiY~N HywY Hywy
[Of, or relating to, the serpent;] rel. n. of Hay~apN. (S.) ＝ -A2- [And rel. n. of HaA: see HaAy^iY~N in art. HwA^.]

HayawaAnN HywAn
an inf. n. of HayiYa, like HayaApN, (IB,) but having an intensive signification: (Msb:) see HayaApN, in two places. ― -b2- See also HaY~N, first sentence. ― -b3- Also Any thing, or things, possessing animal life, (Msb, K, *) whether rational or irrational; [an animal, and animals;] used alike as sing. and pl., because originally an inf. n.; (Msb;) contr. of mawataAnN [q. v.]. (S.) [HayawaAnaAtN is used as its pl. of pauc. And hence,] AlHayawaAnaAtu Alxamosu [The five animals] is applied to what may be killed by a person in the state of A_iHoraAm, and by one engaged in prayer: (Msb in art. fsq:) these are the rat, or mouse, and the biting dog, and either the serpent, the crow termed A^aboqaE, and the kite, or the serpent, the scorpion, and the kite, or the serpent, the scorpion, and the crow, or the scorpion, the crow, and the kite. (Es-Suyootee, in “ El-Jámi' es-Sagheer, ” voce xamosN.) It is originally HayayaAnN; (Sb, K, TA;) the Y which is the final radical letter being changed into w because the occurrence of two Y together is disliked: (Sb, TA:) Aboo-'Othmán [El-Má- zinee] holds the w to be a radical letter; but his opinion is said to be not admissible, because it is asserted that there is no instance in the language of a word of which the medial radical is Y, and the final w. (TA.)

HayawaAniY~N HywAn HywAnY HywAny HywAnyy
[Of, or relating to, an animal or animals]. ― -b2- It is [also] particularly applied to A seller of birds. (TA.)

[
HayawaAniy~apN HywAn HywAny HywAnyh HywAnyp
Animality; or animal nature.]

Hay~uwtN Hywt
: see Hay~apN.

HaAYK HAY HAy
, of the measure faAEilN, [said to be] originally HaAyiwN, is syn. with HaAwK and Haw~aA='N, belonging to art. HwY [q. v.]. (Az, TA.)

A^uHaY~u *
and A^uHaY~N and A^uHaY~K: see art. Hw.

A^uHayowK *
: see art. Hw.

A^aHoyaY *
in the saying A^aHoyaY mino Dab~K [More longlived than a Db~, a kind of lizard, which is supposed to live seven hundred years,] is from AlHayaApu. (TA.) ― -b2- In the sayings A^aHoyaY mino hadiY~K [More shy, or bashful, than the bride] and A^aHoyaY mino muxad~arapK [More shy, or bashful, than a girl kept behind the curtain] it is from AlHayaA='u. (TA.)

tiHoyaApN tHyAh tHyAp wHY
: see the next paragraph.

Alt~aHaAyiY AltHAyY AltHAyy
The two stars in the foot and before the foot of the foremost of Gemini: (Kzw:) or three stars over against AlhanoEap [which is the Sixth Mansion of the Moon]; (IKt, K;) and sometimes the moon deviates from AlhnEp, and makes its abode in AltHAyY: (IKt:) they are between the Milky Way and the stars that follow AlEay~uwq [or Capella]: Aboo-Ziyád El-Kilábee used to say that this name means AlhnEp, and is also pronounced Alt~aHaAy^iY, with': but AHn says that the moon makes its abode in these stars, and not in AlhnEp itself: (TA:) its sing. is tiHoyaApN↓; (IKt, AHn, TA;) if so, of the measure tifoEalapN, like tiHolabapN, not fiEolaApN, like EizohaApN, because there is no such root as taHY; derived from AlHayaA, because its nawo' [here meaning its auroral setting, in midwinter,] is attended with much rain: but AltHAy^Y, with ', is irreg.; as though pl. of taHiy~apN↓ likened to a word of the measure faEiylapN. (IB.)

taHiy~apN A^HyY Hy HyA tHyh tHyp wHY
inf. n. of 2. (Mgh, Msb, K.) ― -b2- Also A salutation, or greeting, (A'Obeyd, AHeyth, Mgh, Msb,) pronounced by one person to another on their meeting; (AHeyth;) particularly the saying salaAmN Ealayoka; (Mgh, * Msb;) and the like; (Mgh;) the most comprehensive form thereof, used by the believer [to his fellow-believer], being the saying Als~alaAmu Ealayokumo waraHomapu A@ll~`hi wabarakaAtuhu: (AHeyth:) hence it is pluralized; the pl. being taHiy~aAtN and taHaAyaA. (Mgh.) ― -b3- Also Continuance, or endurance; or endless, or everlasting, existence:
(IAar, Msb, K, &c.:) and so it is said to mean in the following verse of Zuheyr Ibn-Jenáb ElKelbee; who was a [kind of] king among his people:
qado nilotuhu A_il~aA Alt~aHiy~aho
walakul~u maA naAla AlfataY
[And indeed everything that the young man has attained, I have attained it, except endless existence]: or, as some say, it here means security from death and from evils. (TA. [But more probably the meaning is that next following: for in the Mz, 49th nwE, where this verse is cited, but with mino kul~i in the place of walakul~u, he is said to have been (not a king, but,) “ a nobleman. ” See also, respecting him, p. x. of my Preface.]) And (tropical:) Dominion, or kingship: (Fr, AA, S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.:) because the people of the Time of Ignorance used to greet kings [or rather those of Himyer] by the saying A^abayota Al~aEona, which they addressed to none other than a king; so that when any one of them became a king, it was said of him, fulaAnN naAla Alt~aHiy~apa [meaning (tropical:) Such a one has attained the kingship]. (Mgh: in which, and in the S, the foregoing verse is cited as an ex. of this last meaning.) Alt~aHiy~aAtu lil~`hi means Endless existence belongs to God: (Lth, Msb, TA:) or dominion, or kingship: (Lth, Yaakoob, S, Msb, TA:) or freedom, or security, from all evils, (Khálid Ibn-Yezeed, AHeyth,) and from all causes of the cessation of existence: (AHeyth:) or endless existence, and security from evils, and dominion, and the like: (Fr:) or the expressions [of praise] that indicate and imply the ascription of dominion and endless existence: (Kt:) or salutations and benedictions are Gods, and at his disposal. (Mgh.) [Alt~aHiy~aAtu is also a term applied to the following form of words repeated in the ordinary prayers: Alt~aHiy~aAtu lil~`hi waAlS~alawaAtu waAlT~ay~ibaAtu Als~alaAmu Ealayoka yaAA^ay~uhaA Aln~abiY~u waraHomapu A@ll~`hi wabarakaAtuhu Als~alaAmu EalayonaA waEalaY EibaAdi A@ll~`hi AlS~aAliHiyna A^a$ohadu A^ano laA A_ilaAha A_il~aA A@ll~`hu waA^a$ohadu A^an~a muHam~adFA Eaboduhu warasuwluhu, or (instead of Ebdh wrswlh) rasuwlu A@ll~`hi: see 5 in art. $hd.] ― -b4- The assigning to this word, as used in the Kur iv. 88, the meaning of A gift is a mistake. (Mgh.) ＝ -A2- See also Alt~aHaAyiY.

maHoyFA mHyA
: see HayaApN. ― -b2- Also A time, and a place, of life. (TA.)

muHoYK mH mHY mHy mHyy
and muHoyiyapN, applied to a she-camel, Having living offspring; whose offspring seldom, or never, die. (S.)

muHay~FA mHyA
The face (S, K, Ham p. 23) of a man, because it is specified in salutation; [see 2;] (Ham ubi suprá;) a term used only in praise; (Ham p. 640;) i. e. the face altogether: or the Hur~ of the face [i. e. the ball of the cheek; or what appears of the elevated part thereof; or what fronts one, of the face, &c.]. (K.) ― -b2- Of a horse, it is The place where the flesh is separated (Hyv Anfrq AllHm) beneath the forelock. (Ham p. 23.) And daAy^irapu AlmuHay~aA, in a horse, [The feather in] the place of separation [of the hair] beneath the forelock, in the upper part of the forehead. (TA.)

mHay~iYN mHyY mHyy
act. part. n. of 2; fem. muHay~iyapN: (S, TA:) for in every noun in which three Ys occur together, [the last of them being the final radical, and ending the word,] if it is not formed from a verb, the final radical letter is elided from it, as in EuTaY~N the dim. of EaTaA='N, and in A^uHaY~u the dim. of A^aHowaY: but if it is formed from a verb, that letter remains, as in muHay~iYN from Hay~aY. (S.)

A^aroDN maHoyaApN *
i. q. maHowaApN, i. e. A land containing serpents: (Ibn-Es-Sarráj, S:) or abounding with serpents. (TA in art. HwY.)

A^abuw yaHoyaY *
Death. (TA, Har p. 218.)

Hayovu Hyv
, (S, Msb, Mughnee, K,) indecl., (S, Msb,) with damm for its termination, (S, Msb, Mughnee,) as being likened to final words [such as qabolu and baEodu ending a proposition], (S, Mughnee,) because it does not [regularly] occur otherwise than prefixed to a proposition, (S,) for the being prefixed to a proposition is like the not being prefixed to anything, as the consequence of being prefixed, which is the sign of the gen. case, is not apparent: (Mughnee:) and Hayova, (S, Mughnee, K,) also indecl., (S,) with fet-h, (S, Mughnee,) to render the pronunciation more easy, (Mughnee,) because damm with Y is deemed difficult to pronounce: (S:) and Hayovi, (Mughnee, K,) with kesr, accord. to the general rule observed to prevent the concurrence of two quiescent letters: (Mughnee:) and in like manner, Hawovu and Hawova and Hawovi: (Mughnee, TA:) of which forms, Hwv is asserted to be the original; (L;) though Hayovu is more chaste than Hawovu, and is the form used in the Kur-án: (Az and TA in art. Hwv:) but some of the Arabs make Hyv decl.: (Mughnee:) it is an adverbial noun of place, (S, Msb,) a vague adverbial noun of place, (L,) [signifying Where,] like Hiyna with respect to time: (S, K:) or it is a denotative of place, by general consent: but accord. to Akh it sometimes occurs as denoting time, [signifying when,] as in the following verse, (Mughnee, TA,) which is the strongest evidence of its use in this sense: (TA:)
HayovamaA tasotaqimo yuqad~iro laka A@ll~`
hu najaAHFA fiY gaAbiri AlA^azomaAni
[Whenever thou shalt pursue a right course, God will decree thee success in the time to come]: (Mughnee, TA:) but in most instances it occupies the place of an accus., as an adverbial noun of place; or of a gen., governed by mino, and sometimes by another prep., as in the saying (of Zuheyr, TA in art. q$Em),
ladaY Hayovu A^aloqato raHolahaAA^um~u qa$oEami
[At the place where Calamity, or Fate, has put down her saddle, i. e., made her abode]: and sometimes it occurs as an objective complement, as it is said to do in Aall~`hu A^aEolamu Hayovu yajoEalu risaAlaAtihi [in the Kur vi. 124], i. e. God is knowing: He knows where to bestow his apostolic commissions; yaEolamu being suppressed, as implied by A^aEolamu; or A^aEolamu may be rendered by EaAlimN, and so may govern the accus. case. (Mughnee.) Accord. to rule, (Mughnee,) in every instance, (S, Mughnee,) it is prefixed to a proposition, (S, Msb, Mughnee,) nominal, or verbal, but in most cases the latter; (Mughnee;) as in A^aquwmu Hayovu yaquwmu zayodN [I will stand where Zeyd shall stand]; and Hayovu takuwnu A^akuwnu [Where thou shalt be, I will be]; (S;) and jalasotu Hayovu zayodFA A^araAhu [I sat where I saw Zeyd], the accus. case being preferred in an instance like this; (Mughnee;) and A*ohabo Hayovu $y^ota [Go thou whither thou wilt.] (Msb in art. Hayn.) You should not say Hayovu zayodN [alone]: (S:) or it occurs prefixed to a single word in poetry; (Msb, Mughnee;) as in the saying,
wanaToEunuhumo taHota AlkulaY baEoda Darobihimo
bibiyDi AlmawaADiY Hayovu laY~i AlEamaAy^imi
[And we pierce them beneath the kidneys, after smiting them, with the sharp swords, where the turbans are wound]; (Mughnee;) but this is irregular; (Msb, Mughnee;) though Ks holds it to be regular. (Mughnee.) Lh relates, on the authority of Ks, that some make Hyv to govern a noun in the gen. case, as in the saying,
A^amaA taraY Hayovu suhayolK TaAliEaA
[Seest thou not where Canopus is, rising?]: but he says that this is not of respectable authority: (L:) some write Hayova suhayolK: and some, Hayovu suhayolN, [which is the common reading, shyl being an inchoative, and] the enunciative, mawojuwdN, being suppressed. (Mughnee.) Abu-l-Fet-h says that he who prefixes Hyv to a single word makes it declinable. (Mughnee.) [Accord. to Fei,] BenooTemeem say Hayova when it occupies the place of an accus., as in the phrase, qumo Hayova yaquwmu zayodN [Stand thou where Zeyd shall stand]. (Msb.) Ks says, I have heard among Benoo-Temeem, of Benoo-Yarbooa and Tuheiyeh, those who say Hayova in every case, when it occupies the place of a gen., and that of an accus., and that of a nom.; saying mino Hayova laAyaEolamuwna [Whence they know not], and Hayova A@lotaqayonaA [Where we met]: and he says also, I have heard some of Benu-l-HárithIbn-Asad-Ibn-El-Hárith-Ibn-Thaalabeh, and all Benoo-Fak'as, say Hayovi when it occupies the place of a gen., and Hayova when it occupies the place of an accus.; saying mino Hayovi laA yaEolamuwna, and Hayova A@lotaqayonaA. (L.) Sometimes the proposition after Hyv commences with A_in~a, as in Aijoliso Hayovu A_in~a zayodFA jaAlisN [Sit thou where Zeyd is sitting]. (K in art. A^n, and IAk p. 92.) ― -b2- It sometimes comprises the meanings of two adverbial nouns of place, as when you say, Hayovu Eabodu A@ll~`hi qaAEidN zayodN qaAy^imN [Where' Abd-Allah is sitting, there Zeyd is standing]. (AHeyth, L.) ― -b3- The restrictive maA (maA kaAf~apN) is sometimes affixed to it, and in this case it implies a conditional meaning, [signifying Wherever, or wheresoever, and, accord. to Akh, whenever, or whensoever,] (Mughnee, TA,) and renders two verbs mejzoom, (Mughnee,) as in the saying, HayovumaA tajoliso A^ajoliso [Wherever thou shalt
sit, I will sit], (S,) and in the first of the verses cited above: (Mughnee, TA:) it is not [properly, though it is sometimes improperly,] used as a conditional without mA. (S.) ― -b4- [It is also used, in scientific and other post-classical works, in senses different from those explained above. Thus, mino Hayovu is used to signify As to, or in respect of: so in the phrase mino Hayovu All~afoZi waAlmaEonaY As to, or in respect of, the word and the meaning. Also As, or considered as, absolutely, or abstractedly: so in the phrase mino Hayovu huwa, or mino Hayovu huwa huwa, As, or considered as, such, absolutely, or abstractedly; and AlA_inosaAnu mino Hayovu huwa A_inosaAnN Man, as, or considered as, man, absolutely, or abstractedly. And As, meaning considered merely or only or simply as: so in the saying, AlA_inosaAnu mino Hayovu A_in~ahu yaSiH~u watazuwlu Eanohu Als~iH~apu mawoDuwEu AlT~ib~i Man, as, or considered merely or only or simply as, being healthy and ceasing to be healthy, is the object of therapeutics. And As, meaning since, or because: so in the saying, Aln~aAru mino Hayovu A_in~ahaA HaAr~apN tusax~inu AlmaA='a Fire, as, or since, or because, it is hot, heats water. biHayovu is also vulgarly used in this sense. And correctly as meaning So that; so as that; in such a state, or condition, that: often syn. with Hat~aY.]

, aor. yaHiyju, (Kr, K,) inf. n. HayojN, (TA,) i. q. HaAja, aor. yaHuwju: (Kr, K:) extr., because the A of HaAjapN [which is its logical root] is [originally] w. (TA.)

, (K,) irregular, like A^aHuwaja, (TA,) and A^aHaAjat, The land produced the thorny plants, or trees, called HaAjN: (K:) or abounded therewith. (TA.)

, a coll. gen. n., n. un. with p, (TA,) A certain kind of thorny plant, or tree; (S, K;) a plant of the sour kind (mina AlHamoDi): accord. to ISd, a kind of thorny plant or tree, i. q. kaburN [or caper]: or a certain plant different from that just named: or a certain kind of tree: accord. to AHn, an evergreen, of which the roots extend far into the ground; which, cooked, is used as a medicine; having slender and long leaves, seeming as numerous as the thorns: (TA:) [asparago sylvestri similis: (Golius, from Ibn-Beytár:) this name, and EaAquwl, are now applied by the Arabs to the plant called by European botanists hedysarum alhagi: see EaAquwlN and taranojubiynN:] dim. HuyayojN↓; therefore its medial radical letter is Y; (K;) and HiyayojN↓ is a chaste dial. var. of this dim., agreeably with a usage observed in similar cases [when the medial radical letter is Y]. HuyayojN Hyyj
and HiyayojN: see what next precedes.

1 HaAda Eanohu HAd Enh HAd Enp
, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor. yaHiydu, inf. n. HuyuwdN and HayodapN (S, Msb, K) and HayodN and HayadaAnN and maHiydN (K) and HayoduwdapN, (S, K,) which last is originally HayaduwdapN, with the Y movent; this letter being afterwards made quiescent; for there is not in the language any word of the measure faEoluwlN, except SaEofuwqN; (S; [see the remarks on $ayoxuwxapN, voce $aAxa;]) He declined, or turned aside or away, from it; (S, A, K;) removed, went away, or went far away, from it; (Msb;) namely, a road, (S,) or a thing: (Msb:) he shunned, or avoided, it, from fear, or from disdain. (Az, L.) [See also 3.] You say, maA laka maHiydN Eano *`lika There is not, for thee, any avoiding that. (L.) And HaAdati Ald~aAb~apu The beast became scared, or shied, and quitted the middle of the road. (L.) ― -b2- HAd bihi, and AHAdhu↓, He removed, took away, or took far away, him, or it; [Eano $aYo'K from a thing;] similar to *ahaba bihi and A^a*ohabahu. (Msb.)

He cut, or cut lengthwise, the thong, or strip of skin or leather, and made it to have parts projecting beyond the rest. (L, K.)

, inf. n. muHaAyadapN and HiyaAdN, He went, or turned, aside from, or away from, or he avoided, or he went, or removed, to a distance from, him, or it: (S, L, K:) [see also 1:] or, accord. to the A, he inclined upon, or against, him, or it. (TA.)

see 1.

HayodN Hyd
A rising, or protuberant, or prominent, part of a side of a thing: (L, K:) so of the head; (Lth, L;) as also HayodapN↓: (A:) a knot, knob, or protuberance, of a stick or branch; [as also HayodapN↓: (AHn, TA voce baloTN, q. v.:)] a part of a strap, or thong, projecting beyond the rest: (L:) any rib, (L, K,) or other bone, (L,) that curves much [and is therefore prominent]: (L, K:) [see an ex. voce HaAbK, in art. Hbw:] a knot in the horn of a mountain-goat; (A, * L, K;) or this is termed HayodapN↓: (S, L:) a twisted part of a horn: a twisted internodal portion of a horn: (L:) any prominence in a horn, and in a mountain, (S, L, K,) &c.: (S, L:) a prominent and curved part of a mountain: (T:) a projecting portion, or ledge, of a mountain, resembling a wing: (S, M, L, K:) pl. (of the former word, S) A^aHoyaAdN [a pl. of pauc.] and (of both words, S) HuyuwdN and (of the latter, S) HiyadN: (S, K:) the Huyuwd of a camel are such parts as the hips, or haunches, and thighs. (L.) You say jabalN *uw HuyuwdK and A^aHoyaAdK, meaning A mountain having projecting edges in its lower parts, not in its upper parts. (S.) And qaEadotu taHota Hayodi Aljabali I sat beneath the part of the mountain that projected like a wing. (A.)

HayodapN Hyd Hydh Hydp
: see HayodN, in three places. ― -b2- Also The rugged part of a road. (A.) ― -b3- An evil look, (A, K,) with a turning aside. (A.) You say, maA naZara A_ilaY~a A_il~aA AlHayodapa, (A,) or A_il~aA naZara AlHayodapi, (TA,) He looked not towards me save with an evil look, with a turning aside. (A, TA.)

HayadaY Hyd HydY Hydy
The manner of walking of a proud and self-conceited person. (K.) ― -b2- HimaArN HayadaY (S, K) and Hay~idN↓, (K,) each occurring in a verse of [Umeiyeh the son of] Aboo-'Áïdh El-Hudhalee accord. to different relations thereof, (L, [see jam~aAzN,]) An ass that turns aside from, or shies at, his shadow, by reason of his briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness: (S, K:) or that is wont often to turn aside from things, or to shy at them. (S.) HayadaY is also applied as an epithet to a she-ass. (IAar.) It is [said to be] the only masc. epithet of the measure faEalaY, (S, K,) except dalaZaY a man “ who thrusts vehemently, ” (IJ,) and waqaraY [but this is written in the K waqariY~N] “ a pastor of a waqiyr, or flock of sheep, ” and qafaTaY vir “ multum coiens, ” and jamazaY a “ quick ” ass. (MF.) But probably Hay~idN is the only correct word of the two above mentioned. (L.) [Or HimaArN HayadaY is for HimaArN *uw HayadaY: see jamazaY, voce jam~aAzN.]

HayodaAnN HydAn
Pebbles that become thrown aside from the legs of a beast as he goes along. (S, K.)

Hay~idN Hyd
: see HayadaY.

, like qaTaAmi, (L,) indecl., with kesr for its termination, [and of the fem. gender,] occurs in the phrase (TA) HiydiY HayaAdi, similar to fiyHiY fayaAHi, (S, L, K,) meaning Turn thou aside, or away, [from me:] (A, L:) said by one when the time for fighting is come, (L,) and by one fleeing. HayuwdN Hywd
[That declines, or goes away, much, or frequently]: an intensive epithet, applied by 'Alee to worldly prosperity (Ald~unoyaA). (L.)

maHiydN mHyd
an inf. n. of HaAda. (K.) ― -b2- [It may also be used, agreeably with analogy, as a noun of place, signifying A place to which one turns aside or away; to which one removes, goes away, or goes far away.]

, [sec. pers. Hirota,] aor. yaHaAru, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) and some say yaHiyru, but this is a mistake, (MF,) inf. n. HayorapN (S, A, Mgh, K) and HayarN (S, Msb, K) and HayorN and HayaraAnN, (K,) He was, or became, dazzled by a thing at which he looked, (T, Msb, K,) so that he turned away his eyes from it: this is the primary signification: (T, Msb:) and so tHy~r↓ (A, * Mgh, * K) and AstHAr↓, (K,) and HArbaSaruhu (A, * TA) and bSrh tHy~r↓. (Mgh, and S and A and K in art. qmr, &c.) ― -b2- And hence, (T, Msb,) He was, or became, confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course; (T, Msb, K, * TA;) as also tHy~r↓ (Msb, K) and AstHAr↓. (K.) And HAr, (S, A,) or HAr fiY A^amorihi, (Msb,) i. q. fY Amrh tHy~r↓ [He was, or became, confounded, &c., in his affair, or case]. (S, A.) And [HAr (see its part. n. HaAy^irN) and] tHy~r↓ [and AstHAr↓] He erred, or lost his way. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, said of water, (A, Msb, K,) and tHy~r↓ (S, A, K) and AstHAr↓, (A, K,) (tropical:) It became collected, (S, A, K,) and stayed, (A,) or went round, (S, K, *) or went to and fro, or fluctuated, (Msb, K,) in a place, as
though it knew not which way to run. (A.) ― -b4- See also 5.

He, or it, caused him to become confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course. (S, * Msb, KL.) ― -b2- [Accord. to Golius, as on the authority of the KL, Hy~r, said of water, means (assumed tropical:) It was whirled round in an eddy: but to have this meaning, which I do not find in my copy of the KL, the verb should be Huy~ira.]

[He, or it, caused a thing to descend easily down the throat: or it transmitted food to the stomach: see 10: and see also 4 in art. Hwr]. (S and K voce mi$ofarN, q. v.)

: see 1, in six places. ― -b2- Also (tropical:) It (a cloud) continued without motion, pouring forth its rain, and not being driven by the wind: (IAar:) or went not in any direction: (K:) [and so AstHAr↓: see mutaHay~irN.] ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) It continued; said of time; (TA;) and in like manner it is said of a man. (MF.) And bihi HiyruwA↓ [if not a mistranscription for taHay~aruwA] occurs as meaning (assumed tropical:) Remain ye therein; referring to a place. (TA.) And bimakaAnK AstHAr↓ (assumed tropical:) He alighted and abode some days in a place. (TA.) ― -b4- tHy~r biAlmaA='a (tropical:) It (a place, S, K, and land, TA) became full of water; as also AstHAr↓. (S, K, TA.) ― -b5- tHy~rt Aljafonapu (tropical:) The bowl became full of grease and food; (K, TA;) like as a watering-trough or tank becomes full of water. (TA.) ― -b6- See also what follows.

(As, S.) ＝ -A2- AsotuHiyra Al$~araAbu The beverage, or wine, was made to descend easily down the throat. (S.)

[An enclosure] like a HaZiyrap: or a place of pasturage in which it is prohibited to the public to pasture their beasts. (S, K.) ― -b2- See also HaAy^irN. ＝ -A2- HayoramaA [erroneously written by Golius HaAramaA] i. q. rub~amaA. (K.)

: see what next follows.

(IAar, K) and HayarN↓ (IB, K) Much property, or many cattle; and a numerous family: (K:) and A^anoEaAmN HiyaraAtN many cattle. laA A=tiyhi HayoriY~a Ald~ahori lA A=tyh Hyry Aldhr
(Ibn-'Omar, * Sh, * K) and HiyriY~a Ald~ahori (Sb, Akh, IAar, K) and HiyriY~a dahorK, (S,) or HiyriY dahorK, (CK,) or HayoriY dahorK, (K, TA,) with the last letter quiescent, (K,) and HayoriYa dahorK, or HiyriYa dahorK, (accord. to different copies of the K,) and dahorK HaAriY~a↓ (ISh, K) and Ald~ahori HaAriY~a↓ (ISh) and dahorK Hiyara↓, (IAar, K,) (tropical:) [I will not come to him, or it, or I will not do it,] while time lasts; (A, * K, * TA;) or ever: (ISh, K:) or it may mean while time returns; from HaAra of which the aor. is yaHuwru. (A, TA.) Also HayoriY~a Ald~ahori, or HiyriY~a Ald~ahori, (tropical:) For an incalculable period of time. (Ibn-'Omar, Sh, IAth.)

HayoraAnu HyrAn
(T, S, A, K) and HaAy^irN↓ (T, A, K) and mutaHay~irN↓ (TA) A man in a state of confusion, or perplexity, and unable to see his right course: (K, * TA:) erring; having lost his way: (T, TA:) fem. [of the first] HayoraY (Lh, T) and HayoraA='u: (A, K:) and pl. [of the same] HayaAraY (S, A, K) and HuyaAraY (K) and HayoraY, like the fem. sing. (Lh.) You say, laA tafoEalo *`lika A^um~uka HayoraY [Do not thou that: may thy mother become in a state of confusion, &c.]: and laA tafoEaluwA *`lika A^um~ahaAtukumo HayoraY [Do not ye that: may your mothers become &c.]. (Lh.) And baAy^irN rajulN HaAy^irN↓ A man who does not apply himself rightly to an affair; (S, TA;) who knows not the right course to pursue in his affair; as also fiY A^amorihi mutaHay~irN↓. (TA. [See also the same phrase in art. Hwr.]) ― -b2- [rawoDpN HayoraY is (tropical:) A meadow full of water. (TA.) ― -b3- [HayoraY is also applied as an epithet to the midday sun of summer: see a verse cited in the second paragraph of art. dwm.]

Hay~irN Hyr
: see mutaHay~irN.

HaAy^irN *
: see HayoraAnu, in two places. ― -b2- Also (tropical:) A place in which water collects (S, K, TA) and goes to and fro: (TA:) a watering-trough, or tank, to which a stream of rain-water flows: (K:) or what resembles a watering-trough, or tank, in which the rain-water collects and remains: (A:) a depressed place (K, TA) in which water collects and remains, or goes round, or goes to and fro, not passing forth from it: (TA:) or a place in the ground depressed in the middle and having elevated edges or borders, (AHn, TA,) in which is water: (TA voce yaEobuwbN:) and hence, (TA,) a garden; as also HayorN↓; (K;) which is the form used by most persons, and by the vulgar; like as they say Eayo$pu for EaAy^i$apu: or this form is wrong: it is disallowed by AHn, notwithstanding its being mentioned by A 'Obeyd; but he mentions it only in one place, and it is not found in every copy of his work: (ISd:) pl. HiyraAnN (S, A, K) and HuwraAnN. (S, K.) Hassán Ibn-Thábit uses the phrase HaAy^iru AlbaHori [in a verse which I have cited in the first paragraph of art. rb, app. as meaning (assumed tropical:) The depth of the sea; or part of the sea in which is a confluence of the water, and where it goes round, or to and fro]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also Grease; oily animal matter, that flows from flesh or fat. (K.)

A^aHoyaru mino Dab~K *
, and mino waralK, [More confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course, than a dabb, and than a waral,] are two proverbs; (Meyd;) accord. to Hamzeh El-Isfahánee, said because the dabb, [a kind of lizard, as is also the waral,] when it quits its hole, is confounded, and cannot find the right way to to it; and the like is said of the waral. (Har p. 166.)

mutaHay~irN mtHyr
: see HayoraAnu, in two places. ― -b2- AlakawAkibu AlmutaHay~irapu (assumed tropical:) [The erratic stars; i. e. the planets;] the stars that [at one time appear to] retrograde and [at another time to] pursue a direct [and forward] course; also called Alxun~asu. (S in art. xns.) ― -b3- saHaAbN mutaHay~irN (assumed tropical:) Clouds continuing without motion, pouring forth rain, and not driven by the wind: (IAar:) and musotaHiyrN↓ (assumed tropical:) clouds (sHAb) heavy, and moving to and fro, (S, K) not having any wind to drive them along: (S:) and Hay~irN↓ (tropical:) clouds, or clouds covering the sky, syn. gayomN, (AZ, K, TA,) rising with rain, and continuing without motion, or moving to and fro, but remaining, in the sky: (AZ, TA:) or this last signifies (tropical:) clouds (sHAb) raining, and continuing without motion, or moving to and fro, but remaining in the sky. (A, TA.) ― -b4- See also what follows, in two places.

musotaHiyrN mstHyr
A way leading across a desert, of which the place of egress is not known. (K.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Anything (TA) continuing endlessly: (IAar, TA:) or hardly, or never, ending; as also mutaHay~irN↓. (Sh, TA.) See also this latter word. ＝ -A2- jafonapN musotaHiyrapN (tropical:) A full bowl: (A:) or (assumed tropical:) a bowl containing much grease. (K.) And maraqapN mutaHay~iripN↓ (assumed tropical:) Broth containing much grease. (TA.)

1 HaAzahu HAz HAzh HAzp
, aor. yaHiyzuhu, inf. n. HayozN: see 1 in art. Hwz, in three places. Quasi 5. tHy~z: see 5, and 7, and Q. Q. 2, in art. Hwz; the first in six places.

Hay~izN Hyz
and HayozN: see art. Hwz.

1 HaAsa HAs
, aor. yaHiysu, inf. n. HayosN, He mixed [a thing or things]. (S, A, K; but in this sense, only the inf. n. is mentioned.) ― -b2- He made, or prepared, what is called Hayos: (S, Msb, K:)
and Hy~s↓, inf. n. taHoyiysN, he mixed and prepared what is so called. (TA.)

2 Hay~asa
see above.

HayosN Hys
, originally an inf. n., (Msb,) Dates mixed with clarified butter and [the preparation of dried curd called] A^aqiT, (S, A, Mgh, K,) and kneaded (A, K) vehemently, (A,) or rubbed and pressed with the hand until they mingle together, (Mgh,) whereupon their stones come forth; (K;) and sometimes sawiyq [or meal of parched barley or wheat] is put into it; (A, K;) and a little crumbled bread instead of the AqT: (TA:) or dates, of the kind called baroniY~, and AqT, bruised together, and kneaded vehemently with clarified butter until the stones come forth from it one by one, and then made like variyd: it is the same as waTobapN, except that Hys sometimes has swyq put in it, but wTbp has not: (L:) or dates of which the stones have been taken out, bruised with AqT, and then kneaded, and rubbed and pressed with the hand until the whole becomes like vryd; and sometimes swyq is put with it: (Msb:) accord. to Ibn-Waddáh El-Andalusee, dates of which the stones have been taken out, mixed with swyq; but this is not known, (MF, TA,) because of the deficiency of the ingredients: (TA:) Hr is related to have described it as a variydap composed of A^axolaAT [or various mixtures]. (TA.) A rájiz says,
Aalt~amoru waAls~amonu maEFAv~m~a AlA^aqiTo
AaloHayosu A_il~aA A^an~ahu lamo yaxotaliTo
[Dates and clarified butter together, then AqT, are Hys, except that it is not yet mixed]: (S, MF, TA:) from which it might be understood, that these components, when mixed, are not Hys: but this is the contrary of what is meant: (MF:) the meaning seems to be, that these three things, when brought, are virtually Hys, as being the materials thereof, though not mixed. (TA.)

1 HaASa Eanohu HAS Enh HAS Enp
, aor. yaHiySu, inf. n. HayoSN and HuyuwSN and maHiySN and maHaASN (S, Msb, K) and HayaSaAnN (S, K) and HayoSuwSapN (TA) and HayoSapN↓, (K,) [or the last is an inf. n. of un.,] He turned away from him, or it: (S, A, Msb, K:) and he returned, or went back, and fled, from him, or it: (TA:) and Enh AnHAS↓ signifies the same; (S, K, TA;) and so does Enh tHAyS↓: (TA:) or (K) one says of friends, (S, K,) HaASuwA, (K,) or HASwA Eani AlEaduw~i [they turned away from the enemy]; (S;) [and in like manner, AinoHaAzuwA;] and of enemies, AinohazamuwA; (S, K;) [and in like manner, wal~awoA mudobiriyna.] You say also, HaASa Eani AlqitaAli He turned away from the fight. (A.) And HaASa Eani AlHaq~i He turned away from the truth; he deviated from it. (Msb.) And HaASa Eani Al$~aYo'i He turned away from the thing, and became safe from it. (TA.) And it is said in a trad. respecting the battle of Ohod, faHaASa Almusolimuwna HayoSapN↓ And the Muslims made a wheel away, desiring flight: or, accord. to one relation, faHaADa HayoDapF, which means the same. (TA.) HayoSN also signifies The retiring, or going back, from a thing. (S, TA.) [See also maHiySN, below.]

3 HAyShu HAySh HAySp
, (K,) inf. n. muHaAyaSapN, (TA,) He acted towards him with artifice, or guile; (K;) vied with him; (TA;) and strove to overcome him. (K.) Hence the saying of Mutarrif, related in a trad., when he was asked respecting his going forth from the pestilence, huwa Almawotu nuHaAyiSuhu walaA bud~a minohu, may be interpreted as meaning, [It is death:] we are eager to flee from it [though there is no avoiding it]. (AO, TA.)

see 1.

see 1.

: see what next follows.

, (AA, S, A, and K in art. byS,) and waqaEuwA, (S,) fiY HayoSa bayoSa, (S, A, and K ubi suprà,) and HyS biySa, (S in this art. and in art. byS; and so in the CK ubi suprà, and in a MS. copy of the K, [though app. contradicted by what follows in that work, as will be seen below,] or HiySi biySi, (K ubi suprà, accord. to some copies, and so in the TA,) and HayoS bayoSi, (K ubi suprà,) with fet-h to the first [letter] of each and to the last of each, (K ubi suprà,) and with kesr to the first of each, (S in art. byS,) or to both, and with fet-h to the first of each and kesr to the last of each; and sometimes each of the two [vars., namely, HayoS bayoS and HiyS biyS,] is made perfectly decl. in the second [word], (K ubi suprà,) [so that you say also HayoSa bayoSK, and HiySi biySK, and HayoSi bayoSK; (though the copies of the K differ in respect of these forms, two, for instance, giving one form, which is written HayoSK bayoSK, and one adding HiySK biySK;) for it is said,] the whole make six dial. vars.; and, accord. to MF, each of the two [vars.] is sometimes made perfectly decl. in the first [word] also, [so that you say HayoSK bayoSK, and HySK biySK,] but this he may have inferred from what will be afterwards mentioned on the authority of ISk, (TA in art. byS,) and baASi fiY HaASi↓, (K ubi suprà,) indecl., with kesr for the termination, the A being [originally] Y; (TA ubi suprà;) He fell, (S, K,) and they fell, (S,) into confusion in respect of their case, or affair, from which there was no escape for them: (S and K ubi suprà:) or into straitness and difficulty: (S:) HayoSa bayoSa and HiySa biySa are each two nouns made into one, and made indecl. with fet-h for their termination, as in the instance of jaAriY bayota bayota: or, as some assert, they are two nouns, from HayoSN meaning the “ turning away, ” and “ retiring, ” or “ going back, ” and bawoSN meaning the “ outstripping, ” and “ fleeing; ” and bwS is altered to assimilate it to HyS; and the meaning is, an affair, or a case, of any kind, from which one retires, or goes back, and flees. (S.) (Nh.) And A_in~aka lataHosibu EalaY~a AlA^aroDa HayoSFA bayoSFA, or, as some say, HySi bySi, [i. e., HayoSi bayoSi or HiySi biySi, meaning, Verily thou thinkest the earth to be straitened to me, so that I may not act as I please therein: &c.] (S.) ― -b2- HayoSa bayoSa also signifies The hole of the rat or mouse. , [inf. n. taHoyiynN,] He assigned, or appointed, for him, or it, a time. (K.) Hay~anuwA Duyuwfahumo and A^aHaAnuwhumo↓ have the same meaning [app. They assigned, or appointed, a time for their guests]. (TA.) ― -b2- Hy~n Aln~aAqapa He appointed for the she-camel a time in every day and night in which he should milk her; (S, K;) as also taHay~anahaA↓; (K;) said when one milks her in the day and night once: As says that taHoyiynN is like tawojiybN [the milking a camel but once in the course of each day and night]; but is only after she has shown herself to be pregnant, and her milk has become little in quantity. (TA.) ＝ -A2- He (God) made him, or it, to be not accommodated, adapted, or disposed, to the right way or course or direction. (K) ― -b2- See also 4.

3 muHaAyanapN * and HiyaAnN
[are the inf. ns. of HaAyana]. You say, EaAmalahu muHaAyanapF (S, K) and HiyaAnFA (Lh, TA) [He bargained or contracted with him for work for a certain time]; like musaAwaEapF; (S, K;) from AlHiynu meaning Alwaqotu. (Lh, TA.) And in like manner, AisotaA^ojarahu muHaAyanapF (TA) and HiyaAnFA (Lh, TA) [He hired him, or took him as a hired man or a hireling, for a certain time].

4 AHAn Hyn Hynh Hynp
i. q. A^azomana [i. e. Time, or a long time, passed over him, or it; he, or it, endured, or continued, for a time, or for a long time]. (TA.) ― -b2- A^aHoyana He remained, stayed, abode, or dwelt, (S, K,) for a time in a place. (S.) ― -b3- A^aHoyanati AlA_ibilu The time came, or drew near, for the camels to be milked: or for the camels to have their loads bound upon them. (AA, K. [In the CK, yuEolama is erroneously put for yuEokama.]) ― -b4- A^aHoyana Alqawomu The time of what they desired, or sought, came, or drew near, to the company of men: (K:) the time of their attainment of what they hoped for came, or drew near, to them. (IAar, TA.) ＝ -A2- As a trans. verb: see 2. ― -b2- AHAnhu A@ll~`hu God caused him to die, or destroyed him; (S;) as also Hy~nhu↓, inf. n. taHoyiynN. (KL: but only the inf. n. is there given.) ― -b3- God tried him, or afflicted him with a trial. (K: a meaning indicated therein, but not expressed.)

5 tHy~n HAn tHyn tHynn wHY
, said of spunger (waAri$), He watched for the time of eating, in order that he might enter. (S.) And tHy~n AlT~aEaAma [He watched for the time of the food]. (K voce HaDirN.) And taHay~anotu ruw^oyapa fulaAnK I watched for the time of seeing such a one. (TA.) And tHy~n waqota AlS~alaApi He sought [to know] the time of prayer. (TA.) [And accord. to Freytag's Lex., AstHAn↓ has a similar meaning; i. e. He waited for the just time of a thing; delayed a thing till the fit time.] ― -b2- tHy~n Aln~aAqapa: see 2. ＝ -A2- See also 1. ＝ -A3- As meaning AisotagonaY, it is a vulgar word. (TA.)

10 A_isotaHoyana
see 5.

HayonN Hyn
Death; a state of destruction or perdition: (S, K, TA:) or the time of the appointed term [of life]; or time of death. (Har p. 322.) ― -b2- A trial, or trying affliction. (K.)

HiynN Hyn
i. q. dahorN [Time; or a time; or a space, or period, of time; &c.]: (K:) or, accord. to EshSháfi'ee, time, from the beginning of the world to its end; as also dahorN: (Az voce dahorN:) or a time, (Az, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) in a vague sense, (Mgh, K,) applicable to any time, (Az, K,) little or much, (Mgh, Msb,) long or short, that may be a year and more: or [in some cases] particularly meaning forty years: or seven years: or two years: or six months: or two months: or any morning and evening: (K:) also a space of time; (S, K;) as in the Kur lxxvi. I, (S,) and in the Kur xxxvii. 178: (K:) and a continuous time: (Ham p. 381:) and the day of resurrection; (K;) or the coming to pass of the resurrection; as in the Kur xxxviii. last verse: (Mgh, TA:) or it has two meanings; namely, a time of unknown limit, and also, as in the Kur xiv. 30, six months: (Fr, Msb:) accord. to Er-Rághib, the time of a thing's arriving, or coming, and happening; having a vague meaning, and rendered particular, or special, by that to which it is prefixed: some say that it occurs applied in different ways: to an appointed term; as that to which God makes one to live: and a year; as in the Kur xiv. 30: and to the time when an event takes place; as in the Kur xxx. 16: and to time absolutely: accord. to El-Munáwee, in the [genuine] language of the Arabs, it is applied to [the time of] a glance of the eye, and more than that, to time without end: (TA:) the pl. is A^aHoyaAnN, (S, Msb, K,) and pl. pl. A^aHaAyiynu; (S, * K;) as in the saying, fulaAnN yafoEalu ka*aA A^aHoyaAnFA and fiY AlA^aHaAyiyni [Such a one does so at times, or sometimes]. (S.) In the Kur [xiv. 30], tuw^otiY, A^ukulahaA kul~a HiynK means [Which yieldeth its fruit] every six months: (Fr, Msb, TA:) or every year: or every morning and evening: or, accord. to Az, in every season, uninterruptedly. (TA.) $aYo'K miHoyaAnu↓, also, means Hiynuhu [The time, or season, of a thing]. (K.) [You say, A_ilaY HiynK For a time, or season.] And HiynFA At one time; sometime; at some time; awhile. (Mgh.) Hiyna in the phrase qumotu Hiyna qumota [I stood in the time when thou stoodest, or I stood when thou stoodest,] is an adv. n. of time; (Msb;) [see also an ex. in a verse cited voce xa$afa, and the remarks there subjoined:] and one may well employ in its place lam~aA and A_i*aA (Msb, TA) and A_i*o and mataY and saAEapa (TA) and waqota (Msb, TA) and the like; but not, as many have said, Hayovu; for this is an adv. n. of place. (Msb.) ― -b2- When they make the two times to be distant, the one from the other, [i. e. the time of speaking and the time spoken of,] they do so by means of A_*, and thus, (K,) they say Hiynay^i*K [meaning At that time; then]: (S, K:) and sometimes they suppress the ', substituting for it Y. (TA.) ― -b3- Sometimes, also, they prefix ta to Hiyna; (S, TA;) and say laA taHiyna, meaning It is not, or was not, a time [of such a thing; but this is generally written laAta Hiyna]; as in the Kur xxxviii. 2 [respecting which see art. lyt]. (TA.) Aboo-Wejzeh Es-Saadee says,
AaloEaATifuwna taHiyna maA mino EaATifK
waAlmuToEimuwna zamaAna A^ayona AlmuToEiwu
[The persons who return to the attack when there is none other that returns to the attack, (as is said in the S and L in art. ETf,) or it may mean who act affectionately in the time when there is none other that acts affectionately; as is said in the L in that art.;) and the feeders in the time when it is said, Where is the feeder?]: (S:) ISd says that t is thus prefixed to Hyn like as it is in talaAna meaning AlA=na: but IB says that Ibn-Es-Seeráfee cites the former hemistich thus:
AaloEaATifuwnaho Hiyna maAmino EaATifK
[with the h of pausation]: and some say that the h of pausation is likened to the fem. p, and is then made movent with fet-h. (TA. [See more in art. lyt.]) ― -b4- See also HiynapN, in two places.

HaAnapN HAn HAnh HAnp
: see art. Hwn.

HayonapN Hyn Hynh Hynp
: see what next follows.

HiynapN Hyn Hynh Hynp
[The time appointed for a she-camel to be milked in every day and night;] a subst. from Hay~ana Aln~aAqapa; as also HiynN↓: you say, mataY Hiynapu naAqatika, meaning When is the time of the milking of thy she-camel? and kamo HiynatuhaA, meaning How many times is she milked? (K.) One says also, of a man, (S,) yaA^okulu AlHiynapa and AlHayonapa↓, meaning He eats once in the day and the night: (S, K:) or, accord. to Aboo-'Amr Ez-Záhid, Alwajobap is used as meaning a man's eating once in the day, and AlHynp as meaning a she-camel's being milked once in the day. (IB, TA.) And one says, maA A^aloqaAhu A_il~aA AlHiynapa baEoda AlHiynapa, i. e. AlHiyna baEoda AlHiyni↓ [I do not meet him save time after time; meaning, occasionally]. (K.)

HaAnaApN HAn HAnAh HAnAp
: see art. Hnw.

HaAnuwtN HAnwt
: see arts. Hwn and Hnw.

HaAniyapN HAnyh HAnyp
: see art. Hnw.

HaAniY~N HAn HAnY HAny
: see art. Hnw.

HaAniy~apN HAnyh HAnyp
: see arts. Hwn and Hnw.

HaAy^inN *
Stupid; foolish; or having little, or no, intellect, or understanding. (K.)

HaAy^inapN *
A deadly, or destructive, calamity that befalls one: (K, TA:) a calamity in which is AlHayon: (TA:) pl. HawaAy^inu. (K.) [In the CK it is, in one place, erroneously substituted for HaAniy~apN, as meaning “ wine. ”]

maHuwnapN mHA mHwnh mHwnp
[mentioned in the K in art. mHn] is from AlHayonu or AlmiHonapu. (TA.)

miHoyaAnN mHyAn
: see its syn. HynN.

HayohalN Hyhl
(En-Nadr, AHn, K) and Hay~aholN and Hay~iholN (K) A certain shrub of the smaller kind of HamoD, having no leaves: (En-Nadr, AHn, K:) or the species of HamoD termed harom: (AA, TA:) a coll. gen. n.: (TA:) n. un. with p: (K:) so called because, when rain falls upon it, it grows quickly; and when the camels eat it, and do not speedily void their excrement, they die: (AA, TA: [see the next paragraph:]) at the end of a verse of Homeyd Ibn-Thowr, the name is written AlHay~ahulN, with the vowel of the l transferred to the h. (AHn, K.)

Hay~ahala Hyhl
and Hay~ahalN and Hay~ahalano and Hay~ahalFA and Hay~ahalaA words used in inciting, or urging on: see more in art. HY; (K;) and in art. hl. (TA.)
